clinical_note: A 58-year-old man presents with two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a productive cough that began after a presumed upper respiratory infection; sputum is yellow-green and he reports intermittent low-grade fevers. Over the past 48 hours he developed pleuritic right-sided chest pain and a small amount of hemoptysis, with wakening by orthopnea at night. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history and a remote provoked deep venous thrombosis. Known COPD and chronic hypertension are in his history. He notes new audible wheeze and decreased exercise tolerance compared with baseline COPD symptoms. Given acute worsening with pleuritic pain and prior DVT, he is concerned about superimposed pneumonia versus pulmonary embolism; he denies calf swelling or recent travel.

A 35-year-old male reports 10 days of progressive exertional dyspnea and sharp left-sided pleuritic chest pain. Symptoms began several days after a prolonged 10-hour flight and were preceded by a mild upper respiratory prodrome; he developed a persistent nonproductive cough and low-grade fevers. Over the past 48 hours he noted scant hemoptysis and new right calf swelling with intermittent cramping. He describes exertional lightheadedness and palpitations. He is a current smoker (≈10 pack-years) with no prior thrombotic history. At home he measured oxygen saturation in the low 90s and had tachycardia at rest. He denies recent surgery or active malignancy. He is concerned about possible pulmonary embolism versus atypical pneumonia.

A 45-year-old woman presents with six weeks of progressive, intense generalized pruritus, worst at night, causing excoriations and sleep disturbance. She also describes increasing fatigue and a dull right upper quadrant discomfort that follows fatty meals. Over the past week she noticed pale, clay-colored stools and subtle yellowing of the sclera. On exam she reports small yellow eyelid plaques previously noted by her cosmetician. She has a remote history of hypercholesterolemia diagnosed two years ago and intermittent dry eyes and dry mouth for several months. She drinks minimally and has no recent travel. The constellation of cholestatic symptoms, sicca complaints, and xanthelasma raises concern for an autoimmune cholangiopathy such as primary biliary cholangitis.

A 50-year-old man presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent nonproductive cough that began after a self-limited "bronchitis." He now notes intermittent pleuritic left-sided chest discomfort and mild blood-tinged sputum on two occasions. Over the past week he developed unilateral left calf swelling and tenderness after a prolonged airplane trip. He reports daytime fatigue and loud snoring with witnessed pauses consistent with obstructive sleep apnea; he has well-controlled hypertension and a 25 pack-year smoking history but quit five years ago. He denies fever or orthopnea. The constellation—post-travel calf swelling, pleuritic pain, worsening exertional breathlessness—raises concern for deep venous thrombosis with possible pulmonary embolism.

A 94-year-old male reports two months of progressive postprandial crampy epigastric pain, with a clear worsening over the past three weeks. He describes early satiety and a ten-pound unintentional weight loss as he has begun to avoid meals for fear of pain. He has noted intermittent dark stools and progressive fatigue but denies vomiting or fevers. He has a history of atrial fibrillation and chronic kidney disease stage 3, and he recalls a brief episode of lightheadedness several days ago. Bowel habits are otherwise unchanged. Family reports subtle decline in baseline mobility and appetite. He is concerned about ongoing weakness and loss of weight and seeks evaluation for possible bowel ischemia or obstructive process contributing to his anorexia and bleeding.

An 80-year-old man reports four weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that began after a brief upper respiratory illness. He notes decreased exercise tolerance—now unable to climb a flight of stairs without stopping—and intermittent low-grade fevers with a three-kilogram weight loss. On review he denies purulent sputum or chest pain but describes worsening breathlessness with minimal exertion and occasional lightheadedness. Past pulmonary history is notable for known interstitial lung disease consistent with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis; he has baseline hypertension and a remote smoking history. Home caregiver observed increased work of breathing and falling oxygen saturations with activity. On exam he has bibasilar inspiratory crackles and early digital clubbing, suggesting a subacute exacerbation of his chronic pulmonary fibrosis.

A 53-year-old male presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent productive cough following a community-acquired pneumonia treated outpatient. Sputum is thick and green-tinged with intermittent streaks of blood; coughing provokes sharp pleuritic right-sided chest pain. He reports low-grade fevers, drenching night sweats, and unintentional 8-lb weight loss over two months. Past history notable for COPD and well-controlled hypertension; 30 pack-year former smoker. He notes increased baseline sputum volume and recurrent bronchitic exacerbations compared with his prior course, raising concern for postinfectious bronchiectasis or secondary infection, and he is also worried about possible pulmonary embolism after a recent long car trip. Activity tolerance is markedly reduced.

A 50-year-old female reports progressive shortness of breath and pleuritic right-sided chest pain for five days, acutely worse with minimal exertion. Symptoms began after a ten-hour flight and were accompanied by scant hemoptysis and intermittent palpitations; she describes resting tachycardia at home. She also noticed right calf swelling and tenderness over the past week. Cough is minimal and unlike previous asthma flares; she has a remote history of asthma and a 20 pack-year smoking history. She denies fever, recent upper respiratory infection, or leg trauma. No prior thrombotic events. Activities are limited by dyspnea, and she is concerned about a blood clot or pulmonary embolus.

A 20-year-old female college student presents with sudden-onset pleuritic left-sided chest pain and progressive shortness of breath for 36 hours. Pain is sharp, worse with deep inspiration and cough; she reports scant hemoptysis and lightheadedness when ambulating. She noted increasing right calf swelling and tenderness over the prior three days after a 10-hour bus trip, and she takes combined oral contraceptives. At home she felt tachycardic and more breathless with minimal exertion. She denies fever, recent surgery, or illicit drug use and has no prior clotting history. Symptoms are most concerning for pulmonary embolism from an ipsilateral deep venous thrombosis; she seeks evaluation given worsening hypoxia and persistent pleuritic pain.

A 62-year-old male reports two months of progressive exertional dyspnea, initially only with stairs and now limiting his walking to a few blocks. He describes intermittent exertional chest tightness and two brief near-syncope episodes while climbing, associated with new palpitations. Over the last three weeks he has developed worsening bilateral ankle swelling and persistent dry cough with rare streaks of blood. He had an unprovoked deep vein thrombosis about nine months ago that was treated briefly, and he carries a remote diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with a 30-pack-year smoking history. No fevers or orthopnea. Symptoms suggest possible chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension with right‑sided congestion; he seeks evaluation for progressive exertional limitation and intermittent hemoptysis.

A 7-year-old female presents with five days of persistent cough and progressive noisy breathing that acutely worsened over the past 48 hours. Symptoms began after a runny nose and low-grade fever following exposure at daycare; parents report intermittent wheeze and increased work of breathing with activity. Three days ago she had a brief choking episode while eating, after which she developed frequent coughing and a new inspiratory stridor. At-home use of a quick-acting bronchodilator produced only minimal relief. She has mild decreased oral intake and sleep disruption from coughing. Past medical history notable for atopic dermatitis and a single reactive-airways episode last winter. Examination at home was perceived as pallid with faster breathing, prompting evaluation for possible foreign body aspiration versus asthma exacerbation.

A 6-year-old male presents with a 48-hour history of progressively worsening right-sided throat pain and fever. Symptoms began after a brief nasal congestion and sore throat; he developed severe odynophagia and now refuses solids, with poor oral intake. Parents note drooling and difficulty opening his mouth consistent with trismus. On exam he is febrile with tender ipsilateral cervical lymphadenitis and marked swelling of the right tonsillar pillar with muffled voice. Concern is for a peritonsillar abscess complicating streptococcal pharyngitis; retropharyngeal extension is in the differential. Decreased urine output and dry mucous membranes suggest early dehydration. No known immunodeficiency and no prior airway surgery. Caregiver requests urgent evaluation for potential drainage.

A 34-year-old male reports six weeks of progressive postprandial epigastric pain, early satiety, and persistent bloating that began after a self-limited viral gastroenteritis. He describes frequent nausea with intermittent nonbilious vomiting of undigested food several hours after eating, worsening with solids and fatty meals, and occasional regurgitation. He has unintentionally lost about 12 pounds and notes decreased appetite. Bowel movements are intact but occasionally greasy. He denies fevers or overt jaundice but endorses episodic lightheadedness and palpitations when standing, especially after emesis. No prior abdominal surgery. He tried antacids with minimal relief. Symptoms are most consistent with postinfectious gastroparesis with functional dyspepsia and possible dehydration-related orthostatic symptoms; he seeks evaluation for gastric emptying assessment and nutritional support.

A 28-year-old man presents with three days of progressive blurred vision in his right eye, described as a central gray patch with reduced acuity and color desaturation. He notes sharp periorbital pain that worsens with eye movement and intermittent photophobia; symptoms began after a week of nasal congestion and sore throat. He also reports new, brief numb tingling episodes in his feet and a persistent fatigue that is limiting exercise tolerance. He denies trauma, diplopia, or significant headache but acknowledges a prior remote episode of transient visual blurring last year that resolved. On exam he notes difficulty distinguishing red from green and perceives the central area as darker. He is concerned about inflammatory or demyelinating causes and seeks urgent neuro-ophthalmology evaluation.

A 22-year-old male presents with five days of progressive blurred vision in the left eye, described as a central gray spot that worsened over 48 hours. He notes sharp pain with eye movement and increased photophobia but denies trauma or discharge. Color perception is dulled when compared to the right eye, and he reports a new left-sided relative afferent pupillary defect on home flashlight testing. Two weeks prior he had a brief viral upper respiratory illness with sore throat and low-grade fever. Concurrently he has experienced intermittent paresthesias in the right hand and mild occipital headache without neck stiffness. No prior ophthalmic disease or recent travel; he denies nausea, syncope, or skin rash. He is concerned about sudden vision loss.

A 38-year-old woman presents with ten days of subacute blurring of the left eye, describing central scotoma and colors appearing faded compared with the right eye. Symptoms began after a brief upper respiratory illness and have progressed; she now has aching periocular pain that worsens with eye movement and intermittent photophobia. She reports new fatigue and two episodes of transient numbness and tingling in the right hand over the past month. No eye discharge or trauma. She has a history of autoimmune thyroid disease and episodic migraine without aura. Vision changes are interfering with driving and reading. She denies systemic rash, joint swelling, or fevers. Concern is raised for optic neuritis versus inflammatory optic neuropathy, prompting urgent ophthalmology and neurology evaluation.

An 84-year-old man presents with two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and increasing lower extremity swelling. He now wakes at night gasping for air twice weekly and has mild orthopnea; family notes new-onset palpitations and fatigue for four days. He has a history of hypertension and a bioprosthetic aortic valve; he also carries a diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Onset followed a brief viral cough that did not fully resolve. He describes decreased exercise tolerance from walking one block to remaining seated most of the day. No chest pain but reports lightheadedness with standing. Recent home pulse checks were irregularly irregular. He denies hemoptysis, focal neurologic symptoms, or recent invasive procedures.

A 19-year-old female presents with four days of acute rotational vertigo occurring in spells of 30–60 minutes, classically provoked by head turns. The episodes began after a recent upper respiratory infection with nasal congestion and sore throat; she subsequently developed right‑ear fullness, intermittent high‑pitched tinnitus, and subjective decreased hearing on the right. Associated symptoms include persistent nausea and two episodes of non‑bilious emesis, plus marked imbalance with veering to the right when walking. She denies headache, focal weakness, or visual loss. Symptoms are partially relieved by staying still and worsen on rising from bed. She has noticed brief horizontal eye jerks during attacks and reports no recent head trauma or new medications.

A 62-year-old woman reports three months of progressive exertional dyspnea that now limits climbing a single flight of stairs. She describes intermittent presyncope with minimal exertion and a chronic productive cough with two recent episodes of streaky hemoptysis. Pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort accompanies deep breaths. Over the past month she has developed new bilateral ankle swelling and recalls unilateral right calf pain after a prolonged car trip several months earlier; she was told she previously had a "blood clot." Past medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension. She denies fevers but reports a 6 kg unintentional weight loss. These symptoms raise concern for a pulmonary vascular process superimposed on chronic airways disease.

A 95-year-old female reports acute, painless loss of vision in her left eye over the past 48 hours, preceded by two weeks of intermittent temporal headache and scalp tenderness. She also describes jaw claudication when chewing and new prominent central blurring with metamorphopsia in the right eye, where she has known age-related macular degeneration. On review she notes morning shoulder stiffness and difficulty combing hair suggestive of polymyalgia rheumatica; she has longstanding hypertension. Family members report the left eye is now essentially nonfunctional. No trauma or flashes of light. Symptoms cluster temporally, raising concern for arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy secondary to giant cell arteritis threatening the remaining vision.

A 45-year-old male construction worker reports six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent productive cough that began after a presumed upper respiratory infection. Sputum is purulent with intermittent scant hemoptysis and he describes focal pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort. He also notes low-grade fevers, drenching night sweats and an unintentional 12-pound weight loss over the past month. He is a former 20-pack-year smoker and reports regular silica dust exposure on job sites. On exam he has coarse bibasilar crackles and mild digital clubbing; there is no peripheral edema or known immunosuppression. Symptoms have limited his activity and prompted referral for chest imaging and sputum studies.

A 95-year-old female presents with abrupt, painless loss of vision in the right eye over the past 48 hours, preceded by three weeks of progressive central distortion and intermittent scotoma. She describes a new right temporal headache with scalp tenderness when combing her hair and intermittent jaw ache when chewing; she denies eye discharge or fever. Past history includes long-standing hypertension and age-related macular degeneration in the left eye. On brief ophthalmic assessment there is markedly reduced right visual acuity with a relative afferent pupillary defect. These features are concerning for giant cell arteritis with impending ischemic optic involvement; urgent temporal artery evaluation and inflammatory markers have been arranged for expedited assessment.

A 56-year-old man presents with four weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea that began after a prolonged transcontinental flight. Initially attributed to deconditioning, shortness of breath has escalated over the past week with new right-sided pleuritic chest pain and intermittent blood-tinged sputum. He also notes a swollen, tender right calf and increased night-time snoring with daytime fatigue. Past medical history includes well-controlled hypertension and a remote diagnosis of mild COPD; he is a former 30 pack-year smoker. He denies fever or recent upper respiratory infection. The constellation of acute dyspnea, pleuritic pain, hemoptysis, and unilateral leg swelling raises concern for pulmonary embolism complicating deep venous thrombosis, with underlying cardiopulmonary risk exacerbated by sleep-disordered breathing.

A 21-year-old woman presents with six weeks of daily, throbbing bifrontal headaches and intermittent visual obscurations. Headaches are worse on lying down and with Valsalva, often accompanied by transient binocular diplopia and brief episodes of blurred vision lasting seconds. She describes new right-sided pulsatile tinnitus and morning nausea but denies fever. She has noted a 20-pound weight gain over six months and a history of polycystic ovarian syndrome with oligomenorrhea. Primary care ophthalmoscopy reportedly demonstrated optic disc edema. No prior head trauma or migraine history; headaches started after a period of increased screen time and irregular sleep. Symptoms have gradually worsened, interfering with classes and driving, prompting evaluation for increased intracranial pressure.

A 40-year-old man presents with progressive shortness of breath that began two days ago and acutely worsened overnight. He describes sharp, pleuritic right-sided chest pain with a dry cough and a single episode of scant hemoptysis. Symptoms began after a long transcontinental flight and are accompanied by palpitations, lightheadedness, and low-grade fever. He notes new left calf swelling and tenderness and feels more fatigued with minimal exertion. At baseline he is ambulatory and worked full time until symptoms started; past medical history is notable only for well-controlled hypertension. He is a current smoker, denies recent upper respiratory infection, and has no known cardiac disease or prior thromboembolism.

A 40-year-old woman presents with four days of an acute paracentral scotoma and metamorphopsia in her left eye, describing a persistent dark spot while reading and intermittent shimmering flashes. Symptoms began abruptly after a self-limited febrile upper respiratory illness two weeks earlier. She notes mild subjective blurring, decreased contrast sensitivity and subtle color desaturation on the affected side but no periocular pain or photophobia. She has occasional migraine with visual aura historically, which she says feels different. She denies trauma, flashes of hundreds of floaters, or systemic neurologic deficits. On review, she reports difficulty focusing at near and transient oscillopsia when changing gaze. The presentation suggests a macular or retinal ischemic/inflammatory process such as acute macular neuroretinopathy, warranting urgent retinal and OCT evaluation.

A 15-year-old female presents with three weeks of progressively worse morning headaches described as a constant pressure with intermittent throbbing, worse when bending or with Valsalva. Headaches are associated with brief transient visual obscurations and intermittent blurred vision; she also notes a bilateral pulsatile tinnitus and nausea with two episodes of emesis. Over the past five days she has developed binocular horizontal diplopia and has difficulty sustaining reading at school. She reports a 20–25 pound weight gain over the last six months but no head trauma, fever, or drug use. Ophthalmology exam demonstrated bilateral optic disc swelling, raising concern for increased intracranial pressure and possible idiopathic intracranial hypertension.

A 25-year-old man presents with sudden onset right-sided pleuritic chest pain and acute shortness of breath after three days of a dry cough and mild sore throat. He notes a forceful coughing spell the morning symptoms began, followed by sharp, localized pain worse with inspiration and shallow breathing. He also reports lightheadedness and decreased exercise tolerance over the last 24 hours. He is a current smoker and describes a tall, thin build. At home he noticed diminished breath sounds on the right and a brief episode of palpitations. No hemoptysis or leg swelling. Prior to this he had a self-limited upper respiratory infection. He is otherwise healthy with no chronic lung disease or recent trauma.

A 16-year-old male high-school athlete presents with sudden-onset left-sided pleuritic chest pain and progressive shortness of breath that began halfway through basketball practice last evening. Pain is sharp, worse with deep inspiration and coughing, and associated with an intermittent dry cough and lightheadedness with exertion. He reports a week of nasal congestion and sore throat that largely resolved, and admits to occasional vaping but denies illicit drug use. Symptoms were abrupt after a jump, worsened overnight, and he now notes decreased exercise tolerance. He has no known cardiac disease but recalls childhood wheezing managed intermittently without daily therapy. He is tall and slim. He denies fever, leg swelling, or recent trauma; parents brought him for increasing dyspnea and persistent pleuritic pain.

A 3-week-old male infant with 48 hours of progressive cough and increased work of breathing, noted after a household exposure to an older sibling with a "cold." Parents report persistent rhinorrhea, intermittent low-grade fever, and markedly decreased oral intake with fewer wet diapers. At home they observed rapid breathing and brief desaturations with feeding and crying. On arrival he is tachypneic with nasal flaring, subcostal and intercostal retractions, diffuse expiratory wheeze and scattered crackles; pulse oximetry low 88–92% on room air, improving with supplemental blow-by oxygen. No prior NICU stay; term vaginal delivery. Concern centers on viral bronchiolitis causing respiratory distress and hypoxemia, with feeding intolerance as a secondary issue.

A 38-year-old male reports two days of progressive left-sided neck pain and an intense ipsilateral throbbing headache that began during a vigorous yoga session. Several hours after onset he developed sudden right arm and leg weakness and new difficulty finding words; the deficit fluctuated but did not fully resolve. He also noticed left eyelid droop and a smaller left pupil when he checked a mirror. He has a prior history of migraine and a ten–pack-year smoking history. He recalls a sharp neck twist during a pose but no major trauma. Yesterday he experienced brief right-hand numbness. The picture is concerning for left cervical arterial dissection with focal ischemia; he denies fever, visual loss, or recent infection.

A 1-year-old male presents with three days of intermittent, severe abdominal pain characterized by sudden episodes of inconsolable crying and drawing up of the legs. Caregiver notes recurrent non-bilious vomiting and one passage of dark, mucus‑streaked stool yesterday. There has been markedly decreased oral intake and fewer wet diapers over the past 24 hours with increasing lethargy between pain episodes. A two-week history of mild rhinorrhea preceded the abdominal symptoms. During a recent pain spell the caregiver palpated a transient, firm “sausage‑shaped” mass in the right upper quadrant. No chronic medical problems. Parents are most concerned about progressive dehydration and possible intussusception given the colicky pain, bloody stool, and palpable mass.

A 45-year-old man reports six months of progressive postprandial epigastric pain radiating to the back. The pain is a constant, gnawing discomfort, worse after fatty meals and associated with bloating and intermittent nausea. Over the same period he notes greasy, foul-smelling stools and unintentional weight loss consistent with steatorrhea and malabsorption. He had a prior episode of acute pancreatitis and drinks alcohol daily. Outpatient evaluation recently documented fasting hyperglycemia and increased thirst. An earlier abdominal CT reportedly demonstrated pancreatic calcifications. He denies hematemesis or jaundice. He is concerned about worsening nutrition and new glucose intolerance and requests further evaluation for chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency.

A 27-year-old woman presents with four days of progressive shortness of breath, most noticeable with minimal exertion, accompanied by a new sharp, right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began two days ago. She reports a dry cough and intermittent low-grade fevers but denies sputum production. She noticed right calf swelling and tenderness last week. She also describes occasional palpitations and lightheadedness when climbing stairs. She started a combined oral contraceptive three months ago and has a history of mild intermittent asthma managed with occasional inhaler use. Symptoms are unrelieved by rest and have worsened over several days, prompting concern for a thromboembolic event versus pneumonia; she has no recent travel or immobilization.

A 21-year-old female reports five days of progressive blurring of vision in the right eye, now with a central scotoma and decreased color perception. She describes dull retro-orbital pain that worsens with eye movement and a subjective feverish prodrome two weeks earlier. Symptoms intensify transiently with heat or exercise, and she notes new generalized fatigue and intermittent paresthesias of the feet over the past week. She has a remote history of migraine headaches but says this visual loss is qualitatively different, not preceded by her usual aura. No recent head trauma, no topical exposures, and no current medications. She is worried about an inflammatory optic neuropathy given the painful vision loss and associated neurologic symptoms.

A 78-year-old woman reports acute loss of vision in the right eye after two weeks of progressive blurring and intermittent transient darkening over several minutes. This morning the vision failed completely; she also developed a new, severe right temporal headache and jaw claudication with chewing. She notes scalp tenderness when combing her hair and one-month history of morning stiffness in shoulders and hips with decreased energy and low-grade fevers. On brief exam the right optic disc appeared pale and swollen with an afferent pupillary defect. Primary care obtained inflammatory markers that were markedly elevated and referred urgently for suspected giant cell arteritis causing an ischemic optic neuropathy. No recent trauma, eye pain, or systemic rash reported.

A 54-year-old female presents with new-onset persistent palpitations and progressive tremor. Palpitations began three days ago as episodic and now feel constant; she reports associated heat intolerance, a 10-pound unintentional weight loss over eight weeks, increased frequency of loose stools, and difficulty sleeping. She notes intermittent lightheadedness and exertional dyspnea walking a block. Past history is notable only for well-controlled hypertension managed without medication. On review she endorses worsening anxiety, fine hand tremor, and subtle eye irritation with lid retraction and intermittent diplopia. Symptoms began after a recent upper respiratory illness and have steadily escalated; she denies chest pain, fever, or focal weakness.

A 66-year-old woman presents with three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and new sharp, right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began two days ago. She reports a change from her baseline chronic productive cough—thicker yellow sputum—and two episodes of scant hemoptysis. Symptoms worsened after a prolonged car trip and she noticed left calf swelling and aching over the past week. At baseline she has known COPD with a 40 pack-year smoking history, and treated hypertension. She describes tachycardia and near-syncope with minimal exertion and notes oxygen saturation falls with walking. The temporal sequence—immobilization then unilateral calf swelling followed by acute pleuritic pain and worsening hypoxia—raises concern for pulmonary embolism superimposed on chronic obstructive lung disease.

A 65-year-old man reports nine months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a chronic productive cough that has acutely worsened after a recent upper respiratory infection. He notes daily mucoid sputum, marked reduction in exercise tolerance—now limited to short household tasks—and an unintentional 7-kg weight loss. On prior exam he had bibasilar "velcro" inspiratory crackles and early digital clubbing. He is a former heavy smoker with a 40 pack-year history who quit about a decade ago. Chest CT obtained several months ago showed basilar reticulation with early honeycombing consistent with fibrotic interstitial lung disease. He denies chest pain or hemoptysis but reports more frequent nighttime cough and worse breathlessness with minimal exertion.

A 39-year-old woman reports a two-month history of progressive right leg weakness and intermittent numbness that began in the feet and ascended to the thigh, now causing frequent tripping. She describes electric-shock sensations with neck flexion and daily fatigue limiting work tolerance. Over the past three weeks she has had intermittent binocular diplopia and episodic blurred vision with mild retro-orbital pain on eye movement. She also notes new urinary urgency without dysuria and occasional constipation. Symptoms are fluctuating but have steadily worsened, with a recent episode of increased spasticity in the right lower extremity producing a stiff, unsteady gait. No recent head trauma; she recalls a brief upper respiratory illness six weeks before onset. Findings raise concern for an inflammatory demyelinating process.

A 97-year-old female presents with five days of progressively worsening dyspnea and productive cough following a witnessed choking episode while eating. Family reports low-grade fevers, decreased appetite, and purulent sputum; she has become more lethargic and requires assistance for transfers. Onset of palpitations yesterday correlated with an irregularly irregular pulse at home. She is more hypoxic than baseline, with increased oxygen requirement and orthopnea overnight. Exam reportedly notable for right lower lobe crackles and mild bilateral ankle edema. No reported chest pain or frank hemoptysis. Past baseline includes limited mobility but independent cognition. The picture is most consistent with aspiration pneumonia complicated by hypoxemic respiratory failure and new atrial fibrillation; worsening volume status and decreased oral intake are contributing.

A 45-year-old woman presents with three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea that has intensified over the past 48 hours, now limiting walking across a room. Two days ago she developed sharp, right-sided pleuritic chest pain and one episode of scant hemoptysis. She reports a 10-hour long-haul flight four weeks ago and progressive right calf swelling with tenderness for the past week. She describes intermittent palpitations and mild lightheadedness but denies fever or productive cough. Past medical history notable for intermittent mild asthma and treated hypothyroidism. Symptoms are most consistent with possible thromboembolic disease with secondary pulmonary compromise; she is concerned about deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism and sought urgent evaluation.

A 43-year-old male presents with a 10-day history of cough that became worse over the past 48 hours with new exertional dyspnea, pleuritic right-sided chest pain, and scant hemoptysis. He describes the cough as initially dry then streaked with blood, and reports subjective fever and fatigue. Symptoms acutely intensified two days after a long-haul flight one week ago; he also notes recent right calf swelling and intermittent palpitations. He has a childhood history of mild intermittent asthma but no chronic COPD. He denies intravenous drug use. The combination of acute dyspnea, pleuritic pain, hemoptysis, and unilateral leg swelling raises concern for pulmonary embolism, though infectious pneumonia remains in the differential.

A 98-year-old man presents with ten days of progressive exertional dyspnea and a purulent productive cough that acutely worsened over the past 48 hours with new resting shortness of breath. He reports low‑grade fevers, intermittent chills, and recent decreased appetite after a preceding upper respiratory illness two weeks ago. Background includes long‑standing COPD with prior CT evidence of bronchiectasis and a history of remote tobacco use. He endorses occasional choking with thin liquids and recent increased sputum volumes consistent with possible aspiration. At home caregivers noted greater confusion and two pillow orthopnea; exam shows dependent leg swelling and scattered wheeze with bibasilar crackles. He is more limited than baseline and requires supplemental oxygen at rest.

A 24-year-old female reports a 48-hour history of progressive blurred vision in the right eye, describing a central gray spot and colors appearing washed out. Eye movement provokes a sharp, retro-orbital ache and she notes mild photophobia. She also describes transient numbness and tingling in the left fingertips over the past week and new fatigue with exertion. Symptoms began after a self-limited upper respiratory illness two weeks ago. On exam at urgent care she was noted to have an afferent pupillary defect on the right and slowed color naming compared with the left. She denies trauma, eye discharge, fever, or prior ocular surgery. There is no history of systemic autoimmune disease or diabetes. She is concerned about sudden vision loss.

A 25-year-old male reports progressive right-sided facial weakness for five days, beginning after a painful vesicular eruption in the right external auditory canal. The facial droop worsened over 48 hours and he now has inability to fully close the right eye, drooling, and decreased taste on the anterior tongue. He describes marked sensitivity to sound in the affected ear and intermittent vertical dizziness with brief spinning episodes. Otalgia preceded the rash; he notes mild ipsilateral tinnitus but denies limb weakness, dysarthria, or recent head trauma. He recalls childhood varicella but no recent travel or immunosuppression. Review of systems otherwise notable only for dry eye on the right and low-grade subjective fever during the prodrome.

A 84-year-old male reports a six-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea and persistent dry cough, initially milder after a bronchitic illness two months ago but steadily worse. He notes markedly reduced exercise tolerance, needing to stop after short walks, and new exertional desaturation on stairs. Wife describes occasional nocturnal cough but he denies fever or pleuritic chest pain. At home he developed increasing work of breathing and dependent pitting edema over the past week. Past history notable for hypertension and a remote 30-pack-year smoking history. On brief review he has bibasilar inspiratory crackles and mild digital clubbing and reports an unintended five-pound weight loss. Concern is evolving interstitial lung disease with early right-heart strain versus a chronic obstructive process.

A 55-year-old man presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent cough that began after a presumed viral upper respiratory infection. Initially dry, the cough became intermittently productive; he noted scant blood-streaking last week. He describes new pleuritic right-sided chest pain with deep inspiration and a 4-kg unintentional weight loss accompanied by drenching night sweats and low-grade fevers. He completed a short antibiotic course without improvement. Past history is notable for treated hypertension and a 30–pack-year smoking history, quit five years ago. There is no history of COPD or recent travel. Review of systems otherwise negative. He is concerned given the progressive breathlessness and systemic symptoms.

A 14-year-old male reports a two-month history of progressive occipital headaches described as pressure-like and throbbing, characteristically worse with exertion, coughing, and bending forward. Episodes last several hours and are most severe in the morning, disrupting sleep. He endorses intermittent transient visual blurring and occasional double vision during the worst headaches. Parents report recent mild unsteadiness when running and intermittent numbness and tingling in both hands after prolonged activity. He had a sports-related concussion about six months ago that initially resolved, and he now notes new neck stiffness without fever or infectious symptoms. No prior history of migraine; no obvious trigger other than physical exertion. Symptoms have been gradually worsening, prompting neurologic evaluation.

A 27-year-old male presents with sudden-onset right-sided pleuritic chest pain and progressive shortness of breath that began two hours ago while lifting at the gym. The pain is sharp, worsens with inspiration, and is accompanied by an acute dry cough after a week of upper respiratory symptoms. He is a current smoker with a tall, slender body habitus and denies trauma. En route he felt lightheaded and palpitations; EMS documented tachycardia and mild hypoxemia. On exam he reports decreased breath sounds over the right hemithorax without focal neurologic deficits. He has no prior pulmonary disease. Concern is for spontaneous right pneumothorax; a chest radiograph was obtained and he remains hemodynamically stable.

A 96-year-old female reports two weeks of progressively worsening dyspnea on exertion and new orthopnea. Symptoms began after a brief upper respiratory illness with nasal congestion and low-grade fever and evolved into a persistent, mainly nonproductive cough. Family notes episodes of oxygen desaturation with minimal activity and increased work of breathing when ambulating. She has had occasional choking with thin liquids over the past month. At home she has noted swelling of both ankles and now sleeps propped up on pillows. Her past history is notable for hypertension. Prior examination documented bibasilar crackles. The clinical picture raises concern for a heart-failure exacerbation contributing to hypoxemia, with aspiration risk as a possible contributor to her respiratory decline.

An 88-year-old man presents with three weeks of progressive gait instability and intermittent frontal headaches. Family reports gradual cognitive slowing with recent episodes of urinary urgency and one brief spell of confusion. Two weeks ago he had a ground-level fall without loss of consciousness; since then the shuffling, balance loss, and a new broad-based gait have worsened. He also experienced a transient episode of left arm numbness and mild dysarthria lasting about 20 minutes. Past history notable for hypertension and atrial fibrillation, and he remains anticoagulated. Examination by his PCP documented slowed mentation and postural instability. Differential includes normal-pressure hydrocephalus versus a chronic subdural hematoma related to anticoagulation, with consideration of small-vessel ischemic change contributing to symptoms.

A 26-year-old female presents with three days of progressive shortness of breath and pleuritic right-sided chest pain. Symptoms began after a week of persistent productive cough and wheeze she attributed to seasonal bronchitis but acutely worsened following a four-hour flight. She reports scant hemoptysis and intermittent palpitations; the sudden dyspnea prompted urgent evaluation. At home she developed mild right calf swelling and tenderness. She uses combined oral contraceptives and has a remote history of childhood asthma. There is low-grade fever and nocturnal cough but no other recent immobilization. Symptoms are worse with exertion and deep inspiration and partially relieved by sitting upright. No prior thrombotic events.

A 41-year-old man presents with five days of progressive exertional dyspnea and new pleuritic right-sided chest pain that acutely worsened this morning. He describes a small amount of blood-tinged sputum and intermittent lightheadedness but denies fever. Symptoms began two days after a transcontinental flight during which he noted mild right calf aching; the calf is now visibly swollen and tender. He reports resting tachycardia and shortness of breath on minimal exertion. Past medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension and a 20–pack-year smoking history; he takes no anticoagulants. No prior thromboembolic events. He is concerned the constellation—recent immobilization, unilateral leg swelling, hemoptysis, and tachycardia—represents a pulmonary embolic event.

A 51-year-old man presents with ten days of progressively blurred central vision in the left eye, describing a new central scotoma and metamorphopsia that make reading small print difficult. He notes intermittent bright flashes (photopsias) and decreased color saturation but denies eye pain or discharge. Symptoms began one week after a short course of oral corticosteroids for bronchitis. He has well-controlled hypertension on lifestyle measures and reports intermittent tension-type headaches without focal neurologic deficits. On recent outpatient exam he was noted to have a shallow serous macular detachment on dilated fundus inspection. No prior ocular surgery or history of diabetic eye disease. He is anxious about sudden vision loss and seeks urgent evaluation for possible central serous chorioretinopathy.

A 75-year-old man presents with progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that have worsened over the past three months, with notable decline in exercise tolerance and a 10-pound unintentional weight loss. He reports intermittent low-grade fevers and increased breathlessness after a recent upper respiratory illness. Exam notes bibasilar inspiratory crackles and mild digital clubbing; he desaturates with minimal exertion. Past medical history includes well-controlled hypertension and a remote 30 pack-year smoking history. He was diagnosed with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis approximately a year ago and has had more frequent bronchitic infections recently. No chest pain, orthopnea, or leg swelling reported. He is concerned about progression and reduced ability to manage activities of daily living.

A 90-year-old woman presents with six months of progressive gait instability and new urinary urgency, with intermittent leakage over the past two months. Family notes gradual short-term memory loss, slowed speech, and reduced initiation for several months, and she has had two falls in the last three weeks after an episode of symptomatic urinary tract infection that seemed to precipitate worsening mobility. On exam she demonstrates a broad-based, short-stepped “magnetic” gait and mild apathy with slowed recall. No focal limb weakness is reported. Past medical history includes long-standing hypertension. The constellation of gait difficulty, cognitive decline, and urinary dysfunction has raised concern for possible normal-pressure hydrocephalus versus overlapping mobility impairment from deconditioning; outpatient neuroimaging and cognition testing are requested.

A 52-year-old man reports ten days of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and three days of sharp, pleuritic right-sided chest pain. He noticed scant hemoptysis yesterday and intermittent palpitations with exertion. Symptoms began after a 10-hour flight two weeks ago, since when his right calf has been intermittently swollen and tender. He describes near-syncope with climbing stairs and now limits activity because of breathlessness. He has a prior provoked deep venous thrombosis several years earlier and a 30-pack-year smoking history. He denies fevers or sputum production and has had no recent surgeries. He is anxious about the breathing difficulty but reports good baseline exercise tolerance before this started and is concerned about possible pulmonary embolism.

A 97-year-old female reports six weeks of progressive gait instability, initially mild stumbling now described as a shuffling, magnetic gait with two recent falls and difficulty initiating steps. Family notes new short-term memory loss and slowed processing, and she has developed urinary urgency with occasional daytime incontinence over the same interval. Symptoms evolved insidiously rather than after an acute event; she denies focal weakness or headache but endorses brief lightheadedness on standing. Past medical history notable for long-standing hypertension without prior stroke. Recent outpatient noncontrast head CT reportedly showed ventriculomegaly. On exam she demonstrates postural instability and bradyphrenia. Presentation raises concern for normal-pressure hydrocephalus versus a degenerative gait disorder; plan includes neurology evaluation and consideration of diagnostic high-volume lumbar puncture.

An 11-year-old boy presents with a two-week history of persistent cough and new exertional wheeze after a brief viral upper respiratory illness. Initial rhinorrhea and sore throat resolved, but a dry day- and night-time cough has persisted, with worsening nocturnal cough wakes two to three times nightly. He reports shortness of breath and chest tightness when running during soccer practices and a clear audible wheeze heard by parents. There have been intermittent low-grade fevers but no vomiting or hemoptysis. Past history is notable for seasonal allergic rhinitis and childhood atopic dermatitis; no prior hospitalizations for breathing problems. Symptoms partially abate with rest and are worse with cold air and exercise, suggesting post-infectious airway hyperreactivity or new-onset asthma. Family history is notable for parental allergy.

A 52-year-old man presents with ten days of progressive exertional dyspnea that began after a brief upper respiratory illness; breathlessness has worsened over the past four days and is now provoked by walking one flight. He describes a sharp, pleuritic right-sided chest pain that increases with deep inspiration and a single episode of scant hemoptysis yesterday. He reports intermittent palpitations and subjective lightheadedness but denies fever. Five days ago he noticed swelling and mild ache in his right calf after a long car trip. He is a former 20 pack-year smoker with well-controlled hypertension. On exertion he becomes noticeably breathless and uses shallow respirations. The constellation suggests possible venous thromboembolism with secondary pulmonary involvement rather than simple postinfectious cough.

A 27-year-old male cook presents with four days of progressively worsening right upper quadrant abdominal pain that began as brief biliary colic after a fatty meal and has become constant and deep. He reports associated fevers with intermittent rigors, nausea with several episodes of non-bloody vomiting, and progressive jaundice noticed by yellowing of his eyes. He also describes dark urine and generalized pruritus over the past 48 hours. He recalls an ultrasound years ago that documented gallstones and prior transient postprandial colic. He denies recent travel, antibiotic use, or significant alcohol intake. Pain limits oral intake and he feels more fatigued than usual; he is concerned about an infected or obstructing gallstone and wants urgent evaluation.

An 87-year-old man presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that began after a self-limited bronchitic illness. He notes gradual 5-kg weight loss and increasing fatigue; over the past week he has desaturated to the mid-80s on short walks and developed occasional scant hemoptysis. He has a two-year history of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis with baseline reduced exercise tolerance, and now reports worsening crackling breath sounds at the bases and new digital clubbing. He has chronic atrial fibrillation and hypertension but no chest pain or orthopnea. He denies sputum purulence or fever since the initial illness. The pattern is concerning for acute exacerbation of pulmonary fibrosis with superimposed hypoxemia and functional decline.

A 9-year-old boy presents with a two-week history of progressively worsening cough and shortness of breath, most notable with exertion. Symptoms began after a recent upper respiratory infection and now include frequent nocturnal coughing that wakes him and a sensation of chest tightness with running; parents report audible wheeze during play and markedly reduced exercise tolerance, causing him to skip soccer practice. He had no high fevers, no significant sputum production, and no vomiting. Past history is notable for seasonal allergic rhinitis. Symptoms partially improve with rest but recur with minimal activity. Examination and history raise concern for post-viral airway hyperresponsiveness or new-onset reactive airways disease with exercise-induced bronchospasm.

A 49-year-old man presents with an eight-week history of progressive swallowing difficulty, initially with solids and now with liquids, accompanied by frequent regurgitation of undigested food and increasing halitosis. He notes nocturnal coughing and occasional choking episodes, and developed low-grade fever and productive cough after one severe episode two weeks ago. He reports a 10-pound unintentional weight loss and intermittent nonpleuritic retrosternal discomfort. Past history includes chronic reflux symptoms treated intermittently and a remote smoking history. Exam has been notable to him for new hoarseness and early satiety. The temporal pattern and combined solid/liquid dysphagia with regurgitation raise concern for an esophageal motility disorder such as achalasia, with possible aspiration-related bronchitis.

An 88-year-old female presents with acute right-sided weakness and slurred speech that began two days ago after waking. Family reports right facial droop, intermittent choking on liquids, and an unwitnessed fall at home with new gait instability. Over the past 48 hours she developed fluctuating confusion and reduced oral intake; relatives note she was treated for a urinary tract infection last week. Past medical history includes hypertension and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Brief exam in clinic showed marked right upper and lower extremity weakness with expressive language impairment. Noncontrast head CT in the emergency department demonstrated a new left MCA territory cortical infarct consistent with an embolic stroke. She denies headache, fever, or recent trauma.

A 74-year-old woman presents with five days of progressive exertional dyspnea and pleuritic right-sided chest pain. Symptoms began about two weeks after elective knee arthroplasty with a prolonged period of limited ambulation; she reports new right calf swelling and tenderness that started a week ago. She has a dry cough and intermittent lightheadedness with exertion, and family members noted episodic rapid pulse rates at home. She describes intermittent low-grade fevers and exertional oxygen desaturation. Past medical history includes hypertension and osteoarthritis. She denies hemoptysis or recent long-distance travel. She is increasingly limited by breathlessness and decreased exercise tolerance, raising concern for postoperative venous thromboembolism versus deconditioning or concurrent cardiopulmonary disease.

A 37-year-old man presents with two days of acute right-sided pleuritic chest pain and progressive exertional dyspnea. The pain is sharp, worse with deep inspiration, and he notes one small episode of bright red hemoptysis. Symptoms began shortly after a long commercial flight a week ago; he also developed new right calf swelling and aching over the same interval. He reports intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness and notes his home pulse oximeter has been lower than usual. Past history includes mild intermittent asthma and obesity; he smokes about half a pack daily. He denies fever, recent upper respiratory infection, or trauma. Given the constellation of unilateral calf edema, pleuritic pain, tachycardia, hypoxia, and hemoptysis, he is concerned about a possible venous thromboembolism.

A 62-year-old female reports abrupt, painless loss of vision in her left eye that began on waking six hours ago. She describes near-complete central blurring with a gray curtain and denies eye pain, photophobia, or floaters. She notes two brief, transient episodes of monocular dimming over the past week. Past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia, and intermittent palpitations suggestive of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Exam in clinic revealed a left afferent pupillary defect and fundoscopic retinal whitening with a cherry-red spot. Carotid bruits are audible on auscultation. She denies recent trauma, temporal headache, jaw claudication, or systemic illness. She is anxious about sudden permanent loss and requests urgent vascular and retinal evaluation.

A 59-year-old male presents with sudden-onset pleuritic right-sided chest pain and progressive dyspnea that began two days after a prolonged 10-hour car trip. He describes sharp pain worse with inspiration, associated with intermittent small-volume hemoptysis and a dry cough. Over 48 hours he developed subjective fevers and increasing shortness of breath with minimal exertion. He has known COPD managed with an occasional rescue inhaler and long-standing hypertension. At home he noted palpitations and low oxygen levels, and today reports new right calf swelling and tenderness. There is growing concern for pulmonary embolism versus COPD exacerbation, prompting urgent evaluation; he denies prior thromboembolic disease.

A 50-year-old man presents with two weeks of progressive blurred central vision in the right eye, culminating yesterday in a sudden superior visual field defect. He also reports intermittent diplopia and increased photophobia. Concurrently he developed a new, constant right temporal headache with overlying scalp tenderness and jaw claudication when chewing, which prompted urgent evaluation. He endorses six weeks of morning shoulder stiffness and aching suggestive of proximal myalgia, along with fatigue and low-grade fever. No eye pain, trauma, or prior ocular surgery. Past medical history notable for well-controlled hypertension. Symptoms suggest an inflammatory arteritic process with probable ischemic optic neuropathy; he is concerned about further vision loss and seeks urgent assessment.

A 30-year-old man reports three days of progressive dyspnea and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began shortly after a prolonged transcontinental flight. Initially worse with exertion, shortness of breath is now present at rest and associated with intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness. He developed a productive cough with scant blood-tinged sputum and low-grade subjective fever. He also notes new swelling and tenderness of the right calf over the past 48 hours. Past history is notable only for childhood asthma; he is a current smoker without chronic inhaler use. He denies recent trauma or bleeding disorders. The temporal clustering of immobilization, unilateral calf pain, pleuritic chest pain, hemoptysis, and tachycardic symptoms raises concern for acute venous thromboembolism with possible pulmonary infarction versus infectious pneumonia.

A 22-year-old female reports five days of progressive blurring of vision in the left eye, accompanied by dull periorbital discomfort and sharp pain with eye movement. She notes colors look “washed out” on the affected side and intermittent photopsias; visual acuity feels markedly reduced compared with baseline. Symptoms began after a brief viral upper respiratory illness about ten days earlier and worsen with heat or exertion (Uhthoff-like phenomenon). Over the past two weeks she has also had intermittent paresthesias in the right hand and occasional distal lower extremity numbness. She has a history of episodic migraines but describes the current visual change as distinct. No head trauma, nausea, or fever currently. Family history significant for autoimmune thyroid disease.

A 37-year-old female reports ten days of progressive right-sided numbness and tingling with increasing unsteadiness on her feet and intermittent horizontal diplopia. Symptoms began after a brief febrile upper respiratory illness and have worsened over the past week; she now notices electric shock–like sensations down the spine with neck flexion and urinary urgency developing over several days. She describes prior ocular pain with eye movement and a diagnosed episode of optic neuritis about a year ago. Fatigue is prominent and exacerbates cognitive fog in the afternoons. On review she denies chest pain or recent trauma. The pattern—multifocal sensory deficits, gait ataxia, visual disturbance, Lhermitte phenomenon following a recent infection—raises concern for a demyelinating process rather than peripheral neuropathy.

A 46-year-old male presents with eight weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a daily productive cough. He describes intermittent right-sided pleuritic chest pain, occasional scant hemoptysis, and an unintentional 15-pound weight loss accompanied by night sweats. Symptoms were insidious but noticeably worsened after a prolonged ten-hour car trip one month ago; he also reports intermittent right calf swelling and aching since then. He is a current smoker with a 20-pack-year history and has had recurrent bronchitic illnesses in prior years. He denies high fevers but notes fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance. The new hemoptysis and systemic symptoms raise concern for an underlying pulmonary neoplasm or chronic infection, while the recent immobilization and calf symptoms suggest possible DVT with pulmonary embolism.

A 67-year-old man presents with nine months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough, with a marked decline over the past three weeks following a presumed upper respiratory infection. He reports limited walking tolerance now, frequent stopping for breath, and a roughly 8-pound unintentional weight loss. On exertion he notes lightheadedness and subjective oxygen desaturation. Exam at the clinic revealed bibasilar fine inspiratory crackles and mild digital clubbing. He is a 40–pack-year ex-smoker and denies chest pain or orthopnea. No known prior heart failure. Clinical concern is for evolving interstitial lung disease, possibly idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, with superimposed postinfectious worsening; referral for high-resolution chest imaging and pulmonary function testing was discussed.

An 85-year-old man presents with three months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that began after a winter bronchitis. Shortness of breath initially occurred with hills but now limits walking across the house; he also notes two-pillow orthopnea and mild bilateral ankle swelling. Family reports a five-pound unintentional weight loss and occasional low-grade fevers. Exam findings at clinic include bibasilar fine inspiratory crackles and early digital clubbing. He is a former 40-pack-year smoker with no recent travel. Symptoms suggest an insidious interstitial process with superimposed deconditioning; differential includes evolving pulmonary fibrosis versus organizing pneumonia, with concurrent volume redistribution contributing to edema and orthopnea. He denies hemoptysis or chest pain. Further pulmonary evaluation recommended.

A 78-year-old woman presents with two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a dry cough, with acute worsening over the past 48 hours characterized by pleuritic left-sided chest discomfort and a scant episode of hemoptysis. She reports new intermittent palpitations and notes increasing swelling and tightness in her right calf that began after a recent week of limited mobility following a minor fall at home. At baseline she has well-controlled hypertension and chronic osteoarthritis. She felt lightheaded with exertion yesterday and measured home oxygen saturation in the high 80s on ambulation. No fever or sputum production. The temporal clustering of immobility, unilateral leg swelling, hypoxemia, pleuritic pain, and hemoptysis raises concern for possible pulmonary embolism.

A 95-year-old female reports sudden, progressive loss of vision in the right eye over 48 hours, preceded by two weeks of new temporal headache and scalp tenderness. She describes jaw claudication while eating and low-grade fevers with notable morning stiffness and shoulder girdle aching consistent with polymyalgia-like symptoms. On presentation family noted the right pupil reacted sluggishly and she has markedly decreased visual acuity in that eye. Past medical history includes long-standing hypertension and osteoarthritis; she lives at home with assistance. Concern is high for giant cell (temporal) arteritis given the constellation of monocular visual loss, focal scalp tenderness, jaw pain, proximal muscle stiffness, and elevated inflammatory markers reported on preliminary testing. No recent trauma, infection, or new medications.

A 25-year-old female reports two days of progressively worsening right upper quadrant abdominal pain, sharp and steady, radiating to the right scapula and reliably provoked after fatty meals. She describes associated postprandial nausea with two episodes of nonbloody emesis and low-grade fevers. Over the same period she has noted new yellowing of her eyes and skin with dark urine. She also complains of intense pruritus and decreased appetite. She has a history of intermittent biliary colic over the past year but no prior abdominal surgery. She denies alcohol use or recent travel. The temporal sequence—postprandial pain followed by jaundice and fever—raises concern for choledocholithiasis with possible ascending cholangitis.

A 58-year-old man presents with one week of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and a new, sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain. He reports increased productive cough with yellow-green sputum and intermittent low-grade fevers following a viral upper respiratory illness. He has a remote 40–pack-year smoking history and known COPD that had been stable until this episode. Three days ago he completed a long car trip and noted mild right calf swelling and cramping. He also describes brief lightheadedness when climbing stairs and difficulty sleeping unless propped up. He denies frank hemoptysis but feels more fatigued than usual. Past medical history includes hypertension. He is concerned this represents either an infectious COPD exacerbation or possible pulmonary embolism given the unilateral leg swelling and new pleuritic pain.

A 25-year-old woman presents with progressive daily headaches for six weeks, described as diffuse pressure worse in the mornings and with Valsalva. Headaches are accompanied by transient visual obscurations and intermittent horizontal diplopia on lateral gaze, and she reports a rhythmic whooshing in both ears consistent with pulsatile tinnitus. She notes associated nausea and photophobia but denies fever or recent head trauma. Ophthalmology documented bilateral optic disc swelling at an urgent visit. Symptoms began after a three-month period of rapid weight gain and worsening irregular menses; she carries a prior diagnosis of polycystic ovary syndrome. No personal history of migraine or anticoagulant use.

A 46-year-old man reports six weeks of progressive epigastric pain that intermittently radiates to the mid-back, classically worse after meals and limiting his appetite. He describes bulky, foul-smelling stools and oily spotting on the toilet for the past month, with an unintended ten-pound weight loss. Over the same interval he has had intermittent low-grade fevers and malaise. During the last week he noticed yellowing of his eyes, dark urine, and pale, clay-colored stools, prompting concern for obstructive jaundice. He has a remote history of heavy alcohol binges but drinks only occasionally now and is a former smoker. He denies hematemesis, melena, or prior gallbladder surgery. Symptoms suggest pancreatic or biliary pathology requiring further evaluation.

An 87-year-old female reports ten days of progressive dyspnea, initially with exertion and now at rest, with increasing fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance; she now tires after a few steps. She awakened twice with sudden nighttime breathlessness and uses two pillows for sleep, and has noticed progressive bilateral ankle swelling. Three days ago she developed intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness, and family observed an irregular pulse suggestive of possible atrial fibrillation. She denies chest pain but has a persistent dry cough following a brief upper respiratory illness two weeks earlier. Past history includes hypertension, stage 3 chronic kidney disease, and known moderate aortic stenosis. Appetite is down; no fevers, hemoptysis, or focal neurologic deficits.

A 32-year-old male software engineer presents with three days of progressive blurring and dimming of vision in the right eye, accompanied by sharp pain with extraocular movement. He reports marked desaturation of colors on the affected side and difficulty reading small print. Symptoms began one week after a self-limited upper respiratory illness with sore throat and congestion. He notes intermittent photophobia and new central floaters but denies discharge or ocular trauma. Mild retro-orbital headache and nausea without vomiting accompany episodes of vision change. On exam at urgent care he was noted to have a relative afferent pupillary defect in the right eye. No prior ophthalmologic history aside from remote myopia. Concern raised for optic neuritis versus inflammatory uveitis; urgent ophthalmology evaluation arranged.

An 11-year-old boy presents with two days of persistent vomiting and increasing lethargy. Parents describe a two-week history of excessive thirst and urination with new nocturnal enuresis and an unexplained 5-kg weight loss. Over the past three days he developed intermittent periumbilical abdominal pain and progressive nausea with poor oral intake. Today he is drowsy at times and noted to be breathing deeply and rapidly; caregivers report a sweet, fruity odor on his breath. He has been less active and has had decreased urine output despite earlier polyuria. No medication use or recent travel. The combination of polyuria, polydipsia, weight loss, vomiting, abdominal pain, Kussmaul respirations, fruity breath, and lethargy is concerning for new-onset type 1 diabetes with evolving diabetic ketoacidosis.

A 13-year-old boy presents with five days of progressive blurring of vision in the right eye, accompanied by aching behind the eye and sharp pain with extraocular movement. He reports colors in the affected eye appear "washed out" and parents note he favors the left when reading. Symptoms began about one week after a febrile upper respiratory illness with sore throat and runny nose. On exam at home the family observed the right pupil to be slower to constrict than the left. He denies discharge or trauma but has felt unusually fatigued and has had intermittent fingertip tingling over the last three days. Concern is for an inflammatory optic neuropathy such as optic neuritis from a postinfectious or demyelinating process restricting his school activities.

A 27-year-old female reports an 8-week history of progressive postprandial fullness, early satiety, and persistent nausea. Over the past month she has developed intermittent nonbilious emesis, occurring two to three times weekly, and an 8-pound unintentional weight loss because solid meals provoke worsening symptoms. The problems began after a self-limited gastroenteritis and have evolved to include marked bloating and alternating constipation. She denies fevers, hematemesis, or recent antibiotic use. Appetite is reduced and she feels increasingly fatigued. No prior abdominal surgery. She is most concerned about possible gastroparesis and is requesting evaluation for delayed gastric emptying and brief nutritional counseling to address ongoing weight loss.

A 9-year-old boy presents with an eight-week history of exertional shortness of breath and intermittent wheeze, which began after a presumed viral upper respiratory infection. Over the past three weeks his parents have noticed progressive exercise intolerance at soccer practices with episodes of chest tightness and a sensation of throat constriction during exertion. He wakes with a nocturnal cough about twice weekly and has occasional high-pitched inspiratory noise when laughing or upset. A brief trial of an inhaled bronchodilator at urgent care gave minimal, transient relief. He has a history of seasonal allergic rhinitis with nasal congestion and sneezing, no fevers, and normal growth. Concerns are for exercise-induced bronchospasm versus vocal cord dysfunction with post-infectious cough.

A 4-year-old boy presents with a three-day history of progressive sore throat and rhinorrhea that began after a presumed viral cold. Over 48 hours he developed fever to 39°C, increasing odynophagia and drooling with markedly reduced oral intake; parents note he refuses solids and has had only sips of fluid. Yesterday he began sleeping poorly and now speaks with a muffled “hot potato” voice and demonstrates difficulty opening his mouth. On initial evaluation there is a left-sided tonsillar bulge with uvular deviation and tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, raising concern for a peritonsillar process. He has no respiratory distress, wheeze, or ear pain, and immunizations are reported as up to date. Parents deny recent foreign body exposure.

A 0-year-old female infant presents with 48 hours of progressive nasal congestion and noisy breathing, now with poor oral intake and fewer wet diapers. Symptoms began after an older sibling had a mild cold; she developed rhinorrhea and intermittent coughing on day one and now has audible wheeze with tachypnea and visible subcostal retractions. Caregivers report two brief self-limited pauses in breathing overnight and persistent low-grade fever. Exam by phone notes increased work of breathing and lethargy with shallow feeds. Concern is bronchiolitis, likely viral (RSV exposure suspected), with secondary dehydration from decreased intake and decreased urine output. No rash, emesis, or known congenital cardiac disease reported. Parents seek evaluation for possible oxygen support or IV fluids.

A 43-year-old man reports 48 hours of progressive right-sided weakness and slurred speech. Symptoms began abruptly on waking with clumsiness of the right hand that progressed to difficulty rising from a chair; he now has intermittent right facial droop and dysarthria. He describes a dull occipital headache and new unsteadiness with one ground-level fall but no loss of consciousness. He notes numbness along the right forearm and decreased grip strength. Medical history is notable for poorly controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes; he smokes and had a mild upper respiratory infection about ten days ago. Family members describe brief episodes of confusion and word-finding difficulty. He denies chest pain, fever, or recent head trauma and is worried about a cerebrovascular event.

A 32-year-old woman reports five days of progressive dyspnea and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain that worsens with inspiration and cough. The cough is dry and intermittent; she notes a low-grade fever and mild palpitations with exertion and occasional lightheadedness. Symptoms began after a brief upper respiratory illness two weeks prior and acutely worsened following a long airplane flight. She takes combined oral contraceptives and is otherwise healthy with a history of mild intermittent asthma. She denies hemoptysis, calf swelling, or recent trauma but is concerned about a possible pulmonary embolism given the abrupt onset and risk factors. She has had reduced exercise tolerance and uses her rescue inhaler rarely without clear relief of the current shortness of breath.

A 68-year-old man reports progressive exertional dyspnea and a chronic productive cough that have slowly worsened over the past year, with an acute five-day escalation of shortness of breath accompanied by new right-sided pleuritic chest pain and scant hemoptysis. He describes a 40-pack-year smoking history and has known COPD of a chronic bronchitic phenotype and hypertension. Over the past two months he notes eight pounds of unintentional weight loss and diminished exercise tolerance; the cough intermittently produces yellowish sputum but no high fevers. Symptoms intensified after a recent upper respiratory illness. Examination today is deferred, but his presentation is concerning for a COPD exacerbation versus pulmonary embolism or an underlying lung malignancy given the hemoptysis and weight loss.

An 83-year-old woman reports two weeks of progressively worsening dyspnea on exertion and a productive cough, with increased purulent sputum and intermittent low-grade fevers following a presumed viral URI. She describes a brief choking episode while swallowing pills three days ago and now has new resting dyspnea and mild hypoxemia. Past pulmonary history is notable for COPD and known bronchiectasis; she also has long-standing hypertension. Exam-style symptoms include persistent fatigue, diminished exercise tolerance, bilateral coarse crackles, and scattered wheeze without chest pain. No focal neurologic deficits or dysphagia are reported. The presentation is most consistent with an acute-on-chronic lower respiratory infection, likely with an aspiration component superimposed on COPD/bronchiectasis.

A 21-year-old male student presents with five days of progressive blurred vision in his right eye, associated with sharp retro-orbital pain worsened by eye movement and intermittent diplopia. He noticed color desaturation and a “gray” central spot, and his girlfriend observed the right pupil reacted sluggishly. Symptoms began after a brief viral upper respiratory illness and were preceded two weeks earlier by transient tingling in his feet and occasional electric-shock sensations with neck flexion. He denies trauma, fever, or ocular discharge. On exam he reports photophobia and difficulty reading small print. The pattern—unilateral painful visual loss with an afferent pupillary defect, dyschromatopsia, and antecedent sensory symptoms—is most consistent with optic neuritis and raises concern for a demyelinating process such as multiple sclerosis.

A 98-year-old female reports two weeks of abrupt worsening of central vision in the left eye on a background of longstanding macular degeneration. She describes new metamorphopsia and an enlarging central scotoma with marked difficulty reading, recognizing faces, and dressing; the vision had declined slowly over years but acutely worsened when she noticed a persistent dark blot several days ago. She has known bilateral cataracts and denies ocular pain, purulent discharge, or headache. Caregivers report one near‑fall last week related to the visual change without head injury. Home assessment noted markedly reduced left central acuity. She seeks urgent ophthalmologic evaluation for suspected neovascular conversion with possible subretinal hemorrhage.

A 19-year-old male presents with a two-week history of progressive morning headaches described as throbbing and worse with coughing or bending. Headaches began after a week of sinus congestion and purulent nasal discharge and have become daily, often accompanied by nausea and two brief episodes of non‑generalized right‑hand twitching with preserved awareness. After the second event he experienced transient right arm weakness for about 20 minutes. He also reports intermittent visual obscurations and horizontal diplopia, photophobia, and one night of vomiting; he felt febrile during the initial sinus illness but denies recent trauma. No prior seizures, no anticoagulant use, and no illicit drug use. Symptoms raise concern for intracranial hypertension or venous sinus thrombosis related to recent sinus infection.

A 38-year-old female presents with two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and new orthopnea, reporting awakening once nightly with breathlessness. She describes paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea and a persistent nonproductive cough since a febrile viral illness three weeks ago. Over the past week she has noted increasing lower extremity swelling, intermittent palpitations, and generalized fatigue with reduced exercise tolerance; she also felt lightheaded when climbing stairs. She denies chest pain at rest but describes occasional chest tightness with exertion. No prior cardiopulmonary disease is reported. Symptoms have limited her ability to work and are clearly worse at night and with minimal exertion, raising concern for new-onset cardiomyopathy or decompensated heart failure after the recent infection.

A 72-year-old man presents with six months of progressive gait instability characterized by a short, shuffling, magnetic-appearing step and two to three falls in the past month. The family reports new forgetfulness and slowed thinking over the same interval, with difficulty managing finances and recent episodes of urinary urgency with occasional incontinence. Symptoms insidiously began after a minor head bump last winter but have steadily worsened; walking is more difficult than climbing stairs. A recent noncontrast head CT showed ventriculomegaly without acute hemorrhage, prompting neurology referral for suspected normal-pressure hydrocephalus. Past medical history is notable for long-standing hypertension and chronic lumbar spondylosis, though back pain does not correlate with the current gait decline. He denies fever, limb numbness, or bowel dysfunction.

A 72-year-old woman presents with three months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent nonproductive cough, with marked worsening over the past two weeks. She now reports orthopnea and new bilateral lower-extremity swelling, limiting her ability to climb stairs. On brief exertion she becomes dyspneic and her oxygen saturation falls into the low 80s at times.
