Exam at bedside reveals bibasilar fine crackles and dependent pitting edema; she denies fever, chest pain, or hemoptysis. Past history notable for long-standing hypertension and a remote ten–pack-year smoking history. The subacute course and exam raise concern for interstitial lung disease with possible chronic hypoxemic pulmonary hypertension contributing to right-sided congestion. Further pulmonary evaluation is planned.

A 96-year-old female reports three days of progressive dyspnea and a new productive cough after an episode of choking while eating. Family notes increased sputum purulence and intermittent low-grade fevers since the event; she describes mild right-sided pleuritic discomfort when coughing. At baseline she has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and is more short of breath than usual. On arrival she is more tachypneic with hypoxemia on room air and audible bibasilar crackles with expiratory wheeze; there is mild dependent edema. Clinical concern is aspiration pneumonia superimposed on a COPD exacerbation precipitated by oropharyngeal dysphagia. She denies hemoptysis, calf pain, or recent travel.

An 88-year-old man presents with six months of progressive gait instability characterized by a broad-based, shuffling, somewhat “magnetic” step and two recent falls. Family notes gradual short-term memory loss and slower speech over the same interval, with new urinary urgency progressing to occasional daytime incontinence in the past month. Symptoms markedly worsened after a urinary tract infection treated as an outpatient two weeks ago, with increased apathy and imbalance. He has a history of hypertension and long-standing benign prostatic hyperplasia, but bladder symptoms precede his recent prostatism change. Neurological exam reportedly shows slowed mentation and frontal release signs; prior head imaging demonstrated ventriculomegaly without marked cortical atrophy. Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is suspected; peripheral neuropathy is a possible contributor to his instability.

A 17-year-old female reports a six-week history of progressive unintentional weight loss of about 6 kg with intermittent palpitations and a fine resting tremor. She notes new heat intolerance and frequent night sweating, and over the past month her menses have become irregular and lighter. She has felt a subtle midline neck fullness that moves with swallowing and intermittent anterior neck discomfort. In the last two weeks she developed proximal thigh weakness that makes climbing stairs and carrying groceries more difficult. She also describes intermittent mild binocular horizontal diplopia when tired. Symptoms are gradually worsening, worse with activity and partially relieved by rest. No fevers, cough, or recent travel; past medical history otherwise unremarkable.

A 90-year-old woman presents with three days of progressive dyspnea and a productive cough after a witnessed choking episode while eating. Family reports immediate coughing with small amounts of aspirated material, followed by persistent wheeze and increasing shortness of breath that is now present at rest. She has low-grade fevers and describes thicker, foul-smelling sputum. At home she has required supplemental oxygen for worsening hypoxemia and has had poor oral intake with decreased urine output. On exam she is mildly confused compared with baseline and has bibasilar crackles greater on the right. Past history notable for mild cognitive impairment and hypertension. Impression is acute aspiration pneumonia with hypoxemic respiratory compromise and dehydration.

An 89-year-old female presents with three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and new orthopnea, reporting two pillows to sleep and one episode of waking breathless overnight. She notes a five-pound weight gain and increasing, pitting bilateral lower extremity edema up to the knees. Symptoms began after a brief upper respiratory illness and are accompanied by a mild productive cough but no fever. She describes intermittent palpitations and fatigue limiting her baseline ambulation. Past medical history is notable for long-standing hypertension and known aortic stenosis; chronic kidney disease stage 3 has previously complicated diuretic adjustments. No chest pain or syncope. Family is managing at home but she is more dyspneic with usual activities, prompting evaluation for decompensated heart failure versus arrhythmic exacerbation.

A 66-year-old male presents with an eight-week history of progressive dysphagia, initially to solids and now to both solids and liquids, associated with a 12-pound unintentional weight loss. He reports intermittent odynophagia and frequent regurgitation of undigested food, particularly at night, with several episodes of coughing and mild choking suggestive of nocturnal aspiration. Over the past three weeks he has developed new hoarseness and a sensation of throat fullness. He has a long history of chronic GERD and a 30-pack-year smoking history but denies hematemesis or melena. Recent outpatient labs showed iron-deficiency anemia. Symptoms are progressive rather than episodic, raising concern for an obstructive esophageal process such as malignancy versus a stricture, prompting endoscopic evaluation.

A 48-year-old woman presents with five days of progressively worsening right-sided pleuritic chest pain and exertional dyspnea that began after a long transcontinental flight two weeks ago. Pain is sharp, worse with deep inspiration and coughing, and associated with intermittent palpitations and mild hemoptysis. She describes prior three-day history of right calf swelling and tenderness, and notes recent lightheadedness on exertion. Symptoms are limiting her usual walking and sleep. Past medical history includes hypertension and obesity; she is a former smoker. She denies fever or recent bronchitis but reports occasional nocturnal reflux symptoms. On review, she fears a clot given the travel history; symptoms are most consistent with venous thromboembolism presenting with pulmonary complications.

A 67-year-old male reports four months of progressive gait instability and cognitive slowing. He describes a small‑step, magnetic shuffling gait with difficulty initiating steps and occasional mild dysarthria when fatigued; family reports two ground-level falls in the past month without loss of consciousness. Over the last six months there has been worsening short‑term memory and increased apathy, with new urinary urgency and occasional stress leakage for two months. He denies fevers, headache, or sensory loss. An outpatient head CT last month was reported to show ventricular enlargement. Past medical history notable for treated hypertension. Symptoms have insidiously progressed, and his son is concerned about steadily reduced mobility and safety at home, prompting today's evaluation for suspected communicating hydrocephalus versus neurodegenerative etiology.

A 21-year-old female reports a 10-day history of progressive vision loss in her left eye. She first noticed central blurring and difficulty reading; over several days this evolved into a distinct gray central scotoma and subjective color desaturation, with reds appearing washed out. She describes aching retro-orbital pain that worsens with eye movement and intermittent photophobia. Over the same week she developed mild frontal headache and brief episodes of numbness and tingling in the right hand and forearm. Symptoms began after a febrile upper respiratory illness two weeks ago. She denies ocular discharge, trauma, or diplopia. Given the painful unilateral visual decline with a recent viral prodrome, she is concerned for optic neuritis.

A previously healthy 8-year-old boy presents with a three-week history of progressive cough and audible wheeze that began after a viral upper respiratory infection. The cough is dry, worse at night, and reliably triggered by running and cold air; parents note increasingly labored breathing with exertion and decreased stamina during play. He had low-grade fever during the first two days but has been afebrile since. At urgent care he had diffuse expiratory wheeze and mild intercostal retractions with partial relief after a nebulized bronchodilator. Past history is significant for seasonal allergic rhinitis, and maternal asthma is noted. No recent travel or known sick contacts.

A 40-year-old man reports three weeks of progressive, intermittent right-sided numbness and weakness that first appeared while bending to lift a box and has waxed and waned since. Episodes last several hours and are now accompanied by intermittent diplopia and blurred vision with painful eye movement, and a brief electric shock sensation down the spine when he flexes his neck. He describes new gait instability and fatigue limiting his work, plus urinary urgency without dysuria. Symptoms tend to worsen with heat and exertion. He recalls a febrile upper respiratory illness about two months ago but denies trauma, recent travel, or illicit drug use. No prior neurologic history; family history noncontributory. He seeks evaluation for a possible demyelinating process.

A 23-year-old woman reports a six-week history of progressive, daily morning headaches described as diffuse, throbbing, and worse with lying flat or with Valsalva maneuvers. Headaches are accompanied by nausea, intermittent photophobia, and several brief episodes of transient visual obscurations — she says the vision “flashes dark” for seconds when standing. Over the past two weeks she has experienced unilateral pulsatile tinnitus and had two brief episodes of horizontal diplopia that resolved spontaneously. She notes a 15-pound weight gain in the last three months. No history of trauma, fever, or focal limb weakness. An outpatient ophthalmoscopy documented bilateral optic disc swelling, raising concern for increased intracranial pressure/idiopathic intracranial hypertension as the unifying diagnosis.

A 23-year-old male reports five days of progressively worsening cough and right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began after a recent upper respiratory infection. The cough is now productive of yellow-green sputum with low-grade fevers and malaise; he describes exertional shortness of breath that limits his usual gym routine. He notes intermittent wheeze and a sense of chest tightness but denies syncope or leg swelling. He endorses daily e-cigarette use and works in a shared indoor environment. Past history is notable only for childhood allergic rhinitis. On self-exam he feels decreased air entry at the right base and focal pleuritic tenderness. Clinical concern is for community-acquired lobar pneumonia with superimposed bronchospasm, and he seeks evaluation for antibiotics and a bronchodilator.

A 56-year-old woman reports eight weeks of progressive, fluctuating weakness, beginning with intermittent binocular diplopia and worsening bilateral ptosis that is most pronounced by evening. Over the past month she has developed intermittent dysphagia for solids, morning voice hoarseness, and proximal upper‑extremity weakness—difficulty lifting a grocery bag and brushing her hair—with preserved sensation and no numbness. She notes dyspnea on exertion with stairs but denies orthopnea. Symptoms briefly worsened after a recent upper respiratory infection. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She has lost three pounds unintentionally. No fevers, rashes, or focal sensory deficits are reported. Symptoms are fluctuating and fatigable, prompting concern for a neuromuscular process.

A 43-year-old man reports five days of progressive exertional shortness of breath and sharp, right-sided pleuritic chest pain that worsens with deep inspiration. He has a dry cough and experienced a small episode of hemoptysis yesterday. He describes intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness when climbing stairs. He noticed right calf swelling and aching beginning shortly after a prolonged 12-hour car trip two weeks ago. At home he measured resting oxygen saturation near 88% on a fingertip device. He has a history of well-controlled hypertension and denies fever or recent chest trauma. He is otherwise active but stopped biking this week because of dyspnea. Symptoms raised concern for a thromboembolic event given the unilateral leg swelling, recent immobilization, pleuritic pain, hypoxemia, and hemoptysis.

A 22-year-old female reports a 10-day history of progressive blurring in the right eye, accompanied by aching pain with eye movement and subjective loss of color saturation. Her primary care clinician noted a relative afferent pupillary defect on brief exam. She also describes intermittent diplopia and a fatigable right-sided eyelid droop that worsens toward evening. Symptoms began after a self-limited upper respiratory illness two weeks earlier. She endorses new transient paresthesias in her fingertips and mild unsteadiness when tired but denies fever, discharge, or head trauma. No prior ocular surgery; has occasional tension-type headaches. Concern raised for optic neuritis in the context of a possible postinfectious or demyelinating process; neuro-ophthalmology evaluation is being sought.

A 20-year-old woman presents with a five-day progressive bifrontal headache, described as constant pressure with superimposed throbbing spikes, accompanied by photophobia, nausea, and two episodes of emesis. Over the past 36 hours she developed intermittent right-hand numbness and paresthesia and noted brief twitching of her right thumb consistent with a focal motor seizure. She started combined oral contraceptives six months ago and completed a course of antibiotics for presumed sinusitis two weeks prior. She also reports transient double vision and morning worsening of headache. No prior migraine history, no fevers currently, and no known thrombophilia, though a maternal uncle had an unprovoked deep vein thrombosis. She seeks evaluation for worsening neurologic deficits.

A 26-year-old tall, thin male presents with sudden onset left-sided pleuritic chest pain and acute dyspnea that began while playing soccer two hours ago. Pain is sharp, worse with deep inspiration and coughing, and associated with a dry cough and lightheadedness but no fever. He reports a mild upper respiratory illness with nasal congestion and throat soreness over the past week and smokes intermittently. On exam he notes rapid heartbeat and subjective air hunger; he felt a brief pop sensation in the chest before symptoms intensified. He has no prior cardiopulmonary disease. Concern for primary spontaneous pneumothorax is raised given the sudden unilateral pleuritic pain, diminished breath sounds and hyperresonance on the affected side; pulmonary embolism and asthma exacerbation are secondary considerations.

A 95-year-old female presents with sudden, painless loss of vision in the right eye for about 10 hours. She describes several transient episodes of monocular visual dimming over the past week, now progressed to near-complete vision loss, and reports new temporal headache, scalp tenderness when combing her hair, and intermittent jaw claudication while eating. She has had low-grade fever and malaise for several days but denies ocular pain, discharge, or recent trauma. Past medical history includes hypertension, known dry age-related macular degeneration, and bilateral cataracts under observation. Family notes marked difficulty with activities of daily living due to the acute loss. Findings are most concerning for arteritic ischemic optic neuropathy versus central retinal artery occlusion; urgent ophthalmology and vascular evaluation requested.

A 67-year-old man presents with six months of gradually worsening central blurring in the right eye, now with acute worsening over the past week characterized by marked metamorphopsia and a persistent central dark spot. He denies ocular pain or significant photophobia but notes difficulty reading and distinguishing faces; peripheral vision feels unchanged. Past ocular history includes uncomplicated cataract extraction in the left eye two years ago. Known hypertension is treated conservatively. Prior retinal exam documented macular drusen; recent self-administered Amsler grid testing showed enlarging distortion. He reports no prior intravitreal therapy. Examination elsewhere suggested subretinal hemorrhage and suspected neovascular (wet) age-related macular degeneration of the right eye; he seeks urgent retinal evaluation for possible anti-VEGF treatment.

An 87-year-old man reports two weeks of progressively worse exertional dyspnea after a self-limited upper respiratory illness three weeks ago. He now awakens at night with breathlessness and orthopnea, and describes a chronic productive cough that has become more frequent with scant whitish sputum. Family notes reduced exercise tolerance and a one-week history of new bilateral ankle swelling. He denies chest pain or fever. On exertion he becomes visibly tachypneic and reports wheeze and increased work of breathing; baseline oxygen saturation has dropped into the low 90s. Known history includes COPD with remote smoking. Current presentation is most consistent with acute decompensation—likely COPD exacerbation with superimposed volume overload/heart failure—prompting evaluation for hypoxic respiratory failure and fluid management.

A 24-year-old male presents with three weeks of progressive, fluctuating muscle weakness and double vision. He first noticed intermittent diplopia and unilateral ptosis that worsen by evening and after activity, then developed increasing proximal limb weakness affecting stairs and overhead tasks. Over the past week he reports mild dysphagia with occasional coughing when swallowing thin liquids and a nasal quality to his speech. He also endorses exertional dyspnea with short walks but denies sensory changes, numbness, or pain. Symptoms began after a self-limited upper respiratory infection two weeks prior. No prior neurologic history. Exam at home improved after rest. The pattern of fatigability, ocular involvement, dysphagia, and recent viral prodrome is concerning for a neuromuscular junction disorder such as myasthenia gravis.

A 58-year-old man presents with three months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough, with accelerated breathlessness over the past two weeks. He reports decreased exercise tolerance and a 6‑kg unintentional weight loss; denied fevers or hemoptysis. On exertion he notes lightheadedness and occasional resting breathlessness; his wife noticed finger clubbing. He has a 40–pack‑year smoking history and treated hypertension. Exam was notable for fine inspiratory crackles and mild bilateral lower‑extremity edema. Prior chest radiograph reportedly showed interstitial markings; clinicians are now concerned for a fibrotic interstitial lung disease with associated pulmonary hypertension contributing to hypoxemia. He has not started new medications and denies occupational exposures.

A 51-year-old man reports two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a chronic productive cough, with sudden onset of pleuritic right-sided chest pain and scant hemoptysis beginning yesterday after a prolonged flight. He describes years of purulent sputum consistent with chronic bronchitis and a 30-pack-year smoking history. Three days ago he noticed new right calf swelling and tightness. He has felt intermittently febrile but denies recent upper respiratory infection or known malignancy. Activity tolerance has fallen — he now tires after short walks. The temporal sequence of chronic airway symptoms, recent unilateral leg swelling, and acute pleuritic pain following long travel raises concern for pulmonary embolism superimposed on underlying chronic obstructive airway disease.

A 67-year-old woman reports three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea with new orthopnea and two episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. She describes increasing fatigue and a 5-pound weight gain over the past week with noticeable bilateral pitting ankle swelling. Ten days ago she began intermittent palpitations described as irregular, rapid beats and occasional lightheadedness. She also endorses a nocturnal, nonproductive cough but denies fever, sputum, or syncope. She has a long-standing history of hypertension and notes decreased exercise tolerance—now short of breath after walking one block. Symptoms have worsened despite resting at home. She is concerned about heart failure or an arrhythmia and seeks evaluation for possible decompensation.

A 93-year-old female reports sudden, painless loss of vision in the left eye over the past 48 hours superimposed on chronic central blurring from known age-related macular degeneration. She describes new left-sided scalp tenderness and jaw claudication with chewing that began three days ago, and mild low-grade fevers and fatigue over the past week. She recalls worsening morning shoulder stiffness consistent with prior polymyalgia rheumatica. On exam at home she noted a firm prominence over the left temporal region and denies eye discharge or trauma. Past history significant for cataract surgery years ago and longstanding hypertension. Family is concerned about permanent vision loss; she is being evaluated urgently for possible giant cell arteritis and ischemic optic neuropathy.

A 77-year-old man presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent nonproductive cough that began after a brief upper respiratory illness. He now tires walking a single block and notes intermittent lightheadedness with exertion. He reports an 8-pound unintentional weight loss and intermittent low-grade fevers with night sweats but denies hemoptysis or chest pain. Examination at home noted new fingernail clubbing and his spouse comments he sounds “raspy” at the bases; auscultation revealed bibasilar fine inspiratory crackles on prior clinic exam. He is a former 30 pack-year smoker, stopped two decades ago, and uses no regular inhalers. There is no orthopnea or leg swelling. He is worried about a chronic lung process and reduced exercise tolerance.

A 19-year-old female presents with three days of progressive right-sided pleuritic chest pain and worsening shortness of breath that began after a viral upper respiratory illness. Pain is sharp, localized to the right hemithorax, worse with deep inspiration and coughing; she reports a nonproductive cough with one episode of scant blood-tinged sputum. She notes low-grade fevers and palpitations but denies trauma, leg swelling, or prior clotting disorders. At home she felt markedly short of breath and noted decreased breath sounds on the right with a sense of chest tightness. Past history significant only for intermittent childhood asthma; she occasionally smokes socially. Exam findings of unilateral hyperresonance are concerning for a primary spontaneous pneumothorax; urgent evaluation is planned.

A 28-year-old male presents with three weeks of progressive occipital headaches and new cognitive slowing. Symptoms began after a self-limited upper respiratory infection; headaches were initially intermittent but have become daily throbbing occipital pain with photophobia and transient scintillating visual auras. Over the past week he developed intermittent confusion, slowed speech, and subjective memory lapses. Two days ago a witnessed focal motor seizure characterized by repetitive right-hand twitching with brief dysarthria occurred; postictal confusion lasted several hours. He also reports intermittent low-grade fevers and neck stiffness without nuchal erythema. No prior neurologic history, no recent travel, and no substance use. Family notes decreased work performance and it prompted presentation today.

A 73-year-old woman presents with three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and decreased exercise tolerance. She reports new orthopnea requiring two pillows, leg swelling to the knees, and intermittent palpitations with a brief near-syncope while climbing stairs last week. She notes activity-limiting fatigue and occasional lightheadedness. Primary care recently documented hypertension and chronic kidney disease stage 3; she has no chest pain but family noticed an irregular pulse. Onset of symptoms followed a period of iron-deficiency anemia treated conservatively. Examination raised concern for congestive heart failure with a new harsh systolic ejection murmur consistent with aortic stenosis and an irregularly irregular rhythm suggesting paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Symptoms have worsened despite rest, prompting ED evaluation.

A 44-year-old male presents with a 10-day history of progressive central visual distortion in the right eye described as metamorphopsia and intermittent central blur, worse with reading. He reports a relative central scotoma and difficulty focusing at near but denies flashes, floaters, ocular pain, or discharge. Symptoms began after a week of work-related stress and a recent short course of oral prednisone for a dermatitis flare. Past medical history includes well-controlled hypertension, episodic migraine without aura, and mild myopia corrected with glasses; he is an occasional smoker. No diabetes or head trauma. He is concerned about acute macular pathology; provisional considerations include central serous chorioretinopathy versus focal macular edema and he requests urgent retinal evaluation.

An 18-year-old male college athlete presents with two recent syncopal episodes during soccer practice and progressive exertional dyspnea and palpitations over the past three months. He describes brief chest tightness and lightheadedness with vigorous exertion and a single presyncopal spell last week; symptoms worsened after a mild viral prodrome with myalgias two weeks ago. On arrival he notes intermittent palpitations and fatigue but denies chest pain at rest, syncope with standing, or illicit drug use. Family history is notable for an uncle who died suddenly in middle age. Examination revealed a new harsh systolic ejection murmur that increases with Valsalva and a resting tachycardia. Concern is for obstructive cardiomyopathy or arrhythmic syncope.

A 77-year-old man presents with a four-month history of progressive gait instability and new short-term memory impairment. He describes a slow, shuffling, magnetic-type gait with frequent veering and two recent falls without loss of consciousness; family reports slowing of thought and difficulty managing finances. Over the same interval he developed urinary urgency with nocturia and one episode of urge incontinence, previously attributed to known benign prostatic hyperplasia. He has a history of hypertension. He sustained a minor head bump three months ago with transient headache, after which mobility worsened. Primary care CT reportedly showed ventriculomegaly out of proportion to atrophy. He also notes lightheadedness when standing. Concern is for normal-pressure hydrocephalus versus mixed degenerative and vascular contributors.

A 42-year-old woman reports six weeks of progressive postprandial epigastric pain and early satiety. Pain is dull, worse after fatty meals, often followed by nausea and intermittent non-bilious vomiting; she now tolerates only small portions. She describes greasy, bulky stools with foul odor and an 8-kg unintentional weight loss over two months. She also endorses months of intermittent heartburn previously attributed to reflux. Fatigue has increased and recent evaluation revealed iron-deficiency anemia. She denied fevers, overt jaundice, or hematochezia. Past history notable only for prior episodic biliary-type right upper quadrant pain last year. She reports no alcohol use and no recent travel. Concern is raised for malabsorption or pancreatic exocrine insufficiency versus peptic disease or choledocholithiasis.

A 47-year-old man presents with six weeks of progressive epigastric pain and early satiety, describing a constant gnawing discomfort worsened after meals and relieved slightly by belching. He reports increasing postprandial nausea with two to three episodes of nonbilious vomiting per week and an 8-kg unintentional weight loss. Over the past three weeks he has noticed intermittent black, tarry stools. Primary care noted new iron-deficiency anemia on routine testing. He has a remote history of peptic ulcer disease and admits to regular NSAID use for chronic low back pain; he recalls prior treatment for Helicobacter pylori but is unsure of eradication. No fevers or overt jaundice. Concern is for complicated peptic disease with possible gastric outlet obstruction or underlying malignancy; he requests endoscopic evaluation.

A 72-year-old woman reports a week of intermittent right arm and leg numbness with brief episodes of slurred speech, evolving into persistent right-sided weakness and expressive aphasia since this morning. Symptoms began as transient focal deficits lasting 10–20 minutes, occurring three to four times over five days before progression. She reports intermittent lightheadedness and one presyncopal spell on standing. Past medical history significant for longstanding hypertension and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, with patient noting a recent symptomatic AF episode last week. On review she endorses neck bruit and intermittent monocular visual blurring before some events. No fever or headache. The pattern is concerning for crescendo TIAs from probable cardioembolic or carotid etiology with evolving infarction.

A 34-year-old male presents with two days of sudden, sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain and progressive exertional dyspnea. Pain began abruptly while climbing stairs and is worse with deep inspiration; he reports one small episode of blood-tinged sputum. He notes intermittent palpitations and near-syncope with activity. Five days earlier he completed a 10-hour flight and has had increasing left calf tightness and mild swelling since then. Past history notable for childhood asthma and a prior unprovoked deep venous thrombosis with heterozygous Factor V Leiden; he is not on chronic anticoagulation. He smokes half a pack daily and denies fever or recent immobilizing injury. Symptoms suggest thromboembolic disease with possible pulmonary embolism; he seeks urgent evaluation.

A 64-year-old man presents with two weeks of progressive lower-extremity swelling, reduced urine output, and increasing shortness of breath with minimal exertion. He notes frothy urine and intermittent dark hematuria, and describes new mild proximal muscle weakness and nausea. Symptoms began after a course of over-the-counter NSAIDs for lumbar strain; he has a history of hypertension controlled intermittently. Over the last five days his legs and abdominal girth have worsened and he has had orthopnea at night. He denies fever, rash, or dysuria. Exam consistent with volume overload and oliguria; patient is worried about declining kidney function given prior elevated blood pressure. Concern is acute-on-chronic kidney injury with nephrotic-range proteinuria versus obstructive component.

A 71-year-old man presents with three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a productive cough that acutely worsened over the past 48 hours with new blood-tinged sputum and right-sided pleuritic chest pain. He notes an unintentional 12-pound weight loss over two months and reports a 40 pack-year smoking history; he has a history of COPD and treated hypertension. On minimal exertion he becomes short of breath and reports lightheadedness; at rest he denies fevers but feels fatigued. Examination reveals oxygen desaturation with ambulation and focal dullness with diminished breath sounds at the right upper lung. Concern is for an obstructing right upper lobe process such as malignancy versus superimposed consolidation.

A 34-year-old female reports a two-week history of increasingly frequent unilateral throbbing headaches, now occurring every 2–3 days and lasting 4–12 hours. Attacks typically begin with a scintillating visual aura and progressive photophobia and phonophobia, followed by severe nausea and vomiting. Over the past week she has had two episodes of transient right-sided paresthesia with mild weakness and brief slurred speech lasting 30–60 minutes. She also describes intermittent horizontal diplopia and new gait unsteadiness between headaches. Symptoms began after a mild upper respiratory infection and are worsened by exertion and poor sleep. She denies fever or neck stiffness. Past headaches were less frequent menstrual migraines; mother has migraine history. She sought evaluation because of the new focal neurologic features.

A 65-year-old male reports three months of progressively worsening shortness of breath, initially with brisk stair climbing and now at minimal exertion. He has a chronic productive cough with yellow sputum, intermittent wheeze, and two episodes of scant hemoptysis over the past month following a viral bronchitis. He carries a 40–pack-year smoking history and known COPD with prior exacerbations. Over the last six weeks he notes decreased exercise tolerance with exertional desaturation requiring frequent rest, new mild bilateral lower extremity swelling, fatigue, and an unintended 8-pound weight loss. He denies fevers or overt chest pain but is concerned these changes represent advancing pulmonary hypertension or progression of his obstructive lung disease.

A 39-year-old male presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and fatigue that began three weeks after a febrile upper respiratory illness. He now wakes once or twice nightly breathless (paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea) and requires two pillows to sleep because of orthopnea. He reports 10-pound weight gain and new bilateral ankle swelling, decreased exercise tolerance, and intermittent palpitations with a near-syncope episode after climbing stairs. He describes occasional exertional chest tightness but no sharp pleuritic pain. He has a history of well-controlled hypertension diagnosed two years ago. There is no tobacco use. The temporal clustering and preceding viral prodrome raise concern for new cardiomyopathy with congestive heart failure rather than primary pulmonary disease.

An 80-year-old woman presents with a three-month history of progressive gait instability and two unwitnessed falls at home. Family reports gradual slowing of thought, impaired short-term memory, and increasing difficulty with multitasking over the same interval. She has developed urinary urgency with one episode of daytime incontinence and now needs assistance rising from a chair. On exam she demonstrates a broad-based, magnetic gait with reduced step height and hesitancy to initiate walking but no marked focal weakness. A noncontrast head CT last month reportedly showed ventriculomegaly. She has a history of hypertension. There is no fever, dysphagia, or new visual loss. Concern is for possible normal-pressure hydrocephalus versus a parkinsonian neurodegenerative process contributing to functional decline.

A 25-year-old woman presents with a five-day history of progressive, severe holocephalic headache now maximal and constant for 24 hours, accompanied by nausea and two episodes of vomiting. She reports new intermittent photophobia and transient blurring of vision, and yesterday had two self-limited episodes of left arm numbness and weakness lasting several minutes. A roommate witnessed a brief generalized shaking spell last night. She started combined oral contraceptives three months ago and had a recent treated sinus infection two weeks prior. In the ED she complained of worsening morning headache and ophthalmology noted mild bilateral optic disc swelling. She denies prior migraine history, fever, or recent head trauma. Symptoms prompted urgent neuroimaging for concern about a thrombotic process.

A 26-year-old man reports three months of progressive exertional dyspnea and reduced exercise tolerance, now limiting his ability to play competitive soccer. Over the past two weeks he has experienced intermittent palpitations and two brief presyncopal episodes during intense exertion, described as lightheadedness with transient tunnel vision. He also notes exertional chest tightness without radiation and occasional nocturnal dyspnea that awakens him once or twice per week. Symptoms began insidiously after a viral illness but have steadily worsened despite rest. He denies chest pain at rest, illicit drug use, or recent travel; drinks several energy drinks before games. Family history is notable for an uncle who died suddenly at age 42. No prior cardiac diagnosis or regular medications.

A 21-year-old female reports a 6-day history of progressive blurring and central vision loss in her right eye, accompanied by aching pain worsened by eye movement. She describes colors appearing washed out and intermittent flashing lights; reading is now difficult. Symptoms began after a mild upper respiratory illness two weeks ago. Over the past 48 hours she has noted tingling in the left forearm and transient unsteadiness on stairs but no weakness or headache. She denies trauma, eye discharge, or recent travel. Sleep has been fragmented due to visual symptoms and fatigue. Past medical history notable only for seasonal allergic rhinitis. She takes no regular medications and is concerned about sudden vision decline, seeking evaluation.

An 87-year-old female reports one week of progressive exertional dyspnea now occurring with minimal ambulation and associated orthopnea requiring two pillows. She describes two nocturnal episodes of sudden breathlessness that awaken her and new bilateral ankle swelling. She has intermittent palpitations and mild lightheadedness; family noted an irregular, occasionally rapid pulse at home. Past history includes hypertension and known atrial fibrillation with prior diastolic dysfunction consistent with HFpEF. She denies chest pain or syncope but notes markedly reduced exercise tolerance compared with baseline independence. Symptoms began after a period of decreased mobility and increased dietary sodium. No fever, but she endorses a small-volume productive cough without hemoptysis.

A 15-year-old female reports a three-week history of progressive shortness of breath with exertion and intermittent dry cough that began after a viral upper respiratory infection. Symptoms are most pronounced during running and choir practice, when she develops throat tightness and a high-pitched inspiratory noise rather than classic expiratory wheeze. She notes decreased exercise tolerance and occasional nighttime coughing that wakes her. Past history is notable for atopic dermatitis and perennial nasal congestion with sporadic sneezing. Cold air and anxiety reliably provoke episodes, during which she describes rapid shallow breathing. She denies fevers, chest pain, or hemoptysis; symptoms have been only minimally responsive to rest and throat lozenges.

A 67-year-old woman presents with three months of progressive gait instability characterized by short, shuffling steps and several near-falls. Her daughter reports difficulty initiating walking and a more pronounced magnetic quality to her stride; falls have increased over the past four weeks. She has developed urinary urgency with two brief episodes of incontinence and noticeable slowing of memory and multitasking. She also endorses intermittent dull headaches and mild bilateral lower-extremity numbness and tingling, worse at night. Symptoms began insidiously without antecedent illness. Past medical history notable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes; she attributes the leg paresthesias to diabetes. No visual changes, dysphagia, or focal weakness reported. She is seeking evaluation for progressive balance and cognitive decline.

A 62-year-old woman presents with progressive exertional dyspnea over two weeks, worse with climbing stairs and accompanied by a new productive cough producing yellow-green sputum with occasional blood streaks. She reports pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort that increases with deep inspiration and intermittent wheeze noticed at night. Low-grade fevers and night sweats began five days ago after a recent upper respiratory illness. She has a remote 20 pack-year smoking history, known COPD and hypertension, and baseline limited mobility from osteoarthritis. No recent travel or known sick contacts. She denies chest pressure consistent with angina but notes mild bilateral ankle swelling over several days. Symptoms have limited her ability to perform usual activities.

A 42-year-old man presents with five days of progressive exertional dyspnea and new left-sided pleuritic chest pain. Symptoms began within a week after a long-haul flight; he developed left calf swelling and tenderness three days ago and today noted blood-tinged sputum. He reports intermittent palpitations and feels lightheaded with minimal exertion; at home he noted oxygen saturation in the high 80s on room air. He has a history of treated hypertension but no prior thrombotic events. The sequence of recent prolonged travel, unilateral leg swelling, acute pleuritic pain, hemoptysis, hypoxemia and tachycardia is concerning for deep venous thrombosis with pulmonary embolism, potentially causing pulmonary infarction, and warrants urgent evaluation.

A 71-year-old female reports two weeks of progressive central vision distortion in the left eye, with worsening metamorphopsia and a new central scotoma that limits reading. She also notes an increase in floaters without erythema or purulent discharge and denies severe ocular pain. Three days ago she developed a persistent left-sided temporal headache and intermittent jaw claudication when chewing, which she finds concerning in the setting of her visual change. Past medical history is significant for long-standing hypertension and hyperlipidemia and prior cataract extraction in the right eye. She denies recent trauma, diplopia, systemic fever, or weight loss and seeks urgent evaluation for possible ischemic or neovascular causes of her vision loss.

A 49-year-old man presents with six weeks of intermittent diplopia and bilateral ptosis, progressively worse toward evening and after exertion. He describes fluctuating proximal limb weakness — difficulty rising from a chair and combing hair — and new intermittent dysphagia for solids and liquids over the past two weeks. Shortness of breath with minimal exertion and nocturnal breathlessness raise concern for bulbar and respiratory muscle involvement. Symptoms began shortly after an upper respiratory infection. Past history notable only for well-controlled hypertension. He denies sensory loss, fever, or recent trauma. Examination at home is notable for variable eyelid droop and fatigable weakness. Concern is for myasthenia gravis with possible thymoma; urgent neuromuscular evaluation and chest imaging are requested.

A 53-year-old woman presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea that began after a prolonged upper respiratory illness and is now limiting climbing a single flight of stairs. She has a persistent dry cough and intermittent pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort, with one episode of scant hemoptysis. She reports new exertional palpitations and lightheadedness and has noticed mild ankle swelling toward the end of the day. She is a former 30-pack-year smoker who quit a decade ago and has a history of hypertension. No recent long travel or immobilization. Symptoms raise concern for thromboembolic disease versus evolving interstitial lung process with possible secondary pulmonary hypertension; she denies fever but feels fatigued and has lost a few pounds unintentionally.

A 53-year-old woman presents with a six-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough. Symptoms began as mild shortness of breath on stairs and now limit walking one block; she endorses new orthopnea and two near-syncope episodes with minimal exertion. Intermittent pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort has been present for ten days. One week after a prolonged transcontinental flight she developed unilateral calf swelling and aching. She has a history of treated hypertension and a remote 15-pack-year smoking history but no known COPD or asthma. She denies fevers or sputum production. The temporal pattern and calf swelling raise concern for pulmonary embolism with possible evolving pulmonary hypertension and right-sided strain.

An 84-year-old man reports a six-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that began after a bronchitic illness three weeks ago. He now becomes short of breath with minimal activity, is limited to the house, and wakes at night with breathlessness and intermittent orthopnea. Family notes new bilateral ankle swelling over the past ten days. He denies chest pain, fevers, or sputum production. On prior visits he carries diagnoses of COPD and hypertension. He describes slowed appetite and mild weight loss. Recent exertion causes noticeable desaturation and he has developed digital clubbing; auscultation at baseline reportedly reveals fine inspiratory crackles at the bases. He is worried symptoms are steadily worsening and interfering with daily care.

A 4-year-old female presents with three days of purulent right ear drainage and progressive otalgia after a week-long runny nose. Parents report tugging at the ear, increasing irritability, and a febrile episode to 38.9°C last night. They noticed markedly decreased hearing on the right and a small episode of imbalance with one brief fall today. Drainage began suddenly after presumed bulging of the eardrum and is described as yellow-green; she has had reduced oral intake but no vomiting. On inspection at home there is mild postauricular swelling and tenderness behind the right ear, raising concern for acute otitis media with tympanic membrane perforation and early mastoiditis. No neck stiffness, seizure, or skin rash reported; immunizations up to date and no prior ear surgeries.

A 65-year-old woman presents with four weeks of progressive gait instability and intermittent vertigo. Symptoms began after a brief upper respiratory illness and were initially episodic but have become persistent, with two recent near-falls and increasing difficulty rising from chairs. Family reports new slurred speech over the past week and she describes horizontal oscillopsia with blurred vision on head movement. She also notes a new, constant left-sided tinnitus and subjective hearing decline. She denies focal limb numbness or new weakness. Her past medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension. She remains independent at baseline but is limiting activities because of frequent unsteadiness and fear of falling.

An 82-year-old woman presents with sudden, painless loss of vision in her left eye that began overnight after two weeks of progressive symptoms. She describes several transient episodes of partial visual obscuration in that eye over the past week, now evolving to near-complete loss. Concurrently she has developed a new, constant right-sided temporal headache, scalp tenderness when combing her hair, and jaw claudication with chewing. She reports proximal shoulder and hip stiffness most pronounced in the mornings, low-grade fevers, and fatigue, but denies trauma, diplopia, or recent illness. No prior ophthalmologic procedures. The temporal pattern and constellation of scalp tenderness, jaw pain, new headache, proximal stiffness, and acute monocular vision loss are concerning for an ischemic arteritis process.

A 49-year-old female reports two months of progressive right-sided proptosis with intermittent binocular diplopia, most notable on lateral gaze. She describes blurred central vision and intermittent transient obscurations, and a dull retro-orbital ache that worsens with eye movement. Examination findings at urgent clinic included upper eyelid retraction and periorbital fullness; patient also notes a fine tremor. Over the preceding six weeks she developed palpitations, heat intolerance, and unintended weight loss, suggesting new thyrotoxic symptoms. She has a remote history of well-controlled hypertension. She denies recent trauma, infection, or visual loss sudden enough to suggest vascular occlusion. The temporal sequence and combination of proptosis, eyelid signs, diplopia, and systemic hyperadrenergic features raise concern for thyroid-associated orbitopathy.

A 9-year-old girl presents with six weeks of intermittent crampy periumbilical abdominal pain that has become daily and more severe over the past two weeks. Initially associated with transient watery stools, she now has frequent bloody, watery diarrhea and occasional nonbilious vomiting. Parents report reduced appetite, a 3–4 lb weight loss, and increasing fatigue; she has missed several days of school. Low-grade fevers occur most evenings. On review, she has had two small painful oral aphthous ulcers and recent perianal pain with minor fissuring. She had no recent travel or antibiotic exposure and no known sick contacts. Symptoms are unresponsive to dietary changes at home, raising concern for an inflammatory enteropathy such as pediatric inflammatory bowel disease versus a protracted infectious colitis.

A 77-year-old female reports acute, progressive vision loss in the left eye over three days following two weeks of new temporal headaches. She describes central blurring with intermittent floaters but no discharge or photophobia. Associated symptoms include scalp tenderness over the left temple, jaw claudication when chewing, and morning stiffness in the shoulders and hips lasting 30–45 minutes. She notes low-grade fevers and decreased appetite but denies recent trauma or prior retinal disease. Primary care documented an elevated inflammatory marker earlier this week. Past medical history is notable only for longstanding hypertension. Patient is worried about sudden permanent vision change; symptoms are most consistent with ischemic optic neuropathy in the setting of suspected giant cell arteritis.

An 11-year-old boy presents with three weeks of progressive exertional shortness of breath and a persistent high-pitched cough that began after a presumed viral upper respiratory infection. Symptoms are most pronounced during soccer, with noisy inspiratory breathing and intermittent throat tightness; parents note hoarseness and frequent throat clearing. He also reports sporadic wheeze and chest tightness with activity but denies fever, purulent sputum, or weight loss. Symptoms wake him once or twice weekly and have reduced his exercise tolerance; rest and an over-the-counter cough suppressant provided no benefit. There is no prior history of asthma or allergic rhinitis. Recent school pulse oximetry was normal. Concern centers on a laryngeal process with possible reactive airways component such as exercise-induced laryngeal obstruction.

A 94-year-old man presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that began after a brief upper respiratory illness. He describes increasing orthopnea and two episodes of nocturnal breathlessness waking him from sleep, and reports reduced appetite with a three-kilogram weight loss. On exertion he notes lightheadedness and more frequent palpitations; family observed an irregular pulse. He has intermittent low-grade fevers and persistent bibasilar crackles at rest, with new bilateral pitting edema. Caregivers recall a remote smoking history and longstanding mild dysphagia with occasional choking. The constellation raises concern for chronic interstitial lung disease with superimposed aspiration and decompensated congestive heart failure, possibly precipitated by atrial fibrillation. He denies chest pain or hemoptysis.

A 94-year-old man reports three weeks of progressively worse exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough, worsened after a presumed upper respiratory infection about ten days ago. He has a long-standing diagnosis of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and hypertension. Over the past week he notes increased breathlessness at rest with intermittent low-grade fevers, reduced appetite, and a two-kilogram weight loss. At home he is now requiring supplemental oxygen for desaturation with minimal exertion. On exam he has new bibasilar inspiratory crackles without focal consolidation by history and no leg swelling. He denies chest pain or syncope. Clinical concern is for acute exacerbation of his fibrotic lung disease versus a superimposed infection contributing to hypoxemia.

A 0-year-old male infant is brought for progressive respiratory distress over three days, beginning with clear rhinorrhea and low-grade fever and evolving to frequent cough and audible wheeze. Parents describe increasing work of breathing with nasal flaring, intercostal retractions and persistent tachypnea; oral feeds have decreased markedly and urine output is reduced. Caregivers noted two brief oxygen desaturations while asleep. There was a recent household upper respiratory illness preceding symptoms. Birth history significant for late prematurity. On exam in clinic he had diffuse wheeze and coarse breath sounds. Working impression is viral bronchiolitis with hypoxemia and dehydration risk; differential includes early bacterial superinfection or evolving lobar pneumonia.

A 33-year-old female presents with a six-day history of progressively blurred vision in the left eye, now described as a central gray patch with reduced acuity and color desaturation. She notes sharp retro-orbital pain that worsens with eye movement and intermittent photophobia; floaters have been present since onset. Symptoms began two weeks after a self-limited upper respiratory infection and are accompanied by low-grade headaches but no fever or discharge. She denies trauma, diplopia at rest, or prior ocular disease. On review she reports increased fatigue and one transient episode of numbness in the left hand last month. Exam by primary clinician suggested a relative afferent pupillary defect in the left eye; referral for neuro-ophthalmology and urgent imaging was arranged.

A 13-year-old boy presents with two weeks of progressively worse morning headache and intermittent throbbing occipital pain. Headaches are worse on waking and with bending forward, and over the last five days he has had two episodes of vomiting and several brief visual obscurations described as transient gray-outs. He also reports intermittent horizontal diplopia and a new whooshing sound in his right ear when lying flat. Mother notes recent weight gain this year. He had a mild nasal congestion episode consistent with sinusitis three weeks ago and bumped his head on a gym mat about ten days ago without loss of consciousness. On examination he endorses neck stiffness and is concerned about blurring; concern raised for raised intracranial pressure such as idiopathic intracranial hypertension or postinfectious process.

A 34-year-old man presents with five days of progressive pleuritic right-sided chest pain and exertional dyspnea. Pain is sharp, worse with deep inspiration and coughing, and began after a 10-hour flight two weeks ago; he notes a prior week of nasal congestion and sore throat that resolved. Over the past 48 hours he developed a dry cough with one small episode of blood-tinged sputum and intermittent palpitations with lightheadedness. He also reports progressive swelling and tenderness of the right calf since returning from travel. He has a history of intermittent exercise-induced asthma but uses no daily inhaler. He denies recent trauma, known bleeding disorder, or anticoagulant use. Symptoms are limiting work and prompt evaluation for suspected deep vein thrombosis with secondary pulmonary embolism.

A 6-year-old male with history of atopic dermatitis presents with four days of progressive cough and audible wheeze. Symptoms began with nasal congestion and low-grade fever after a classmate developed bronchiolitis; parents report a household contact with similar illness. Over three days cough worsened and he developed increased work of breathing with intermittent intercostal and subcostal retractions, nocturnal cough disturbing sleep, and decreased oral intake. There is occasional nonbilious emesis after coughing but no hemoptysis. On exam at urgent care he was noted to be tachypneic with inspiratory and expiratory wheeze. Parents deny known asthma diagnosis. Concern is for viral bronchiolitis or viral-induced reactive airways disease with early dehydration; bacterial pneumonia is considered less likely.

A 20-year-old male reports sudden onset of right-sided pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath that began while playing basketball two days ago. Pain is sharp, worse with deep inspiration and coughing, and accompanied by a persistent dry cough and mild lightheadedness on exertion. He describes a tall, thin body habitus and occasional vaping with prior childhood intermittent asthma, but no recent travel or immobilization. He recalls several days of viral upper respiratory symptoms last week. On self-exam he notes decreased breath sounds on the right and a sense of chest tightness. No fever, hemoptysis, or leg swelling. Symptoms are progressive, limiting activity; he sought evaluation because the dyspnea is now present at rest.

A 27-year-old male construction worker presents with sudden left-sided pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea that began two hours ago while lifting a heavy beam. Pain is sharp, worse with inspiration, and associated with an acute nonproductive cough and lightheadedness. He describes progressive shortness of breath and subjective palpitations but denies fever. He is tall and thin, reports a five-year history of intermittent marijuana and tobacco smoking, and recalls a bronchitis-like upper respiratory illness two weeks ago. Onset followed a forceful Valsalva maneuver while lifting. He notes mild neck swelling and crepitus under the left clavicle. No prior lung disease, no recent travel, and no known coagulation disorders. Family history is notable for an uncle with early spontaneous pneumothorax.

A 63-year-old woman presents with progressive exertional dyspnea for three months, acutely worse over the past two weeks after a presumed bronchitic illness. She has a chronic productive cough with occasional small-volume hemoptysis and reports decreased exercise tolerance, early oxygen desaturation with minimal exertion, and 5–6 lb unintentional weight loss. Exam shows increased basal inspiratory crackles at both lung bases and mild dependent lower extremity edema. Past pulmonary history includes COPD and a remote pulmonary embolism treated years ago; she has a remote heavy smoking history. She has intermittent low-grade fevers and limited response to prior inhaled bronchodilator therapy. Concern is for progression of underlying fibrotic or bronchiectatic lung disease versus recurrent infection or thromboembolic complication.

A 65-year-old woman reports progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough over the past nine months, with a more pronounced decline in the last two weeks after a presumed viral upper respiratory infection. She now becomes breathless on minimal exertion, notes new exertional oxygen desaturation with lightheadedness, and has lost six pounds unintentionally. She describes intermittent pleuritic chest discomfort but denies frank hemoptysis. Examination at home revealed new bibasilar inspiratory crackles and subtle digital clubbing. Past history includes a remote provoked deep vein thrombosis and a remote, light smoking history. She reports increasing fatigue and difficulty climbing a single flight of stairs, prompting evaluation for interstitial lung disease versus superimposed infection or thromboembolic complication.

A 52-year-old woman reports ten days of progressive exertional dyspnea with a sudden onset of sharp, right-sided pleuritic chest pain two days ago. She has a persistent nonproductive cough and intermittent palpitations; she felt tachycardic at rest last night and notes low-grade fevers. Symptoms began after a 12-hour flight two weeks ago. She also describes new swelling and aching of the left calf for five days. Past medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension and adult-onset asthma, and she is a former smoker. She denies hemoptysis but feels more breathless than with prior bronchospasm. Given the temporal pattern, unilateral leg swelling, and acute pleuritic pain with tachycardia, she is concerned about possible deep venous thrombosis with pulmonary embolism.

A 77-year-old woman presents with three months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough, worsened over the past two weeks after a presumed viral upper respiratory infection. She denies fever or productive sputum but reports decreased exercise tolerance and mild activity-related lightheadedness. She is a former 30-pack-year smoker with a history of well-controlled hypertension. Examiner noted bibasilar inspiratory crackles and mild digital clubbing; resting oxygen saturation was 91% on room air with desaturation on minimal exertion. Outpatient chest radiograph reportedly showed basilar interstitial markings. Referring clinician is concerned for interstitial lung disease, most consistent with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, and has arranged expedited pulmonary function testing and high-resolution chest CT.

A 1-year-old male presents with two days of progressively worse, intermittent severe abdominal pain characterized by sudden screaming episodes during which he draws his knees up, followed by periods of apparent comfort. Parents report four episodes of nonbilious vomiting and one passage of red, mucus‑streaked stool this morning. Oral intake has declined markedly and wet diapers are fewer over 24 hours; caregivers describe increased lethargy and a low‑grade fever after a recent upper respiratory infection last week. On examination at home they felt a firm, sausage‑shaped mass in the right mid‑abdomen. No prior surgeries. The pattern of colicky pain, vomiting, bloody stool, and a palpable abdominal mass raises concern for intussusception with dehydration and systemic effects.

A 22-year-old female reports a two-month history of progressive epigastric burning pain and early postprandial fullness, worse after larger meals and frequently awakening her at night. Pain is partially relieved by over-the-counter antacids but now accompanied by nausea and intermittent non-bilious vomiting. Over the past three weeks she notes an 8-pound unintentional weight loss and two episodes of dark, tarry stools. She began regular NSAID use for dysmenorrhea about three months ago. She also complains of new fatigue with exertion. No prior peptic ulcer disease or liver disease. Social history is negative for tobacco or heavy alcohol. She is concerned about a possible ulcer with occult gastrointestinal bleeding, and requests evaluation for iron deficiency and upper GI pathology.

A 40-year-old woman presents with three days of progressive shortness of breath and sharp, right-sided pleuritic chest pain that worsens with inspiration and minimal exertion. She describes one small episode of hemoptysis and palpitations; she felt unusually tachycardic yesterday. Over the past week she noticed new right calf swelling and tenderness after a long transcontinental flight two weeks ago. She has a history of childhood asthma that is usually well controlled and carries combined hormonal contraception. She is overweight and denies fever or recent immobilization aside from the flight. Symptoms began abruptly and have interfered with climbing stairs; she is anxious about a pulmonary embolic event given the calf findings and sudden dyspnea.

A 41-year-old man presents with three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and pleuritic right-sided chest pain that began after a long transcontinental flight. He reports episodic scant hemoptysis and a dry cough, worse with exertion, and notes new right calf swelling and mild palpitations intermittently. He describes decreased exercise tolerance, brief wheeze relieved with his occasional albuterol inhaler, and a remote 10 pack-year smoking history, quit five years ago. He denies fevers or night sweats and has no recent upper respiratory symptoms. Past history is notable only for childhood asthma. Symptoms have steadily worsened rather than fluctuating, and he is concerned about a blood clot given the leg swelling and shortness of breath.

A 23-year-old female reports six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and intermittent wheeze following a brief upper respiratory illness. She describes a dry cough that worsens at night and with exercise, and intermittent chest tightness with uphill walking; symptoms are triggered by cold air and spicy meals. She uses an albuterol inhaler PRN with partial relief. She has seasonal allergic rhinitis and frequent heartburn consistent with reflux. She denies fevers, weight loss, tobacco use, or hemoptysis. She recalls a spontaneous pneumothorax several months ago that required observation but no surgery. Symptoms have limited her running tolerance and led to missed workouts and one clinic visit for recurrent bronchitic episodes in childhood. She is concerned about exercise-induced bronchospasm versus vocal cord dysfunction.

A 77-year-old female reports ten days of progressive exertional dyspnea with intermittent pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort. She notes new orthopnea and a nocturnal cough producing scant sputum, and has felt two brief episodes of palpitations. Family noticed increased swelling of her ankles and mild asymmetry of the right calf. Symptoms began after a mild upper respiratory illness three weeks ago and have steadily limited her ambulation. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and atrial fibrillation, and she had a remote proximal deep vein thrombosis six months prior. No fevers or syncope. Examination and testing are pending, but she is concerned about possible pulmonary embolism versus cardiac decompensation as explanations for the subacute dyspnea.

A 17-year-old female reports a six-week history of progressive palpitations and episodic diaphoresis with an unintentional 12-pound weight loss. She endorses persistent heat intolerance, a coarse resting hand tremor, and increasing nervousness that interferes with concentration at school. Menstrual cycles which were previously regular have become oligomenorrheic over the past two months. She notes a painless anterior neck fullness that seems to swell intermittently and occasional binocular diplopia with a sensation of eye prominence. She denies fever, sore throat, or recent infections. Review of systems otherwise notable for mild insomnia and decreased exercise tolerance. Findings are most consistent with a thyrotoxic process causing cardiac and ocular manifestations, and she seeks evaluation for autoimmune thyrotoxicosis with ophthalmopathy.

A 48-year-old man presents with four days of progressive exertional dyspnea and a new sharp, right-sided pleuritic chest pain. Symptoms began gradually after a ten-hour car trip and have worsened; he noted scant hemoptysis yesterday and intermittent palpitations with lightheadedness. He also reports new right calf swelling and tenderness that started two days ago. At home he felt mildly short of breath at rest and required extra pillows overnight. Past medical history is notable only for well-controlled hypertension and a 20 pack-year smoking history; he is not on chronic medications. No recent surgery. He is concerned about a clot given the travel and leg swelling; he denies fever, productive cough, or leg trauma.

A 73-year-old female reports three months of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that began after a brief viral upper respiratory illness. Initially short of breath only on stairs, she now desaturates with minimal exertion and has marked decline in exercise tolerance, reporting daytime fatigue. She denies fevers, sputum production, or hemoptysis. Primary care exam documented bibasilar fine inspiratory crackles and mild digital clubbing on inspection. No history of recent travel or known occupational exposures. Given the subacute course with crackles, clubbing, and exertional hypoxemia, she is most concerning for interstitial lung disease, likely pulmonary fibrosis, with possible secondary pulmonary hypertension contributing to her decreased functional capacity.

A 66-year-old man presents with three months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a chronic productive cough that has worsened over the past three weeks. Cough produces scant blood-tinged sputum intermittently; he reports four-pillow orthopnea is absent but notes new exertional desaturation climbing a single flight of stairs. He has low-grade night sweats, a 15-lb unintended weight loss, and increasing fatigue. Examined at clinic he had bibasilar inspiratory crackles and early digital clubbing. He describes intermittent palpitations but no syncope. Past history is notable only for long-standing hypertension and a 40-pack-year smoking history with decades of construction work and possible asbestos exposure. He denies fevers or recent infections; symptoms are concerning for an interstitial or neoplastic pulmonary process.

An 86-year-old female reports three weeks of progressive central vision distortion in the right eye, describing wavy lines and intermittent central blind spots that make reading and recognizing faces difficult. Vision fluctuates during the day and she notes micropsia and increased difficulty with close work; there is no pain, redness, or flashes aside from occasional floaters. She has a prior diagnosis of macular drusen and bilateral pseudophakia from remote cataract surgery, and she worries this represents new bleeding or neovascular change. She has well-controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. No headache, jaw claudication, or systemic malaise. She experienced one near-fall at home when the central field suddenly blanked, prompting concern for rapid decline in the right macula.

A 19-year-old female college athlete reports sudden right-sided pleuritic chest pain and progressive shortness of breath that began during practice earlier today. Pain is sharp, worse with inspiration, and associated with a dry cough and lightheadedness; she denies fever or hemoptysis. She had a five-day viral upper respiratory illness with nasal congestion and sore throat last week. On exam she notes palpitations and subjective tachycardia; she has a history of mild intermittent asthma without recent inhaler use. Symptoms progressed over hours and she felt an abrupt improvement in cough but worsening dyspnea. She reports no trauma, tobacco use, or recent travel. Concern is for primary spontaneous pneumothorax versus asthma exacerbation; she is anxious and prefers evaluation for cause.

A 62-year-old man presents with a six-month history of progressive exertional dyspnea and a daily productive cough that has acutely worsened over the past two weeks. He reports new scant hemoptysis and intermittent pleuritic right-sided chest pain, along with a five-kilogram unintentional weight loss and decreased exercise tolerance. He is a 40 pack-year former smoker with recurrent bronchitis in prior winters. On exam he appears mildly tachypneic with resting desaturation on exertion and focal coarse breath sounds with mild digital clubbing. He denies fevers or night sweats. Concern is for an underlying structural process—eg, COPD with possible right upper lobe neoplasm or postinfectious consolidation—so cross-sectional chest imaging and sputum studies have been requested for further evaluation.

A 43-year-old woman reports eight weeks of progressive postprandial epigastric pain that intermittently radiates to the mid back and wakes her at night. Pain is dull with sharp flares after fatty meals and is accompanied by nausea and one to two greasy, foul-smelling stools daily. She notes an unintentional 9-pound weight loss and episodic dark urine with pale stools and generalized itching over the last month. She recalls a hospital visit for biliary colic two years ago but never had definitive treatment. She drinks alcohol socially and denies fevers or overt vomiting. Over-the-counter antacids provide minimal relief. She is concerned about persistent jaundice and malabsorption; differential considerations include choledocholithiasis with biliary obstruction, chronic pancreatitis, or a ductal stricture.

A 99-year-old man presents with progressive gait instability and recurrent falls, worsening over the past six weeks after a gradual decline for several months. He reports shuffling and difficulty initiating steps, with two ground-level falls in the last two weeks and no loss of consciousness. Family describes increasing short-term memory problems and slowed processing over the same interval. He has developed urinary urgency with occasional incontinence that is new. Prior records note a broad-based, “magnetic” gait on physical therapy assessment and a remote ischemic stroke several years ago; he also has chronic hypertension under outpatient management. No fevers, focal sensory changes, or new focal weakness are reported. The constellation raises concern for normal-pressure hydrocephalus versus progression of cerebrovascular leukoencephalopathy.

A 10-year-old boy presents with a six-week history of persistent cough and progressive exertional dyspnea that began after a febrile viral upper respiratory infection. Parents describe audible wheeze and intermittent chest tightness with activity, plus two to three episodes per week of nocturnal coughing that wakes him. He now tires quickly and cannot finish soccer practice due to breathlessness and exercise intolerance. There has been occasional sputum production but no ongoing fever. On a few occasions parents noted a brief inspiratory high-pitched noise at the throat. He has a history of atopic dermatitis and prior seasonal sneezing. A trial of an inhaled bronchodilator given at home produced modest, short-lived improvement. Primary concerns are postinfectious reactive airways disease or exercise-induced laryngeal obstruction.

A 53-year-old woman reports progressive exertional dyspnea for the past eight weeks, beginning after a protracted “bronchitis”-like illness and now limiting her daily walking. She has a persistent productive cough with intermittent streaks of blood, pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort, and increasing fatigue. She notes night sweats and an unintended five-kilogram weight loss over two months. Past medical history is notable only for well-controlled hypertension; she is a 30-pack-year former smoker. On review she describes decreased exercise tolerance and occasional wheeze; at home she feels more breathless lying flat. She denies fever currently but notes persistent coarse inspiratory crackles and subtle clubbing of the fingertips. She is concerned about an underlying chronic infection or malignancy and seeks evaluation.

A 0-year-old male presents for progressive noisy breathing and poor feeding over the past three weeks. Parents report inspiratory stridor noted since birth that has become louder and more work-dependent, worse when supine or during feeds, and accompanied by choking with occasional brief apneic pauses and perioral cyanosis. He has had poor weight gain and frequent regurgitation. At home he develops tachypnea and subcostal retractions with crying; caregivers palpate frequent wet-sounding breaths. No fever or significant cough. Clinically the picture suggests upper airway obstruction—laryngomalacia versus vocal cord dysfunction—with concern that concomitant gastroesophageal reflux and intermittent aspiration are contributing to feeding intolerance and failure to thrive. No known congenital cardiac diagnosis, though cardiopulmonary evaluation is requested.

A 42-year-old male reports six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a daily productive cough that began after a severe upper respiratory infection two months ago. Sputum is copious, purulent, occasionally blood‑streaked and foul‑smelling, with nocturnal cough that disrupts sleep. He describes intermittent wheeze and basal crackling that worsens with exertion, and low‑grade fevers and mild unintentional weight loss over the same interval. Past history notable for childhood asthma and lifelong recurrent sinusitis; he is a former 10–pack‑year smoker who quit five years ago. He denies recent travel or occupational exposures. He is concerned about bronchiectasis or postinfectious bronchiolitis given the volume of sputum and recurrent sinonasal symptoms and seeks evaluation for imaging and airway clearance.

A 76-year-old woman presents with three months of progressive gait difficulty characterized by a slow, magnetic, broad-based gait and several near-falls. Her daughter notes increasing short-term memory impairment, apathy, and difficulty initiating steps over the same interval. Family also reports new urinary urgency with occasional incontinence and nocturia. Symptoms began insidiously and were not associated with focal weakness, syncope, or new headache, though she endorses intermittent frontal pressure. Treated for a urinary tract infection two weeks ago with transient fever but persistent cognitive slowing and imbalance. Past mobility was limited by knee osteoarthritis, but current decline is out of proportion to joint pain. Examination and history raise concern for normal pressure hydrocephalus versus neurodegenerative parkinsonian syndrome; neurology evaluation and brain imaging are planned.

A 79-year-old woman reports sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye over the past 24 hours, describing a dense central scotoma and intermittent floaters. This event was preceded by two weeks of progressive right-sided temporal headache, scalp tenderness when combing her hair, and jaw claudication with chewing. She also notes new morning stiffness and aching in both shoulders and hips for several weeks, accompanied by low-grade fevers and fatigue. She denies eye trauma, discharge, or neurologic weakness, and has no recent infections. Past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Symptoms are most consistent with a vasculitic process affecting the optic circulation, and she is concerned about permanent visual loss.

A 76-year-old man reports six months of progressive gait instability with increasing frequency of falls and difficulty initiating steps, described by family as a "shuffling, magnetic" pattern. Over the same interval he has developed cognitive slowing, short-term memory lapses, and occasional word-finding difficulty, with new urinary urgency and two episodes of daytime incontinence in the past three months. Symptoms acutely worsened after a treated urinary tract infection two months ago. Past history is notable for hypertension and remote lumbar spondylosis. A non-contrast head CT three months earlier reportedly showed ventriculomegaly greater than expected for cortical atrophy. On review he endorses intermittent orthostatic dizziness and mild slowness of movement but denies focal weakness, sensory loss, or resting tremor.

A 5-year-old boy presents with four days of progressive cough and noisy breathing that began after rhinorrhea and mild sore throat. Parents describe frequent daytime coughing spells and nighttime paroxysms with audible expiratory wheeze and increased work of breathing, now with occasional intercostal retractions. He has a low‑grade fever and has taken in less fluids, with reduced activity and poor sleep. On day three he developed right ear pain and tugging, concerning for acute otitis media. He has a prior history of intermittent reactive airway disease related to viral infections but no prior intubations.
