Symptoms have not improved with supportive care at home, and clinic exam showed tachypnea with scattered wheezes, concerning for a viral‑induced asthma exacerbation complicating an upper respiratory infection.

A 46-year-old woman reports sudden onset right-sided pleuritic chest pain and progressive dyspnea beginning two days after an eight-hour flight. Pain is sharp with deep inspiration and is accompanied by lightheadedness and intermittent palpitations; she noted a scant blood-tinged cough this morning. She also describes new swelling and tenderness of the right calf for the past 48 hours. Medical history is notable for obesity and perimenopausal estrogen replacement therapy; she is a former smoker. She denies recent trauma, prior thrombotic events, or active infection. Symptoms have worsened with minimal exertion and she feels more short of breath at rest. She is concerned because family members have had clotting disorders.

A 56-year-old man presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a chronic productive cough that has acutely worsened. He reports occasional blood-tinged sputum and pleuritic right-sided chest pain, worse with deep inspiration. Over the past month he has noticed a 12-pound unintentional weight loss and decreased exercise tolerance; he also describes new swelling and aching in the right calf. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history and a remote diagnosis of COPD with baseline exertional limitation. He is treated for hypertension. There was a recent upper respiratory illness two months ago that preceded the cough. Concern is for pulmonary embolism or an underlying malignancy exacerbating COPD.

A 31-year-old man presents with abrupt onset left-sided pleuritic chest pain and progressive shortness of breath that began 48 hours ago. The pain is sharp, localized to the lateral chest, worse with deep inspiration and coughing, and increases with exertion. He describes intermittent palpitations and one episode of lightheadedness without syncope. He noted scant streaks of blood in sputum once yesterday. Five days before symptom onset he experienced aching and mild swelling of the right calf after a 10-hour bus trip. He is a current smoker with occasional wheeze during exertion and reports a low-grade fever and decreased exercise tolerance since symptoms started. No recent upper respiratory infection or known bleeding disorder. He is concerned the calf pain and new respiratory symptoms may be related.

A 59-year-old man presents with three months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough, noticeably worse over the past two weeks after a mild "chest cold." He reports intermittent pleuritic left-sided chest discomfort, low-grade fevers, and a 10-pound unintentional weight loss. Activity tolerance has fallen from walking two blocks to stopping after a single flight of stairs. He is a former 20-pack-year smoker and worked in shipyard construction with prolonged asbestos exposure three decades ago. On review he notes early morning shallow breathing but no swollen legs. Examination revealed finger clubbing and bibasilar inspiratory crackles. Past medical history notable only for hypertension. He denies hemoptysis, wheeze, or significant reflux.

A 91-year-old woman reports progressive exertional dyspnea over the past six months, with notable worsening over the last two weeks accompanied by new orthopnea and increased lower-extremity swelling. She describes a persistent dry, nonproductive cough and a small unintentional weight loss over several months. Home oxygen saturations fall with minimal exertion. She has no fever, sputum, or chest pain. Prior records document bibasilar inspiratory crackles and mild digital clubbing on exam. She recalls a remote tobacco history and longstanding hypertension. Family noted decreasing activity tolerance and occasional nocturnal breathlessness. The temporal pattern suggests chronic interstitial lung disease with chronic hypoxemia and possible secondary pulmonary hypertension contributing to peripheral edema and worsening dyspnea.

A 57-year-old female presents with six weeks of progressive central vision loss in the right eye, initially noticed as intermittent metamorphopsia and a small dark central scotoma when reading. Over two weeks the distortion worsened and she now reports difficulty focusing on print, intermittent photopsias and a sense that straight lines appear wavy. She has a remote diagnosis of dry age-related macular degeneration with known macular drusen, and describes this change as qualitatively different and more abrupt, raising concern for neovascular conversion. She denies ocular pain, diplopia, or systemic neurologic symptoms. She wears bifocals and has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, both treated. No recent head trauma or flashes in the left eye.

A 60-year-old woman presents with two weeks of progressive shortness of breath initially with exertion now occurring at rest, preceded by a brief upper respiratory infection. She describes orthopnea requiring two pillows and nightly awakening with breathlessness consistent with paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. She reports new bilateral ankle swelling and a three‑kilogram weight gain over ten days, reduced exercise tolerance, and intermittent palpitations with sudden racing episodes. She notes a dull exertional chest tightness but denies syncope. Past history includes long-standing hypertension and remote smoking. On review she mentions increased fatigue and clear sputum production without fever. Symptoms are most suggestive of volume overload from cardiac decompensation, possibly precipitated by arrhythmia. Further evaluation for heart failure and rhythm disturbance is requested.

A 79-year-old female presents with acute, painless loss of vision in the right eye that began this morning after two weeks of new temporal headaches and scalp tenderness. She describes jaw claudication with chewing and progressive proximal shoulder and hip stiffness in the mornings consistent with polymyalgia rheumatica. She reports low-grade fevers, night sweats, and unintentional three-pound weight loss over the past month. On exam she notes a dense right central visual field defect and a new relative afferent pupillary defect; the right optic disc appears pale and swollen per outpatient ophthalmoscopy. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia but no prior cerebrovascular events. Symptoms are most consistent with giant cell arteritis causing arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy.

A 25-year-old man reports five days of progressive blurred vision in the left eye with aching retro-orbital pain that worsens on eye movement. He describes colors as "washed out" and noticed intermittent photopsias and a small central scotoma this morning. Symptoms began about two weeks after a brief viral upper respiratory illness; he denies trauma or discharge. He also experienced a transient tingling sensation in the right hand two days ago that resolved spontaneously. Past ocular history notable only for high myopia. He denies fever, neck stiffness, or recent travel. No chronic medical problems, no regular medications, and no illicit drug use. He is concerned the vision loss is getting steadily worse and wants urgent evaluation.

A 75-year-old man reports six months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent nonproductive cough, now limiting his ability to walk across the house. Symptoms began insidiously and have steadily worsened; he has lost about eight pounds and notes increased breathlessness after a recent upper respiratory illness three weeks ago with low-grade fever. Family reports new finger clubbing and he endorses frequent nocturnal cough but denies hemoptysis or chest pain. He is a former 40–pack-year smoker who quit two decades ago and has known hypertension. On prior clinic visit he was noted to have bibasilar crackles and exertional desaturation. He is being evaluated for possible interstitial lung disease/pulmonary fibrosis versus chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis given the subacute course.

A 21-year-old woman presents with two days of sudden right-sided pleuritic chest pain and progressive shortness of breath, sharp with inspiration and worse on exertion. She notes scant blood-tinged sputum and mild pleuritic cough after a week-long upper respiratory illness. Three days ago she developed aching and swelling of the left calf following a long bus trip. She started combined oral contraceptives two months ago and smokes intermittently. She has a history of mild intermittent asthma but uses no inhaler regularly. On review she reports palpitations and lightheadedness but no fever or syncope. Symptoms suggest possible pulmonary embolism secondary to deep venous thrombosis, with asthma and recent viral bronchitis as potential confounders.

A 92-year-old woman presents with seven days of progressively worsening dyspnea and a productive cough that began after a choking episode while eating ten days ago. Cough is mucoid with intermittent low-grade fevers, and she now complains of pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort with increased work of breathing. Family reports new intermittent confusion and reduced oral intake over the past 48 hours. She has a baseline history of COPD and chronic atrial fibrillation but states these symptoms are markedly worse than usual. At home she was noted to be more short of breath with minimal exertion and mildly hypoxemic. Clinical concern is for aspiration-related pneumonia precipitating a COPD exacerbation with superimposed hypoxemia.

A 0-year-old female infant presents with three days of progressive cough and increased work of breathing after two days of clear rhinorrhea. Parents report intermittent fevers to 38.5°C and markedly decreased oral intake with poor latch. An older sibling had a recent upper respiratory illness. At home caregivers noted audible wheeze, shallow rapid respirations consistent with tachypnea, and visible subcostal retractions with feeding. A portable oximeter intermittently recorded saturations in the low 90s. There has been less urine output, raising concern for dehydration. No vomiting or rash. Born at term without known cardiac abnormalities. The presentation is most consistent with viral bronchiolitis complicated by mild hypoxemia, significant feeding intolerance, and evolving respiratory distress.

A 62-year-old woman reports two months of progressive exertional dyspnea and marked reduction in exercise tolerance, now awakening twice weekly with paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea and needing two pillows for sleep. She notes new bilateral ankle swelling and a sense of abdominal fullness with early satiety. Over the past three weeks she has had intermittent palpitations with an irregular, rapid sensation and brief episodes of exertional chest tightness that resolve with rest. Symptoms began after a period of increasing fatigue and have gradually limited daily activities. She has a long history of hypertension and no recent fever or cough. There is no focal weakness or leg pain suggestive of DVT.

A 34-year-old woman presents with progressive shortness of breath for 48 hours, sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain, and a single small episode of hemoptysis. Symptoms began after a 10-hour long-haul flight five days ago; she also describes a week of worsening right calf swelling and tenderness. She endorses intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness with minimal exertion but denies fever or purulent cough. She uses combined oral contraceptives and reports two prior first-trimester miscarriages without a diagnosed coagulopathy. She is increasingly limited by dyspnea when climbing stairs. Given the temporal relationship to travel, unilateral calf symptoms, and oxygen desaturation on moderate activity, she is concerned for deep venous thrombosis with possible pulmonary embolism.

A 31-year-old male recreational runner reports two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and intermittent central chest tightness that began after a febrile upper respiratory illness. Symptoms are worse with climbing stairs and are accompanied by episodic palpitations and one brief presyncopal spell while exercising. He also notes new mild bilateral ankle swelling and orthopnea overnight, and a persistent dry cough. Chest discomfort is pressure-like, non-radiating, and improves somewhat with rest. He denies prior cardiac disease, tobacco use, or recent travel. Family history is noncontributory. Examination at home revealed a noticeably reduced exercise tolerance. He is concerned about a possible cardiac complication after the recent viral illness, given the combination of dyspnea, palpitations, edema, and near-syncope.

A 13-year-old boy presents with six days of progressive gait instability and slurred speech. Symptoms began three days after a febrile upper respiratory illness; parents first noticed unsteady truncal ataxia and frequent falls, then new horizontal nystagmus. He now has intermittent occipital headache and two morning episodes of nonbloody vomiting. At urgent care he demonstrated left-sided limb dysmetria and dysdiadochokinesia; there is no focal sensory loss. He has had low-grade fevers but no neck stiffness, rash, or recent head trauma. He has never had seizures and is not on any chronic medications. Parents report worsening coordination with handwriting and difficulty negotiating stairs, prompting urgent neurologic evaluation.

An 85-year-old man presents with sudden left-sided weakness and slurred speech beginning approximately 14 hours ago. Symptoms were maximal at onset and he now has dense left hemiparesis with right-sided facial droop and difficulty swallowing; family notes intermittent confusion since the event. Earlier the same morning he experienced a transient monocular visual loss in the right eye that resolved in minutes. Past history is notable for paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and long-standing hypertension, with a prior brief TIA last year. On initial exam there was a right carotid bruit. No recent fever, trauma, or anticoagulant changes. The temporal pattern and embolic risk factors suggest an acute ischemic cerebrovascular event.

An 11-year-old girl presents with three episodes over the past two weeks of severe left-sided throbbing headache with transient right-sided weakness. Each event began with a shimmering visual aura and blurred vision, progressed to photophobia and nausea with occasional vomiting, and included transient expressive aphasia and mild gait instability; deficits resolved over 30–90 minutes. Mother reports the first episode occurred five days after a febrile upper respiratory illness. There is no history of seizures, head trauma, or chronic illness, and she has had normal developmental milestones and school performance. No recent medication changes or toxin exposures. Parents are concerned about recurrent focal neurologic symptoms and progressive headache intensity, prompting emergency evaluation.

A 1-year-old male is brought for four days of progressive cough and noisy breathing after a sibling’s runny nose at daycare. Parents report rhinorrhea and intermittent low-grade fever for three days, then worsening tachypnea and audible wheeze with feeding yesterday. He is fussier, taking smaller feeds and producing fewer wet diapers. On exertion and with coughing he has brief perioral pallor and increased work of breathing with intercostal retractions. At home he had one vomiting episode after coughing. On brief otoscopic check the right tympanic membrane appeared erythematous. No prior chronic lung disease; born at term with mild eczema. Concern is for viral bronchiolitis versus early viral pneumonia or reactive airways exacerbation with hypoxemia requiring observation.

An 86-year-old man presents with six months of progressive gait instability characterized by short, shuffling steps and difficulty initiating ambulation, with three falls in the past month. Family reports insidious short-term memory decline and increased apathy over four months; he has developed urinary urgency and occasional urge incontinence over the past two months. Neurologic exam has been notable for a magnetic, broad-based gait and slowed heel-to-toe progression. A recent noncontrast head CT performed in clinic demonstrated ventriculomegaly without acute infarct. Past medical history notable for longstanding hypertension and known benign prostatic hyperplasia, neither of which fully explains the constellation. Symptoms have resulted in reduced independence and need for home assistance.

An 89-year-old male presents with ten days of progressive exertional dyspnea and a dry cough that began after a brief upper respiratory illness. He reports worsening breathlessness at rest over the past 48 hours with intermittent lightheadedness; wife notes oxygen saturation in the mid-80s on room air, now improved with home oxygen. Examination at bedside shows bilateral fine bibasilar inspiratory crackles and chronic digital clubbing. His records note a prior diagnosis of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis with a background of COPD and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and he describes reduced exercise tolerance and a three-kilogram weight loss over two months. He denies chest pain, hemoptysis, or fever, but feels markedly more fatigued and limited walking across the room.

An 8-year-old girl presents with a two-week history of progressively worse headaches and intermittent visual disturbance. Headaches are diffuse and pressure-like, most severe on awakening and with bending forward, and are accompanied by nausea and photophobia. Parents describe brief transient graying or blurring of vision when she stands and occasional morning vomiting. She also reports a new rhythmic whooshing in both ears. Symptoms began after a recent uncomplicated sinus infection. At a school visit she squinted while reading; outpatient ophthalmology documented bilateral optic disc swelling. She has no fever, neck stiffness, focal weakness, or prior neurologic history. Family denies head trauma. Parents are particularly worried about the evolving visual symptoms and persistent morning headaches.

A 36-year-old man reports six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and intermittent palpitations, now limiting his ability to climb one flight of stairs. He describes orthopnea requiring two pillows and two episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea with nocturnal, nonproductive cough. He has noticed new bilateral ankle swelling and early fatigue; on several occasions he felt lightheaded and nearly syncope during exertion. He denies persistent chest pain at rest but endorses brief pleuritic chest discomfort after heavy activity. He recalls a viral upper respiratory illness a few months earlier followed by prolonged malaise. He has no history of diabetes or chronic lung disease, drinks alcohol socially on weekends, and is not taking regular medications. Symptoms are most consistent with evolving cardiomyopathy and decompensated heart failure.

A 32-year-old woman reports five days of progressive exertional dyspnea and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began shortly after a seven-hour flight. Pain is worse with deep inspiration and coughing; she has noted scant hemoptysis and intermittent lightheadedness on exertion. She also reports palpitations and subjective tachycardia without fever. Over the past two days she developed new swelling and tenderness of the right calf. Past history is notable for childhood-onset intermittent asthma, usually controlled with occasional albuterol inhaler, and she uses combined oral contraceptives. She denies recent infection, surgery, or pregnancy and does not smoke. Symptoms minimally improved with rest; the temporal cluster of recent immobilization, unilateral calf swelling, pleuritic pain, dyspnea, and hemoptysis raises concern for thromboembolic disease.

A 70-year-old woman presents with five days of progressive dyspnea and productive cough after a week-long upper respiratory illness; she reports purulent sputum, right-sided pleuritic chest pain that worsens with deep inspiration, and low-grade fevers. Symptoms began gradually but acutely worsened with exertion over the last two days, now causing significant activity limitation. She notes new swelling and aching of the left calf and intermittent lightheadedness. Past medical history includes COPD and hypertension; she is a former 40-pack-year smoker. She denies orthopnea, palpitations, or recent travel. On review, she describes increased fatigue and poor appetite. The temporal pattern raises concern for a COPD exacerbation versus pneumonia with possible thromboembolic complication.

A 39-year-old man presents with six weeks of progressive postprandial epigastric pain and early satiety. The pain is crampy, worse after fatty meals, and frequently followed by greasy, foul-smelling stools and intermittent nonbilious vomiting when he overeats. He reports an unintentional 10-pound weight loss and increasing fatigue. Primary care recently documented iron-deficiency anemia and referred him for further evaluation. He recalls a gallstone-related pancreatitis admission two years ago but has had no recent heavy alcohol use. He denies hematemesis, overt melena, or jaundice. The constellation of steatorrhea, weight loss, and prior pancreatitis raises concern for pancreatic exocrine insufficiency and evolving chronic pancreatitis with secondary gastric emptying dysfunction and malabsorption.

A 54-year-old man reports two weeks of intermittent palpitations and increased fatigue with exertion, accompanied by a 6–7 lb unintentional weight loss and new heat intolerance. He notes a fine resting tremor and left anterior neck pain that began after a self-limited upper respiratory illness three weeks ago; low-grade fevers were present early in the course. Palpitations are described as irregular and more pronounced at rest, with occasional lightheadedness but no syncope or chest pain. He was found to be in new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response at an outside clinic. The constellation of thyrotoxic symptoms with recent viral prodrome raises concern for the thyrotoxic phase of subacute thyroiditis precipitating atrial fibrillation.

A 22-year-old male presents with five days of progressive blurring and central vision loss in his left eye, associated with sharp retro-orbital pain that worsens with eye movement and marked color desaturation. He also notes photophobia and a mild, pressure-like frontal headache. Two weeks prior he had a self-limited upper respiratory illness with sore throat and nasal congestion. Since the visual symptoms began he has intermittent numbness and tingling in his right hand and foot and new urinary urgency without dysuria. He denies trauma, fever, or purulent discharge. No prior ocular disease; family history notable for autoimmune thyroid disease. He is concerned about possible inflammatory or demyelinating optic neuritis.

A 26-year-old female presents with sudden onset shortness of breath and left-sided pleuritic chest pain that began 36 hours ago and has gradually worsened. She describes sharp pain with inspiration, associated palpitations and lightheadedness, and reports coughing up a teaspoon of blood-tinged sputum once last night. She notes new right calf aching and swelling over the past day after a long transatlantic flight five days ago. She uses combined oral contraceptives and has a remote history of mild intermittent asthma. She denies fevers, smoking, or recent trauma. Symptoms are worse with exertion and when supine, and she felt near-syncope while standing yesterday.

A 98-year-old woman reports a two-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that began after a brief upper respiratory illness. She describes marked decline in baseline stamina, now needing to pause after minimal walking; family notes increased breathlessness at rest and new exertional oxygen desaturation. She has long-standing hypertension and a prior diagnosis of chronic interstitial lung disease with basilar reticulation. On exam she endorses low-grade fevers early in the course and notes mild ankle swelling. She denies chest pain or syncope. Current symptoms are accompanied by bibasilar fine inspiratory crackles and reduced appetite; the change is gradual but steadily worse, prompting consideration of an acute exacerbation of underlying pulmonary fibrosis.

An 8-year-old girl presents with six weeks of crampy periumbilical abdominal pain, described as intermittent and worse with meals and after prolonged stool withholding at school. Parents report progressive constipation for several months with hard, painful stools and a small perianal fissure, and two episodes of nonbilious vomiting after large meals. She has early satiety and a 2.5‑kg weight loss with decreased appetite, and caregivers note increasing pallor and occasional lightheadedness on exertion. No fevers, hematochezia, or urinary symptoms. Past history notable only for atopic dermatitis. Symptoms began gradually after a change in routine and are variably relieved by stool softening at home; concern raised for iron deficiency from poor intake or possible celiac-related malabsorption.

A 38-year-old man presents with progressive exertional dyspnea and new pleuritic right-sided chest pain for five days, describing sharp pain worse with deep inspiration and coughing. Symptoms began two weeks after a transcontinental flight, initially with aching and mild swelling of the right calf that he attributed to travel. Over the past three days he has noted intermittent palpitations, lightheadedness on exertion, and one episode of blood-tinged sputum. He reports low-grade fevers and decreased exercise tolerance but no prior cardiopulmonary disease. He denies recent trauma, night sweats, or illicit drug use. Review of systems otherwise notable only for ankle edema; he has no current medications and works a desk job.

A 90-year-old female reports six months of progressive gait instability and cognitive slowing. Family notes a broad-based, somewhat magnetic gait with two recent falls and growing difficulty initiating steps; she has developed urinary urgency with occasional leakage. Cognitive changes include worsening short-term memory and apathy that interfere with daily tasks. She had an acute decline after a recent urinary tract infection. Past medical history is notable for long-standing hypertension and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Neurologic exam demonstrates slowed processing without focal cranial nerve deficits. Prior brain imaging showed periventricular white matter disease. Differential considerations include normal-pressure hydrocephalus versus vascular cognitive impairment, with recurrent falls and incontinence posing the main safety concerns.

A 49-year-old woman reports six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a productive cough that acutely worsened three days ago with new pleuritic right-sided chest pain and scant hemoptysis. She notes greenish sputum and intermittent low-grade fevers during the subacute course. Two weeks ago she endured prolonged travel and developed mild unilateral calf swelling; she also has a remote postpartum deep venous thrombosis. Past medical history is notable only for well-controlled hypertension. She now becomes short of breath after climbing a single flight of stairs and feels more fatigued with ordinary activities. She denies recent upper respiratory infection, night sweats, or rash, and seeks evaluation because the combination of chest pain, blood‑tinged sputum, and progressive dyspnea is new and concerning.

A 64-year-old man presents with five days of progressive shortness of breath and a new, sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain. He developed a dry cough with scant hemoptysis and low-grade fevers beginning three days ago and notes marked fatigue with minimal exertion; walking upstairs now causes lightheadedness and desaturation. One week prior he experienced new swelling and tenderness of the right calf after a long car trip. Past history includes COPD and hypertension with a remote 40-pack-year smoking history; he denies recent surgery or known malignancy. He has intermittent palpitations but no syncope. Examination findings are consistent with possible pulmonary embolism with small pleural effusion versus COPD exacerbation, prompting urgent imaging.

A 23-year-old female presents with acute dyspnea and pleuritic left-sided chest pain for three days. Symptoms began after a 10-hour flight and have progressed; she notes sudden onset shortness of breath at rest and sharp pain worse with inspiration. She reports a nonproductive cough and scant hemoptysis. She also noticed swelling and aching in her left calf over 48 hours. She has intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness but no fever or sputum production. She takes combined oral contraception and recently recovered from a sinus infection two weeks ago. No prior thrombotic history. Denies smoking or illicit drug use. Family history noncontributory.

A 9-year-old girl presents with a three-month history of persistent cough and increasing shortness of breath with exertion. Symptoms began after a winter viral URI and have progressed over the last two weeks, with nocturnal coughing that wakes her twice weekly and intermittent wheeze heard by parents. Cough is worse with exercise and cold air; she reports throat tightness and noisy inhalation during sports consistent with paroxysms of dyspnea. She has known seasonal allergic rhinitis and a history of recurrent sinusitis, most recently treated with a short antibiotic course, and reports occasional chest tightness relieved partially by her school rescue inhaler. No fevers or weight loss. No prior hospitalizations. Concern is for reactive airways disease with exercise-induced bronchospasm and possible paradoxical vocal fold motion contributing to persistent cough.

A 19-year-old woman reports a six-week history of daily, pulsatile occipital headaches that usually begin within minutes of standing and can last several hours. Episodes are commonly preceded by a transient scintillating visual aura and associated with photophobia, nausea, and a sense of neck tightness. She also describes orthostatic lightheadedness with palpitations and two near-syncope events while standing from seated position. Symptoms began after a viral upper respiratory illness and have progressively worsened with exertion. She notes long-standing joint hypermobility and occasional unexplained fainting as a teenager. She denies focal weakness, fever, or recent head trauma. Symptoms limit attending classes and provoke anxiety about future collapses.

A 77-year-old man with known COPD and hypertension presents with eight days of progressive dyspnea and a worsening productive cough. He reports greenish sputum, intermittent low-grade fevers, and new right-sided pleuritic chest pain that is worse with deep inspiration; he denies frank hemoptysis. Baseline exertional tolerance has declined markedly, and he notes audible wheeze and increased use of his rescue inhaler. Symptoms began after a brief viral upper respiratory illness two weeks ago and have steadily worsened, now causing shortness of breath with minimal activity. Family noticed mild ankle swelling over the past week. Clinical concern is for COPD exacerbation complicated by bacterial pneumonia with possible small parapneumonic effusion; no recent travel or known sick contacts.

A 14-year-old male presents with two weeks of intermittent horizontal diplopia and progressive left ptosis. Symptoms began after a self-limited upper respiratory infection with sore throat and nasal congestion three weeks ago. Diplopia is binocular, worse in the evenings and with sustained reading, and partially improves after rest. He reports fatigable chewing and mild choking on liquids at night but denies fever, headache, or focal numbness. Parents note increased eyelid droop after sports practice. He also describes difficulty sustaining upgaze on prolonged tasks. No antecedent trauma or chronic illness. The pattern of fluctuating ocular and bulbar weakness raises concern for a neuromuscular junction disorder such as juvenile myasthenia gravis.

A 24-year-old woman presents with ten days of progressive neurologic symptoms beginning as painless blurred vision in her right eye that evolved into periorbital pain with eye movement and intermittent diplopia. Three days after the visual change she developed tingling and numbness in the right arm and intermittent electric shocks down the spine with neck flexion consistent with Lhermitte phenomenon. Over the past week she has noticed unsteady gait, decreased coordination on the right, and new urinary urgency without dysuria. Symptoms began shortly after a self-limited upper respiratory illness two weeks ago. She denies head trauma, fevers now, or recent travel. No prior neurologic history; family history notable only for a maternal aunt with an autoimmune thyroid condition. She seeks evaluation for a unifying inflammatory or demyelinating process.

A 99-year-old man presents with four days of progressively worsening dyspnea and a new productive cough after an episode of choking while eating. He has known chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and describes increased sputum production that is yellow-green, associated with low-grade fevers and decreased appetite. He notes new orthopnea and worsening bilateral lower extremity swelling over the past 48 hours. At baseline he ambulated with a cane; now he is resting frequently with shortness of breath and intermittent confusion. Family reports audible wheeze and one brief episode of coughing up a small amount of blood. No chest pain or syncope. The clinical picture is most suggestive of aspiration-related pneumonia superimposed on COPD with hypoxia and possible volume overload.

A 13-year-old male presents with a three-week history of progressive morning headaches, described as pressure-like and worse with coughing or bending. Over the past two days he developed intermittent binocular horizontal diplopia and brief transient visual obscurations on standing. He also reports pulsatile tinnitus in the ears and frequent associated nausea with two episodes of vomiting. Headaches are moderately photophobic but not migrainous in throbbing quality; ibuprofen provided temporary relief. Two weeks ago he had a presumed viral sinus infection with nasal congestion. Mother reports he was seen at a local ED last week where the discharge note documented bilateral optic disc swelling. No fever, neck rigidity, or focal limb weakness noted.

A 43-year-old male presents with four days of progressive shortness of breath and a sharp, right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began acutely after a 10-hour car trip. Dyspnea is worse with exertion and accompanied by scant hemoptysis and mild pleuritic positional chest discomfort. He notes progressive swelling and tenderness of the left calf since the trip. Onset was preceded by a week of nasal congestion but no fever. Past medical history notable for well-controlled hypertension and a 20-pack-year smoking history; BMI 32. He denies recent surgery or anticoagulation. At home he noticed palpitations and lightheadedness. Concern is high for deep venous thrombosis with pulmonary embolism given immobilization, unilateral calf edema, tachycardia, pleuritic pain, and hemoptysis.

A 65-year-old woman presents with six-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent nonproductive cough. She notes breathlessness with walking up one flight of stairs and two recent near-syncope episodes when climbing; she also reports new right ankle and calf swelling and mild intermittent pleuritic chest tightness on exertion. She had an unprovoked left lower-extremity DVT four months ago treated with a three-month course of anticoagulation. On recent exam she described neck fullness and palpitations, and a prominent pulmonic component of the second heart sound was documented. Portable pulse oximeter readings drop into the mid-80s with minimal activity. The presentation raises concern for chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension with exercise-induced hypoxemia and evolving right-heart strain.

A 56-year-old woman presents with a six-month history of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent, initially dry but now intermittently productive cough. Symptoms began insidiously after several upper respiratory infections and have worsened despite inhaler trials, with markedly reduced exercise tolerance and a three-kg unintentional weight loss. She reports intermittent low-grade fevers, nocturnal cough related to reflux, and occasional pleuritic chest discomfort but denies hemoptysis. She has a 20 pack-year smoking history and a remote diagnosis of limited systemic sclerosis, raising concern for connective-tissue–related interstitial lung disease. On review she notes increased breathlessness with stair climbing and new finger clubbing at home; prior outpatient chest radiograph reportedly showed basilar prominence. She prefers outpatient evaluation for pulmonary fibrosis vs chronic aspiration-related lung injury.

A 99-year-old female presents with three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a worsening nonproductive cough. She reports new orthopnea and two episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea after a recent viral upper respiratory illness, and family notes increasing lower-extremity swelling and decreased exercise tolerance. She has a long-standing interstitial lung disease, presumed idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, with a chronic dry cough that acutely worsened. Home pulse irregularity suggests atrial fibrillation and she carries a history of hypertension. On exam she has bibasilar crackles and dependent edema. The temporal pattern and findings are most consistent with decompensated cardiopulmonary disease—exacerbation of underlying fibrosis with superimposed volume overload and atrial arrhythmia—prompting urgent assessment of oxygenation, volume status, and rhythm.

A 90-year-old female reports three months of progressive gait instability and cognitive slowing, with marked worsening over the past three weeks after a recent urinary tract infection. She describes small, shuffling steps with difficulty initiating gait and frequent turning pauses; she has fallen twice at home. Family notes intermittent confusion, short-term memory loss, and decreased conversational output. She also endorses urinary urgency and occasional daytime incontinence. A prior noncontrast head CT reportedly showed ventriculomegaly. She has a long history of hypertension and osteoarthritis but denies focal limb weakness, new headache, fever, or visual change. Symptoms interfere with dressing and transfers, and she now requires more assistance with ambulation.

A 99-year-old female presents with seven days of progressive, painless loss of central vision in the right eye described as a dark central scotoma and distortion of faces and print. Symptoms began after two weeks of new temporal headaches, scalp tenderness when brushing hair, and intermittent jaw claudication with chewing. She reports low-grade fevers and generalized fatigue and notes several months of morning shoulder stiffness consistent with prior polymyalgia rheumatica. Primary care documented a markedly elevated inflammatory marker and noted right temporal artery prominence and tenderness on exam, prompting urgent referral. Past ocular history includes bilateral cataracts; medical history notable for long-standing hypertension. Concern is arteritic ischemic optic neuropathy from presumed giant cell arteritis; she denies trauma, diplopia, or eye pain.

A healthy-appearing 18-year-old male presents with sudden onset right-sided pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea that began while playing basketball yesterday evening. The pain is sharp, worse with deep inspiration, and associated with a dry cough and intermittent wheeze; he denies trauma or fever. Two weeks prior he experienced a self-limited upper respiratory illness. He admits occasional nicotine vaping. He reports lightheadedness and persistent breathlessness at rest. Prehospital assessment noted tachycardia. On exam there are decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance to percussion over the right hemithorax, findings concerning for a primary spontaneous pneumothorax. He has no prior hospitalizations and no family history of lung disease.

A 16-year-old female varsity soccer player presents with progressive exertional shortness of breath and wheeze over the past ten days, worse since a week-long viral upper respiratory illness that followed a weekend tournament. She describes chest tightness with jogging and nocturnal cough awakening her twice weekly, and reports using her rescue inhaler more frequently than usual. Symptoms are reproducible with sprinting and there is mild throat tightness and occasional inspiratory noisy breathing at maximal effort, raising concern for exercise-induced bronchospasm with possible paradoxical vocal cord motion. She has a history of physician-diagnosed asthma and seasonal allergic rhinitis but no prior hospitalizations. Symptoms limit practices and school gym; denies fever, hemoptysis, or syncope.

A 93-year-old man reports ten days of progressive dyspnea and cough that began after a brief choking episode while eating; cough is productive of mucopurulent sputum with intermittent low-grade fevers and decreased appetite. He notes worsening exertional desaturation and now requires extra pillows overnight for breathlessness. Home baseline includes chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and long-standing hypertension. Over the past 48 hours he developed palpitations and lightheadedness; emergency evaluation documented hypoxemia and new atrial fibrillation with an irregularly rapid pulse. On exam at home he has increased work of breathing and coarse bibasilar crackles. Concern is for aspiration pneumonia precipitating a COPD exacerbation with secondary hypoxemia and arrhythmia. He denies chest pain or focal neurologic symptoms.

An 11-year-old female reports two weeks of increasing polyuria and polydipsia with an unintentional 5–6 kg weight loss, now acutely worse over the past 48 hours with persistent nausea, intermittent vomiting, and diffuse abdominal pain. Parents note progressive fatigue and recent lethargy at school; she has had poor oral intake since symptoms intensified. Over the last day she developed rapid, deep breathing and appeared flushed between emesis episodes. There is no known prior metabolic disease; family history is notable for maternal autoimmune thyroid disease. Triage exam was concerning for dehydration and tachypnea. The chronology and cluster of symptoms are most consistent with new-onset autoimmune type 1 diabetes with concern for evolving diabetic ketoacidosis.

A 71-year-old man reports a six-month history of progressive balance disturbance and cognitive slowing, now notable for short, magnetic steps and difficulty initiating gait. He describes increasing apathy, slowed speech, and impaired multitasking, with three near-falls and one fall last month without head injury. Family notes new urinary urgency with occasional urge incontinence. Symptoms acutely worsened after a treated urinary tract infection three weeks ago. Noncontrast CT performed last week showed ventriculomegaly out of proportion to cortical atrophy. Past medical history notable for long-standing hypertension. Neurology was consulted for suspected normal-pressure hydrocephalus versus mixed degenerative disease; he now requires a cane and assistance with several activities of daily living.

A 60-year-old man reports an eight-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea and persistent nonproductive cough, beginning after a bronchitis-like illness. Symptoms have steadily limited his walking tolerance; he now desaturates with minimal exertion and notes low-grade fevers and reduced appetite. He denies chest pain but has noticed increasing bilateral ankle swelling. Past history is notable for treated hypertension and a 40 pack-year smoking history. On exam he has digital clubbing, bibasilar inspiratory crackles, and mild resting hypoxemia with greater desaturation on ambulation; there is 1+ pitting edema of the ankles. Clinically there is concern for a developing interstitial lung process with possible secondary pulmonary vascular involvement.

A 27-year-old female reports five days of progressive blurred central vision in the right eye accompanied by aching with eye movement and increased photophobia. She describes colors appearing washed, a small central gray spot, and intermittent holocephalic headache that is distinct from her baseline migraines. Two weeks ago she had a self-limited viral upper respiratory illness. She also noticed a brief episode of left-leg numbness and tingling yesterday that resolved after an hour. No trauma, purulent discharge, or fever. Past medical history notable for occasional migraine without aura; family history positive for autoimmune thyroid disease. Symptoms are worsening, impairing work and driving, and she is most concerned about ongoing visual decline and intermittent paresthesia.

An 82-year-old woman reports 10 days of progressively worsening dyspnea and a productive cough that began after a presumed upper respiratory infection. Sputum was initially clear but turned yellowish and she has had intermittent low-grade fevers and fatigue. During the past three days she developed orthopnea and new bilateral lower extremity swelling, with marked reduction in exercise tolerance and breathlessness on minimal exertion. She also notes recent palpitations and an irregular sensation in her chest. At home she observed transient exertional desaturation. She denies chest pain or hemoptysis. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. On exam she describes bibasilar inspiratory crackles limiting deep breaths and reduced oral intake secondary to shortness of breath.

An 83-year-old man presents with a 10-day history of progressive exertional dyspnea and right-sided pleuritic chest pain. He initially developed a dry cough after a recent upper respiratory illness, then noted new low‑grade fevers and decreasing exercise tolerance; over the past 48 hours he is short of breath at rest. He also reports recent swelling and aching of the right calf. His past history includes chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation. He describes intermittent lightheadedness but denies chest pressure typical of ischemia. At baseline he uses a cane and reports greater orthopnea than usual. The presentation raises concern for acute pulmonary embolism or superimposed pneumonia on chronic lung disease with hypoxemia.

A 46-year-old man reports three months of progressive exertional dyspnea and markedly reduced exercise tolerance, now limiting him to brief walks. Symptoms began insidiously after an unprovoked left lower-extremity DVT last year and have been accompanied by intermittent pleuritic chest discomfort and scant hemoptysis on two occasions. He describes presyncopal lightheadedness with exertion and occasional palpitations. Nighttime snoring, daytime fatigue, and obesity suggest possible untreated obstructive sleep apnea contributing to dyspnea. He is a former smoker with 15 pack-years. There is episodic unilateral leg swelling but no fever or infectious symptoms. The clinical picture raises concern for chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension or persistent thromboembolic disease versus asthma exacerbation, and he wishes to proceed with cardiopulmonary evaluation.

A 93-year-old woman presents with a three-month history of progressive gait disturbance and cognitive slowing. Family reports a magnetic, shuffling gait with short steps and hesitation, reduced short-term memory, and increasing apathy. Over the past month she sustained two ground-level falls without loss of consciousness and developed new urinary urgency with occasional daytime incontinence. Caregivers also note difficulty with sequencing tasks and occasional orthostatic lightheadedness on rising. She denies focal limb weakness, chest pain, or fever. On exam she is mildly bradyphrenic with a broad-based gait and unsteady turns. Clinicians are considering normal-pressure hydrocephalus versus chronic small-vessel vascular cognitive impairment as contributors; fall risk mitigation and assessment for reversible causes, including dehydration or urinary infection, have been initiated.

A 66-year-old woman reports five days of intermittent vertigo and progressive slurred speech with worsening right-sided limb clumsiness. Symptoms began as brief lightheaded spells after a recent mild upper respiratory illness one week ago and have evolved into persistent unsteadiness with two near-falls; she endorses nausea and brief episodes of horizontal diplopia, worse with head rotation and on standing. She denies chest pain or focal numbness. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and recently documented paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. On self-assessment she notes right-hand coordination difficulty and audible dysarthria when fatigued. Family observed transient improvement between episodes before deterioration. Current concern is posterior circulation ischemia given cerebellar signs and vascular risk factors; she was referred urgently for neuroimaging and cardiology evaluation.

A 35-year-old female reports sudden onset of multiple new floaters and intermittent flashes of light in her right eye for two days, now accompanied by a dark curtain starting from the temporal field and subtle blurring centrally. She notes mild decrease in visual acuity when reading and difficulty with peripheral vision. Symptoms began after a weekend of heavy lifting and Valsalva maneuvers. Past ocular history is significant for high myopia and a posterior vitreous detachment diagnosed several months ago. She denies trauma, pain, photophobia, discharge, or systemic illness but has a mild tension headache without focal neurologic deficits. No prior eye surgeries. She is concerned about a possible retinal detachment given progressive field loss.

A 37-year-old man presents with a one-week history of progressive blurring of vision in the right eye accompanied by central darkening and reduced color saturation. He reports mild periocular aching that worsens with eye movement and an intermittent dull occipital headache. Symptoms began about ten days after a self-limited viral upper respiratory illness. He endorses occasional floaters but no trauma, photophobia, or systemic fevers. An outside exam documented decreased visual acuity in the right eye and a relative afferent pupillary defect with subtle optic disc edema on fundoscopy. Past ocular history includes a remote episode of anterior uveitis; he has no known systemic autoimmune diagnosis and takes no chronic medications.

A 53-year-old man presents with six months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a chronic productive cough that has acutely worsened after a respiratory infection two weeks ago. Sputum has increased to yellow-green with occasional scant hemoptysis and he reports intermittent wheeze and frequent nocturnal coughing that awakens him. His exercise tolerance has declined; he becomes short of breath with one flight of stairs. He is a 30–pack-year former smoker and has known hypertension. During this flare he experienced low-grade fevers and malaise but denies pleuritic chest pain. Prior chest radiograph reportedly showed hyperinflation. Clinically this appears consistent with recurrent bronchitic exacerbations, raising concern for evolving COPD or bronchiectasis as contributors to his symptoms.

An 88-year-old man reports three days of progressively worsening vision in the right eye that culminated in sudden, painless monocular vision loss this morning. He describes a new, persistent right temporal headache and scalp tenderness when combing his hair over the past week, with intermittent jaw pain on chewing. For six weeks he has had morning shoulder and hip stiffness limiting dressing, previously attributed to polymyalgia rheumatica. Baseline ophthalmic history includes age-related macular degeneration in both eyes and decreased acuity from bilateral cataracts; he has long-standing hypertension. He denies trauma, eye discharge, or diplopia. The acute visual loss with adjacent temporal pain and proximal stiffness raises concern for ischemic optic neuropathy from temporal arteritis, prompting urgent specialty evaluation.

A 24-year-old male recreational soccer player reports two months of intermittent palpitations and progressive exertional dyspnea. He describes brief lightheadedness and two near-syncope episodes during high-intensity practice, and one transient loss of consciousness last week with rapid recovery. Chest tightness accompanies several episodes, worse with exertion and relieved by rest. He denies fever, chest trauma, or illicit drug use. On exam he notes a positional change in symptoms when leaning forward. Family history is notable for a paternal sudden cardiac death in his forties. He has no prior cardiac diagnosis but recently noticed decreased exercise tolerance and occasional nocturnal palpitations. Concern is raised for an inherited cardiomyopathy or exercise-related arrhythmia given the harsh systolic murmur and exertional syncope.

A 98-year-old man presents with progressive exertional dyspnea for roughly two months, with abrupt worsening over the past three days accompanied by a newly worsened, dry cough and reduced tolerance for walking across the room. Family reports six pounds of unintentional weight loss and decreased appetite over several weeks and intermittent nocturnal confusion. He had previously been diagnosed with presumed idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and baseline exertional dyspnea but was ambulatory without supplemental oxygen until recently. Today he is noted to be more tachypneic with resting hypoxemia at home and persistent bibasilar fine inspiratory crackles on exam; there is concern for an acute exacerbation of fibrosis possibly precipitated by a superimposed lower respiratory infection. Past history includes longstanding hypertension.

A 48-year-old man presents with six weeks of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and a persistent nonproductive cough that began after a moderately severe SARS-CoV-2 infection. He describes intermittent pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort with deep inspiration and marked fatigue when climbing stairs; exertional symptoms are accompanied by lightheadedness and documented desaturation with ambulation. He reports a 25 pack‑year smoking history and recent 6‑lb weight loss but denies fever or hemoptysis. At home he notes new audible wheeze and reduced exercise tolerance. On review he endorses orthopnea only occasionally. Concern is for postinfectious organizing pneumonia or evolving interstitial lung disease with possible secondary pulmonary hypertension, rather than uncomplicated reactive airways disease.

A 95-year-old male reports a six-month history of progressive gait instability with a shuffling step and increasing need for a walker. Family notes an intermittent resting tremor and generalized slowness of movement consistent with parkinsonian features; over the past month he has had two falls, one after standing quickly with lightheadedness suggestive of orthostatic symptoms. He now coughs while eating and describes intermittent throat clearing, concerning for oropharyngeal dysphagia, and two weeks ago was treated for aspiration pneumonia. Caregivers also describe poorer stamina and reduced engagement with activities. Past medical history notable only for longstanding hypertension. He denies new focal weakness, visual change, or fever since the pneumonia treatment.

A 79-year-old female presents with a three-month history of progressive gait instability and two recent falls. She describes a broad-based, shuffling gait and intermittent hesitation when initiating steps, with worsening balance particularly when rising from chairs. Family reports increasing urinary urgency and occasional incontinence over the last six weeks and subtle short-term memory loss with slowed attention. Past medical history notable for hypertension and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation; she had a transient ischemic attack last year. Outpatient brain MRI reportedly showed ventriculomegaly, raising concern for normal pressure hydrocephalus versus vascular gait disorder. She denies headache, fever, or visual change. Symptoms interfere with dressing and transfers; she uses a cane infrequently and fears further falls.

A 60-year-old male reports three months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent nonproductive cough, with marked worsening over the past four weeks. Initially short of breath only with stair climbing, he now becomes breathless after walking two blocks and notes an 8-pound unintentional weight loss and increasing fatigue. He denies fevers, night sweats, chest pain, or hemoptysis. He has reproducible oxygen desaturation into the high 80s with moderate exertion. Exam has bilateral bibasilar inspiratory "Velcro" crackles and early digital clubbing. Past history notable for well-controlled hypertension; 20 pack-year former smoker with prior construction work and possible silica exposure. Clinical concern is progressive interstitial lung disease, most consistent with pulmonary fibrosis, prompting urgent pulmonary evaluation.

A 59-year-old man reports three months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that have accelerated over the past two weeks, now limiting him to short walks. He notes an 8-pound unintentional weight loss and intermittent low-grade fevers but denies hemoptysis or chest pain. Office exam revealed fine bibasilar inspiratory crackles and early digital clubbing; pulse oximetry falls from 97% at rest to 88% with minimal ambulation. He is a former smoker with a history of well-controlled hypertension. Given the subacute course, clubbing, crackles, and exertional desaturation, the team is concerned about interstitial lung disease—most suspicious for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis—and has arranged pulmonary function testing and a high-resolution chest CT.

A 66-year-old woman reports progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough for approximately six months, with more rapid decline over the past three weeks after a brief upper respiratory illness. She notes increasing fatigue and an unintentional 5-kg weight loss; denies fever or hemoptysis. Examination at a recent clinic visit documented bibasilar crackles and early digital clubbing. She becomes breathless with minimal ambulation and reports her oxygen saturation falls with exertion. A prior outpatient chest CT reportedly showed bibasilar reticular change and mild traction bronchiectasis, prompting concern for interstitial lung disease; she has a history of well-controlled hypertension. No history of tobacco use or occupational dust exposure is elicited.

A 24-year-old woman presents with five days of progressive right-sided pleuritic chest pain and exertional shortness of breath. Pain is sharp, worse with deep inspiration, and associated with a nonproductive cough and two episodes of scant hemoptysis. She notes palpitations and near-syncope on ambulation; on exertion she becomes markedly dyspneic. She returned from a 14-hour bus trip one week ago and started combined oral contraceptives two months earlier. She also had an upper respiratory infection with nasal congestion and sore throat about ten days prior. Over the last 48 hours she developed mild swelling and tenderness in her left calf. Childhood intermittent asthma is noted but she has been otherwise healthy.

An 82-year-old woman presents with six months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough, now worse over the past week with intermittent low-grade fevers and decreased appetite. She reports a 10-pound unintentional weight loss and notes difficulty climbing one flight of stairs that was previously tolerated. History is significant for seropositive rheumatoid arthritis and a remote 20 pack-year smoking history, quit decades ago. On exam she notes finger clubbing and reports home oximetry falls into the high 80s with minimal exertion; she endorses basal crackling sensations rather than wheeze. The pattern suggests chronic fibrotic interstitial lung disease likely related to connective tissue disease, with recent acute symptom exacerbation possibly from superimposed infection or progressive fibrosis.

A 63-year-old male reports progressive exertional dyspnea and a chronic productive cough that has worsened over six weeks. He describes years of morning sputum production consistent with chronic bronchitic symptoms but now notes new scant hemoptysis and an unintentional seven-pound weight loss over two months. Five days ago he developed acute right-sided pleuritic chest pain and an abrupt increase in shortness of breath following a prolonged automobile trip. He is a former 40-pack-year smoker with a history of hypertension. He denies fevers or night sweats but reports decreased exercise tolerance, intermittent wheeze, and loss of appetite. He is concerned this represents a new complication—possible pulmonary embolism, infection, or malignancy—and requests urgent evaluation.

A 43-year-old female presents with three weeks of progressive, fatigable weakness affecting proximal arms and thighs, accompanied by intermittent binocular diplopia and unilateral ptosis that worsen toward evening. Symptoms began several days after a self-limited upper respiratory infection and have evolved to include mild dysphagia with nasal regurgitation of liquids and exertional dyspnea when climbing stairs. She notes diurnal fluctuation—near-normal strength in the morning with marked fatigue by night. No sensory loss, numbness, or objective joint swelling. Past medical history notable only for well-controlled hypertension. Family history noncontributory. Review of systems otherwise negative for fever or weight loss. Exam concerns suggest neuromuscular junction disease, and she is worried about breathing overnight.

A 73-year-old man reports seven days of progressive exertional dyspnea and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain. He describes a dry cough with a single episode of scant blood-tinged sputum and subjective palpitations when ambulating. Symptoms started after a prolonged automobile trip two weeks ago; he also notes new swelling and tenderness of the left calf. Past history includes hypertension and a remote 30-pack-year tobacco history; he completed treatment for localized prostate cancer several years ago. He denies fever, orthopnea, or recent upper respiratory infection. The temporal sequence of recent immobilization, unilateral leg swelling, pleuritic pain, exertional hypoxemia, and hemoptysis is concerning for acute pulmonary embolism with possible pulmonary infarction.

A 38-year-old man presents with ten days of progressive exertional dyspnea and intermittent pleuritic right-sided chest pain that began shortly after a transatlantic flight. He reports scant hemoptysis on three occasions and a persistent dry cough; dyspnea is worse with climbing stairs. He describes new right calf aching and swelling for four days and notes palpitations and low-grade fevers overnight. He is an active smoker with no history of chronic lung disease and denies recent upper respiratory symptoms, orthopnea, or leg trauma. Onset followed prolonged immobilization, and symptoms cluster suggest thromboembolic disease with possible pulmonary infarction; alternative considerations include atypical infection or underlying airways hyperreactivity. He has not started any new medications.

An 18-year-old female presents with two weeks of progressive left leg weakness and sensory changes after a febrile upper respiratory illness three weeks ago. She describes numbness and tingling ascending from the foot to the knee, intermittent electric shocks down the spine with neck flexion consistent with Lhermitte’s phenomenon, and increasing imbalance—notably difficulty climbing stairs. Over the past week she has had transient blurred vision and sporadic diplopia, worse with fatigue, alongside daily low-level fatigue and new urinary urgency without dysuria. Symptoms fluctuate but have overall worsened, prompting concern for a central process rather than peripheral injury. She denies headache, fever, recent trauma, or prior neurologic history.

A 39-year-old woman reports six days of progressive exertional dyspnea and sharp, pleuritic right-sided chest pain that began two days after a 10-hour bus trip. She notes scant hemoptysis yesterday and new right calf swelling and tenderness for 48 hours. Symptoms worsen with minimal exertion; she felt tachycardic and lightheaded when climbing stairs. She uses combined oral contraceptives and has a history of adolescent asthma and chronic atopic dermatitis but has been otherwise well. She denies fever, recent surgery, or illicit drug use. She is worried the pain and dyspnea are worsening despite resting and notes decreased exercise tolerance compared with baseline. Concern is raised for thromboembolic disease versus infectious or reactive airways processes.

An 8-year-old boy presents with a two-week history of daily morning headaches, described as pressure-like and often awakening him; headaches are worse with coughing and associated with photophobia and two episodes of non-bloody vomiting. Five days ago parents observed brief, focal clonic jerking of the right hand with transient post-ictal drowsiness and subsequent weakness of the right arm lasting about an hour. There has been mild new imbalance on stairs and a single fall without loss of consciousness. Symptoms began after a febrile upper respiratory infection three weeks ago. No prior seizures or head trauma. Past history notable only for eczema. Family history is positive for migraine in a maternal aunt. Parents report no recent medication changes or toxin exposures.

A 42-year-old woman presents with five days of progressive exertional dyspnea and pleuritic right-sided chest pain. The dyspnea began as mild breathlessness on climbing stairs and has progressed to shortness of breath at rest; chest pain is sharp and worse with deep inspiration. She reports a dry cough with occasional scant hemoptysis and low-grade fevers. Two days ago she noticed right calf swelling and aching after a prolonged intercity bus trip two weeks earlier; she has longstanding varicose veins. She is a former light smoker and has treated hypothyroidism. No recent trauma. Symptoms are worse with exertion and improved slightly when upright. She denies orthopnea and is concerned for pulmonary embolism versus infectious pneumonia.

A 45-year-old woman with a remote history of mild asthma reports one week of progressive exertional dyspnea and right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began two days ago. The pain is sharp, worse with deep inspiration, and associated with a productive cough producing yellow sputum with occasional blood-tinged streaks. She describes intermittent low-grade fevers, decreased exercise tolerance, and recurrent wheeze not relieved by her inhaler. Symptoms began after a recent upper respiratory illness and followed a prolonged car trip the prior week. She denies focal leg swelling or calf pain. She is concerned about a blood clot versus a complicated pneumonia given the hemoptysis and pleuritic pain; plans were made for urgent imaging and oxygen titration based on clinical exam.

A 40-year-old woman presents with a six-week history of progressive epigastric pain and pronounced early satiety. Pain is crampy, worse after meals, and accompanied by nausea and intermittent non-bilious vomiting; she now tolerates only small, frequent meals. She notes a 10-pound unintentional weight loss and one episode of dark, tarry stool last week followed by increasing fatigue. She has a remote history of heartburn controlled intermittently with over-the-counter remedies and reports occasional NSAID use for menstrual cramps. No fevers or overt hematemesis. Physical exam earlier revealed mild epigastric tenderness and pallor. She is concerned about peptic ulcer disease or gastric outlet obstruction and was referred for endoscopic evaluation; iron-deficiency anemia is suspected given the symptoms.

A 75-year-old woman reports two weeks of intermittent right-sided weakness, slurred speech, and brief episodes of expressive aphasia that initially lasted 10–20 minutes but have become more frequent and prolonged. Yesterday she had a three-hour episode with persistent mild right facial droop and unsteady gait, prompting evaluation. She endorses several recent near-falls and progressive difficulty managing stairs. She has a history of hypertension and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and notes recent palpitations without syncope. She denies headache, visual loss, or seizure activity. There is mild baseline memory decline but no acute confusion. Symptoms are not positional and were not preceded by trauma or infectious prodrome. Family reports the speech deficits are new and concerning for transient ischemic events.

An 87-year-old female reports progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent nonproductive cough for approximately six months, initially with subtle decline in walking tolerance that has recently limited household ambulation. The cough is dry and worse with exertion; she also describes increasing fatigue, a 6-kg unintentional weight loss, and intermittent low‑grade fevers after a bronchitic illness two months ago. She notes occasional pleuritic chest discomfort and new digital clubbing, and home pulse oximetry readings fall into the low 80s with activity. Outpatient chest radiography reportedly showed basilar reticular changes; on exam she has fine inspiratory crackles at both bases. Overall presentation is most consistent with progressive interstitial lung disease, complicated by exertional hypoxemia and concern for secondary pulmonary hypertension.

A 7-year-old boy presents with a seven-day history of worsening cough and shortness of breath that began after a rhinorrheal illness with low-grade fever. Cough was initially intermittent and dry but has become paroxysmal and nocturnal, waking him twice most nights; parents note audible wheeze and reports of chest tightness when running. He now tires quickly during play and has avoided sports at school. Caregivers administered his rescue inhaler at home once with partial symptomatic relief. No vomiting, hemoptysis, or cyanosis. Past history is notable for atopic dermatitis and seasonal allergic rhinitis. No prior intubations or chronic lung disease. Family has seasonal allergies but no cystic fibrosis history.

A 70-year-old female presents with three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a nonproductive cough that has worsened over the past 48 hours when she developed right-sided pleuritic chest pain and low‑grade fevers after a prolonged car trip. She now reports orthopnea and episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, plus new bilateral lower‑extremity swelling and intermittent palpitations with an irregular sensation in her chest. Symptoms began gradually but accelerated after the period of immobility; she is concerned about a blood clot but also notes increasing fatigue consistent with congestive symptoms. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and osteoarthritis. She denies recent cough with sputum, active tobacco use, or recent travel-associated illness other than the long drive.

A 17-year-old male reports six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and intermittent chest tightness that occur during soccer practice and when exposed to cold air. He describes noisy breathing with episodic inspiratory stridor and throat tightness, accompanied by a dry cough and occasional hoarseness. Symptoms began after a presumed upper respiratory infection three months ago and now substantially reduce his exercise tolerance, though they improve with rest and coached breathing. He denies fever, syncope, hemoptysis, or leg swelling. Past history notable for seasonal allergic rhinitis; he denies tobacco or vaping. Examination at school revealed audible inspiratory noise during exertion. Differential considerations include exercise-induced bronchoconstriction versus paradoxical vocal fold motion; spirometry with bronchodilator challenge and outpatient laryngoscopy were requested.

A 99-year-old male presents with sudden right-sided weakness and confusion for the past 24 hours. Family notes acute onset of slurred speech and expressive aphasia with a right facial droop; he is slower to follow commands than his baseline of mild vascular cognitive impairment. Caregiver reports a brief prodrome of decreased oral intake and low-grade fever with urinary frequency over three days, raising concern for a urinary tract infection and dehydration that may have precipitated symptoms. Past history is notable for long-standing hypertension and atrial fibrillation, increasing embolic stroke risk. No chest pain or shortness of breath. Examination findings are consistent with left hemispheric ischemia; goals are stabilization, stroke evaluation, and addressing infection and volume status.

A 41-year-old female reports four days of progressive shortness of breath and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began three days after a long-haul flight. Dyspnea is worse with exertion and associated with intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness; she describes a dry cough with one episode of blood-tinged sputum. She also notes subjective fever and chills and new swelling and tenderness in the left calf. Past history is notable only for mild intermittent asthma; she takes combined oral contraceptives. She denies recent trauma, smoking, or illicit drug use. Symptoms have steadily worsened despite rest, and she became more breathless climbing stairs yesterday, prompting presentation for evaluation for possible pulmonary embolism versus infectious or inflammatory pulmonary process.

A 94-year-old female presents with five days of progressive shortness of breath and a new productive cough after a choking episode while eating. The sputum is purulent and foul-smelling, and family reports low-grade fevers and reduced oral intake. She now becomes breathless at rest and intermittently requires supplemental oxygen for desaturation with minimal exertion. On exam there are coarse inspiratory crackles localized to the right lower lung and decreased air entry basally. Past medical history notable for COPD and chronic hypertension; she was previously independent with transfers. Clinical impression is aspiration-related pneumonia complicating underlying COPD, with concern for oropharyngeal dysphagia as the precipitant. No chest pain or hemoptysis reported; family wishes discussion of management options.

A 24-year-old female reports three days of progressive exertional dyspnea, pleuritic right-sided chest pain, and a dry cough. She noted scant hemoptysis this morning and intermittent low-grade fevers. Symptoms began after a prolonged bus trip one week ago and were preceded by new right calf swelling and tenderness over two days. She takes combined oral contraceptives and has a maternal history of early venous clots. During activity she feels lightheaded and palpitates, and at rest notices a rapid heart rate. She denies recent surgery, trauma, or significant illness beforehand. The timing and constellation suggest possible deep venous thrombosis complicated by pulmonary embolism, and she seeks evaluation for hypoxia and acute cardiopulmonary compromise.

A 29-year-old female presents with a 10-day history of progressive blurred vision in the right eye, associated with retro-orbital pain that worsens with eye movement and marked photophobia. She reports intermittent diplopia and new floaters with occasional flashes; morning headaches are more prominent and are occasionally accompanied by brief transient visual obscurations. Symptoms began after a self-limited upper respiratory infection two weeks ago and have steadily intensified. She also notes new low-frequency pulsatile tinnitus and episodic nausea with the worst headaches. She has a distant history of episodic migraine but describes this pain as different and more localized behind the right eye. No recent trauma, contact lens use, fever, or skin rash. Concern for optic neuritis versus raised intracranial pressure is expressed.

A 64-year-old woman with hypertension and a remote 30-pack-year smoking history reports three weeks of worsening productive cough on a background of chronic COPD and known bronchiectasis. Cough initially produced clear sputum but became purulent with low-grade fevers and a two-pound weight loss; she notes increased dyspnea on exertion compared with baseline. Two days ago she developed acute, pleuritic right-sided chest pain and a single small episode of hemoptysis. She also describes new swelling and tenderness of the right calf. She denies chest pressure, syncope, or recent travel. The temporal progression—bronchiectasis/COPD exacerbation with fever and purulence, now acute pleuritic pain plus unilateral leg swelling—raises concern for superinfection and possible pulmonary embolism.

A 71-year-old woman presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough. Symptoms began insidiously and have worsened from breathlessness on stairs to needing frequent rest after short walks; she now sleeps on two pillows for orthopnea and reports one episode weekly of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. She has noticed a three-kilogram weight gain and new bilateral ankle swelling. She describes intermittent palpitations and family members noted an irregularly irregular pulse. On exam she reports basilar crackles and reduced exercise tolerance compared with her usual. Past medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension. She denies chest pain, fever, hemoptysis, or recent travel.

A 39-year-old female reports three weeks of progressive right-sided paresthesia and intermittent blurring of vision in the left eye. Symptoms began as fingertip tingling that ascended to involve the forearm, now accompanied by unsteady gait and frequent stumbling. She endorses an electric shock sensation with neck flexion and new urinary urgency with occasional hesitancy. Fatigue and mild cognitive slowing interfere with work. She recalls a febrile upper respiratory infection about six weeks ago but denies recent trauma or systemic infection currently. Past history notable only for episodic migraine without aura. The pattern raises concern for an inflammatory demyelinating process such as multiple sclerosis or focal transverse myelitis, prompting urgent neurologic evaluation.

A 2-year-old male is brought for two days of progressive right ear pain and fever. Symptoms began after a week of nasal congestion and rhinorrhea; caregivers note increased fussiness and poor oral intake. Over the past 24 hours he developed high fevers to about 39.5°C, persistent otalgia, and new postauricular swelling with erythema and tenderness behind the right ear. This morning there was purulent otorrhea and caregivers report muffled responses to sound and reduced speech-like vocalizations. He has intermittent nonbilious vomiting and fewer wet diapers. No history of recurrent ear disease. Examination elsewhere reportedly documented a bulging right tympanic membrane. Clinical concern is acute otitis media complicated by mastoiditis, warranting urgent ENT evaluation.
