A 48-year-old male presents with three months of progressive dysphagia initially to solids and now to liquids, accompanied by intermittent odynophagia and frequent regurgitation, worse when lying flat. He reports an eight-kilogram unintentional weight loss and diminished appetite. Longstanding heartburn treated intermittently with over-the-counter antacids preceded these symptoms for several years, and he has a prior diagnosis of Barrett’s esophagus on surveillance endoscopy. Over the past two weeks he developed a hoarse voice and nocturnal cough with occasional choking episodes. A recent workup documented iron-deficiency anemia. He smokes occasionally and denies fever or overt gastrointestinal bleeding. He is concerned about progressive obstruction versus malignant transformation and requests expedited evaluation.

An 18-year-old female reports a six-week history of progressive palpitations, unintentional weight loss of about 6 kg, and persistent heat intolerance. She describes a fine hand tremor, fragmented sleep with early morning awakening, and increasing fatigue limiting her ability to climb stairs due to proximal leg weakness. Menstrual cycles have become irregular over the same interval. Symptoms began insidiously and accelerated after a brief viral upper respiratory illness one month ago. She notes intermittent lightheadedness during palpitations and new ocular irritation with upper lid retraction and mild protrusion of the right eye. She denies chest pain, syncope, or recent medication changes. Family history is noncontributory. Overall presentation is most consistent with a hyperadrenergic endocrine process.

A 62-year-old woman reports six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent nonproductive cough that began after a brief upper respiratory illness. She now requires two pillows to sleep because of breathlessness, notes new bilateral lower extremity swelling, and experiences intermittent exertional chest tightness when climbing stairs. She is a former 30–pack-year smoker with long-standing hypertension and recalls prior outpatient documentation of 'lung scarring.' She denies fever, hemoptysis, or sputum production. Her walking tolerance has declined from a mile to a few blocks. The pattern suggests evolving cardiopulmonary disease—possible progression of interstitial lung disease with secondary pulmonary hypertension or occult heart failure—warranting chest imaging and BNP evaluation.

A 73-year-old woman presents with a six-month history of progressive gait instability, cognitive slowing, and new urinary urgency. Her family notes difficulty initiating steps with short, shuffling, "magnetic" movements and two recent low-energy falls. Cognitive changes are mainly executive dysfunction and slowed processing with intermittent short-term memory lapses, requiring frequent reminders. Urinary urgency has progressed to occasional urge incontinence over the past two months. She has a remote fall with brief head trauma a year ago and a history of well-controlled hypertension. CT head performed by outpatient neurology shows ventriculomegaly without acute hemorrhage. Family reports transient improvement in gait and concentration after a large-volume lumbar puncture last month. The overall picture is most consistent with possible normal-pressure hydrocephalus.

A 59-year-old man reports two months of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and decreased exercise tolerance, now limiting his ability to climb a flight of stairs. He has a persistent, mostly dry morning cough with one episode of scant blood-tinged sputum and intermittent wheeze, worse with exertion. He notes new ankle swelling and mild right-sided chest discomfort when active. Symptoms began several months after a remote pulmonary embolism and longstanding history of chronic bronchitic cough related to a 35-pack-year smoking history. He endorses loud snoring and daytime somnolence consistent with possible obstructive sleep apnea. He denies fever or infection symptoms. Concern is for evolving pulmonary hypertension, chronic thromboembolic disease, or COPD progression prompting further cardiopulmonary evaluation.

A 73-year-old male reports eight weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that began insidiously after a bronchitis-like illness. He now becomes breathless walking one block and has had two episodes of scant hemoptysis. He describes fatigue, unintentional 10-pound weight loss, and diminished appetite. He is a former 40-pack-year smoker who quit a decade ago and has a history of hypertension, otherwise independent. On review he notes mild lower extremity swelling and uses two pillows at night for sleep. Examiners documented bibasilar crackles and mild pitting ankle edema. He denies fever, chest pain, or orthopnea beyond needing extra pillows; he is concerned about worsening exercise tolerance and progressive shortness of breath.

A frail 86-year-old man presents with three months of progressive exertional dyspnea that has acutely worsened over the past two weeks. He notes a persistent dry cough and reports becoming short of breath after walking two blocks, with new lightheadedness on minimal exertion. He had a self-limited upper respiratory infection three weeks ago. On review he describes a 5-pound unintentional weight loss and decreased appetite. Past history notable for hypertension and a remote 40-pack-year smoking history. Home oxygen not used. On exam he reports exertional oxygen desaturation and exam previously documented bibasilar fine inspiratory crackles; no lower-extremity edema. He denies chest pain, hemoptysis, or fever and is worried about progressive lung disease.

An 84-year-old man reports two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea that has accelerated over the past three days, now occurring with minimal ambulation and at rest. He describes new orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, a persistent nonproductive cough, and mild fatigue. Symptoms began after a self-limited upper respiratory infection three weeks ago. At home he notes increased shortness of breath with decreased exercise tolerance and new ankle swelling. He is a former smoker with known hypertension and COPD, and this episode feels worse than prior "bronchitis" flares. On review he denies chest pain or syncope but endorses lightheadedness with exertion. Prior baseline required activity modification; today he appears more dyspneic and reports room-air oxygen saturation lower than usual.

A 31-year-old female reports three weeks of progressive sensory changes and gait disturbance after a viral upper respiratory illness. She first noticed intermittent paresthesias in the right arm and leg that now cause numbness and difficulty buttoning clothes; bending the neck produces brief electric shocks consistent with Lhermitte's phenomenon. Two weeks in she developed blurring and pain with left eye movement suggestive of optic neuritis, and over the past week she has had urinary urgency and a spastic-appearing gait with several near-falls. She endorses mild fatigue but denies fever, headache, or recent head trauma. She recalls a transient episode of numbness last year that resolved. Neurologic process of demyelination is suspected; MRI and neuro-ophthalmology referral arranged.

A 75-year-old woman presents with two weeks of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and a three-night history of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea and orthopnea. Family reports new palpitations and intermittent lightheadedness beginning five days ago; she notes a recent upper respiratory cough that resolved. She has gained three pounds of edema and now has bilateral pitting lower-extremity swelling and decreased exercise tolerance. On review she endorses mild productive cough and chronic baseline dyspnea attributed to long-standing COPD and hypertension. Exam findings described by primary care include irregular heartbeat and bibasilar crackles. Past history notable for hypertension and stage III chronic kidney disease. She denies chest pain, syncope, or fever. Symptoms are most consistent with acute heart failure exacerbation, likely precipitated by new arrhythmia.

A 40-year-old man presents with four days of progressive exertional dyspnea and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain. He reports an episode of blood-tinged sputum yesterday and a persistent dry cough. Symptoms began two days after a ten-hour coach bus ride; he also notes new swelling and aching in the right calf for five days. He is a current tobacco smoker and has well-controlled hypertension. He denies fever, sputum purulence, or recent upper respiratory infection. He has intermittent exertional palpitations and lightheadedness on minimal activity. No history of bleeding disorder. Concern is raised for pulmonary embolism from probable deep venous thrombosis versus viral or bacterial pneumonia or an acute exacerbation of underlying airway disease.

A 43-year-old woman presents with six weeks of progressive palpitations, tremor, and heat intolerance. She reports an 8-pound unintentional weight loss despite increased appetite and intermittent exertional dyspnea with lightheadedness. Episodes of rapid, irregular heartbeat are accompanied by fine hand tremor, excessive sweating, and difficulty concentrating at work. She notes new neck fullness and a sensation of throat tightness, plus episodic eye irritation with lid retraction and blurred vision. Menstrual cycles have become irregular over the past two months, and she describes mild proximal muscle weakness when climbing stairs. No prior thyroid disease. Symptoms began insidiously and worsen with minimal exertion; she denies chest pain, syncope, or recent medication changes.

A 15-year-old boy presents with three days of progressive right-sided facial weakness and numbness that began two days after a viral upper respiratory illness. He notes difficulty closing the right eye, drooling, and altered taste on the anterior tongue, and reports new hyperacusis in the affected ear. Symptoms progressed over 48 hours then plateaued; he also has intermittent frontal headache and mild dysarthria when speaking fast. There is right-sided otalgia but no ear discharge, no skin vesicles, and no limb weakness or sensory change. He denies head trauma, fever currently, or recent travel or tick exposure. Family is concerned for acute facial nerve palsy (Bell’s palsy versus Ramsey Hunt), and he requests evaluation for causes and prognosis.

A 97-year-old female reports a two-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea with new orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. She describes a persistent dry cough and a single brief episode of pleuritic chest discomfort. Family notes gradual anorexia and decreased mobility after a recently treated urinary tract infection, and she has noticed bilateral ankle swelling and increased fatigue. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and known diastolic heart failure; her pulse has felt irregular at home. She denies fever or purulent sputum. Presentation is most consistent with a congestive heart failure exacerbation in the setting of deconditioning, with concern for possible concomitant pulmonary embolism or aspiration-related lung injury given recent illness and reduced intake.

An 84-year-old woman reports three days of progressive, painless vision loss in the right eye, starting as blurred central vision and evolving to a persistent dark central spot that interferes with reading and facial recognition. She notes a two-week history of new temporal headaches and scalp tenderness, with jaw claudication when chewing and increasing fatigue; she has felt low-grade fevers over the past week. On exam the right temporal artery felt prominent and tender. Past medical history includes hypertension and prior polymyalgia rheumatica; she underwent cataract extraction in that eye two years ago. She denies trauma, flashes, or eye discharge. Symptoms began after a brief upper respiratory illness two weeks earlier, and she is most concerned about permanent vision loss.

A 93-year-old man presents with two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a new productive cough. Family reports scant yellow sputum and intermittent low-grade fevers, with several episodes of coughing and choking while eating solids over the past month. He notes nocturnal cough and positional worsening when lying flat, plus decreased appetite and an unintentional 5-kg weight loss over three months. At baseline he has mild cognitive impairment and limited mobility from osteoarthritis. He has experienced episodic desaturation with minimal exertion and increasing dependence on assistance for meals. The cluster of dysphagia with recent choking, subacute constitutional symptoms, and bibasilar crackling cough suggests aspiration-related lower respiratory infection superimposed on chronic frailty; no recent antibiotic courses or hospitalizations are reported.

A 33-year-old woman reports ten days of progressive blurring and decreased vision in her left eye associated with a deep, aching retro-orbital pain that is worse with eye movement. She notes colors look "washed out" and recently developed difficulty reading fine print; her partner observed a sluggish left pupil in bright light. Symptoms began shortly after a self-limited upper respiratory illness and are exacerbated by hot showers or vigorous exercise. She also recalls a brief episode of right-leg numbness and tingling three months ago that resolved over days. There is no trauma, discharge, or floaters. Examined elsewhere she was told the finding might represent optic neuritis, raising concern for a demyelinating process such as multiple sclerosis.

A 38-year-old female reports a two-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea and sharp, right-sided pleuritic chest pain. Symptoms began shortly after a 10–12 hour flight, initially with a dry cough and low-grade fevers, and she noticed new right calf swelling and aching five days later. Dyspnea worsens on climbing stairs and is associated with occasional lightheadedness; she has not had hemoptysis. She describes mild childhood asthma that has been quiescent for years and currently uses combined hormonal contraception. At home she observed mild breathlessness with minimal exertion and transient lightheadedness but no syncope. Given the temporal link with prolonged travel, focal calf swelling, and exertional desaturation, she is concerned about possible deep venous thrombosis with pulmonary embolism.

A 90-year-old female presents with a six-month history of progressive gait instability and cognitive slowing. She describes a magnetic, shuffling gait with decreased step height and several ground-level falls in the past month without loss of consciousness. Family notes increasing short-term memory loss, word-finding difficulty, and apathy limiting daily activities. She has new urinary urgency with occasional nocturnal incontinence. Symptoms progressed after a period of reduced mobility from painful hip osteoarthritis, and baseline peripheral sensory neuropathy has worsened balance. Medical history includes long-standing hypertension. Home observation revealed slowed responses and a broad-based gait; concern is raised for normal-pressure hydrocephalus versus mixed degenerative change. No fevers, chest pain, or focal seizure activity reported.

A 34-year-old woman presents with three days of progressive dyspnea and sharp, right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began a day after a transcontinental flight. She reports an episode of frank hemoptysis yesterday and notes intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness. Two weeks ago she developed swelling and aching of the right calf that she attributed to travel. She uses combined hormonal contraception and smokes a half-pack daily; no prior thrombotic history. Onset was acute and symptoms have worsened with minimal exertion; she also has a low-grade fever and poor exercise tolerance. She denies recent trauma or known malignancy. The constellation is concerning for pulmonary embolism secondary to deep venous thrombosis.

A 99-year-old female reports progressive gait instability and slowing over the past five months, describing a wide-based, shuffling walk and two recent near-falls. Family notes increasing forgetfulness and executive slowing with difficulty managing finances and sequencing tasks. She has new urinary urgency and occasional urge incontinence that began around the same time as the gait changes. She denies headache or acute focal weakness but reports lightheadedness on standing. Past history is notable for long-standing hypertension and peripheral neuropathy related to prior glucose intolerance. Providers have raised concern for normal-pressure hydrocephalus given the triad of gait disturbance, cognitive change, and urinary symptoms; orthostatic hypotension and multifactorial deconditioning are considered contributing factors. Neurology follow-up is planned.

A 51-year-old woman presents with four days of progressive shortness of breath and right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began after a recent ankle fracture left her non–weight-bearing. Dyspnea worsens with exertion and is accompanied by a dry cough and a small amount of blood-tinged sputum. She notes new intermittent palpitations and had one feverish evening. She also reports swelling and tenderness of the right calf for two days. Past medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension and intermittent exercise-related asthma. No recent long-distance travel. The temporal link to immobilization with unilateral leg swelling raises concern for deep venous thrombosis complicated by pulmonary embolism with pleuritic inflammation and minimal hemoptysis, prompting urgent evaluation.

A 57-year-old woman presents with two weeks of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and a dry cough that began after a mild upper respiratory infection. Symptoms have evolved to include intermittent pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort and a sense of breathlessness at rest over the past three days. She reports new unilateral calf swelling and aching after a prolonged car trip ten days ago, and notes decreased exercise tolerance compared with baseline. She is a former smoker with a history of hypertension and obstructive sleep apnea. There is no fever, hemoptysis is denied, and she has progressive fatigue and occasional nighttime awakenings from shortness of breath. She is concerned about a pulmonary embolus but also worried about chronic lung disease given her smoking history.

A 72-year-old female reports a ten-day history of progressive exertional dyspnea and a dry cough that began after a presumed upper respiratory infection. Symptoms acutely worsened over 48 hours with new pleuritic right-sided chest pain and subjective fevers; she noticed new swelling and mild erythema of the right calf. She has known COPD, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and hypertension at baseline and limited mobility from knee osteoarthritis. On walking she becomes more short of breath and her oxygen saturation falls into the high 80s. She denies sputum production or orthopnea. The temporal cluster of calf swelling, pleuritic pain, hypoxemia, and acute dyspnea raises concern for pulmonary embolism versus COPD exacerbation.

A 63-year-old male presents with three weeks of progressive dyspnea on exertion and a dry cough that acutely worsened over the past 72 hours after a presumptive upper respiratory infection. He now reports pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort and subjective low-grade fevers; he becomes markedly short of breath with minimal ambulation and notes new ankle swelling. Home pulse oximetry drops to the high 80s with exertion. He has a 40–pack-year smoking history, quit ten years ago, and a remote left lower-extremity deep venous thrombosis five years ago treated with brief anticoagulation. He denies hemoptysis but endorses fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance. He is particularly concerned about a possible pulmonary embolus versus an infectious process or COPD exacerbation.

A 12-year-old female presents with a four-day history of increasing thirst and urinary frequency, waking overnight to urinate and consuming large volumes of fluid. Parents note a 3-kg weight loss and progressive fatigue despite a normal appetite. She developed a sweet, fruity odor to her breath and, over the past two days, intermittent crampy periumbilical abdominal pain with one episode of nonbilious vomiting. She appears mildly dehydrated and has missed school because of lethargy. She denies fever, respiratory symptoms, or dysuria. Past history notable only for eczema; family history significant for maternal autoimmune thyroid disease. The timeline and clustering of symptoms are most consistent with new-onset insulin deficiency causing hyperglycemia and osmotic fluid losses.

A 64-year-old woman reports progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and a chronic productive cough that has steadily deepened over the past three months and acutely deteriorated in the last two weeks after a viral upper respiratory illness. She describes daily purulent sputum with intermittent wheeze, two recent episodes of scant hemoptysis, and low‑grade fevers. Activity tolerance has fallen from walking a block to a few steps; she notes new nocturnal breathlessness and brief orthopnea. Over the same interval she developed mild bilateral ankle swelling and a 3‑kg unintentional weight loss. She is a former smoker with known hypertension but no prior heart failure. She is concerned about possible worsening chronic lung disease versus a superimposed infectious or thromboembolic complication.

A 79-year-old female reports a three-month history of progressive unsteadiness and difficulty initiating gait, now described as short, shuffling steps with occasional freezing when turning. Family notes gradual cognitive slowing and mild word-finding difficulty over the same period, and she has developed new urinary urgency with two brief episodes of incontinence. She sustained two ground-level falls last month without loss of consciousness; a recent treated urinary tract infection briefly worsened her confusion. Past medical history is notable for long-standing hypertension and atrial fibrillation. Prior imaging showed chronic small-vessel ischemic change. At home she demonstrates a broad-based gait and subtle executive dysfunction. Concern is raised for normal pressure hydrocephalus versus progression of vascular cognitive impairment, and family is seeking neurosurgical evaluation for possible CSF drainage testing.

A 74-year-old female reports six months of slowly progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough, with a more marked decline over the past two weeks after a presumed upper respiratory infection. She now uses 2 L oxygen at home and becomes breathless dressing herself; she also notes new bilateral ankle swelling and mild orthopnea. Prior outpatient evaluation documented velcro-like inspiratory crackles and chest radiograph with increased interstitial markings; she carries a working diagnosis of suspected idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. She is a former 30–pack-year smoker and has long-standing hypertension. Over the recent exacerbation she developed intermittent low-grade fevers and a two-pound weight loss, prompting concern for progression of fibrosis with possible superimposed infection or evolving pulmonary hypertension.

A 13-year-old boy presents with four days of progressive abdominal pain that began as vague periumbilical discomfort and migrated to the right lower quadrant over 24 hours. Pain is constant, sharp, and worsened by movement; he now walks stiffly and avoids running. He reports poor appetite, two episodes of non-bloody emesis, and a low-grade fever. Onset followed a mild sore throat and nasal congestion one week earlier. Parents note decreased urine output and less activity than usual. He has localized tenderness in the right lower quadrant with mild guarding but no visible rash or joint swelling. Differential considerations include acute appendicitis versus postinfectious mesenteric adenitis, and he requests evaluation for possible surgical abdomen.

A 65-year-old woman presents with a three-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea and a productive cough that has become purulent. She reports intermittent blood-tinged sputum and new right-sided pleuritic chest pain for two days, with a subjective fever and increased fatigue. Symptoms acutely worsened after a prolonged car trip last weekend; she now notes mild swelling of the right calf and difficulty climbing a single flight of stairs. Past medical history is notable for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and long-standing hypertension, and a remote provoked deep venous thrombosis five years ago. She denies night sweats or weight loss. The constellation raises concern for infectious bronchitic exacerbation versus pulmonary embolism on a background of chronic lung disease.

A 65-year-old man presents with progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough for several months, now limiting him to short walks and causing fatigue with minimal exertion. Symptoms began after a prolonged bronchitic illness and have insidiously worsened; he notes a two-month interval of accelerated breathlessness and intermittent mild weight loss. He is a former 30 pack-year smoker and has a history of well-controlled hypertension. On review he denies fevers, chest pain, or hemoptysis. Exam previously documented basilar inspiratory crackles and mild digital clubbing; home oxygen is not used but he reports breathlessness when climbing stairs and occasional lightheadedness. Prior outpatient evaluation raised concern for pulmonary fibrosis with exertional desaturation on walk testing.

An 80-year-old female presents with six weeks of progressive gait instability and intermittent confusion, with a more pronounced decline over the past two weeks after a minor fall in which she struck her head but did not lose consciousness. Family notes slower recall, increasing daytime somnolence, new urinary urgency with occasional incontinence, and intermittent slurred speech accompanied by right-hand clumsiness. She reports two near-falls and now requires a walker for steadying. Past history is notable for atrial fibrillation on anticoagulation, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. She denies fever, persistent headache, or vomiting but felt briefly dazed after the fall. Symptoms cluster around cognitive and motor dysfunction, prompting concern for a subacute intracranial process or cerebrovascular etiology.

A 50-year-old male presents with a 10-day history of progressive exertional dyspnea that acutely worsened three days ago with pleuritic right-sided chest pain and scant hemoptysis. Symptoms began after a week-long car trip; he now notes new left calf swelling and discomfort. He describes palpitations and lightheadedness on exertion and has been more short of breath at rest, limiting walks to the block. He is a former 20 pack-year smoker and has a history of well-controlled hypertension. On review he denies fever or recent infection. The temporal sequence—prolonged travel, unilateral calf swelling, then sudden dyspnea with pleuritic pain and hemoptysis—raises concern for thromboembolic disease with possible right-heart strain.

A 91-year-old female presents with a 48-hour history of progressive, painless loss of vision in the right eye, preceded by ten days of new, severe right-sided temporal headache and scalp tenderness. She endorses jaw claudication with chewing and several brief episodes of transient monocular visual blackout over the prior week (amaurosis fugax). For two months she has experienced morning stiffness and proximal shoulder girdle aching consistent with polymyalgia rheumatica, accompanied by intermittent low-grade fevers and decreased appetite. Past medical history is notable for longstanding hypertension. She denies ocular trauma or discharge; family reports the right pupil seemed sluggish. The constellation of symptoms raises concern for giant cell arteritis with possible ischemic optic neuropathy.

A 95-year-old male reports six weeks of progressive gait difficulty with a broad-based, shuffling gait and increasing unsteadiness. He has fallen twice at home over the past month and now needs a cane for ambulation. Family also reports slowed thinking, short-term memory decline, and increased apathy over the same interval. Urinary urgency progressing to occasional incontinence began about four weeks ago. He had a presumed urinary tract infection treated at home two weeks ago, after which his gait and cognition acutely worsened. He denies new focal weakness, headache, or visual change but describes intermittent lightheadedness when standing. Past history is notable for long-standing hypertension. No recent hospitalizations or new medications.

A 74-year-old female reports ten days of progressive left monocular vision loss, beginning as intermittent blurring and fleeting diplopia and evolving over 48 hours into a dense central scotoma. She describes associated left temporal scalp tenderness and new-onset jaw claudication with chewing. Examination at clinic noted a palpable, slightly nodular temporal artery on the left. She also reports several weeks of morning stiffness and aching across the shoulders and hips consistent with polymyalgia rheumatica, plus low-grade fevers and fatigue. There is no eye discharge, trauma, or preceding headache. Symptoms are most consistent with ischemic optic neuropathy secondary to giant cell arteritis, and she is concerned about further vision loss.

A 78-year-old man with hypertension and known COPD reports six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that has recently limited walking across his home. Symptoms began after a mild upper‑respiratory illness and have evolved to intermittent pleuritic chest discomfort and increasing fatigue with an unintentional five‑pound weight loss. He is a former 40 pack‑year smoker. Examiner notes bibasilar inspiratory crackles and mild digital clubbing with trace bilateral ankle edema; he denies fever or significant sputum production. He recalls prior imaging showing emphysematous change. He is concerned about worsening fibrosis versus superimposed heart failure or occult malignancy and seeks further evaluation.

A 94-year-old woman with known hypertension and chronic atrial fibrillation presents with acute-on-subacute neurologic change: family reports two weeks of progressive gait instability and intermittent falls, with sudden worsening over the past 24 hours marked by new left-sided weakness and slurred speech. She is more confused than baseline and intermittently drowsy; caregivers also note urinary frequency and low-grade fever for two days. There was one brief syncope episode after standing this morning. No recent head trauma. Examination at home revealed pale skin and a cool left hand compared with the right. The pattern is concerning for a right hemispheric ischemic event precipitated by dehydration and possible urinary tract infection contributing to delirium and orthostatic hypotension.

A 78-year-old woman with longstanding hypertension and known interstitial lung disease presents with three weeks of progressive dyspnea that began after an upper respiratory infection. Initially a dry cough, she now produces scant yellow sputum and reports low-grade fevers and new pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort. Over the past five days she has developed orthopnea and increased lower extremity swelling, with markedly reduced exercise tolerance and two episodes of near-syncope on exertion. On review she notes worsening baseline resting breathlessness and audible wheeze at night. Family reports increased use of her portable oxygen. She denies focal neurologic deficits, abdominal pain, or urinary symptoms. This course is concerning for ILD exacerbation versus superimposed pneumonia with possible cardiopulmonary congestion.

A 32-year-old female presents with progressive exertional dyspnea and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began 48 hours ago. Symptoms started as a mild nonproductive cough after a long transatlantic flight and have evolved to resting shortness of breath with intermittent palpitations and one episode of scant hemoptysis. She also notes new right calf swelling and tenderness for three days. Past history is notable for intermittent asthma managed with as-needed inhalers and current use of combined oral contraception. She denies fever, recent surgery, or known COVID-19 infection. No prior thromboembolic events. The temporal association with recent prolonged travel, calf findings, tachycardia, and pleuritic pain raises concern for pulmonary embolism secondary to deep venous thrombosis.

A 48-year-old man presents with progressive right-sided hearing loss and episodic rotational vertigo over the past six months, with two weeks of worsening imbalance and daily high-pitched tinnitus. Hearing decline was insidious at first but acutely worse after a self-limited upper respiratory infection three weeks ago; vertigo episodes last minutes and are associated with nausea and difficulty walking. He reports intermittent occipital headaches and a recent episode of right facial numbness while bending. Past medical history notable for well-controlled hypertension. No otorrhea or fever. He is concerned about a possible vestibular schwannoma versus recurrent Meniere-like attacks; formal audiometry and MRI brain/head-neck are pending.

A 36-year-old male reports three weeks of intermittent binocular diplopia and progressive bilateral ptosis, most pronounced by evening. Symptoms are fatigable — double vision worsens after sustained reading or driving and improves with brief rest — and he describes new neck weakness when lifting his head from a pillow. Over the past week he has had episodic nasal regurgitation and choking with thin liquids, raising concern for bulbar involvement. He denies ocular pain, headache, sensory loss, or limb paresthesias. Symptoms began shortly after a self-limited upper respiratory illness two weeks prior. He has a history of seasonal allergic rhinitis, is a nonheavy smoker, and notes no recent weight loss or fevers. He is concerned about a neuromuscular disorder given the fluctuating pattern.

A 21-year-old male reports a 10-day history of progressively worsening left-sided throbbing headache that began after an upper respiratory/sinus infection. Head pain is constant now, worse with Valsalva and leaning forward, and is accompanied by photophobia, nausea with intermittent vomiting, and brief blurred-vision episodes. In the last 48 hours he developed intermittent right arm paresthesias and a sense of neck stiffness; he also notes low-grade fevers and one episode of transient confusion. He denies prior migraine history, recent head trauma, or illicit drug use. Sleep is fragmented by severe morning pain, and over-the-counter analgesics provide minimal relief. He sought evaluation due to increasing neurologic symptoms and concern for an intracranial complication.

A 72-year-old woman presents with sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye that began abruptly this morning. Over the prior week she noted intermittent transient dimming of the same eye lasting minutes and a new, dull temporal headache with scalp tenderness and jaw pain when chewing. She denies eye redness, discharge, or trauma. Medical history is notable for long-standing hypertension and intermittent palpitations concerning for atrial fibrillation. Outside ophthalmoscopy was reportedly abnormal, and she was referred urgently for concern for central retinal artery occlusion. Given the constellation of amaurosis fugax, temporal headache, and jaw claudication, clinicians are worried about giant cell arteritis as an etiology versus an embolic event. She feels anxious but has no focal limb weakness.

A 57-year-old man presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and reduced exercise tolerance, now limiting him to short walks. He describes intermittent pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort and a nonproductive cough that this week produced scant blood-tinged sputum. He notes mild orthopnea and new right calf swelling that he attributed to a prior recent right lower-extremity DVT two months ago. Symptoms are worse with climbing stairs and accompanied by daytime fatigue and occasional lightheadedness on exertion. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history and a background of well-controlled hypertension. No fever or infectious symptoms. He denies recent travel other than a long car trip prior to the calf swelling. He is concerned because symptoms have progressed despite rest.

A 26-year-old woman presents with five days of progressive shortness of breath that began after a mild upper respiratory infection. She now reports sharp, pleuritic right-sided chest pain that worsens with deep inspiration and a single episode of scant hemoptysis. She endorses subjective fevers, drenching night sweats, and new limitation of exercise tolerance—previously she was very active. Over the past 48 hours she noticed a dull ache and mild swelling in her right calf. She has a history of intermittent childhood asthma and intermittent wheeze on exam at home, and uses nicotine-containing vaping products. No recent immobilization other than a long car ride last week. She is seeking evaluation for possible complication given progressive dyspnea and focal chest pain.

A 71-year-old female reports three months of progressive gait instability and declining short-term memory. She describes a broad-based, shuffling gait with frequent hesitations and two recent falls; family notes she repeats questions and has difficulty managing finances. Over the same period she developed new urinary urgency with occasional incontinence. A recent head CT from an outside facility reportedly shows ventriculomegaly. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes, with distal decreased vibration consistent with diabetic peripheral neuropathy that may worsen balance. Symptoms worsened after a minor trip last month but there is no fever or focal limb weakness. Clinical concern is for normal pressure hydrocephalus versus multifactorial gait impairment related to neuropathy and vascular disease.

An 85-year-old man presents with a three-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea and a dry cough that began after a mild upper respiratory illness. Over the past two nights he developed new palpitations and noticed the dyspnea at rest with orthopnea, requiring two pillows, and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea awakening him once nightly. Family reports increasing fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance. On exam he has bilateral pitting leg edema and bibasilar crackles at the lung bases. He has a background of hypertension and coronary artery disease. He denies chest pain or fever. Symptoms suggest decompensated heart failure, possibly precipitated by new-onset atrial fibrillation with associated exertional hypoxemia and fluid retention.

A 64-year-old man presents with a two-month history of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that began after a brief upper respiratory illness. He now becomes short of breath with climbing a single flight of stairs and notes intermittent sharp pleuritic right-sided chest pain. Over the past three weeks he has had scant streaks of hemoptysis and an unintentional 10-pound weight loss accompanied by low-grade fevers. He is a former 40-pack-year smoker and has obstructive sleep apnea treated with nightly therapy; he also carries a history of hypertension. He denies recent travel or known sick contacts. Symptoms have steadily limited activity, prompting concern for an underlying chronic pulmonary process and need for prompt imaging.

A 38-year-old male presents with ten days of progressive right-sided pleuritic chest pain and exertional dyspnea that began after a week of nasal congestion and sore throat. Pain is sharp, worsens with deep inspiration, and is accompanied by a dry cough and intermittent low-grade fevers. He notes new palpitations and brief lightheadedness when climbing stairs and a persistent reduction in exercise tolerance. Two weeks ago he had a long car trip and recalls transient swelling and tenderness of the right calf that resolved. He is a current smoker with no chronic lung disease. Symptoms cluster temporally, raising concern for a thromboembolic process versus postinfectious pleurisy; he seeks evaluation due to increasing shortness of breath and recurrent chest pain.

A 61-year-old male reports three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea with a new sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began acutely after a prolonged car ride. He has a productive cough with yellow sputum and intermittent low-grade fevers, and he notes unintentional weight loss and increasing fatigue. Past history is notable for hypertension and a prior provoked deep venous thrombosis. Over the past two days he developed swelling and aching in the right calf and more pronounced breathlessness with minimal exertion; he also experienced palpitations. At home he felt lightheaded and noticed worsening shortness of breath. On exam he describes focal right lower‑lung crackles and subjective hypoxemia. Symptoms are most concerning for pulmonary embolism with possible infarction or superimposed pneumonia.

A 56-year-old female reports progressive exertional dyspnea for ten days associated with new right-sided pleuritic chest pain and a persistent dry cough. Symptoms began about a week after a prolonged car trip; she developed mild unilateral calf swelling three days later and noted sudden worsening of breathlessness with minimal exertion. She had one episode of scant hemoptysis and intermittent low-grade fevers but denies sputum production or wheeze. She describes mild dependent ankle swelling and denies orthopnea. Past medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension and a 20-pack-year remote smoking history. She is concerned about a clot given the recent travel and calf swelling; no prior pulmonary disease or recent hospitalization.

A 94-year-old female presents with four days of progressively worsening dyspnea and a productive cough after a brief choking episode while eating. Family reports new low‑grade fevers and decreased appetite; at home she developed increased work of breathing and oxygen saturation in the mid‑80s on room air. Exam at bedside noted bibasilar crackles and coarse bronchial breath sounds. She has known moderate COPD and chronic systolic heart failure with prior paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and caregivers describe longstanding oropharyngeal dysphagia. The clinical picture is most consistent with aspiration-related infection and hypoxemic respiratory compromise superimposed on underlying cardiopulmonary disease; she denies chest pain or focal neurologic deficit but is notably more fatigued and less ambulatory than baseline.

A 49-year-old woman presents with a three-month history of persistent dry cough and progressive exertional dyspnea that began after a prolonged viral bronchitis. Cough is daily, worse with talking and exercise, often accompanied by throat clearing and salty-tasting postnasal drainage; she also describes intermittent acid regurgitation. Over the last four weeks she has noted wheeze on exertion and an episodic high-pitched inspiratory noise with a sensation of throat tightness consistent with paradoxical vocal fold motion. She reports one episode of scant hemoptysis but denies fever or weight loss. Activity tolerance has declined; she uses inhalers intermittently with limited benefit. Past history includes seasonal allergic rhinitis and a ten-pack-year remote smoking history. She is otherwise well and has no known occupational exposures.

A 41-year-old woman reports 10 days of progressively worse exertional dyspnea and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain, worse with deep inspiration. The pain began after a long-haul flight two weeks ago and is accompanied by a dry cough and two episodes of scant hemoptysis. She also noticed new right calf swelling and aching over the past week and has intermittent palpitations with mild lightheadedness on exertion. Past medical history significant for well-controlled hypertension and intermittent childhood asthma; she had a self-limited upper respiratory infection three weeks ago. No recent medication changes. Given the travel history, unilateral leg swelling, pleuritic pain and hemoptysis, there is concern for pulmonary embolism.

A 97-year-old woman with known COPD and hypertension presents with three days of progressive dyspnea and a productive cough. Family reports greenish sputum, subjective fevers and decreased appetite after a recent upper respiratory illness; she has required more frequent supplemental oxygen for increasing hypoxia. On arrival she is more lethargic than baseline with new confusion and reduced oral intake. Exam notable for diffuse expiratory wheeze and bibasilar crackles; caregivers describe mild peripheral edema but no chest pain. The picture is most consistent with an acute COPD exacerbation precipitated by community-acquired pneumonia with associated delirium and worsening oxygenation, prompting consideration of inpatient treatment and short-term respiratory support.

A 75-year-old woman reports a four-month history of progressive gait instability and subtle short-term memory decline. She describes a slow, shuffling, broad-based (“magnetic”) gait with two recent falls over the past month and increasing urinary urgency that progressed to occasional incontinence after a treated urinary tract infection two months ago. Family notes worsening apathy and episodic difficulty initiating steps. She has known lumbar spinal stenosis with intermittent neurogenic claudication that she feels worsens walking tolerance, and a longstanding history of hypertension. No chest pain or focal weakness is reported. Symptoms are insidious rather than acute, and she denies fever or delirium. The pattern raises concern for a mobility-cognitive-urinary syndrome such as normal-pressure hydrocephalus versus multifactorial gait impairment from stenosis.

A 6-year-old female is brought for three months of intermittent crampy periumbilical abdominal pain with increasing early satiety and several episodes of nonbloody loose stools. Parents note two postprandial vomiting episodes, progressive decrease in appetite, and slowing of weight and height gain compared with peers. She appears paler and more fatigued at school. Symptoms began after a viral upper respiratory illness but have persisted despite elimination of obvious triggers. History is notable for childhood atopic dermatitis and occasional mouth ulcers. No blood in stool, fevers, or urinary symptoms. Concern is for malabsorptive or inflammatory causes such as celiac disease or lactose intolerance, with possible iron-deficiency anemia contributing to lethargy, versus a functional abdominal pain disorder; outpatient GI evaluation and growth assessment are planned.

A 39-year-old male presents with three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and an intermittent productive cough that began after a presumed viral upper respiratory infection. The cough was initially dry but became green-tinged, with low-grade fevers and nightly wheeze. Over the past 48 hours he developed sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain and scant hemoptysis. He also reports new swelling and aching in the right calf after a long car trip two weeks ago. He is a 10 pack-year former smoker and has no prior cardiopulmonary disease. He denies intravenous drug use or recent surgery. Symptoms limit his usual exercise and have not improved with OTC cold remedies.

A 1-year-old female presents with three days of progressive cough and poor feeding. Symptoms began with clear rhinorrhea and a low-grade fever after a household contact with known RSV; over 48 hours the cough became more frequent with audible expiratory wheeze and intermittent worse coughing with feeds. Parents report two small episodes of non-bloody vomiting after meals and noticeably decreased breast- and bottle-feeding. At home she has had increased work of breathing with visible subcostal retractions and mild nasal flaring but no sustained cyanosis. No prior wheeze or hospitalizations. Exam today is concerning for viral bronchiolitis with reactive wheeze and possible reflux-associated aspiration contributing to feeding intolerance.

A 16-year-old female presents with three weeks of intermittent palpitations and near-syncope, most pronounced when standing or during the first minutes after exertion. Episodes are described as rapid, irregular heartbeats with associated lightheadedness, exertional dyspnea, and a sensation of chest tightness; symptoms improve when she lies down. She notes one episode of faint blurred vision but no true loss of consciousness. Symptoms began after a brief febrile viral illness and are now triggered by dehydration and prolonged standing at school. Past history notable for iron-deficiency anemia diagnosed last year and baseline anxiety, both managed conservatively. Home pulse recordings captured frequent premature ventricular contractions. No focal neurological deficits, cough, or fevers at present. She denies substance use.

A 23-year-old male reports progressive blurry vision in the right eye for ten days, described as decreased acuity and difficulty distinguishing colors, particularly red. Symptoms began shortly after a self-limited febrile upper respiratory illness three weeks ago and are associated with aching pain on eye movement and intermittent photopsias. He notes profound fatigue and a new heat sensitivity: vision transiently worsens after hot showers. Over the past three days he has developed brief paresthesias in the left foot and occasional neck discomfort when bending forward. He denies trauma, eye discharge, or systemic rash. On exam elsewhere he felt mild proximal leg weakness. He is most concerned about an evolving optic neuropathy; prior history is unremarkable and there is no current medication use.

A 29-year-old male presents with three days of pleuritic left-sided chest pain and progressive dyspnea on exertion. Pain is sharp, worse with deep inspiration, and began after a 10-hour flight six days ago; he also notes one episode of scant hemoptysis. He reports progressive tachycardia and mild fever but denies sputum production aside from prior rhinorrhea two weeks ago. He describes new swelling and tenderness of the left calf over the past four days. Past history is notable for exercise-induced asthma as a child and a remote ankle sprain; he denies bleeding disorders, recent surgery, or IV drug use. He smokes intermittently and attributes some anxiety to the shortness of breath.

A 92-year-old man presents with an eight-week history of progressive gait instability and worsening cognition, initially noted as slowed steps and difficulty initiating transfers. Family reports increasing urinary urgency with two episodes of incontinence and two low-energy falls over the past month. One week ago he had a 15-minute episode of slurred speech with transient right facial droop and confusion that resolved. He has known atrial fibrillation, and anticoagulation has been limited because of fall risk. On review he is more forgetful and less conversational than baseline. Concern centers on possible normal-pressure hydrocephalus contributing to gait apraxia and incontinence, with a superimposed embolic transient ischemic attack given his paroxysmal deficits.

A 58-year-old woman presents with six weeks of progressive proximal leg weakness and persistent aching in her shoulders and hips, now making it difficult to rise from a chair and climb stairs. Symptoms began after a mild upper respiratory illness and have been accompanied by intermittent low-grade fevers, unintentional 7-lb weight loss, and new difficulty swallowing solid foods. She recently noticed a violaceous rash on her upper eyelids and a scaly erythematous patch over the anterior chest. She reports mild exertional shortness of breath but no chest pain. Past medical history is notable only for well-controlled hypertension. She denies recent travel or new medications. Onset, symmetric proximal weakness, cutaneous findings, dysphagia, and respiratory symptoms raise concern for an inflammatory myopathy such as dermatomyositis with possible lung involvement.

An 8-year-old girl presents with a three-week history of persistent dry cough that began after a febrile viral upper respiratory infection. The cough is paroxysmal, worse at night, and provoked by exercise; parents note decreased tolerance for running and intermittent audible wheeze on exertion. There was transient low-grade fever the first few days but no choking or emesis. She also reports occasional chest tightness during play. Past history includes atopic dermatitis and seasonal allergic rhinitis. Home exposure to household tobacco smoke is reported. School staff administered an inhaled bronchodilator once with brief improvement. Primary concerns are ongoing reactive airway symptoms versus post-infectious small-airways disease.

An 86-year-old woman presents with ten days of progressive exertional dyspnea now occurring at rest, associated with two nights of orthopnea requiring two pillows and a dry cough. She describes new intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness beginning three days ago after treatment for a urinary tract infection; she also felt mildly febrile at home. Family notes increasing lower extremity swelling. On arrival she is hypoxic on room air and has an irregularly irregular tachycardia. Lung exam reveals bibasilar crackles without wheeze. She has no chest trauma, hemoptysis, or focal neurologic symptoms. Concern is for acute decompensated heart failure precipitated by new-onset atrial fibrillation versus infectious or thromboembolic pulmonary disease.

A 2-year-old female presents with a six-week history of progressive postprandial regurgitation and intermittent non-bloody vomiting associated with increasing feeding refusal and poor weight gain. Parents describe frequent arching of the back and irritability with meals, worsening since introduction of thicker solids, and fewer wet diapers over the past several days. She has a history of atopic dermatitis with perioral eczema and occasional noisy swallowing but no fever or respiratory distress. On exam she appears thin for age with dry mucous membranes. Working impression centers on gastroesophageal reflux disease with possible eosinophilic esophagitis or food protein–induced intolerance; structural obstruction is considered less likely. Plan includes feeding modification, hydration support, and expedited referral for pediatric gastroenterology and endoscopic evaluation.

A 15-year-old male reports a two-week history of progressive morning headaches following a soccer collision three weeks ago that caused a brief loss of consciousness and was labeled a concussion. Pain is pressure-like and worse with bending, coughing, and Valsalva; he rates it 6–8/10. Symptoms include transient visual obscurations, intermittent horizontal diplopia, pulsatile tinnitus, persistent nausea with one episode of emesis, and mild posterior neck stiffness. He denies fever, photophobia beyond increased light sensitivity during headaches, or focal limb weakness, but teachers have noted brief inattentive spells. Primary care documented bilateral optic disc swelling on fundoscopic exam. No prior migraine history, no recent infections, and no medication use. Family history noncontributory.

A 13-year-old male reports four days of progressive blurring in his right eye with aching retro-orbital pain that worsens on eye movement. He describes colors as faded and has difficulty focusing at school; his teacher noticed decreased reading performance and a possible central visual field defect. Symptoms began about two weeks after a febrile upper respiratory illness. He also has intermittent tingling in the fingertips of his left hand and occasional clumsiness with balance when running, along with increased fatigue limiting sports. There is no head trauma, vomiting, or known allergy exposure. Parents are most concerned about sudden vision loss; an inflammatory optic neuropathy such as optic neuritis is suspected and prompts urgent ophthalmology/neurology evaluation.

An 89-year-old male reports a two-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea with new right-sided pleuritic chest pain. He notes an increase in productive cough with yellow sputum and intermittent low-grade fevers since he had a recent minor fall and remained largely sedentary. He has a background of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and says his baseline exercise tolerance is markedly reduced. On presentation he was mildly hypoxemic and more tachypneic than usual. The temporal cluster—immobilization followed by worsening dyspnea, pleuritic pain, and sputum production—raises concern for a subacute pulmonary embolism, possibly with superimposed bronchitic infection complicating his underlying COPD. He denies syncope or frank hemoptysis.

A 39-year-old man reports three weeks of progressively worse exertional dyspnea and intermittent pleuritic right-sided chest pain. Symptoms began within days of a long transatlantic flight and an initial bronchitic upper respiratory illness; his cough became productive of yellow sputum and over the past week he has had occasional streaks of hemoptysis. He also notes low-grade fevers, night sweats, and an unintended seven-pound weight loss over the last month. He is a current smoker with roughly a 15 pack-year history. In the past five days he developed new right calf pain and swelling and has noticed palpitations with minimal exertion. He denies prior chronic lung disease or recent hospitalizations.

A 78-year-old man reports six months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a nonproductive cough that has accelerated over the past month. He now becomes breathless after walking one block and requires frequent rests; family notes an eight-pound unintentional weight loss. He denies fevers or purulent sputum. Past history includes well-controlled hypertension and remote shipyard work with possible asbestos exposure. He endorses chronic heartburn. Prior exam documented bibasilar “Velcro” crackles and new digital clubbing; ambulatory oximetry demonstrated significant desaturation with exertion. He has no orthopnea or peripheral edema. Clinical concern is for a fibrotic interstitial lung process as the primary cause of his declining exercise tolerance.

A 99-year-old male reports progressive dyspnea and a productive cough for the past seven days, beginning after an evening choking episode while eating. He describes yellow sputum, low-grade fevers and increased work of breathing with exertion; family noted new mild confusion and decreased oral intake. Baseline oropharyngeal dysphagia after a remote left hemispheric stroke limits swallowing and he has chronic COPD and long-standing hypertension. At home he tolerated only minimal fluids and developed intermittent oxygen desaturation, prompting presentation. On exam he notes coarse crackles in the right lower lung and increased respiratory rate. Concern is for aspiration pneumonia with hypoxemia on background COPD exacerbation; no chest pain, hemoptysis, or peripheral edema reported.

A 2-year-old male presents with three days of worsening cough and noisy breathing after a household upper respiratory infection. Symptoms began as clear rhinorrhea and low-grade fever, progressing to persistent daytime cough, intermittent wheeze, and increased work of breathing over 48 hours. At home he has had tachypnea with noticeable intercostal and subcostal retractions and has taken fewer bottles with one episode of nonbilious emesis. On exam he is irritable with scattered expiratory wheeze and mild crackles; oxygen saturations have been intermittently low on room air. Parents report a similar bronchiolitis hospitalization as an infant and a history of eczema. They deny choking events or rash changes. Concerns include viral bronchiolitis with reactive airways and mild dehydration.

A 92-year-old female reports an eight-week history of progressive gait instability with three unwitnessed falls. Family notes increasing urinary urgency with daytime incontinence and subtle cognitive slowing—worse word finding and difficulty with multitasking. She describes brief episodes of slurred speech and transient right-hand clumsiness lasting minutes, and occasional lightheadedness on standing. She had a treated urinary tract infection two weeks ago. Past medical history significant for longstanding hypertension and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, with prior presyncopal episodes. At baseline she remains independent with limited ambulation. Concerns center on possible normal pressure hydrocephalus versus recurrent transient ischemic events or chronic small-vessel ischemic change as contributors to the triad of gait disturbance, dementia-like symptoms, and urinary dysfunction. Further outpatient evaluation planned.

A 10-year-old male is brought for a 10-day history of progressive daily morning headache and intermittent non-bloody emesis, worse over the past 48 hours. Symptoms began after a febrile upper respiratory illness two weeks ago and have evolved to include intermittent blurred vision and brief diplopia, sensitivity to light, and increasing clumsiness with unsteady gait and two recent falls. Parents report new lethargy and decreased appetite but no loss of consciousness or seizure activity. On review, he has mild neck stiffness and occasional horizontal eye movements described as "jittery" by his parents. No prior neurologic problems, no recent head trauma, and vaccinations are up to date. Differential considerations include postinfectious cerebellitis versus intracranial process causing increased intracranial pressure.

A 53-year-old female reports two weeks of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain. Symptoms began shortly after a prolonged flight three weeks ago and are accompanied by a dry cough, intermittent wheeze, and low‑grade fevers with night sweats; she denies hemoptysis. She notes intermittent right calf swelling over the past month and a 6‑pound unintended weight loss. Exercise tolerance has declined from walking one mile to only a few blocks without breathlessness. She has a history of hypertension and hypothyroidism and is otherwise independent in activities of daily living. No recent upper respiratory infection is recalled. The overall picture is concerning for a thromboembolic event versus evolving focal pulmonary inflammatory process, prompting further diagnostic evaluation.

A 59-year-old female presents with a 36-hour history of intermittent right-sided weakness and slurred speech that has evolved into persistent mild expressive aphasia. The deficits began as brief right arm clumsiness over three days and worsened following an episode of palpitations. She reports a prior event last month of transient monocular vision loss in the right eye lasting ten minutes. Past medical history notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia; she endorses intermittent palpitations concerning for paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and is not anticoagulated. She denies recent head trauma or infection. Prior outpatient exam documented a left carotid bruit. The temporal clustering of transient visual loss, focal neurologic deficits, and palpitations raises concern for cardioembolic TIA versus evolving ischemic stroke.

A 92-year-old female reports ten days of progressive loss of vision in the right eye, describing gradual darkening and blurred central vision with intermittent flashes and new floaters. Two weeks before visual change she developed a persistent, unilateral temporal headache with scalp tenderness and episodic jaw claudication that limits chewing. She notes low-grade fevers, fatigue, and new morning stiffness and aching in both shoulders, which she attributes to longstanding osteoarthritis but says feels different. She denies trauma, eye discharge, or prior recent ocular infection; she has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Family helped her seek care after she could no longer read and developed slight difficulty navigating steps on the affected side.

A 22-year-old female reports two months of intermittent palpitations and progressive lightheadedness. Palpitations are rapid and occasionally irregular, most prominent within minutes of standing and during mild exertion, frequently accompanied by near-syncope and brief presyncopal episodes. She describes marked exercise intolerance, persistent fatigue affecting daily activities, and new heat intolerance with increased sweating. Episodes typically improve when she lies down. Symptoms began several weeks after a febrile viral illness she recalls as infectious mononucleosis. She has a history of generalized anxiety that she feels has worsened with these symptoms but denies chest pain, syncope with injury, focal neurologic deficits, or shortness of breath at rest. The clinical picture is suggestive of orthostatic tachycardia and autonomic dysfunction prompting further cardiovascular and autonomic evaluation.

An 81-year-old woman reports two weeks of progressive central vision loss in the right eye with sudden further decline two days ago; she describes a new central scotoma and blurring rather than pain. Over the past week she developed a dull temporal headache, scalp tenderness when combing her hair, and intermittent jaw claudication with chewing. She also notes morning shoulder stiffness and stiffness rising from chairs consistent with polymyalgia rheumatica, plus low-grade fevers and malaise. Her primary care clinician documented a right relative afferent pupillary defect and ordered inflammatory markers, which were elevated. She has chronic hypertension controlled on therapy. Clinical picture is most consistent with giant cell arteritis with suspected arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy, prompting urgent referral for treatment and definitive evaluation.

A 90-year-old male presents with three weeks of progressive shortness of breath and a productive cough. Symptoms began after several episodes of choking with liquids; he has longstanding oropharyngeal dysphagia following a prior ischemic stroke and reports recurrent aspiration. Cough is worse at night and associated with low-grade fevers, decreased appetite, and a seven-pound weight loss. Over the past five days he notes increased resting dyspnea and requires intermittent supplemental oxygen at home. On exam he endorses clear sputum turning thicker, and caregivers describe noisy swallowing and drooling. On auscultation there are new bibasilar crackles and occasional wheeze. No chest pain or peripheral edema is reported. He remains alert but more fatigued with exertion.

A 69-year-old female presents with two months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a chronic productive cough that has recently increased in volume and purulence. Over the past week she developed intermittent streaks of hemoptysis and audible wheeze, worse with exertion. Three weeks ago she had a self-limited upper respiratory illness after which symptoms failed to resolve. In the last five days she complains of sharp, pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort and new right calf swelling and tenderness, raising concern for deep venous thrombosis with possible pulmonary embolism. She is a former smoker with a remote 35–pack-year history, and the clinical picture suggests underlying COPD with superimposed bronchiectasis as contributors to recurrent sputum production and hemoptysis. No fevers, weight loss, or recent travel.

A 61-year-old man presents with five days of progressive exertional dyspnea and new pleuritic right-sided chest pain. He describes scant hemoptysis and orthopnea compared with his baseline COPD-related shortness of breath; symptoms began after a week of limited ambulation following an ankle sprain. He notes new right calf swelling and tenderness and reports a 40 pack-year smoking history and long-standing hypertension. On review, he endorses palpitations and marked fatigue, and his partner observed more pronounced diaphoresis with minimal exertion. He denies fever or recent travel. The temporal pattern—immobilization then unilateral leg swelling followed by acute respiratory worsening—raises concern for venous thromboembolism with possible pulmonary embolism on a background of chronic obstructive lung disease.

A 77-year-old male presents with a three-month history of progressive gait instability and cognitive slowing. He describes shuffling, small-stepped gait and several near-falls while turning; family reports worsening word-finding difficulty and apathy. Over the past month he developed urinary urgency with nocturia and one episode of urinary incontinence. He notes intermittent lightheadedness and presyncope on standing, with one brief syncopal spell this week. Outpatient head CT showed ventriculomegaly with mild periventricular white-matter change, raising concern for normal-pressure hydrocephalus versus chronic small-vessel ischemic disease. Past medical history notable for hypertension; no recent head trauma or new focal weakness. Symptoms have gradually limited his mobility and prompted today's evaluation.

A 10-year-old boy presents with two weeks of progressive proximal muscle weakness and a violaceous periorbital rash. Parents note he now needs his hands to push up from a chair, struggles to climb stairs, and has dropped his school backpack twice. The rash includes scaly papules over the knuckles and extensor forearms. Symptoms followed a febrile upper respiratory illness a week earlier and have been accompanied by low-grade fevers, pronounced morning fatigue, and intermittent dysphagia with occasional coughing on liquids. He has become less active and lost a few pounds. Exam findings and the pattern of weakness with heliotrope and Gottron-like lesions are concerning for an inflammatory myopathy such as juvenile dermatomyositis, with parents also noting a small tender subcutaneous nodule suggestive of early calcinosis.

An 85-year-old woman presents with progressive dyspnea and increased sputum production over three weeks, acutely worse over the past five days after a choking episode while eating. She describes purulent, foul-smelling sputum and subjective fevers with decreased appetite; family notes new confusion and slower ambulation. She has a history of bronchiectasis and hypertension. On review, she reports orthopnea is absent but now becomes breathless at rest and with minimal exertion. At home she has noted lower baseline exercise tolerance and intermittent wheeze. Today she appears more hypoxemic than usual with increased respiratory rate and basilar crackles on exam, raising concern for aspiration pneumonia complicating chronic bronchiectasis; differential also includes an acute exacerbation or superimposed infection.

A 71-year-old female reports two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea with a sudden increase in shortness of breath and new pleuritic right-sided chest pain over the past 48 hours. She notes a three-day history of mild cough with scant sputum and a painful swollen right calf after a long car trip two weeks prior. In clinic she is tachycardic and mildly hypoxemic on room air. Past medical history is notable for COPD and well-controlled hypertension. She denies fevers or hemoptysis but feels more fatigued and lightheaded with exertion. The temporal pattern and unilateral leg swelling raise concern for deep venous thrombosis with possible pulmonary embolism precipitating acute decompensation on chronic lung disease.

A 39-year-old woman presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a dry cough that acutely worsened over the past 48 hours with new pleuritic right-sided chest pain and a single scant episode of hemoptysis. She describes intermittent wheeze and audible breathlessness climbing stairs, and notes one-sided calf swelling and tenderness for three days. Symptoms began after a self-limited upper respiratory infection and she has a history of mild childhood asthma. She is otherwise active, currently on combined oral contraception, and denies recent travel. She reports occasional lightheadedness with exertion and subjective oxygen desaturation at times. The clinical picture is concerning for thromboembolic disease with secondary pulmonary parenchymal irritation.

A 48-year-old man presents with three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and intermittent right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began after a prolonged car trip four weeks ago. Pain is sharp, worse with deep inspiration, and has been accompanied by small-volume hemoptysis and episodic palpitations and lightheadedness on exertion. He notes a week of mild unilateral calf aching and recent lower-extremity swelling. Chronic morning cough and exertional wheeze have persisted for years since a 20 pack-year smoking history. He has well-controlled hypertension. He reports loud snoring with daytime somnolence suggestive of sleep-disordered breathing. He denies fever, rhinorrhea, or weight loss. Symptoms raise concern for acute thromboembolic disease on a background of chronic airway disease.

A 31-year-old female presents with three weeks of progressive neurologic symptoms beginning with subacute blurred vision in the left eye accompanied by pain with eye movement. One week after the visual symptoms she developed intermittent right-sided paresthesia involving arm and leg and a brief electric shock sensation down the spine when she flexes her neck. Over the past ten days she reports new mild gait instability, increased fatigue, and urinary urgency without dysuria. Symptoms began after a self-limited upper respiratory illness; she denies trauma, fever, or recent travel. On review, she notes occasional transient double vision and worse imbalance on uneven surfaces. No prior neurologic history; family history noncontributory. She seeks evaluation for progressive focal neurologic deficits.

An 85-year-old woman presents with six months of progressive balance decline and recurrent falls described as brief episodes of her feet “sticking” to the floor. Family reports slow walking with short, shuffling steps and difficulty initiating gait; she now needs a walker indoors. She has noticed worsening short-term memory and slowed thinking, with episodes of urinary urgency and two occasions of urge incontinence. Symptoms began after a minor head bump last year but progressed gradually rather than acutely. Examination at home noted increased lower-extremity stiffness and brisk reflexes. Past medical history includes long-standing hypertension and mild osteoarthritis of the knees. No fever, limb numbness, or new focal vision loss. Family is concerned about increasing dependence and cognition.

A 73-year-old female reports progressive gait instability for two months with two recent unwitnessed falls. She describes a slow, shuffling, magnetic-appearing gait with difficulty initiating steps and frequent near-falls when turning. Over the same interval family notes worsening short-term memory, slowed thinking and new apathy affecting medication management. She also endorses urinary urgency with occasional daytime incontinence. Noncontrast head CT performed in the ED last week demonstrated ventriculomegaly out of proportion to cortical atrophy. Past medical history notable for long-standing hypertension and knee osteoarthritis limiting exercise. She denies headache, focal weakness, sensory loss, fever, or recent infection. Symptoms are insidious and progressive, raising concern for a gait disorder such as normal-pressure hydrocephalus versus multifactorial mobility decline.

A 53-year-old female presents with a three-month history of progressive epigastric pain and early satiety, now accompanied by intermittent postprandial vomiting and increasing difficulty swallowing solid foods. Pain is described as gnawing and worse with larger meals; she notes new nocturnal heartburn and occasional tarry stools. Over the same interval she has had unintentional weight loss of about 10–15 pounds and worsening fatigue consistent with iron-deficiency anemia. She denies fevers or overt hematemesis and has minimal alcohol intake. Prior conservative management for dyspepsia provided only transient relief. The constellation of obstructive symptoms, melena, weight loss, and anemia raises concern for gastric outlet obstruction or an underlying gastric neoplasm, and she seeks endoscopic evaluation.

A 32-year-old man presents with abrupt right-sided pleuritic chest pain and worsening shortness of breath that began 24 hours ago. Pain is sharp, worse with deep inspiration, and limits his ability to climb stairs; he also notes palpitations and exertional dyspnea that are new. Two weeks of a persistent dry cough followed a viral upper respiratory illness, and he had a single episode of scant blood-tinged sputum yesterday. He reports intermittent wheeze with exertion and reduced exercise tolerance over the past month. He returned from a long-haul flight five days ago. Past history is notable only for mild childhood asthma; he denies chronic tobacco use. He has had low-grade fevers intermittently and is concerned about possible clot or pneumonia.

A 60-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and known obstructive sleep apnea presents with ten days of progressive exertional dyspnea and increased productive cough. Two days ago he developed sudden left-sided pleuritic chest pain and scant hemoptysis, associated with palpitations and shortness of breath at rest. He returned from a prolonged car trip two weeks ago and notes new left calf swelling and tenderness since then. He denies fever but reports darker sputum and decreased exercise tolerance compared with baseline. Onset was gradual for cough but abrupt for chest pain and hemoptysis, raising concern for thromboembolic disease superimposed on COPD exacerbation with possible hypoxemia and tachyarrhythmia.

A 59-year-old woman presents with ten days of progressive exertional dyspnea that began after a brief upper respiratory infection. She now reports persistent productive cough with green sputum, intermittent pleuritic right-sided chest pain, and low-grade fevers. Shortness of breath is worse with exertion and when lying flat; she notes one recent episode of waking breathless at night. Over the past week she developed new bilateral ankle swelling and mild fatigue. Past medical history notable for long-standing hypertension and a 40-pack-year smoking history (quit five years ago). No recent travel or immobilization. She denies hemoptysis but feels more breathless than with prior bronchitis episodes, prompting evaluation for possible pneumonia, heart failure exacerbation, or thromboembolic complication.

A 19-year-old male presents with acute right-sided pleuritic chest pain and progressive shortness of breath that began abruptly four hours ago during pickup basketball after an episode of forceful coughing. Pain is sharp, worse with inspiration, and associated with a dry cough and a single episode of scant hemoptysis. He notes background intermittent wheeze with exertion treated with an albuterol inhaler and regular vaping of nicotine and cannabis. He describes being tall and thin with no prior hospitalizations. On self-exam he noticed right-sided crepitus under the clavicle overnight. Symptoms followed a week of nasal congestion and sore throat. He denies fever, recent travel, or trauma.
