Concerned for a spontaneous pneumothorax with right-sided decreased breath sounds and possible subcutaneous emphysema.

A 96-year-old man presents with ten days of progressively worsening dyspnea and new pleuritic right-sided chest pain. Symptoms began after a recent urinary infection that limited his mobility; family noted right calf swelling and increased fatigue five days ago. He reports a dry cough, exertional oxygen desaturation now prompting supplemental oxygen at home, and a low-grade fevers with intermittent confusion. Past pulmonary history includes COPD; he also has paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. He denies significant sputum production or recent travel. Onset and progression suggest possible acute pulmonary embolism from a suspected deep venous thrombosis with superimposed acute hypoxemic respiratory failure on chronic lung disease; pneumonia and aspiration are considered in the differential.

A 31-year-old man presents with a four-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that began after an upper respiratory illness. He reports intermittent scant hemoptysis over the past week and pleuritic right-sided chest pain with deep inspiration. He notes low‑grade fevers, drenching night sweats, and an unintended 6‑kg weight loss since symptoms started, with markedly reduced exercise tolerance and early fatigue climbing stairs. He is a current smoker with no known cardiopulmonary disease but was treated for presumed community-acquired pneumonia two months ago with transient improvement. There is no recent travel or known sick contacts. He is concerned the cough is worsening and seeks evaluation because of the bleeding and progressive shortness of breath.

A 22-year-old man presents with four days of progressive left eye pain and blurred vision that began after an evening of extended contact lens wear. He notes increasing photophobia, a thick mucopurulent discharge, and mild periorbital swelling; the pain is sharp and wakes him at night. Symptoms followed a freshwater lake swim about one week earlier. On attempted self-cleaning his vision worsened rather than improved. He denies systemic fever or recent trauma. Urgent care documented marked conjunctival injection and a central corneal opacity with an epithelial defect concerning for contact lens–associated keratitis or corneal ulcer; given the water exposure and severe pain out of proportion to exam there is additional concern for Acanthamoeba infection. Past ocular history notable only for nightly soft contact lens use and seasonal allergic rhinitis.

A 95-year-old female presents with a three-month history of progressive gait instability and cognitive slowing. Family describes a magnetic, short-stepped gait with two falls in the past month and increasing need for assistance with transfers. Over the same period she has developed new urinary urgency progressing to occasional incontinence. Caregiver notes subtle memory loss, slowed speech, and difficulty with executive tasks rather than focal weakness. She reports intermittent frontal headaches and worsening imbalance when turning. Past history is notable for well-controlled hypertension and chronic osteoarthritis limiting mobility at baseline. No fevers or sensory changes. She had a minor head bump two weeks ago without loss of consciousness. Symptoms have insidiously worsened, prompting evaluation for possible normal pressure hydrocephalus or other structural cause.

A 29-year-old man presents with five days of progressive right periorbital pain and horizontal diplopia that began after a week of purulent nasal congestion consistent with sinusitis. Pain is constant, worse with eye movement, and accompanied by a throbbing frontal headache and low-grade fever. He reports eyelid droop and visible redness of the conjunctiva on the right; exam notes mild proptosis and limitation of adduction and upward gaze suggestive of ophthalmoplegia. Vision is subjectively blurred on the affected side. No recent trauma. Past history includes seasonal allergic rhinitis. Symptoms evolved rapidly over several days, raising concern for an infectious complication extending from the sinuses to the cavernous sinus or adjacent soft tissues, prompting urgent evaluation.

An 81-year-old female presents with two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent nonproductive cough, acutely worsened over the past 48 hours by new right-sided pleuritic chest pain and scant hemoptysis. She notes decreased exercise tolerance and orthopnea compared with baseline, and reports a long automobile trip three weeks ago. On exam she has mild right calf swelling and increased work of breathing; oxygen saturation falls with minimal exertion. Past history includes COPD and hypertension but no recent infections. The temporal clustering of calf swelling, pleuritic pain, exertional desaturation, and hemoptysis raises concern for a pulmonary embolic event with associated hypoxemia; alternative considerations include COPD exacerbation or pulmonary infarction.

An 84-year-old male reports progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough over the past three months, with notable worsening after a chest infection three weeks ago. He now tires after walking a block and has occasional resting dyspnea; family noticed weight loss and decreased appetite. Exam previously documented bibasilar inspiratory "velcro" crackles and mild digital clubbing; ambulatory pulse oximetry shows desaturation to the mid-80s with exertion. Prior high-resolution CT described basal-predominant reticulation and traction bronchiectasis suggestive of fibrosing interstitial lung disease, most consistent with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Past history includes hypertension and chronic gastroesophageal reflux, the latter reportedly worse at night. He denies wheeze, hemoptysis, or recent tobacco use.

A 95-year-old female reports five days of progressively worsening dyspnea and productive cough with low-grade fevers and chills. Symptoms began after an episode of choking on liquids; she notes persistent oropharyngeal dysphagia since a prior left hemispheric stroke. Cough is thick, yellowish and worse when supine, and she now requires more assistance with activities of daily living. Background includes COPD, chronic atrial fibrillation, and hypertension. On review she complains of fatigue and decreased appetite; family notes recent unintentional weight loss and increased confusion. At home she has intermittent episodes of breathlessness at rest and appears more tachypneic than baseline. Concern is for aspiration-related pneumonia with hypoxemia on home pulse oximetry and possible COPD exacerbation.

A 50-year-old man presents with progressive exertional dyspnea and a chronic productive cough that has gradually worsened over several years, with a 10-day exacerbation after a presumed upper respiratory infection. He notes increased purulent sputum, intermittent streaks of blood, low-grade fevers, and an unintentional 10-pound weight loss over three months. He reports recurrent respiratory infections requiring outpatient antibiotics in the past and has recently observed new finger clubbing and markedly reduced exercise tolerance. He has a history of hypertension. He denies chest pain or orthopnea. Given the chronic purulence, recurrent infections, hemoptysis, and clubbing, he is concerned about underlying bronchiectasis or another structural lung disease.

A 94-year-old female presents with three days of progressive dyspnea and a dry cough. Dyspnea began at rest and worsens with minimal exertion; she reports new pleuritic right-sided chest tightness and intermittent low-grade fever. Family notes recent left calf swelling and pain after a week of reduced mobility following a minor fall. On evaluation she has oxygen desaturation and resting tachycardia with an irregularly irregular pulse concerning for new atrial fibrillation. Exam notable for diminished breath sounds at the right base and mild bilateral crackles with pitting ankle edema. Past medical history includes COPD and hypertension. She denies chest pain of ischemic character, but the temporal pattern raises concern for pulmonary embolism complicating chronic lung disease.

A 49-year-old man reports five days of progressive right-eye vision loss that began with a sudden shower of floaters and intermittent flashes and has evolved into a curtain-like peripheral shadow over 48 hours. He describes increasing central blurring and difficulty distinguishing red tones in the affected eye, with transient photophobia and a dull periorbital ache and occasional frontal headache but no focal weakness or nausea. Vision is sufficiently impaired to limit reading and driving. His ocular history includes high myopia; medical history notable for diet-controlled type 2 diabetes. He denies recent trauma or prior retinal surgery. Symptoms have steadily worsened, and he is concerned about possible retinal detachment.

A 60-year-old female reports a four-week history of progressive proximal stiffness and aching primarily in the shoulder and hip girdles. Pain is worst in the morning, with prolonged stiffness lasting more than an hour and marked difficulty rising from a chair or dressing; she notes some improvement with gentle activity. Associated symptoms include low-grade fevers, fatigue, and intermittent myalgic tenderness around the shoulders. Over the past three days she developed a new, persistent temporal headache and brief episodes of jaw claudication when chewing. She denies focal limb weakness or sensory loss but describes occasional neck stiffness. No recent infection or travel. Symptoms began insidiously and have substantially limited daily activities, prompting evaluation for an inflammatory myopathy or polymyalgia rheumatica with possible cranial arteritis.

A 30-year-old woman presents with ten days of progressive exertional dyspnea and sharp, right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began after a self-limited upper respiratory infection two weeks ago. She describes a dry cough with two episodes of scant hemoptysis and intermittent palpitations with a near-syncopal spell while climbing stairs. She also notes new swelling and tenderness of the left calf over the past five days. She uses combined oral contraceptives and has no recent long-distance travel or surgeries. She reports a history of mild intermittent asthma as a child but no chronic cardiopulmonary disease. No fever, rash, or alcohol use. Symptoms have worsened despite rest, raising concern for thromboembolic disease with possible pulmonary infarction.

A 15-year-old male reports a two-week history of progressively worse morning headaches, described as pressure-like and worse when lying flat. Headaches are now accompanied by intermittent nausea and two episodes of nonbloody vomiting. Over the past 48 hours he developed horizontal double vision and intermittent blurred vision, particularly with lateral gaze, and has noticed intermittent neck stiffness. Parents noted a transient inability of the right eye to abduct yesterday. He had a self-limited sinus infection three weeks ago treated conservatively. No recent head trauma, fever, or loss of consciousness. He has missed school due to symptoms and over-the-counter analgesics provide minimal relief. Review of systems otherwise notable only for mild fatigue.

A 10-year-old female presents with a three-day history of worsening cough and audible wheeze following a five-day viral upper respiratory infection. Her mother reports progressive shortness of breath with running and climbing, frequent nocturnal cough awakening her twice nightly, and chest tightness described as pressure with exertion. She has a history of intermittent asthma diagnosed at age six, exercise-induced bronchospasm, and allergic rhinitis with seasonal nasal congestion; parents also note atopic dermatitis since infancy. Today she has low-grade fever and reduced activity tolerance but no ear pain or vomiting. Onset was gradual after the URI, with clear sputum and increased use of rescue inhaler at home without sustained relief. There is no known sick contact with pertussis or recent travel.

A 66-year-old man presents with progressive exertional dyspnea for three months with marked worsening over the past two weeks after a presumed viral upper respiratory infection. He describes a persistent dry cough, early fatigue with climbing stairs, and a two-kilogram unintentional weight loss. On exam he notes finger clubbing and reports new exertional oxygen desaturation that required short periods of supplemental oxygen at home. He denies chest pain or hemoptysis. Prior chest radiograph months ago reportedly showed interstitial markings. He is a former 30 pack-year smoker who quit a decade ago and has a history of well-controlled hypertension. Clinical concern is for underlying idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis with possible postinfectious exacerbation and evolving pulmonary hypertension.

A 47-year-old woman reports a three-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent nonproductive cough that began after a self-limited upper respiratory illness. She describes intermittent right-sided pleuritic chest pain and two episodes of scant hemoptysis over the past week. Associated symptoms include low-grade fevers and a noticeable decline in exercise tolerance; she has felt paler and more fatigued than usual. Symptoms acutely worsened after a recent transcontinental flight, prompting concern for thromboembolic disease. Past medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension and adult-onset asthma; she is a former smoker with a 10 pack-year history, quit five years ago. She denies leg swelling, syncope, or night sweats.

A 63-year-old woman reports progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough for the past two months, with a sharper decline over the last two weeks. She notes low-grade fevers, unintentional 4-kg weight loss, and early satiety from limited activity. She becomes breathless after climbing one flight of stairs and denies chest pain or hemoptysis. Past medical history is notable for seropositive rheumatoid arthritis and well-controlled hypertension; she has a 30–pack-year smoking history, quit five years ago. On exam she reports fatigue and the clinician noted fine inspiratory "velcro" crackles at both bases and subtle digital clubbing. Concern is for rheumatoid-associated interstitial lung disease versus subacute infection or progressive fibrosing ILD.

A 48-year-old woman reports abrupt onset of right-sided neck pain and a severe occipital headache two days ago after a vigorous neck stretch during a yoga class. Within an hour she experienced transient right monocular vision loss for about ten minutes followed by left arm weakness and slurred speech that resolved over 20–30 minutes. Since then she has had persistent dull right neck pain, intermittent lightheadedness, and new right eyelid droop with a slightly smaller pupil. She denies fever, recent infections, or anticoagulant use. Past history is notable for migraine with visual aura. Given the temporal association with neck movement, transient focal neurologic deficits, ipsilateral ocular ischemia, and Horner-like signs, carotid artery dissection with transient ischemic events is suspected.

A 46-year-old man reports three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain, worse with deep inspiration and coughing. He describes a productive cough with occasional blood-tinged sputum, intermittent low-grade fevers, and an unintentional eight-pound weight loss accompanied by night sweats. Symptoms began insidiously after a long transcontinental flight six weeks ago; he notes decreased exercise tolerance and a single episode of mild calf soreness but denies persistent leg swelling. He has no known chronic lung disease and a remote 10–pack-year smoking history. Clinic chest radiograph demonstrated a right upper‑lobe opacity. The constellation raises concern for pulmonary embolism versus focal pneumonia or underlying malignancy, and further imaging and sputum studies were requested.

A 44-year-old woman presents with two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began acutely after a prolonged nine-hour flight. The pain is sharp, worse with deep inspiration, and associated with a persistent dry cough and two episodes of scant hemoptysis. She also describes intermittent palpitations, lightheadedness on exertion, and a 4–5 day history of swelling and aching behind the right calf. She has a history of well-controlled hypertension and intermittent atopic asthma managed infrequently with inhaler use. No fevers until low-grade chills began three days ago. She denies recent trauma. Concerned about possible deep venous thrombosis with embolic complication; symptoms have limited her walking and sleep.

An 8-year-old girl presents with a 36-hour history of intermittent, colicky periumbilical pain now localizing to the right lower quadrant. Pain occurs in 5–10 minute spasms during which she draws up her legs and appears pale; between episodes she is sleepy and less interactive. Associated symptoms include nausea, two episodes of nonbilious vomiting, decreased oral intake, and one small mucoid, bloody stool. Mother measured a low-grade fever at home. Symptoms began three days after a brief upper respiratory illness with rhinorrhea. Past history is otherwise unremarkable. Examination at home was notable for pallor during pain episodes. There is concern for an obstructive process such as intussusception given migratory colicky pain, episodic lethargy, vomiting, and bloody stool.

A 58-year-old woman presents with ten days of progressive exertional dyspnea and sharp, pleuritic left-sided chest pain that began after a prolonged airplane trip. Pain is worse with deep inspiration and cough; she describes intermittent palpitations and mild lightheadedness. Over the past week she has noted a dry cough with two small blood-tinged sputum streaks and persistent left calf swelling with tenderness, which she attributes to the same period of inactivity. At rest she feels mildly short of breath and reports episodic tachycardia. She has a history of well-controlled hypertension but no prior lung disease. There is concern for an acute thromboembolic event given the recent immobilization, calf findings, pleuritic pain, hemoptysis, and new hypoxemic symptoms.

A 49-year-old man presents with a six-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea and intermittent pleuritic right-sided chest pain. He has had a persistent dry cough that over the past two weeks produced scant blood-tinged sputum on one occasion, and reports night sweats with an unintentional ten-pound weight loss. Exercise tolerance has declined significantly — he can no longer climb a flight of stairs without stopping. He is a current smoker with a 30 pack-year history. He denies fevers or recent travel. On self-exam he notes decreased breath sounds on the right and occasional shortness of breath at rest. No known history of chronic lung disease or heart failure.

A 5-week-old female presents with a two-week history of progressive, projectile, nonbilious vomiting and poor oral intake. Initially mild reflux after feeds became forceful vomiting occurring immediately postprandially and interrupting feeds; she has fewer wet diapers and diminished stooling over three days. Parents report poor weight gain and increasing irritability; on exam she appears dry with decreased urine output. Notably caregivers observed visible gastric peristaltic waves across the upper abdomen and a firm, mobile 1–2 cm olive-shaped mass in the RUQ. Birth course included brief physiologic jaundice resolved by week two. No fever or bloody stools. Concern for hypertrophic pyloric stenosis with secondary dehydration and failure to thrive; plan for confirmatory ultrasound and fluid resuscitation.

A 66-year-old man presents with acute right-sided weakness and slurred speech that began 36 hours ago and worsened over the first 12 hours. Initially he noted subtle right-hand clumsiness and numbness, now with a right facial droop and mild dysphagia when swallowing solids. He reports new intermittent palpitations over the past week and has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia; he is not anticoagulated. On exam he has decreased strength (3/5) in the right arm and leg with impaired coordination and an unsteady gait. No headache, fever, or chest pain. Carotid bruit was noted on bedside auscultation. Symptoms are most consistent with an embolic left hemispheric ischemic stroke, possibly related to paroxysmal atrial fibrillation or carotid disease.

A 40-year-old woman reports sudden-onset, severe spinning vertigo beginning 48 hours ago, persistent and worse with head movement. Symptoms are accompanied by nausea with two episodes of emesis and marked gait instability requiring support to ambulate. She noticed horizontal nystagmus on self-observation and describes intermittent oscillopsia but denies hearing loss or tinnitus. There has been no slurred speech, focal limb weakness, or recent head trauma. She recalls a week-long upper respiratory infection about ten days before onset. Past medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension and episodic migraine without aura. She is concerned this could represent vestibular neuritis versus a posterior circulation event given the abrupt course; she has not had fever, ear pain, or documented stroke previously.

A 50-year-old male reports three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea with a daily productive cough and recent pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort. Over the past five days he has had two small episodes of hemoptysis and notes persistent right calf tightness and swelling that began after a prolonged car trip two weeks ago. He describes intermittent wheeze at night and has known obstructive sleep apnea treated with airway therapy; he is a former 25–pack-year smoker who quit five years ago and has a history of hypertension. He denies fever or weight loss. The temporal cluster of travel-associated calf swelling, new hemoptysis, and worsening dyspnea raises concern for subacute pulmonary embolism versus an alternative pulmonary process.

An 18-year-old female reports a three-week history of progressive daily morning headaches. Pain is diffuse and pressure-like, worse with coughing or bending, and associated with intermittent blurred vision and episodic pulsatile tinnitus. Over the last two days she has noticed binocular horizontal diplopia with lateral gaze and persistent mild nausea without vomiting. She denies fever, neck stiffness, or prior migraine history. She reports approximately 25-pound weight gain over the past six months. An outpatient eye exam last week reportedly showed bilateral optic disc swelling. No recent head trauma, sinus infection, or new medications. She is concerned about worsening vision given the combination of morning headache, visual obscurations, pulsatile tinnitus, and papilledema.

An 81-year-old woman reports progressive right monocular visual blurring over the past week that progressed to a dense central vision loss this morning. Over the preceding two weeks she has experienced new-onset right temporal headache and focal scalp tenderness, with eating-related jaw claudication. She also describes marked morning shoulder stiffness consistent with polymyalgia symptoms and intermittent low-grade fevers. Her review is otherwise notable for a modest unintentional weight loss over several weeks. She has a history of long-standing hypertension. She denies recent trauma, ocular discharge, or marked photophobia. Symptoms evolved insidiously and she is anxious about possible permanent vision impairment, prompting urgent assessment.

A 17-year-old male reports sudden onset of sharp, right-sided pleuritic chest pain and acute shortness of breath that began two hours ago while playing basketball. He describes the pain as localized, worse with inspiration, and associated with rapid breathing and lightheadedness. Over the past week he had a dry cough after a self-limited viral illness and notes intermittent exercise-induced wheeze in childhood. He uses e-cigarettes occasionally and is a tall, thin athlete. He denies fever, leg swelling, or significant trauma. He has mild right shoulder discomfort but no prior hospitalizations. Given the abrupt pleuritic pain, acute dyspnea, and risk factors, he is concerned for primary spontaneous pneumothorax, possibly related to an apical subpleural bleb, rather than infectious pneumonia.

A 7-year-old girl presents with a five-day history of cough and progressive noisy breathing. Symptoms began with rhinorrhea and low-grade fever, then 48 hours ago she had a brief choking episode while eating and since has persistent cough, audible wheeze and intermittent inspiratory stridor. Parents report increased work of breathing and decreased activity; she has had poor oral intake but no vomiting. At school a trial of a bronchodilator produced partial relief of wheeze. On exam at home she appeared mildly tachypneic with asymmetric breath sounds and prolonged expiratory wheeze. Concern is for foreign body aspiration with secondary reactive airways disease versus viral bronchiolitis; no prior hospitalizations, history notable only for atopic dermatitis.

A 44-year-old female reports a three-month history of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that began after a self-limited upper respiratory illness. She now tires after short walks, notes intermittent pleuritic chest discomfort and low-grade fevers, and has lost roughly 3 kg unintentionally. She describes occasional lightheadedness on exertion and episodic fingertip color changes in cold consistent with Raynaud phenomenon. She denies smoking or known cardiac disease. Primary care noted bibasilar inspiratory crackles on auscultation and observed brief oxygen desaturation with ambulation. The presentation is concerning for a developing interstitial lung process, such as organizing pneumonia or connective tissue–related interstitial lung disease, and she has been referred for pulmonary function testing and high-resolution chest imaging.

A 64-year-old woman presents with three months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough, with marked worsening over the past ten days after a mild upper respiratory illness. She describes new pleuritic chest discomfort on deep inspiration and increasing fatigue with a 4-kg unintentional weight loss. At home she notes oxygen saturation falls with walking. She has bibasilar “Velcro” crackles on prior exam and now mild digital clubbing noted by family. Past history includes well-controlled hypertension and a remote 30 pack-year smoking history, quit two decades ago. Clinically concerned for evolving interstitial lung disease/pulmonary fibrosis with secondary hypoxemia; denies fever, wheeze, or peripheral edema.

A 93-year-old female reports sudden painless loss of vision in the right eye over the past 48 hours, preceded by ten days of new temporal aching and intermittent jaw tiredness when chewing. She notes associated scalp tenderness when combing her hair and two weeks of morning stiffness and proximal shoulder weakness limiting dressing. There have been brief episodes of horizontal diplopia over the last week but no eye redness, discharge, or trauma. She has a history of well-controlled hypertension and prior right cataract extraction two years ago. Family denies recent infections or falls. Symptoms are concerning for an ischemic optic process in the setting of suspected giant cell arteritis with secondary polymyalgic features.

A 68-year-old man presents with three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and decreased exercise tolerance, now limiting him to short walks. He describes a productive cough with occasional scant hemoptysis and new right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began after a prolonged car trip two weeks ago. He reports intermittent low-grade fevers and an unintended eight-pound weight loss over the past month. Symptoms are worse with exertion and when supine at night. Past medical history notable for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and long-standing hypertension; former 40 pack-year smoker who quit ten years ago. He denies recent infectious exposures. Exam and imaging are pending, with clinical concern for pulmonary embolus versus postinfectious or malignant process given the hemoptysis and weight loss.

A 35-year-old male reports progressive shortness of breath and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain for seven days, worse with inspiration and exertion. He notes a dry cough that began after a mild upper respiratory illness and two episodes of scant hemoptysis. Over the last 48 hours he developed intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness with walking. He describes new swelling and aching in the right calf since his return from a long-haul flight two weeks ago. He has subjective low-grade fevers and decreased exercise tolerance compared with baseline; history is notable only for mild childhood asthma. He is most concerned about a blood clot given the leg swelling and pleuritic pain and denies recent trauma.

A 57-year-old woman presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent productive cough that began after a viral upper respiratory infection. Initially she produced green sputum but over the past three days developed scant hemoptysis and new left-sided pleuritic chest pain. She notes a recent long car trip one week ago and new mild swelling and tenderness of the left calf. She is a former smoker with a 30–pack-year history. On exertion she becomes breathless and reports lightheadedness; at rest she has intermittent palpitations and low-grade fever. Exam was notable for tachycardia and decreased breath sounds with bibasilar crackles, and oxygen saturation falls with ambulation. Concern is raised for pulmonary embolism versus infectious bronchopneumonia with possible pulmonary infarction.

A 69-year-old female presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea, now occurring with minimal activity and occasionally at rest. Symptoms began after a presumed respiratory infection and have been accompanied by a dry cough, intermittent pleuritic right-sided chest pain, and two episodes of scant hemoptysis. She reports increasing fatigue, decreased exercise tolerance, and new bilateral ankle swelling with mild exertional presyncope when climbing stairs. She has a remote provoked pulmonary embolism and longstanding hypertension and is a former smoker with a 20-pack-year history. She denies fevers or purulent sputum. Concern is for chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension or right-sided heart strain from recurrent embolic disease versus COPD exacerbation; outpatient cardiopulmonary evaluation and imaging were requested.

A 71-year-old woman reports six months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a dry cough, with marked worsening over the past three weeks. She notes decreased exercise tolerance — now short of breath after minimal exertion — intermittent low-grade fevers and an unintentional 6-pound weight loss. At home she and family have observed finger clubbing and persistent basilar crackles on recent clinic exam. She is a former 10–pack-year smoker who quit decades ago and denies hemoptysis or chest pain. Past history is notable for seropositive rheumatoid arthritis that has been clinically quiet for several years. The chronic cough, crackles, clubbing, prior connective-tissue disease, and subacute decline suggest possible interstitial lung disease, chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis, or occult infection.

A 76-year-old man reports a two-week history of progressive dyspnea and a worsening productive cough after a recent upper respiratory illness. Sputum has darkened and he endorses intermittent low-grade fevers and fatigue; he now tires with minimal exertion and is short of breath at rest. He has a prior diagnosis of COPD and notes increased wheeze compared with baseline. On review he describes new orthopnea and mild bilateral pedal swelling that developed over several days. He denies chest pain but notes occasional lightheadedness when ambulating. Symptoms are worse overnight and he has used his rescue inhaler more frequently without relief. He is concerned about persistent hypoxia and reduced functional status.

A 21-year-old male college student reports sudden onset left-sided pleuritic chest pain and acute shortness of breath that began two hours after a bout of forceful coughing. Pain is sharp, worse with inspiration, and accompanied by a persistent nonproductive cough and a sensation of chest tightness; he notes mild wheeze intermittently. On self-examination he felt lightheaded but has not had fever, hemoptysis, or recent trauma. He is tall and thin with no chronic medication use. At presentation he describes decreased breath sounds on the left and a subjective hyperresonant quality when tapping that side. Given the acute, post-cough presentation and exam findings, primary spontaneous pneumothorax is suspected and he requests evaluation for chest radiography and possible decompression.

A 19-year-old male reports two weeks of progressive right-sided visual loss and intermittent paresthesia. Vision blurring began after a brief upper respiratory illness and evolved into sharp central scotoma with retro-orbital pain that worsens with eye movement. He also describes tingling in the right arm and leg, subtle gait unsteadiness when descending stairs, new urinary urgency, and profound fatigue; daily holocephalic headaches are noted but without fevers or photophobia. Symptoms have interfered with reading and classwork. Prior outpatient exam documented reduced visual acuity on the right and a relative afferent pupillary defect. Differential consideration includes optic neuritis with possible early demyelinating disease such as multiple sclerosis versus postinfectious inflammatory neuropathy. He denies recent head trauma or substance use.

A 4-year-old male with three days of rhinorrhea now has a progressively barky cough and hoarseness, worst at night. The cough began after a runny nose and low-grade fever and intensifies with agitation; caregivers report intermittent inspiratory stridor and audible noisy breathing when upset. He has mild intercostal retractions and tachypneic episodes during coughing spells, with decreased oral intake and two nights of poor sleep. No vomiting or significant wheeze. Symptoms partially improve with cool-mist exposure at home. There is a recent illness in daycare. Past history notable only for mild eczema. Parents deny known asthma or prior hospitalizations. Concerned about worsening work of breathing and dehydration risk, they seek evaluation for possible viral croup.

A 22-year-old male college athlete presents with two weeks of intermittent spinning vertigo and a persistent dull occipital headache after a head-on collision during soccer. Vertigo is brief, triggered by rolling in bed or looking up, and associated with nausea and intermittent tinnitus; he describes occasional visual blurring and brief diplopia when symptoms peak. The occipital pain is worse with neck rotation and Valsalva, raising concern for a cervicogenic component; he also notes mild light sensitivity and unsteady gait on uneven ground. He denied loss of consciousness but had transient disorientation after the impact. No history of migraines or anticoagulant use. Symptoms began within 48 hours of the collision and have fluctuated despite rest, prompting evaluation for post-concussive vestibular dysfunction versus benign paroxysmal positional vertigo.

A 34-year-old female reports progressive shortness of breath for ten days, beginning after a self-limited upper respiratory infection. Dyspnea is worse with exertion and when lying flat, and is accompanied by a persistent nonproductive cough and intermittent pleuritic right-sided chest pain that increases with deep inspiration. She notes new wheeze on auscultation at home and mild palpitations with activity. Low-grade fever and decreased exercise tolerance have been present; she also describes a single episode of scant hemoptysis. She has a remote history of childhood asthma but has required no recent inhalers. No leg swelling until yesterday, when she noticed mild calf tightness after a long car trip. She is concerned about pneumonia versus pulmonary embolism and sought evaluation due to worsening symptoms.

A 1-year-old male presents for persistent cough and noisy breathing that began five days ago after a brief choking episode while eating. Caregiver reports an initial vigorous cough with gagging, followed by progressive tachypnea, intermittent wheeze, and visible subcostal retractions. He has had low-grade fever and decreased oral intake since onset and two brief periods of duskiness noted at home with crying. Nighttime cough is worse and feeds often end in coughing. On auscultation at home the caregiver describes focal rattling and occasional high-pitched sounds. No prior wheezing history, immunizations up to date. Concern is for aspiration-related pneumonitis versus developing focal pneumonia or reactive airways inflammation, prompting evaluation for hypoxemia and possible chest imaging.

A 44-year-old female presents with two days of progressive dyspnea and pleuritic right-sided chest pain after a 10-hour car trip. She notes sudden-onset shortness of breath at rest, worse with inspiration, accompanied by a dry cough and one episode of hemoptysis. She reports new swelling and aching in the right calf for three days. At triage she was tachycardic and mildly hypoxic on room air. She takes combined oral contraceptives and had a treated upper respiratory infection last week. She denies known malignancy or recent surgery and has no prior thrombotic events. She describes mild anxiety about the symptoms but had normal exercise tolerance until this week.

A 15-year-old female reports two weeks of intermittent right-hand numbness and brief speech arrest occurring several times daily. Episodes last 30–90 seconds, begin with a metallic taste and flashing lights in the left visual field, and are sometimes followed by a throbbing unilateral headache with photophobia. Symptoms began after a self-limited upper respiratory infection and have increased in frequency over the past five days, often after poor sleep or stress. She notes mild persistent paresthesia between spells but no fever, syncope, or clear weakness. Past history includes a mild concussion last year. She describes new situational anxiety and fragmented sleep. Differential considerations include focal seizures versus complicated migraine; family history is noncontributory. She seeks evaluation for neurologic imaging and outpatient neurology follow-up.

A 44-year-old man reports three months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a daily productive cough that began after a prolonged bronchitis episode. Sputum is yellow-green and he notes two small episodes of hemoptysis. He describes intermittent wheeze and occasional pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort with deep breaths or coughing. Over the same interval he has had low‑grade fevers, night sweats, and an unintended 7-pound weight loss, with markedly reduced exercise tolerance. He is a 20 pack‑year smoker and works as an auto mechanic with frequent dust and solvent exposure. Past respiratory history includes childhood pneumonia and recurrent sinus infections. He denies recent travel or sick contacts but is concerned symptoms are not resolving despite rest.

An 8-year-old girl is brought for a 10-day history of progressive cough and shortness of breath that began after a mild upper respiratory infection. Parents describe frequent nocturnal cough, audible wheeze with exertion, and chest tightness when she runs at school; she has become fatigued and stopped soccer practice because of decreased exercise tolerance. There has been intermittent rhinorrhea and low-grade fever the first three days, without vomiting or hemoptysis. On exam at home they noted prolonged exhalation and occasional retractions at night. Past medical history is notable for eczema and seasonal allergic rhinitis. No recent travel or known pertussis exposure. Symptoms partially improve with quiet rest but worsen with activity and nighttime, prompting evaluation for asthma versus postinfectious reactive airways.

A 39-year-old female presents with three weeks of intermittent right upper quadrant abdominal pain that has become more constant and more severe. The pain is colicky, typically precipitated by fatty meals, and radiates to the mid-back and right scapula. She reports associated nausea with two episodes of non-bloody emesis and intermittent subjective fevers with chills. Over the past week she developed dark urine and mild scleral icterus, accompanied by troublesome generalized pruritus. Appetite is decreased because of discomfort. She remembers several brief biliary-colic–type episodes after heavy meals over the past year. Past medical history notable only for obesity; she denies alcohol use or recent travel.

A 22-year-old woman reports a four-day history of progressive right upper quadrant abdominal pain that began after a fatty meal and now radiates to the right scapula and mid-back. The pain is colicky with several intense spasms, accompanied by intermittent fevers and rigors, nausea with two episodes of nonbloody emesis, and anorexia. Over 48 hours she noticed dark urine, pale stools, and new generalized pruritus; family members have commented on yellowing of her eyes. She recalls two prior brief episodes of postprandial biliary-type pain last year but no surgeries. She denies recent travel, alcohol use, or unusual food exposures. Symptoms have limited oral intake and prompted this urgent evaluation for possible biliary obstruction or ascending cholangitis.

A 64-year-old man reports six months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a dry cough, with marked worsening over the past six weeks that now limits him to short walks. He describes intermittent low-grade fevers and an unintentional 10-pound weight loss, and notes reduced exercise tolerance. Prior exam documented bibasilar inspiratory crackles and mild digital clubbing. He is a former 30-pack-year smoker and worked in construction with possible asbestos exposure. He has a history of hypertension. He denies hemoptysis, orthopnea, or recent travel. The temporal progression and clubbing raise concern for an interstitial lung process—idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis or chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis—with infectious exacerbation considered.

A 97-year-old man reports progressive gait instability and cognitive slowing over the past six months, with acute worsening during the last two weeks after a presumed urinary tract infection treated at home. He describes a short-stepped, shuffling gait and frequent hesitancy when initiating steps, and has had two ground-level falls without head trauma. Family notes increased urinary urgency and new daytime incontinence alongside intermittent disorientation and word-finding difficulty. He also endorses lightheadedness on standing suggestive of orthostatic symptoms. Past history includes long-standing hypertension and chronic atrial fibrillation. Clinical concern is for normal-pressure hydrocephalus as an underlying cause of the triad, with superimposed delirium from infection and possible orthostatic contribution to recent falls.

A 15-year-old girl presents with two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and chest tightness that began abruptly during soccer tryouts. She describes a loud inspiratory noise and throat tightness with peak exertion and an expiratory wheeze and dry cough that can persist for 30–60 minutes after stopping. Symptoms are reliably triggered by cold air and strong odors and have reduced her exercise tolerance; she reports two nocturnal awakenings with coughing. There was a mild upper respiratory illness immediately before onset. Past history includes seasonal allergic rhinitis and childhood atopic dermatitis. Parents report occasional throat tightness without wheeze at school during stress. She denies fever, chest pain, or syncope. Examination and spirometry are pending.

A 34-year-old woman presents with two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and intermittent pleuritic right-sided chest pain. Pain is sharp, worse with deep inspiration, and accompanied by a dry cough with two episodes of scant hemoptysis. She reports recent palpitations and lightheadedness on standing but denies fever. Symptoms began about one week after a transatlantic flight and she has been on combined oral contraceptives for contraception for the past year. She also notes new swelling and mild tenderness of the right calf. Past history is notable only for seasonal allergic rhinitis. She has not experienced recent trauma or major illness. She is concerned symptoms are worsening with minimal exertion and requests evaluation for possible thromboembolic disease.

A 14-year-old male reports a four-day history of recurrent severe headaches with prominent brainstem-type symptoms. Episodes began after a mild upper respiratory infection and consist of unilateral throbbing pain with a scintillating visual aura, brief transient right arm paresthesia, and intermittent diplopia. Headaches are accompanied by photophobia, phonophobia, and nausea with occasional nonbilious vomiting; individual events last 30–60 minutes and sometimes awaken him from sleep. He also notes several spells of vertigo and unsteady gait between headaches, worse with exertion. He has missed two days of school and is increasingly anxious about recurrence. He denies fever, neck stiffness, or recent head trauma. No prior migraine history, and family history is noncontributory.

A 40-year-old man reports six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent productive cough that began after a presumed viral upper respiratory infection. Sputum is yellowish with two brief episodes of scant hemoptysis; he also describes new right-sided pleuritic chest pain when taking deep breaths and an audible wheeze at night. Symptoms limit walking up a flight of stairs and have not responded to over-the-counter expectorants. He notes intermittent low-grade fevers and night sweats but no weight loss. Past medical history is notable for a treated pneumonia several years ago. He is an occasional smoker (about a ten pack-year lifetime history) and works in construction with intermittent dust exposure. No regular medications or known drug allergies.

A 14-year-old male presents with six weeks of progressive daily holocephalic headache and intermittent visual disturbances since a soccer-related concussion. Headaches are pressure-like, worse with bending and Valsalva, and associated with transient visual obscurations and brief scintillating scotomas; he also reports new pulsatile tinnitus and morning nausea with occasional emesis. Twice he experienced lightheadedness and near-syncope when arising quickly from sitting. Parents note increased somnolence and difficulty concentrating at school. Primary care documented bilateral optic disc blurring and referred for neurology; there has been no fever, neck stiffness, focal limb weakness, or seizure. Current impression centers on post-concussive headache with concern for intracranial hypertension and secondary visual compromise; orthostatic symptoms raise possible autonomic contribution. Further neuro-ophthalmologic evaluation is planned.

A 74-year-old man reports a six-month history of progressive gait difficulty characterized by short, shuffling, magnetic steps and trouble initiating walking, with three recent falls. Family members note slowing of thought, short-term memory loss, and increased apathy over the same interval. He has developed new urinary urgency with occasional urge incontinence rather than nocturia alone. Past medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension. He describes mild unsteadiness on turning and needs a cane for longer distances; there is no limb numbness or tremor. Symptoms evolved gradually and were not preceded by infection. Outside CT head reportedly demonstrated ventriculomegaly, and primary concern is possible idiopathic normal pressure hydrocephalus versus progressive neurodegenerative gait disorder.

A 32-year-old man reports acute-onset shortness of breath and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain developing over 36 hours. Dyspnea is constant, worse with exertion, and associated with lightheadedness and a single small episode of hemoptysis. He describes progressive left calf swelling and tenderness since an ankle fracture required immobilization three weeks ago after a soccer injury. He notes a recent prolonged car trip and is a current smoker. He denies fever, cough before this event, or known bleeding disorders. At home he felt palpitations and mild near-syncope. The presentation is most concerning for pulmonary embolism from a left lower-extremity deep venous thrombosis given the temporal sequence of immobilization, localized calf findings, tachycardia, and exertional hypoxemia.

An 87-year-old woman reports ten days of progressive shortness of breath and a dry cough that acutely worsened over the last 48 hours. Symptoms began after a viral upper respiratory prodrome with mild rhinorrhea and now include new right-sided pleuritic chest discomfort and occasional scant hemoptysis. She also notes recent left calf swelling and increased exertional dyspnea that limits ambulation. Past history is notable for COPD and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation; she admits to missing several doses of her anticoagulation last week. She has thicker, yellow-tinged sputum but no high fevers. Examination at home was limited; family is concerned for possible pulmonary embolism vs COPD exacerbation with superimposed infection, prompting evaluation in clinic.

A 71-year-old female presents with sudden, painless loss of vision in the right eye for two days, preceded by three days of intermittent diplopia and transient visual obscurations. She also reports a three-week history of new, bandlike temporal headaches with tenderness over the scalp and jaw claudication when chewing, and progressive morning stiffness in both shoulders consistent with polymyalgia-type symptoms. She notes low-grade fevers and fatigue but denies trauma, photophobia, or nausea. Her medical history is notable only for long-standing hypertension. There has been no prior eye disease; family history is noncontributory. Examiner is concerned for ischemic optic neuropathy secondary to giant cell (temporal) arteritis and expedited evaluation and vascular imaging were requested.

An 80-year-old man reports ten days of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and increased cough producing yellow-green sputum. Over the past 48 hours he notes new orthopnea, waking with breathlessness requiring two pillows, and a single episode of near-syncope when climbing stairs. He describes intermittent pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort and audible wheeze at baseline. Family observed progressive ankle swelling and decreased exercise tolerance compared with his usual chronic obstructive pulmonary disease baseline; he has a remote history of hypertension. He denies chest pressure consistent with ischemia but is concerned about a possible infection or heart failure flare given low-grade chills and reduced oral intake. He has not recently started new medications or traveled.

An 8-year-old male presents with ten days of progressive morning headaches, nausea, and intermittent non‑bilious vomiting. Headaches are pressure‑like, worse on awakening and partially relieved by sitting up; over the past four days he developed unsteady gait with frequent tripping, described as clumsy by his parents. Mother reports two brief episodes of double vision and transient blurred vision when he looks to the right. Symptoms began after a mild febrile upper respiratory infection; he had low‑grade fever and decreased appetite early in the illness but is currently afebrile. At school teachers noted increased somnolence and decreased concentration. Parents also observed transient one‑sided eye crossing at home. No history of head trauma or witnessed seizures.

A 71-year-old man presents with a two-week history of progressive right-sided visual blurring and two brief episodes of transient monocular vision loss described as a curtain coming down. He also reports a new, persistent throbbing temporal headache with overlying scalp tenderness and pain when chewing; jaw claudication began about one week after the headache onset. Over the past two months he has noticed morning stiffness and aching in his shoulders consistent with polymyalgia-type symptoms, accompanied by low-grade fevers and malaise. He experienced one episode of double vision while bending forward. He has a remote history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. No recent head trauma, focal weakness, or infectious prodrome are reported. He sought evaluation because vision symptoms have become more frequent.

A 50-year-old man reports six weeks of progressive epigastric pain, described as gnawing and worse after meals, with early satiety and intermittent postprandial nausea. He notes an unintentional eight-pound weight loss and two weeks of dark, tarry stools. Over the past week he has had lightheadedness when standing and increasing fatigue; he appears paler than usual. He has a remote history of GERD and admits to recent frequent NSAID use for chronic back discomfort. He denies hematemesis but is concerned about ongoing bleeding. Examination and history raise concern for peptic ulcer disease with possible gastric outlet obstruction or underlying gastric malignancy leading to iron-deficiency anemia; he requests evaluation with endoscopy and testing for H. pylori.

A 20-year-old male college student presents with a seven-day history of progressive exertional shortness of breath and pleuritic right-sided chest pain, worse with deep inspiration. He reports a brief episode of hemoptysis and a dry cough beginning three days after a prolonged 10-hour bus trip. He also notes new right calf swelling and tenderness that developed around the same time. He has felt intermittently febrile with palpitations but denies syncope. Past history is notable for a heterozygous factor V Leiden mutation identified incidentally last year; no recent surgery or hormonal therapy. He is a non-smoker, denies illicit drug use, and says symptoms now limit climbing stairs and participating in sports.

A 65-year-old woman reports three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and an increasingly productive cough. Symptoms began after a mild upper respiratory illness and now include yellow-green sputum, intermittent pleuritic chest discomfort, and marked decline in exercise tolerance. She has longstanding COPD and bronchiectasis and a remote pulmonary embolism; she also carries hypertension. She notes new dependent ankle swelling and more frequent nighttime breathlessness. In clinic she is mildly hypoxemic on room air with bibasilar crackles and diminished air entry at the bases. Concern is for an exacerbation of underlying bronchiectasis/COPD with possible superimposed infection and evolving right‑sided volume overload related to chronic pulmonary vascular disease. Further imaging and sputum studies are planned.

A 3-year-old boy presents with four days of progressive left-sided ear pain and fever that began after a week of rhinorrhea and cough. Parents note constant tugging at the left ear, decreased oral intake, poor sleep and increased irritability. Overnight he developed purulent otorrhea and new postauricular erythema with focal tenderness; he also seemed mildly unsteady when walking today. There has been no vomiting, rash, or seizure activity. Brief exam by parents and at urgent care reportedly showed a bulging left tympanic membrane and reduced response to whispered words on that side. The constellation is most consistent with acute left otitis media with otorrhea and early mastoid inflammation following an antecedent viral upper respiratory infection.

A 92-year-old man reports three months of progressive gait instability and slowed thinking, initially unsteady steps that have evolved into a wide-based, shuffling/magnetic gait and two recent falls. Family notes increasing short-term memory loss and apathy with difficulty initiating activities; he now requires a cane and help with transfers. He also has new urinary urgency and nocturia with one episode of daytime incontinence. Symptoms acutely worsened after a treated urinary tract infection last month but have not returned to baseline. Examination at home shows mild bradykinesia without focal limb weakness. A prior noncontrast head CT reportedly demonstrated ventriculomegaly without infarct. Past history notable only for controlled hypertension. No fever, chest pain, or new visual change.

A 98-year-old female presents with two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and new orthopnea, reporting two episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea that awakened her at night. She has a persistent dry cough that became minimally productive after a brief choking episode while eating a week ago and has since had low-grade fevers and increased fatigue. Family note decreased oral intake and recent mild confusion. On exam she demonstrates bibasilar crackles and pitting pedal edema; oxygen saturation on room air is low compared with baseline. Past history is notable for long-standing hypertension and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation with remote tobacco exposure. Clinical concern centers on acute decompensated heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, possible aspiration pneumonia, and hypoxemia on a background of chronic cardiopulmonary disease.

A 26-year-old man reports five days of progressive right-sided pleuritic chest pain and exertional dyspnea. Symptoms began after a viral upper respiratory prodrome with rhinorrhea and low-grade fever; an initial dry cough became productive with occasional blood-tinged sputum over the past two days. He describes sharp inspiratory pain, reduced exercise tolerance, intermittent wheeze, and palpitations but denies calf swelling. He returned from an eight-hour bus trip after a weekend soccer tournament and is an occasional smoker with a history of mild intermittent asthma. On review he reports subjective fevers and night sweats. Given focal pleuritic pain, hemoptysis, tachycardia and recent immobilization, the differential emphasizes pulmonary embolism versus community-acquired pneumonia with reactive airways component.

A 48-year-old man reports three weeks of recurrent spinning vertigo and progressive imbalance, initially episodic but now occurring several times daily. Episodes are typically provoked by turning in bed or looking upward, last 30–60 seconds, and are accompanied by nausea and sweating; he endorses two near-falls. Over the same interval he has noticed fluctuating left-sided hearing loss, aural fullness, and low-frequency tinnitus after a self-limited upper respiratory infection two weeks before onset. He denies focal weakness, diplopia, or syncope. Past medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. No otorrhea or ear trauma. He is concerned about possible Meniere disease versus BPPV or postviral labyrinthitis and requests further evaluation.

A 36-year-old man presents with progressive exertional shortness of breath for six days, now present at rest, associated with sharp pleuritic right-sided chest pain and two episodes of scant hemoptysis. Symptoms began after a weeklong work trip with prolonged travel; he notes new right calf swelling and aching three days after returning. He developed a productive cough with green sputum and low-grade fevers shortly thereafter, and reports intermittent wheeze and chest tightness consistent with his history of mild intermittent asthma. He feels palpitations and is more easily fatigued climbing stairs. He denies recent trauma, illicit drug use, or prior thromboembolism. The timeline suggests possible deep venous thrombosis complicated by pulmonary embolism, though superimposed bronchitic infection is also a consideration.

A 24-year-old male presents with two days of progressive shortness of breath and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain. He describes an acute increase in dyspnea on exertion and several episodes of lightheadedness and palpitations; one small episode of hemoptysis yesterday. He also notes new swelling and aching in his right calf since returning from a prolonged 12-hour bus trip five days ago. He is an active smoker and had a mild upper respiratory infection about ten days ago that resolved. He denies fever, prior cardiopulmonary disease, recent surgery, or illicit IV drug use. Symptoms began abruptly and have limited his ability to walk across a block; he is worried about a blood clot or pulmonary embolism given the travel and calf swelling.

A 16-year-old female reports two weeks of progressive exertional shortness of breath and new right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began after a viral upper respiratory infection. She describes a persistent dry cough, worsening exercise intolerance, and intermittent wheeze, previously episodic with her history of mild intermittent asthma. Symptoms intensified overnight with sharper, localized right chest pain and a sense of decreased air movement on that side. She denies fever, significant sputum production, or leg swelling but notes occasional lightheadedness on stair climbing. Her mother heard an audible wheeze and describes quieter breath sounds on the right. No prior hospitalizations. She is otherwise well appearing but limited by dyspnea on exertion, prompting concern for an evolving pulmonary complication.

A 42-year-old man reports a two-week history of progressive dry cough and exertional dyspnea, noting new pleuritic right-sided chest pain and scant hemoptysis for the past 48 hours. Symptoms began after a prolonged upper respiratory illness three weeks ago but have not fully resolved; he describes intermittent wheeze and reduced exercise tolerance compared with baseline. He has a history of well-controlled hypertension and chronic gastroesophageal reflux, and smokes about half a pack daily for two decades. Over the last four days he developed right calf swelling and tenderness, which he relates to a long car trip two weeks ago. He denies fevers or night sweats. He is worried these findings may represent a pulmonary embolism versus worsening chronic airway disease.

A 29-year-old woman reports five days of progressive blurring in the right eye with sharp pain aggravated by eye movement. Vision has declined from baseline to difficulty reading fine print; colors appear washed in the affected eye. She describes intermittent photophobia and a dull periorbital headache that worsens toward evening, and notes mild nausea with the headaches. One week before symptoms she had a brief viral upper respiratory illness with nasal congestion and low-grade fever that resolved. Over the last two days she developed intermittent numbness and tingling in the left hand without weakness. She denies trauma, double vision, or recent topical eye exposures. Onset was abrupt and symptoms are steadily worse, now interfering with work and driving, prompting urgent evaluation.

A 30-year-old woman reports five days of progressive vision loss in her left eye, beginning as vague central blurring and now described as a persistent gray spot centrally. She endorses aching periorbital pain that worsens with eye movement and noticeable color desaturation—reds look muted—along with intermittent flashes of light. Symptoms began after a brief upper respiratory infection approximately two weeks ago. She also has a dull occipital headache and mild unsteadiness on stairs but denies fever, trauma, or sensory numbness. Past medical history is notable only for migraine. The visual disturbance is impairing reading and driving, prompting evaluation for an acute optic process.

A 16-year-old male reports five days of progressive blurring of central vision in the right eye with sharp retro-orbital pain that worsens on eye movement. He describes colors appearing "washed out" on the affected side and notes difficulty reading small print; his parents observed the right pupil reacting less briskly. Symptoms began three days after a self-limited febrile upper respiratory illness and are accompanied by frontal headache and intermittent nausea but no fever currently. He also endorses episodic numbness and tingling of the left fingertips and feeling slightly unsteady when running. No eye discharge, trauma, or prior ocular problems. Family history is notable only for autoimmune thyroid disease. Optic neuritis is suspected; he was referred urgently for ophthalmology and neuroimaging.

A 15-year-old male reports three days of progressive blurred vision in his right eye, initially episodic but now persistent, with central gray smudging and noticeable desaturation of color when comparing eyes. He endorses mild periorbital pain that worsens with eye movement and intermittent photophobia; there has been no trauma. Symptoms began shortly after a week of nasal congestion and sore throat. He also notes two brief episodes of right-hand numbness and a single spell of unsteadiness yesterday. At home he and his parents observed that the right pupil seemed less reactive to light and he is having difficulty reading distant text. No prior ophthalmic history or fever. Concern is for acute optic neuropathy, most consistent with optic neuritis in the setting of recent viral prodrome.

A 73-year-old man reports six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea with a persistent nonproductive cough. He notes insidious decline in exercise tolerance and now becomes short of breath with minimal exertion; symptoms acutely worsened after an upper respiratory infection two weeks ago. On exam he has basilar inspiratory crackles and new digital clubbing described by his outpatient clinician. He is a former 45-pack-year smoker and has longstanding seropositive rheumatoid arthritis treated conservatively. He denies pleuritic chest pain, hemoptysis, or overt peripheral edema. The subacute course in the setting of RA and prior tobacco exposure raises concern for underlying interstitial lung disease with a possible inflammatory exacerbation and evolving hypoxemia.

A 61-year-old female presents with three days of progressive dyspnea and sharp, pleuritic left-sided chest pain. She reports a single episode of light hemoptysis and subjective palpitations with worse exertional breathlessness compared with her usual baseline chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. She has a history of hypertension and a remote deep venous thrombosis; she completed a long overnight car trip the week prior. At home she noted a rapid heart rate and increasing lightheadedness, and an urgent care pulse oximeter registered low saturation on room air. No fevers, calf pain, or focal neurologic symptoms. Given acute hypoxemia, pleuritic pain, prior DVT, and recent immobilization, she is being evaluated with concern for pulmonary embolism.

A 43-year-old man reports a six-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent productive cough, initially following a winter upper respiratory infection. Sputum is yellow with occasional blood streaks; he notes low-grade fevers, drenching night sweats and a 5-kg unintentional weight loss. Cough provokes sharp, pleuritic right-sided chest pain and intermittent wheeze; symptoms wake him at night and limit stair climbing. He has a 20-pack-year smoking history and works in masonry with chronic dust/silica exposure. He was treated twice as an outpatient for presumed bronchitis with only transient improvement. He denies orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, recent travel, known TB contact, or peripheral edema. Concerns are progressive infection, postinfectious bronchiectasis, or early occupational lung disease.

A 91-year-old female presents with two weeks of progressively worsening shortness of breath, acutely worse over the past three days. Symptoms began after a brief choking episode while eating, followed by productive yellow sputum and intermittent low-grade fevers. She now endorses pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort, orthopnea requiring two pillows, and resting hypoxemia with increased work of breathing. Caregivers note reduced appetite and one fall last week. On review she reports new mild bilateral ankle swelling and intermittent palpitations but denies chest pressure or syncope. Physical findings at home include persistent tachypnea and audible bibasilar crackles. The clinical picture is concerning for aspiration-related pneumonia with possible superimposed congestive failure and dehydration.

A 68-year-old man presents with three months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough, noting that he now becomes breathless walking one block and has had several episodes of lightheadedness with exertion. Symptoms intensified after a brief bronchitic illness six weeks ago. He reports a 10-pound unintentional weight loss and decreased exercise tolerance; denies fevers or hemoptysis. On review he describes mild bilateral ankle swelling overnight and uses two pillows for sleep, but no chest pain. He is a former 30 pack-year smoker with long-term occupational dust exposure. Prior outpatient exam documented bibasilar crackles; he now notices digital clubbing and intermittent exertional desaturation, raising concern for fibrotic interstitial lung disease with possible secondary pulmonary hypertension.

A 37-year-old female reports six weeks of progressive palpitations, heat intolerance, and unintentional 12-pound weight loss despite increased appetite. Initially episodic, the palpitations are now daily and accompanied by a fine hand tremor, intermittent lightheadedness, and exertional dyspnea when climbing one flight of stairs. She notes new diffuse neck fullness with mild anterior neck discomfort and an enlarging soft swelling over the thyroid region. Other complaints include increased sweating, three to four loose bowel movements per day, irregular menses for two cycles, and gritty eye irritation with worse eye prominence on photographs. Fatigue and difficulty sleeping are worsening. No recent travel or medication changes; no known cardiac disease. She denies fever, rash, or focal neurologic symptoms.

A 30-year-old man presents with a five-day history of progressively worsening bifrontal pounding headache, described as constant pressure with superimposed sharp exacerbations, worse in the morning and when bending forward. He notes associated nausea and photophobia and intermittently hears a whooshing sound in both ears. Over the past two days he has experienced brief (15–30 minute) episodes of right-arm weakness and numbness and one episode of double vision; he denies loss of consciousness. He reports a low-grade fever and a self-limited sinus infection two weeks ago. No recent head trauma, neck stiffness, or illicit drug use. Symptoms are impairing work and prompt evaluation for a possible intracranial or postinfectious process is requested.

A 31-year-old man reports abrupt onset of left-sided pleuritic chest pain and progressive shortness of breath over the past 24 hours. Pain sharp, worse with deep inspiration and coughing; he also noted a small amount of blood-streaked sputum this morning. He describes intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness but no fever. Three days prior he developed aching and swelling of the right calf after a 10-hour bus trip; he is a current smoker and admits occasional anabolic steroid use for bodybuilding. On review of systems he denies recent upper respiratory infection or trauma. Symptoms cluster temporally with recent prolonged travel and unilateral leg swelling, raising concern for pulmonary embolism from an evolving deep vein thrombosis.

A 47-year-old man presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and worsening fatigue. He now develops orthopnea, requiring two pillows, and brief paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea that awakens him once or twice per week. Bilateral ankle swelling has progressed from mild to obvious by evening, and he describes intermittent palpitations with occasional lightheadedness on standing but no syncope. Symptoms began after a self-limited viral respiratory illness. He denies chest pain, fever, or cough productive of sputum. Recent outpatient echocardiography documented a reduced ejection fraction with dilated left ventricle, felt to represent nonischemic cardiomyopathy. Past history is notable for treated hypertension; he does not use tobacco. Review of systems otherwise unremarkable.

A 32-year-old man presents with two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and new left-sided pleuritic chest pain. Symptoms began several days after a seven-hour flight and followed a brief upper respiratory illness; he now has a dry cough with two episodes of scant hemoptysis. He reports recent right calf swelling and aching that worsens when standing. On review he notes palpitations and lightheadedness with exertion but no syncope or fever. Past history includes mild childhood asthma and a remote tobacco history. He denies recent trauma, intravenous drug use, or anticoagulant therapy. The temporal pattern and unilateral leg symptoms raise concern for thromboembolic disease with possible pulmonary embolism.

A 26-year-old woman reports four days of progressive shortness of breath and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began two days after a nine-hour airplane flight. Dyspnea is worse with exertion and deep inspiration and is accompanied by a dry cough and one episode of blood-tinged sputum. She also notes intermittent palpitations and subjective fevers. After the flight she developed right calf tightness and mild swelling. She uses combined oral contraceptives and has a history of mild childhood asthma and seasonal allergic rhinitis. She denies recent immobilization aside from the flight and does not smoke. Symptoms have gradually intensified, prompting evaluation for possible pulmonary embolism versus asthma-related bronchospasm.

A 70-year-old woman presents with two weeks of progressively worse exertional dyspnea and fatigue, now limiting her walk to a few blocks. She reports new orthopnea requiring two pillows and one episode of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea; family noted gradual swelling of both ankles over the same interval. She has a persistent, dry cough but denies fever or sputum. Symptoms began after a recent upper respiratory illness and have been accompanied by occasional palpitations consistent with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Her past history is notable for long-standing hypertension and prior echocardiographic suggestion of diastolic dysfunction. She denies chest pain at rest but notes mild exertional chest tightness and a 5-pound weight gain over ten days, raising concern for congestive heart failure exacerbation.

A 39-year-old woman reports six weeks of progressive epigastric pain and early satiety. The discomfort is dull and crampy, reliably worse 30–60 minutes after eating and notably provoked by fatty meals; she also describes new intolerance of fried foods. She has daily nausea and two episodes of non-bilious vomiting this month, with postprandial bloating and intermittent right upper‑quadrant fullness. Over the interval she has lost about 8 lb unintentionally because of reduced oral intake. She wakes at night with occasional heartburn but denies fever, jaundice, melena, or hematemesis. She recalls treatment for H. pylori in the past and says symptoms began after a brief viral illness, gradually limiting work and sleep.

A 77-year-old man reports six months of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough. He first noticed breathlessness climbing a flight of stairs and now becomes short of breath after walking one block, with symptomatic drops in oxygen saturation on exertion and occasional lightheadedness. He has lost about 5 kg unintentionally and feels more fatigued; he denies fevers, night sweats, or hemoptysis. Examination revealed bibasilar "velcro" inspiratory crackles, mild digital clubbing, and trace ankle edema. Pertinent history includes a remote 20 pack‑year smoking history, prior occupational silica exposure, and well-controlled hypertension. The time course and findings are most suggestive of a chronic interstitial lung process with associated exertional hypoxemia.

An 80-year-old female presents with six months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent nonproductive cough, with a notable stepwise worsening over the past three weeks. She reports new exertional desaturation requiring pauses on stairs and a 10-pound unintentional weight loss. She has long-standing seropositive rheumatoid arthritis and remote tobacco exposure. On exam she notes basilar inspiratory crackles and observed digital clubbing at the fingertips. No chest pain or fever. A recent chest radiograph reportedly showed bibasilar reticular markings; primary team is concerned for rheumatoid-associated interstitial lung disease with developing hypoxemia. She denies ankle edema or orthopnea. Functional decline has limited household ambulation and prompted referral for pulmonary evaluation.

A 6-year-old female presents with a three-week history of worsening cough, described as paroxysmal episodes with occasional posttussive emesis and an intermittent inspiratory "whoop." Symptoms began after a febrile upper respiratory infection and have persisted despite symptomatic care. Parents report daily nocturnal coughing, exercise-related shortness of breath with audible expiratory wheeze, and mild intercostal retractions during spells; sleep is frequently disrupted. She has a background of atopic dermatitis and recurrent otitis media. There is a household contact with prolonged cough. She has no hemoptysis or cyanosis. Exam concerns include reactive airways disease versus pertussis, with secondary consideration of atypical chronic infection or underlying ciliary dysfunction given the pattern of recurrent infections.

An 85-year-old woman presents with three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that began after a presumed viral bronchitis. She now becomes breathless climbing a single flight of stairs and notes intermittent low-grade fevers and a 6–7 pound unintentional weight loss. She reports new exertional desaturation with brief lightheadedness and mild orthopnea at night. Examination at home noted increased work of breathing and resting tachypnea; on clinic auscultation she has bilateral bibasilar inspiratory crackles and mild digital clubbing. Past history notable for remote breast cancer treated decades ago and a 20 pack-year smoking history, quit >30 years. She denies chest pain or hemoptysis but is concerned about progressive decline and decreased exercise tolerance.

A 20-year-old college student presents with sudden-onset pleuritic left-sided chest pain and progressive shortness of breath that began 10 hours ago. Pain is sharp, worse with inspiration, and accompanied by lightheadedness and a single episode of small-volume hemoptysis. She notes palpitations and a fast heartbeat at rest. Over the past two days she developed swelling and tenderness in the right calf. Risk factors include combined oral contraceptive use for six months and a long-haul flight one week prior. She denies fever, cough, or recent trauma. No prior thrombotic events.
