Symptoms have worsened despite rest, prompting evaluation for possible deep venous thrombosis with pulmonary embolism given the constellation of unilateral leg swelling, pleuritic pain, tachycardia, and hypoxemic symptoms.

A 65-year-old man presents with a three-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent productive cough that began after a brief upper respiratory illness. Sputum has been purulent with new streaks of bright blood today. Over the past 48 hours he developed sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain and increased breathlessness on minimal exertion. Past imaging reportedly showed bronchiectasis; he is a former 30-pack-year smoker. He also describes intermittent palpitations and noted recent swelling of the left calf. He denies fever but feels more fatigued than usual. Concern centers on a bronchiectasis exacerbation with superimposed infection versus possible pulmonary embolism related to a new atrial arrhythmia.

A 92-year-old female reports a two-week history of progressive blurring of central vision in the right eye, with abrupt profound deterioration three days ago. She describes a dark central scotoma and difficulty reading; family noticed a right-sided afferent pupillary defect on informal testing. Over the past week she developed a new, constant right temporal headache and scalp tenderness when combing hair, and she endorses jaw fatigue when chewing harder foods. She also notes several weeks of morning stiffness in her shoulders and a four-pound unintentional weight loss. Her past history is notable for treated hypertension. No fever or recent trauma. She is most concerned about sudden permanent vision loss and requests urgent evaluation for suspected giant cell arteritis.

A 21-year-old female college student reports four days of progressive blurring of vision in her right eye with aching retro-orbital pain that is worse with eye movement. She describes central dimness and a gray spot centrally and notes colors look "washed out" on that side. She also has light sensitivity and a mild frontal headache but denies fever, trauma, or discharge. Two weeks earlier she had a brief upper respiratory illness that resolved. Over the past ten days she has intermittently noticed tingling in her left hand and foot that comes and goes. Past medical history notable only for seasonal allergic rhinitis. No ocular surgery or contact lens issues. Symptoms are limiting studying and prompted urgent evaluation.

A 41-year-old male presents with five days of progressive, painful vision loss in his right eye. He noticed periocular ache exacerbated by eye movement two days before blurring progressed to a central scotoma and reduced color saturation; he reports difficulty distinguishing reds. On exam he had a right afferent pupillary defect and decreased visual acuity at bedside. Symptoms began after a week-long upper respiratory infection. He also endorses intermittent paresthesia in the left forearm over the past month and a remote history of migraine without aura. He is a current smoker. Working concern is optic neuritis versus ischemic optic neuropathy with possible early demyelinating disease prompting urgent neuro-ophthalmology evaluation.

A 2-year-old female is brought by her mother for 12 hours of progressively worsening intermittent abdominal pain and repeated vomiting. Mother describes abrupt episodes of inconsolable crying every 10–20 minutes with the child drawing up her legs, followed by short periods of sleepiness and pallor. Vomitus recently became bilious and oral intake is minimal; there have been only one wet diaper in 12 hours. Mother noted a single maroon-streaked stool this morning and felt a tender, sausage-shaped mass in the right mid-abdomen. Low-grade fever and rhinorrhea began four days ago after a presumed viral URI. No history of surgery or known bleeding disorder. The pattern and findings are concerning for intussusception with dehydration and intermittent bowel obstruction.

A 47-year-old woman presents with a six-week history of persistent productive cough and progressive exertional dyspnea that began after a self-limited upper respiratory infection. Sputum is yellowish, occasional small-volume hemoptysis occurred last week, and she describes intermittent pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort with nocturnal wheeze and chest tightness. She reports low-grade fevers and increased fatigue but denies significant weight loss. Past history notable for childhood asthma and lifelong seasonal allergic rhinitis; she is a non-smoker. Symptoms are worse with exertion and when bending forward; reflux-type heartburn is reported at night. She has tried over-the-counter cough suppressants and antacids with minimal benefit and is concerned about unresolved infection or a post-infectious airway process.

A 95-year-old female reports three days of progressive dyspnea and orthopnea, with one episode of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea last night. Symptoms began after a week of productive cough and low-grade fever attributed to a bronchitic illness; family notes increased fatigue and intermittent confusion. She developed palpitations and lightheadedness, and an outpatient ECG reported new atrial fibrillation. She now has bilateral lower-extremity swelling and reduced oral intake. The constellation is most consistent with acute decompensated heart failure precipitated by infectious bronchitis and new-onset atrial fibrillation, presenting with volume overload, peripheral edema, exertional limitation, and bibasilar crackles.

A 28-year-old woman reports six weeks of intermittent palpitations and persistent heat intolerance that began about two weeks after a brief febrile upper respiratory illness. She describes an 8–10 pound unintentional weight loss, a fine bilateral hand tremor, and resting tachycardia. Over the last month she has developed anterior neck tenderness with a mildly firm, diffusely enlarged gland that is painful with swallowing. She also endorses insomnia, increased anxiety, and new irregular menstrual bleeding. Symptoms worsen with exertion and have impaired her concentration at work. She denies chest pain, syncope, cough, or fever since the initial illness. No prior thyroid disease, no regular medications, and only seasonal allergies in the past. She has not used stimulants or illicit drugs.

A 48-year-old female reports three weeks of intermittent, rapid palpitations and progressive exertional dyspnea that began after a recent upper respiratory illness. Palpitations are described as irregular, racing episodes lasting minutes, occasionally accompanied by lightheadedness and one near-syncope. She notes new orthopnea and brief nocturnal gasping with paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and progressive bilateral ankle swelling. Mild, nonradiating chest tightness occurs with exertion but no severe pleuritic pain. She has a remote history of hyperthyroidism treated in the past. No fever, cough with purulent sputum, or leg pain suggestive of deep venous thrombosis. Symptoms have limited her usual walking tolerance and prompted this visit to evaluate possible arrhythmia or decompensated cardiac failure.

A 29-year-old man presents with six days of progressive bilateral leg weakness and numbness that began two days after a self-limited febrile upper respiratory illness. He first noticed tingling in his feet that ascended to mid‑torso, now with a clear sensory level and sharp thoracic back pain; standing produces unsteady gait and frequent stumbling. He endorses urinary urgency with occasional hesitancy over the past 48 hours. He also reports brief electric shock sensations down his spine with neck flexion consistent with Lhermitte phenomenon. On exam he notes brisk lower‑extremity reflexes and decreased vibration sense below the waist. Past history is notable only for childhood eczema. He denies trauma, leg swelling, or bowel incontinence.

A 14-year-old female reports three months of progressive fatigue, an 8-pound weight gain, and increasing cold intolerance. She describes persistent constipation and diffuse hair thinning with dry skin; parents noted a slower pulse during soccer practice. Menstrual cycles have shifted from regular to heavy and irregular over the same interval. Symptoms began about two weeks after an uncomplicated viral upper respiratory illness and have caused daytime somnolence and poor concentration at school. On examination by primary care she had a firm midline thyroid enlargement and resting bradycardia; primary care suspected hypothyroidism. No palpitations or anxiety. Family history is notable for maternal hypothyroidism. No medication or substance use.

A 37-year-old man presents with three months of progressive postprandial epigastric pain and early satiety that began after a self-limited gastroenteritis episode. Pain is crampy, worse after fatty meals, and occasionally provokes nonbilious vomiting; over-the-counter antacids gave minimal relief. He reports pale, greasy stools and an unintentional 10-pound weight loss, and has noticed intermittent yellowing of his eyes but no fevers or melena. He denies alcohol or illicit drug use and has no prior abdominal surgery. Symptoms have gradually limited his work and appetite. He tried a short proton pump inhibitor trial without improvement. Concern centers on a malabsorptive process versus biliary or pancreatic pathology, and he is seeking further evaluation for steatorrhea and chronic postprandial pain.

A 43-year-old man reports six months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough. Initially short of breath only with brisk walking, he now tires climbing a single flight of stairs and has had intermittent low-grade fevers and fatigue. The cough is nonproductive, worse with exertion and at night; he also describes chronic heartburn with nocturnal regurgitation. He worked for a decade in metal fabrication with frequent welding exposure and has a 10 pack-year smoking history, quit five years ago. He notes an 8-pound unintentional weight loss and has observed bulbous fingertip changes. At an urgent visit last month a clinician documented bibasilar inspiratory crackles. He denies hemoptysis, chest pain, or lower-extremity edema but is concerned about possible interstitial lung disease.

A 72-year-old female presents with three months of progressive exertional dyspnea that has acutely worsened over the past ten days following a bout of bronchitis. She describes a persistent dry cough, intermittent low-grade fevers, and marked decline in walking tolerance—now short of breath after a single flight of stairs. She is a former 30–pack-year smoker and has a remote diagnosis of COPD and hypertension. On exam she reports increased fatigue and occasional nighttime cough; outpatient notes document new bibasilar inspiratory crackles and resting hypoxemia. She denies chest pain or leg swelling but notes needing more frequent rest breaks with activities of daily living. She seeks evaluation for possible postinfectious exacerbation versus evolving interstitial process.

A 26-year-old woman reports progressive neurologic symptoms that began three weeks ago after a self-limited upper respiratory illness. One week after the URI she developed acute right eye pain with blurring and color desaturation consistent with optic neuritis, followed over several days by intermittent electric shock–like sensations down the spine with neck flexion (Lhermitte’s phenomenon). She now has bilateral lower-extremity paresthesias, mild gait instability that causes frequent near-falls, new urinary urgency, and pronounced fatigue. Symptoms worsen with heat and exertion. Exam at urgent care noted decreased vibration in the toes and a slightly spastic gait. No prior neurologic history, no trauma, and no recent vaccinations. She is otherwise healthy and denies headaches, fevers, or weight loss.

A 65-year-old woman presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea, acutely worse over the past three days with new left-sided pleuritic chest pain and lightheadedness on exertion. She describes a chronic productive cough for years with baseline exertional limitation that has declined; she is a former smoker. Past history is notable for COPD and atrial fibrillation for which she takes chronic anticoagulation. On review she reports new bilateral lower extremity swelling and an 8-lb unintentional weight loss over two months; she denies fevers. Current symptoms are concerning for a pulmonary embolism or COPD exacerbation with right-heart strain, though cardiac ischemia is felt less likely given the pleuritic quality and cough.

A 6-year-old male presents with five days of progressive right ear pain and fever following a two-day runny nose and nasal congestion. Parents report sudden onset of purulent otorrhea yesterday with noticeable decreased hearing on the right and increasing irritability. He has refused most food and has had two brief episodes of imbalance when walking. Onset was after a mild viral upper respiratory illness; symptoms have not responded to acetaminophen at home. There is new tender swelling behind the right ear and persistent full sensation in the ear. He has no history of recent trauma, foreign body, or chronic ear disease but had one prior ear infection last year. No cough, rash, or conjunctivitis.

A 34-year-old woman presents with six days of progressively worsening dyspnea and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain. She reports a dry cough with a single episode of scant hemoptysis and intermittent low-grade fevers. Symptoms began three days after a transatlantic flight; she also developed new right calf swelling and aching over the past four days. Past history is notable for childhood asthma treated intermittently and current combined oral contraceptive use. She denies recent trauma or known bleeding disorder. Shortness of breath is worse with exertion and deep inspiration, limiting her ability to climb stairs. She is increasingly concerned about a pulmonary embolism given the temporal link to travel and unilateral leg swelling.

A 70-year-old female reports a six-month history of progressive gait difficulty and cognitive slowing. She describes steps feeling "glued," requiring a wider base and a cane for the past six weeks, with two recent falls when getting up from a chair. Family notes increasing short-term memory loss, slowed speech, and blunted affect over three months. She also reports urinary urgency with occasional stress and urge incontinence developing over the same period. Symptoms worsen in the evening and slightly improve after rest. Past medical history notable for well-controlled hypertension and osteoarthritis of the knees, which she says predates current problems but does not explain the new cognitive change. No focal weakness, headache, fever, or photophobia. She denies syncope but acknowledges increased anxiety about mobility.

A 46-year-old man presents with five days of progressive exertional dyspnea and sharp left-sided pleuritic chest pain. He notes a recent 7-hour car trip two weeks ago and a mild COVID-19 infection three weeks earlier. Two days ago he developed scant hemoptysis and new left calf swelling and tenderness; he also reports intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness. Shortness of breath worsens with exertion and he felt his oxygen was low at rest. He is a current smoker with a 20 pack-year history and has treated hypertension. No history of heart failure or chronic lung disease. He denies fever, recent immobility other than the trip, or illicit drug use. Symptoms are concerning for venous thromboembolism with pulmonary involvement.

A 93-year-old man reports a two-month history of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that began after a self-limited bronchitic illness. He notes increasing fatigue, reduction in walking distance from a few blocks to a single room, and an unintentional 6-pound weight loss. He now becomes breathless at rest and occasionally awakens short of breath when climbing stairs. Exam elsewhere by family revealed new basilar inspiratory crackles; home pulse oximetry shows desaturation into the mid-80s with minimal exertion. A recent outpatient CT chest reportedly demonstrated subpleural reticulation with early honeycombing suggestive of pulmonary fibrosis. Past history notable for well-controlled hypertension and a 40 pack-year remote smoking history; no ongoing fevers or sputum production.

A 90-year-old man reports three days of progressive dyspnea and a productive cough that began after a brief choking episode while eating. Sputum is copious and foul-smelling with intermittent low-grade fevers and right-sided pleuritic chest discomfort. He notes increased work of breathing at rest and a drop in exertional tolerance from baseline COPD with chronic bronchitic features; he uses home oxygen intermittently and has required higher flow the last two nights. Past stroke left him with mild oropharyngeal dysphagia, and family describe decreased oral intake and lethargy. On arrival he is tachypneic with audible crackles over the right lower lung field and peripheral oxygen desaturation. Differential priorities include aspiration pneumonia with superimposed COPD exacerbation and focal consolidation.

A 98-year-old woman presents with six months of progressive gait instability and cognitive slowing, with abrupt worsening over the past two weeks after a treated urinary tract infection. Her family reports increasing short-term memory loss, apathy, and daytime somnolence; she now requires assistance for transfers and has had three low-energy falls at home. Gait is described as broad-based with difficulty initiating steps and a magnetic quality, and she has new urinary urgency with occasional incontinence. On exam at home she was slow to respond with reduced attention and mild postural instability but no focal limb weakness. The clinical picture suggests possible normal-pressure hydrocephalus exacerbated by intercurrent infection and deconditioning; primary concerns are fall risk, cognitive decline, and functional loss.

An 88-year-old man presents with a six-month history of progressive gait instability and intermittent confusion. He and his daughter describe a broad-based, shuffling/magnetic gait with several near-falls and two more significant falls in the past month. Over the same interval he developed urinary urgency that recently progressed to occasional daytime incontinence. Family notes worsening short-term memory and slowed thinking, with episodes of overnight disorientation. He has a long-standing history of treated hypertension. He also reports brief lightheadedness on standing that preceded one fall. A non-contrast head CT performed several months ago demonstrated ventriculomegaly without acute hemorrhage. No prior neurosurgical procedures; no fevers, focal weakness, or chest pain. The constellation raised concern for normal-pressure hydrocephalus with contributory orthostatic symptoms.

A 9-year-old boy presents with five days of progressive unsteady gait and multiple near-falls. Symptoms began abruptly with truncal instability and difficulty navigating stairs, now accompanied by intermittent projectile vomiting and daily holocranial headache. Parents report new slurred speech and brief episodes of horizontal nystagmus on attempted lateral gaze, but he remains awake and interactive without focal limb weakness or sensory change. Two weeks prior he had a diffuse vesicular rash consistent with varicella and low-grade fever that resolved. No recent head trauma, no known toxin exposures, and immunizations otherwise up to date. Examination at home shows worsening dysmetria on finger-to-nose testing and inability to tandem walk, prompting concern for postinfectious cerebellar dysfunction.

A 65-year-old female presents with acute onset shortness of breath and sharp, pleuritic right-sided chest pain that began 48 hours ago and has progressively worsened with minimal exertion. She endorses a dry cough and intermittent lightheadedness but denies fever or bilateral leg symptoms. She notes new left calf swelling and tenderness starting about a week after a prolonged 10-hour car trip two weeks ago. At home she felt palpitations and describes resting tachycardia with episodes of oxygen desaturation. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and osteoarthritis. She reports decreased exercise tolerance compared with baseline and is worried the symptoms may relate to a blood clot given the unilateral leg swelling; she has no recent surgery or known clotting disorder.

A 74-year-old woman presents with acute, painless loss of vision in her right eye progressing over 48 hours, preceded for two weeks by intermittent transient visual obscurations and new floaters. She reports associated persistent temporal scalp tenderness and jaw claudication with chewing, and has noted morning stiffness of the shoulder and hip girdles for the past three weeks limiting dressing. She describes low-grade fevers and an unintentional three-pound weight loss over a month. Primary care initiated empiric high-dose steroids after palpating a tender, cord-like right temporal artery. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She denies head trauma, focal limb weakness, or diplopia. No prior ocular surgery; home vision decline was previously attributed to cataracts.

A 70-year-old woman presents with four months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that began after a winter upper respiratory illness. Initially short of breath only with stairs, she now becomes winded walking across a grocery aisle and notes increased fatigue and a 7-pound unintentional weight loss. Her primary care clinician documented new bibasilar inspiratory "Velcro" crackles and reported exertional oxygen desaturation; she denies fevers, hemoptysis, or orthopnea. She is a former 10–pack-year smoker who quit decades ago and has well-controlled hypertension. She also describes intermittent pleuritic chest discomfort and mild daytime anorexia. She has not been on supplemental oxygen and seeks evaluation for progressive symptoms and concern for interstitial lung disease.

A 91-year-old man presents with six months of progressive cognitive slowing and new gait instability. Family reports a gradually shuffling, magnetic gait with difficulty initiating steps and worsening short-term memory; he has had three ground-level falls in the past four weeks. Over the last month he developed urinary urgency that progressed to intermittent incontinence. Exam is notable for broad-based gait and mild frontal release signs at home. Past medical history includes hypertension and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, managed outpatient. Symptoms are most consistent with possible normal-pressure hydrocephalus versus mixed vascular cognitive impairment; the family denies preceding infection, acute focal weakness, or visual loss. They seek evaluation for mobility support and etiologic workup.

A 5-year-old boy presents with four days of progressively worsening cough and audible wheeze, preceded by two days of clear rhinorrhea and low-grade fever. Parents describe paroxysmal nocturnal coughing, shortness of breath with play, and increased work of breathing with mild intercostal retractions. He has decreased oral intake and poor sleep. On exam at home he appeared pale and fatigued between coughing spells. No known aspiration or foreign-body event. Past history notable for intermittent viral-induced wheeze last winter and chronic atopic dermatitis. No known cardiac disease. Symptoms partially responded to humidified air at home but coughing and activity limitation have increased, prompting evaluation for bronchiolitis versus reactive airways exacerbation and assessment of oxygenation.

A 44-year-old man presents with two months of intermittent exertional syncope and progressive exertional dyspnea. Episodes occur when climbing stairs or during heavy lifting, often preceded by several minutes of central chest tightness and palpitations; one episode required him to sit. He also reports daytime lightheadedness and occasional near-fainting after standing quickly. Denies orthopnea, fever, or focal weakness. On prior outpatient ECG he had frequent premature ventricular complexes and a noted harsh systolic murmur that increases with Valsalva. Past history significant for well-controlled hypertension. Family history remarkable for a father who died suddenly in his 50s. He attributes worsening to a recent increase in gym activity and is concerned about a structural cardiomyopathy.

A 13-year-old male presents with two weeks of progressive dizziness and unsteady gait after a febrile upper respiratory illness; parents note onset about six days after the infection. He now has daily morning headache that worsens with head movement, intermittent nausea with one emesis, and new slurred speech. Onset included transient double vision and horizontal oscillopsia; at home he has had two near-falls. Symptoms cluster around coordination and brainstem-cerebellar dysfunction rather than isolated vertigo. There is no history of trauma, seizures, or chronic neurologic disease. Exam at triage showed truncal ataxia, dysmetria on the right, and horizontal nystagmus. Concern is for postinfectious cerebellitis versus other inflammatory or structural posterior fossa processes.

A 77-year-old male reports six months of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough. He describes a two-week acceleration with shortness of breath with minimal activity, intermittent low-grade fevers, and an 8-kg unintentional weight loss. He now notices activity-related oxygen desaturation and marked fatigue limiting his walking tolerance. Prior exam documented bilateral basilar inspiratory "velcro" crackles and early digital clubbing. He is a former 30–pack-year smoker with known hypertension. He denies chest pain, wheeze, or hemoptysis. Recent high-resolution chest imaging was reported to show basilar reticular change concerning for a usual interstitial pneumonia pattern, and he presents for evaluation of suspected idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis with progressive hypoxemia.

A 28-year-old woman presents with acute progressive shortness of breath and sharp left-sided pleuritic chest pain for the past 48 hours. Pain is worse with inspiration and associated with a dry cough and intermittent palpitations; she reports subjective lightheadedness and a recent sense of tachycardia. She noticed new right calf swelling, tenderness, and mild erythema two days ago after a six-hour car ride, and she is currently taking combined oral contraceptives. Past history is significant only for mild intermittent asthma and seasonal allergic rhinitis. There is no fever, recent trauma, or illicit drug use. Given the temporal sequence—post‑travel calf symptoms followed by acute dyspnea and pleuritic pain—she is concerned about pulmonary embolism secondary to deep vein thrombosis.

A 61-year-old female reports three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and intermittent right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began after a prolonged period of immobility during travel several weeks ago. She describes a new, nonproductive cough with occasional scant hemoptysis and reports one week of increasing unilateral calf swelling and tenderness. Episodes of palpitations and lightheadedness occur with minimal exertion; she has noticed transient resting tachycardia at home. She denies fever or night sweats but feels more fatigued than usual and avoids stairs because of breathlessness. No prior history of venous thromboembolism. The temporal sequence—travel, leg symptoms, then acute respiratory complaints—raises concern for deep vein thrombosis with pulmonary embolism and possible secondary hypoxemia.

A 62-year-old woman presents with sudden-onset episodic right facial droop and right arm weakness with slurred speech that began 36 hours ago. Each episode has lasted 10–20 minutes and has occurred three times, with near-complete resolution between events. She also describes a brief painless left monocular visual loss lasting about five minutes. Her medical history is notable for hypertension and a recent episode of palpitations two weeks ago suggestive of atrial fibrillation. On exam a cervical bruit was auscultated and mild residual right-hand clumsiness persists. The pattern is most consistent with recurrent transient ischemic attacks, likely embolic from a cardiac source with possible carotid atherosclerotic disease; she denies headache, fever, or recent trauma.

A 55-year-old woman reports six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a daily productive cough, initially clear sputum that developed intermittent blood-tinged streaks over the past ten days. Symptoms began after a presumed bronchitis; she now notes low-grade fevers, pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort with deep breaths, and an unintentional five-pound weight loss. She describes occasional wheeze and increased nighttime shortness of breath limiting stairs. Past history is notable for well-controlled hypertension and a remote unprovoked DVT for which she is not anticoagulated; she is a former 30 pack-year smoker who quit five years ago. No recent travel. Concerned symptoms could reflect postinfectious bronchiectasis, occult infection, or thromboembolic disease given prior DVT.

A 28-year-old woman reports abrupt onset of left-sided pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath that began 36 hours ago. The pain is sharp, worse with deep inspiration and coughing, and associated with scant hemoptysis and intermittent palpitations. She describes progressive left calf swelling and tenderness starting two days before the chest symptoms after a prolonged transatlantic flight; she uses combined oral contraceptives and has no prior thrombotic events. She has low-grade fevers and decreased exercise tolerance but denies wheeze, prior asthma, or recent immobilization other than the flight. Symptoms began while walking and have not improved with rest. No recent surgery or pregnancy. Given the temporal sequence of calf pain then sudden dyspnea and pleuritic pain, she is concerned about pulmonary embolism related to deep venous thrombosis.

A 32-year-old woman reports a 10-day history of progressive vision loss in her right eye, describing central blurring and a small persistent scotoma. Vision worsens with eye movement and she notes aching periocular pain; colors appear washed on the right. Symptoms began shortly after a self-limited upper respiratory infection. She also describes intermittent tingling in the right forearm and occasional heat-related worsening of visual symptoms when showering. At a brief exam she had reduced visual acuity on the right and a relative afferent pupillary defect. She denies trauma, headache, or jaw pain. Given the subacute monocular visual loss with pain and sensory symptoms, optic neuritis with concern for an underlying demyelinating process was discussed and neuro-ophthalmology referral arranged.

A 63-year-old female presents with four days of progressive exertional dyspnea and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain that increases with deep inspiration. Symptoms began after a prolonged car trip and have progressed from breathlessness climbing stairs to shortness of breath at rest; she also describes intermittent palpitations and a dry cough. She noticed new swelling and tenderness of the right calf yesterday. She reports a low-grade fever and mild diaphoresis but denies hemoptysis. Past medical history is notable only for well-controlled hypertension. Given the temporal pattern after immobilization, the constellation of pleuritic pain, tachyarrhythmic sensations, hypoxia-related dyspnea, and unilateral leg swelling raises concern for pulmonary embolism secondary to deep vein thrombosis.

A 32-year-old female presents with ten days of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent nonproductive cough that began after an upper respiratory illness. The cough is worse at night and with deep inspiration; she developed a sharp pleuritic left-sided chest pain when taking deep breaths. She reports intermittent palpitations with exertion, low-grade fevers, and marked fatigue with decreased exercise tolerance compared with baseline. On exertion she now notices audible wheeze and chest tightness; she denies hemoptysis, syncope, or unilateral leg swelling. She has a history of childhood asthma, off inhalers for several years. Symptoms evolved after a week of rhinorrhea and sore throat and have not improved with rest, raising concern for persistent postinfectious bronchospasm.

A 71-year-old woman reports progressive exertional dyspnea and a dry cough for approximately six months, with a marked deterioration over the past three weeks. She now fatigues with walking a single block and notes resting breathlessness; family observed new fingertip clubbing. She describes increasing bibasilar crackle sensation (patient-reported) and several episodes of nocturnal cough without fever. Over the last two weeks she developed bilateral ankle swelling and mild orthostatic lightheadedness. She has a history of treated hypertension and remote tobacco exposure. She denies chest pain or hemoptysis. The timeline and clubbing raise concern for underlying interstitial lung disease with secondary pulmonary hypertension and early right-sided heart failure, and she reports intermittent mild resting oxygen desaturation at home.

A 39-year-old man reports two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and sharp left-sided pleuritic chest pain that began acutely after a long flight. Symptoms started as a dry cough following a recent upper respiratory illness but have evolved to occasional small-volume hemoptysis and marked reduction in exercise tolerance. He notes new swelling and tenderness in the left calf and intermittent palpitations with exertion. He has low-grade fevers and orthopnea is denied. Past history is notable for intermittent childhood asthma but no chronic lung disease. He is a current smoker with no known clotting disorder. He is concerned about a possible pulmonary embolism given the travel and calf swelling.

A 28-year-old man presents with sudden onset right-sided pleuritic chest pain and progressive shortness of breath that began while playing basketball this morning. Pain is sharp, worsens with deep inspiration, and accompanied by a dry cough and lightheadedness. He reports a two-week prodrome of upper respiratory symptoms with intermittent coughing but no fever. He is tall, thin, a current occasional smoker, and has had spontaneous transient chest tightness with exertion in the past. On arrival he notes neck fullness and a sensation of air under the skin. He denies trauma, hemoptysis, or recent travel. Symptoms are most consistent with a primary spontaneous pneumothorax with possible subcutaneous emphysema; tachycardia and diminished right-sided breath sounds were noted at triage.

A 25-year-old man presents with sudden left-sided pleuritic chest pain and progressive shortness of breath that began overnight. He reports a five-day prodrome of dry cough and mild rhinorrhea, then developed an acute popping sensation after a bout of forceful coughing while playing soccer; the pain is sharp, worse with inspiration, and associated with dyspnea and lightheadedness. He is an occasional cigarette smoker. On self-exam he noticed crepitus in the left supraclavicular region and now describes reduced air entry on the left without fever. He denies trauma, hemoptysis, or prior lung disease. Symptoms worsen with exertion, prompting urgent evaluation for possible spontaneous pneumothorax.

An 8-year-old girl presents with a two-week history of intermittent binocular diplopia and new blurred vision, most pronounced in the afternoons and at school. Parents report a drooping right eyelid that worsens with play and improves after rest, and occasional periorbital pain without nausea or vomiting. She has mild photophobia and daily frontal headaches that awaken her once or twice per week. Symptoms began about a week after a brief viral upper respiratory illness; there is no recent head trauma or fever now. Exam at school noted variable horizontal eye misalignment and reduced near reading tolerance, impacting homework. Past history includes seasonal allergic rhinitis and normal developmental milestones. No prior ocular surgery or known refractive error. Family denies seizures or facial weakness.

A 59-year-old female reports progressive exertional dyspnea and a nonproductive dry cough over the past nine months, with marked worsening in the last four weeks such that she tires after short walks and needs frequent rest. She notes occasional exertional lightheadedness and mild night cough that she attributes to reflux. She has developed resting fingertip clubbing and describes increasing baseline fatigue and unintentional 6–8 lb weight loss. On exam she feels short of breath with minimal exertion and recalls a prior diagnosis of systemic sclerosis; she was recently told her pulmonary symptoms may represent fibrosis. She also has well-controlled hypertension. No fevers, hemoptysis, or new cardiac chest pain are reported.

A 33-year-old man presents with four days of progressive exertional dyspnea and new left-sided pleuritic chest pain. The dyspnea is worse with minimal exertion and accompanied by a dry cough and two episodes of scant hemoptysis. He developed left calf swelling and aching 48 hours after a prolonged overnight bus trip and notes mild low-grade fevers and sweats. He has a remote history of childhood asthma but has not used inhalers in years. He smokes a pack a day and denies illicit drug use. No recent trauma or surgery. He is anxious about a possible blood clot given the calf swelling and worsening breathlessness, and reports intermittent palpitations.

An 82-year-old man reports two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and persistent dry cough that has limited his walking pace. He notes a recent 48-hour change with new pleuritic right-sided chest pain and scant hemoptysis after a brief period of reduced mobility following a minor fall. He now has low-grade fevers and generalized fatigue. At baseline he carries a diagnosis of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis treated conservatively and is a former smoker. On brief exam he had bibasilar inspiratory crackles and the patient mentions new right calf swelling and mild discomfort. He denies frank orthopnea or chest pressure. Symptoms have steadily worsened, prompting evaluation for acute exacerbation, pulmonary embolism, or superimposed infection.

A 65-year-old man reports six months of progressive gait unsteadiness with two ground-level falls in the past month. He describes a slow, short-stepped, broad-based (magnetic) gait and increasing difficulty initiating steps; family notes slowed thinking and recent short-term memory decline over the same interval. Urinary urgency with occasional urge incontinence began three months ago and has worsened, limiting outings. He endorses mild distal numbness and paresthesia in the feet consistent with longstanding diabetic peripheral neuropathy. Past medical history includes treated hypertension and type 2 diabetes, both reportedly stable. He denies limb weakness, fever, or recent head trauma. Examination at the clinic revealed frontal release signs and cautious ambulation; clinical concern is raised for a hydrocephalus-related syndrome such as normal-pressure hydrocephalus.

An 80-year-old woman presents with two months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that has noticeably worsened during the past week after a bronchitic illness. She reports decreased exercise tolerance, early satiety from breathlessness, and unintentional 6-pound weight loss. On review she notes intermittent low-grade fevers and new resting breathlessness requiring frequent sitting; family observed finger clubbing. Exam at home revealed increased work of breathing and persistent wheeze previously attributed to a remote 30-pack-year smoking history; she also has long-standing controlled hypertension. She denies chest pain or frank hemoptysis. Symptoms began insidiously and have clustered around insidious interstitial symptoms with recent acute decline, prompting concern for progressive pulmonary fibrosis with superimposed infection or acute exacerbation.

A 5-year-old boy presents with two days of progressively worse cough and noisy breathing. Symptoms began with clear rhinorrhea and a low-grade fever after daycare exposure; caregivers recall a brief choking episode on a small snack three nights ago. Since then he has had persistent inspiratory stridor and intermittent wheeze, louder on the right, with diminished oral intake and decreased activity. At home he appears more tachypneic with visible subcostal retractions and occasional gagging but no cyanosis. He has a prior history of intermittent reactive airways triggered by viruses and several past otitis media episodes. Caregivers are concerned for a retained airway foreign body versus a viral-driven reactive airway exacerbation given the temporal choking event and focal noisy breathing.

A 33-year-old female reports three months of progressive upper gastrointestinal symptoms, beginning with intermittent heartburn and postprandial regurgitation and evolving over six weeks into progressive solid‑food dysphagia and intermittent odynophagia. She experienced a recent food impaction that she relieved by self-induced regurgitation and subsequently noted approximately 10 lb of unintentional weight loss and decreased appetite. A two‑week trial of a proton‑pump inhibitor provided minimal improvement. Primary care testing last month revealed iron‑deficiency anemia. She has lifelong eczema and seasonal allergic rhinitis. She denies NSAID overuse, hematemesis, or fevers. Concern is for an obstructing ring or peptic stricture versus eosinophilic esophagitis; endoscopic evaluation with biopsy has been scheduled.

A 47-year-old man presents with two weeks of progressive exertional chest pressure and shortness of breath; the pressure is described as a tightness across the mid-chest that reliably occurs with climbing a single flight of stairs and eases with brief rest. Over the past five days he has developed palpitations and intermittent lightheadedness, once nearly fainting after exertion. He reports new ankle swelling and wakes once nightly with breathlessness, needing two pillows to sleep, and had a single episode last week of sudden severe dyspnea waking him from sleep. He denies cough, fever, or pleuritic pain. Past medical history is significant for treated hypertension and a 20-pack-year smoking history. No recent travel or known infectious exposure.

A 34-year-old female reports four days of progressive exertional dyspnea and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain that increases with deep inspiration. She also has a dry cough, intermittent wheeze, and subjective low-grade fevers; she noticed mild palpitations and feels more short of breath when climbing stairs. Symptoms began several days after a long transatlantic flight and she has used a rescue inhaler with only partial relief. Past history is atopic asthma, otherwise healthy. She takes combined oral contraceptives and recalls a brief right calf ache after the flight but denies hemoptysis, syncope, or recent upper respiratory infection. She seeks evaluation because her exercise tolerance has declined and chest pain persists despite rest.

An 89-year-old man presents with two weeks of progressive dyspnea, acutely worse over the past 48 hours, and a three-day productive cough with yellow sputum and low-grade fevers. He endorses new orthopnea and increased ankle swelling; family notes mild confusion and lethargy since the breathing worsened. Symptoms began after a recent dental extraction, and he reports a chronic history of COPD and hypertension. On exam he has audible wheeze and bibasilar crackles at the lung bases consistent with volume overload versus consolidation. Concern is for aspiration-related pneumonia precipitating COPD exacerbation and a decompensated heart failure component, with hypoxic delirium. He denies chest pain, hemoptysis, or recent travel.

A 28-year-old woman presents with three weeks of progressively worsening daily headache, described as diffuse pressure worse in the mornings and with Valsalva maneuvers, now accompanied by transient visual obscurations and intermittent horizontal diplopia. She reports new pulsatile tinnitus on the right, photophobia, and episodic nausea without emesis. She notes a recent 15-pound weight gain over six months and irregular menses. On exam she endorses blurred vision on waking and occasional lateral gaze difficulty. No history of migraine or recent head trauma. The constellation of progressive headache, optic disc swelling complaints, visual disturbances, and sixth-nerve–type diplopia raises concern for increased intracranial pressure, most consistent with suspected idiopathic intracranial hypertension, prompting urgent neuro-ophthalmology evaluation and neuroimaging.

An 84-year-old male presents with two weeks of progressive dyspnea and a new productive cough following a viral upper respiratory illness. He reports greenish purulent sputum and intermittent low-grade fever for five days, with worsening shortness of breath on exertion and one episode of scant hemoptysis yesterday. Over the past 24 hours he developed pleuritic right-sided chest pain and marked fatigue, prompting evaluation. He has a history of COPD and hypertension and is a former smoker. On ambulatory exertion he notes oxygen levels fall and he becomes noticeably more breathless. Exam at home revealed increased wheeze and diminished breath sounds at the right base. Primary concerns are COPD exacerbation with superimposed pneumonia versus pulmonary embolism.

An 82-year-old man presents with a two-week history of progressive decrease in urine output and increasing bilateral leg swelling. He has long-standing hypertension and known chronic kidney disease but reports a recent change with worsening nocturnal urinary hesitancy and straining consistent with prostatic obstruction. Over the last five days he notes worsening fatigue, mild anorexia, intermittent nausea, and new muscle weakness with occasional palpitations. Family members describe brief episodes of lethargy and subtle confusion. Exam findings at home include progressive peripheral pitting edema and shortness of breath when climbing stairs. He worries this represents acute-on-chronic kidney injury from urinary retention with resultant volume overload and possible hyperkalemia. No recent antibiotics or procedures; no chest pain or focal neurologic deficits. He seeks evaluation for catheterization and assessment of renal function.

A previously healthy 18-year-old male presents with abrupt onset of left-sided pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea that began during soccer practice two days ago. The pain is sharp, worse with inspiration and coughing, and associated with a persistent dry cough and mild palpitations on exertion. He reports decreased exercise tolerance and intermittent chest tightness but denies fever, hemoptysis, or syncope. He vapes daily and had a brief upper respiratory infection one week earlier. On exam he describes asymmetric respiratory effort and diminished breath sounds on the left; he has no prior lung disease. Concern is for primary spontaneous pneumothorax versus viral pleuritis or bleb-related collapse; chest radiograph is pending and urgent pulmonary follow-up arranged.

A 52-year-old woman reports sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye this morning following two weeks of progressively worsening right temporal headache and scalp tenderness when combing her hair. She describes intermittent jaw claudication with chewing and new, pronounced morning stiffness in the shoulders and hips for six weeks, limiting dressing. Over the past month she has had low-grade fevers, fatigue, and a three-pound unintentional weight loss. There is an associated patchy visual field deficit and blurring that preceded the complete loss. She has a history of well-controlled hypertension on oral therapy and denies recent trauma, eye discharge, or systemic rash. Symptoms evolved from dull temporal pain to acute visual decline, raising concern for an inflammatory vasculitic process affecting the optic circulation.

A 1-year-old male presents with an eight-hour history of intermittent, colicky abdominal pain and progressive non-bilious vomiting. Parents describe recurrent episodes of intense crying during which he draws his legs up, separated by periods of relative calm. He passed one red-tinged stool this morning and has developed watery diarrhea and markedly decreased oral intake. Over the past several hours he has had fewer wet diapers and appears unusually lethargic with low-grade fever. On brief home exam the caregiver palpated a firm, sausage-shaped mass in the right upper abdomen. There was a viral upper respiratory illness about one week ago. No prior gastrointestinal surgery or known chronic illness. The timeline and clustered symptoms raise concern for possible intussusception with dehydration.

A 10-year-old boy presents with a three-week history of progressive morning headaches and recurrent projectile vomiting, most pronounced on arising and with bending forward. Parents report new intermittent horizontal diplopia and blurred vision, accompanied by increasing unsteadiness and a broad-based gait with frequent falls while running. He has had decreased appetite and an unintentional 4-pound weight loss over two weeks and appears more lethargic with declining attention at school. There is no fever, recent head trauma, or systemic illness reported. On brief clinic exam he demonstrates bilateral papilledema and mild dysmetria on heel-to-shin testing. Family denies prior neurologic problems; symptoms have intensified over the last week, prompting urgent further neuroimaging and neurology referral.

A 68-year-old woman presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough, described as worse over the past two weeks after a bronchitic upper respiratory illness. She reports new low-grade fevers, fatigue, and a three-kilogram unintentional weight loss. On exertion she becomes short of breath and notes episodes of lightheadedness; family noticed her fingers appear broader. She has remote 20 pack-year smoking and a long-standing history of rheumatoid arthritis. On exam she endorses reduced exercise tolerance; auscultation reveals fine bibasilar inspiratory crackles. She denies chest pain or frank hemoptysis. She is most concerned about worsening breathlessness interfering with daily activities and seeks evaluation for possible interstitial lung disease or postinfectious complication.

An 88-year-old male presents with five days of progressive dyspnea and a productive cough that began after a choking episode while eating. Family reports the sputum is foul-smelling and he developed low‑grade fevers within 48 hours; over the past two days he has had new confusion and decreased oral intake. He carries a history of COPD and baseline reduced exercise tolerance. At home he has intermittent resting hypoxemia by pulse oximetry and appears more tachypneic than usual. Caregivers recall intermittent oropharyngeal dysphagia for months prior. The temporal clustering of choking, foul sputum, fever, hypoxemia and altered mental status is most consistent with aspiration pneumonia on a background of chronic lung disease.

A frail 84-year-old man reports ten days of progressive exertional dyspnea and a productive cough after a recent influenza-like illness. He describes greenish sputum, intermittent low-grade fevers, and new pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort with deep breaths. He notes worsening orthopnea and has required nocturnal supplemental oxygen more often than his baseline from underlying COPD and long-standing hypertension. Family members report decreased appetite and reduced ambulation; he has intermittent wheeze and increased use of his rescue inhaler. He denies frank hemoptysis but notes mild bilateral ankle swelling compared with baseline. The constellation is most consistent with acute on chronic bronchitis or community-acquired pneumonia with possible early heart-failure exacerbation; he has a 40-pack-year smoking history.

A 28-year-old woman reports a three-week progression of daily pressure-type headaches, worse on waking and with bending, accompanied by brief episodes of transient visual obscurations and intermittent binocular diplopia. She describes new constant pulsatile tinnitus on the right, morning nausea without emesis, and increased photophobia. Symptoms began after a 10–15 pound weight gain over two months and are exacerbated by Valsalva maneuvers. She denies fever, recent infection, or prior migraine history. An urgent exam noted bilateral optic disc swelling consistent with papilledema and a horizontal abduction deficit suggestive of a sixth-nerve palsy. No limb weakness or sensory changes; she is otherwise healthy and not taking new medications.

A 68-year-old man reports three months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough, with marked worsening over the past two weeks after a presumed upper respiratory infection. He notes new exertional desaturation—shortness of breath when climbing a single flight of stairs—and an unintentional 5-kg weight loss. Examination at clinic visit revealed bibasilar inspiratory crackles and early digital clubbing. He is a former smoker (20 pack‑years, quit 25 years ago) and has long-standing hypertension treated intermittently. He denies fevers, hemoptysis, or ankle swelling. The pattern, clubbing, and progressive hypoxemia raise concern for an underlying interstitial lung process such as pulmonary fibrosis with possible secondary pulmonary hypertension; further imaging and pulmonary function testing were requested.

A 2-year-old female presents with sudden onset intermittent severe abdominal pain and vomiting for 14 hours. Episodes occur every 20–30 minutes with loud crying and drawing up of the legs; between episodes she appears lethargic and pale. Parents report two episodes of dark red, “currant-jelly” stool and markedly decreased oral intake. She has low-grade fever and fewer wet diapers over the last 12 hours. On exam at home they palpated a firm, sausage-shaped mass in the right upper abdomen and noted signs of mild dehydration. Symptoms began after a mild runny nose and cough earlier in the week. Concern for intussusception with associated dehydration; transported for urgent evaluation.

A 37-year-old female reports four months of secondary amenorrhea and new spontaneous milky nipple discharge, initially noted after stopping combined hormonal contraception. She also describes progressive, bifrontal headaches for three weeks with intermittent peripheral visual blurring and difficulty noticing objects on both temporal sides. Concurrent symptoms include persistent fatigue, decreased libido, and an unintentional 10-pound weight gain. She has been trying to conceive for a year without success. On review, she denies galactorrhea-related breast pain, fever, or focal weakness. The constellation of amenorrhea, galactorrhea, hyposexuality, headaches, and bitemporal visual changes raised concern for hyperprolactinemia from a pituitary macroadenoma; neuroimaging has been ordered and endocrine evaluation is underway.

A 19-year-old male college student presents with four days of progressively worsening unsteadiness and slurred speech following a brief febrile viral illness. He developed myalgias and low-grade fever five days ago that resolved, then three days later noticed sudden gait instability with frequent veering and two near-falls. Family observed slurred words and intermittent horizontal double vision. He endorses nausea, a constant holocephalic headache, and oscillating blurred vision but denies headache photophobia or photophobia-associated vomiting. On exam he reports coarse head tremor and intermittent limb dysmetria when reaching; no clear limb weakness or sensory loss reported. He denies head trauma, recent travel, or substance use. Symptoms are progressive, impairing ambulation and concentration, and began shortly after the preceding viral syndrome.

A 31-year-old woman presents with six weeks of progressive postprandial epigastric burning and early satiety. Pain is worst after solid meals, rated 4–6/10, and is intermittently accompanied by nausea and nonbilious vomiting; she reports one episode of black, tarry stool last week. She has unintentionally lost about 6 pounds and notes increased fatigue and lightheadedness consistent with her known iron-deficiency anemia. She used over-the-counter NSAIDs nightly for a wrist strain over the past two months and had documented H. pylori infection treated in adolescence. The temporal pattern and combination of bleeding, weight loss, prior H. pylori, and recent NSAID exposure raise concern for peptic ulcer disease with possible partial gastric outlet obstruction; she denies alcohol or tobacco use.

A 64-year-old woman presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and three weeks of a productive cough with yellow sputum; she now tires after short walks and avoids stairs. She reports intermittent pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort and two episodes of scant hemoptysis over the past week. She notes persistent left calf swelling since an outpatient diagnosis of left lower-extremity DVT two months ago. Home history includes well-controlled hypertension and a 25 pack-year remote smoking history; she stopped ten years ago. She describes new exertional lightheadedness and occasional palpitations but denies fever, night sweats, or weight loss. The temporal clustering of prior DVT, progressive dyspnea, pleuritic pain, and edema raises concern for chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension with a superimposed bronchitic process.

A 61-year-old female presents with eight weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that began after a brief bronchitic illness. She notes intermittent pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort, low-grade fevers, and a 6–8 pound unintentional weight loss. Symptoms limit walking several blocks; she reports new oxygen desaturation with minimal exertion. Exam at the clinic revealed fine bibasilar inspiratory crackles and subtle digital clubbing. She is a former 20 pack-year smoker who quit a decade ago and has a history of well-controlled hypertension. No orthopnea or peripheral edema is reported. Given the subacute course, clubbing, and desaturation, concern is for an underlying interstitial lung process such as pulmonary fibrosis, with possible secondary pulmonary vascular involvement.

A 38-year-old female reports six weeks of progressive palpitations, unintentional 11-pound weight loss, and marked heat intolerance. Palpitations occur daily, sometimes with lightheadedness and a fine tremor of the hands, and one episode lasted several hours with an irregularly irregular heartbeat. She describes worsening anxiety, insomnia, and recent menstrual irregularity with lighter, more frequent cycles. Over the past month she has developed eye irritation and apparent proptosis with periorbital swelling, and notes a new, diffusely enlarged, non-tender anterior neck mass that moves with swallowing. Symptoms began after a brief upper respiratory infection and have increasingly limited her exercise tolerance and work. She denies prior thyroid disease or known autoimmune disorders.

A 70-year-old man reports six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that began after a self-limited upper respiratory illness. Initially able to walk the dog, he now becomes breathless after a single flight of stairs and notes intermittent lightheadedness with exertion. He describes new mild bilateral ankle swelling and orthopnea at night. On review he endorses diminished exercise tolerance, a 40-pack-year smoking history, and a background of hypertension. Exam at home has revealed audible bibasilar crackles and occasional wheeze; he also noticed oxygen saturation dropping into the high 80s with minimal ambulation. Patient is concerned about underlying interstitial lung disease versus evolving pulmonary hypertension/right-sided strain and requests further evaluation.

A 9-year-old female presents with a two-week history of progressive dry cough and increasing shortness of breath during play that began after a febrile upper respiratory infection. Parents describe frequent nocturnal coughing spells and new chest tightness; she now tires easily in gym class and wheezes audibly with exertion. There has been no persistent high fever or hemoptysis. Past history is notable for atopic dermatitis and chronic seasonal allergic rhinitis. On brief clinic exam she showed scattered expiratory wheezes and mild tachypnea. Clinical concern is for new-onset asthma or viral-induced reactive airways disease, with post-infectious bronchiolitis considered given the prolonged cough and incomplete recovery since the initial infection.

An 85-year-old woman presents with ten days of progressive vision loss in the right eye, beginning as blurred central vision and worsening to near-complete loss centrally. She reports a two-week history of a new, persistent right temporal headache and intermittent jaw claudication with chewing; over the past week she has noticed scalp tenderness when combing her hair. She describes new morning stiffness in both shoulders limiting dressing, consistent with polymyalgia rheumatica–type symptoms. She underwent cataract surgery in the left eye several years ago and has longstanding hypertension. She denies ocular trauma or purulent discharge but reports low-grade fevers and increased fatigue, and is worried the visual loss may be permanent.

A 71-year-old man presents with two weeks of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and a productive cough that began after a presumed upper respiratory infection. Sputum is thick and yellow, associated with intermittent pleuritic left-sided chest discomfort and audible wheeze at baseline; he reports using his rescue inhaler several times daily without relief. He notes increased orthopnea over the past three nights and mild bilateral ankle swelling, limiting his ability to climb stairs. Past history includes COPD with a 45 pack-year smoking history and well-controlled hypertension. He denies hemoptysis or weight loss but feels febrile with night sweats. Symptoms represent a change from his usual COPD course, prompting concern for superimposed bronchitic exacerbation or evolving cardiopulmonary decompensation.

An 80-year-old female reports three months of progressive gait instability with a widened, shuffling step and two recent near-falls, accompanied by insidious short-term memory decline and word-finding difficulty. Family notes increasing urinary urgency and one episode of daytime incontinence over the past month. She describes a minor head bump on carpeted floor two weeks ago after which imbalance and intermittent headache worsened. No new focal weakness or sensory loss. Past medical history includes well-controlled hypertension and chronic knee osteoarthritis limiting endurance. Home uses a cane intermittently. Review of systems negative for fever, chest pain, or focal vision change. Symptoms concern for a chronic subdural process unmasking possible normal-pressure hydrocephalus versus progression of neurodegenerative disease.

A 7-year-old girl presents with a two-week history of progressively worsening morning headaches and intermittent nonbilious vomiting. Caregiver notes headaches awaken her and improve as the day progresses; pain is pressure-like and accompanied by transient double vision and blurred vision. Over the past five days she has developed an unsteady gait and occasional stumbling, with difficulty climbing stairs. There has been decreased appetite but no fevers or recent head trauma. She had a viral upper respiratory illness three weeks ago. On a recent school visit teachers noted increased somnolence and slower concentration. Outpatient exam reportedly documented papilledema and a left sixth-nerve palsy. Family denies seizures, rash, or recent travel.

A 53-year-old female presents with three days of progressive exertional dyspnea and pleuritic right-sided chest pain. Symptoms began after a week-long domestic flight; she subsequently noted right calf swelling and sharp localized pain. She reports scant blood-tinged sputum and intermittent lightheadedness but no fever. Dyspnea is worse with minimal exertion and when supine. Past medical history notable for well-controlled hypertension and a 30-pack-year smoking history, quit five years ago, and ongoing menopausal estrogen therapy. She denies chronic cough or known lung disease. On review, she endorses tachycardia and anxiety related to breathing difficulty. The timeframe and calf swelling raise concern for deep venous thrombosis complicated by pulmonary embolism; alternative cardiopulmonary causes are under consideration.

A 64-year-old man reports six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that began after an episode treated as bronchitis. Cough is now intermittently blood-tinged and is associated with reduced exercise tolerance; he becomes winded after climbing one flight of stairs. He also notes unintentional eight-pound weight loss, night sweats, and occasional low-grade fevers. He is a former 40–pack-year smoker and has a history of hypertension. He denies orthopnea or lower-extremity edema but notes increased work of breathing at night. On review he tried over-the-counter expectorants with minimal relief. Concern is for an underlying structural or inflammatory pulmonary process given bibasilar inspiratory crackles on self-observed exam and progressive systemic symptoms.

A 35-year-old man reports four days of progressive blurred vision in his right eye accompanied by deep periorbital pain that worsens with eye movement. He describes color desaturation and a central dark spot that developed over 48 hours; exam demonstrated a relative afferent pupillary defect. Symptoms began about one week after a febrile upper respiratory illness. He also recalls two brief, self-limited episodes of right-sided numbness and tingling two months ago. He denies trauma, jaw claudication, or rash. The pattern of unilateral painful visual loss with dyschromatopsia and an RAPD is most consistent with acute optic neuritis and raises concern for an underlying demyelinating process.

A 41-year-old woman presents with a two-week history of progressive right facial numbness and intermittent diplopia. Symptoms began several days after a self-limited upper respiratory illness and have evolved to include intermittent blurred vision, right-hand paresthesias, and mild dysarthria. She reports brief worsening of visual blurring and limb heaviness with heat and exertion, and over the past week developed gait unsteadiness on stairs and new urinary urgency without dysuria. She has episodic migraines in her past and a remote history of mononucleosis. She denies trauma, fever, or peripheral neuropathy risk factors. The constellation of focal sensory signs, ocular involvement, ataxia, and autonomic bladder symptoms raises concern for an inflammatory demyelinating process; outpatient MRI and neurology referral are planned.

A 62-year-old woman presents with six weeks of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and a dry, nonproductive cough. Symptoms began insidiously but intensified over the past two weeks; she now becomes short of breath after climbing a single flight of stairs. She reports intermittent low-grade fevers, decreased appetite with 6-lb unintentional weight loss, and mild fatigue. She has a remote 20 pack-year smoking history and a history of well-controlled hypertension. She also notes recent increased exposure to pet parrots in a household move. On review she denies chest pain or leg swelling. Exam at baseline shows bibasilar inspiratory crackles, early digital clubbing, and resting oxygen saturation of 91% on room air. Findings are concerning for an interstitial lung process, possibly hypersensitivity pneumonitis or evolving pulmonary fibrosis.

A 57-year-old woman presents with progressive exertional dyspnea over six months, now limiting her ability to climb one flight of stairs, with a dry, nonproductive cough and recent acute worsening after a viral upper respiratory illness. She notes unintentional 8-lb weight loss and increasing fatigue. Exam findings reported by her PCP include bibasilar inspiratory crackles and new digital clubbing; she describes lightheadedness with exertion and intermittent palpitations but no chest pain or orthopnea. Past medical history is notable for seropositive rheumatoid arthritis treated previously with methotrexate and a remote 20-pack-year smoking history, quit 15 years ago. She denies hemoptysis; family history is noncontributory. She is concerned about worsening breathing and possible pulmonary fibrosis.

A 91-year-old man presents with two months of progressive gait instability and frequent near-falls, now with two ground-level falls in the past three weeks. He describes short, shuffling steps and difficulty initiating walking, accompanied by new urinary urgency and daytime dribbling. Family notes subtle cognitive slowing and increased apathy over the same period. He also reports intermittent lightheadedness on standing and a transient episode of slurred speech last month. Past history is notable for long-standing hypertension and chronic atrial fibrillation, with prior imaging demonstrating chronic small-vessel ischemic changes. Examination today is limited by frailty but reveals broad-based, cautious gait and decreased lower-extremity vibratory sensation. Concern is for a multifactorial neurologic process—possible normal-pressure hydrocephalus versus vascular gait disorder with orthostatic component.

A 90-year-old man presents with a three-month history of progressive gait instability and recurrent falls, now occurring twice weekly. He describes difficulty initiating steps and a heavy, shuffling or "magnetic" quality to his stride, requiring contact with furniture to ambulate. Family reports gradual slowing of thought and new word-finding difficulty over the same period, and he has developed daytime urinary urgency with one episode of incontinence. He also notes episodic lightheadedness when standing. Past medical history is notable for long-standing hypertension. There was no antecedent head trauma or infection. The constellation of gait disturbance, cognitive decline, and urinary symptoms raises concern for possible normal-pressure hydrocephalus versus mixed chronic cerebrovascular change; neurology referral and brain imaging have been requested.

A 17-year-old female presents with a three-week history of intermittent lightheadedness and near-syncope, most pronounced on prolonged standing and walking between classes. She describes palpitations and an anxious tachycardia when upright, with one brief syncopal episode at home that resolved spontaneously. Symptoms are accompanied by daily headaches that are pressure-like rather than migrainous, intermittent blurred vision, and pervasive fatigue with poor concentration affecting school performance. She notes new exercise intolerance and occasional nausea but no fever or chest pain. The cluster began after a febrile viral upper respiratory illness four weeks ago. No prior neurologic disorder; menstrual history is regular. Symptoms improve rapidly when supine and are worse in warm environments and after prolonged standing.

A 21-year-old female college student reports an eight-week history of intermittent crampy lower abdominal pain with progressive diarrhea, markedly worse over the past two weeks. She now has four to six loose stools daily, occasional visible blood, urgency with tenesmus, and frequent nocturnal bowel movements. She endorses an unintentional 6-pound weight loss and persistent low-grade fevers with daytime fatigue that limit activity. Over the last month she has developed migratory arthralgias affecting knees and ankles. No recent travel, sick contacts, or antibiotic use. Symptoms disrupt classes and sleep and have not improved with over-the-counter remedies. She is increasingly concerned these findings represent inflammatory bowel disease and requests further evaluation.

A 51-year-old man reports six weeks of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and a persistent cough. The cough began after a treated pneumonia three months ago and was initially productive but has evolved into intermittent hemoptysis over the past two weeks. He also describes new, sharp right-sided pleuritic chest discomfort and decreased exercise tolerance—now short of breath after minimal exertion. Associated symptoms include an 8-pound unintentional weight loss and nocturnal diaphoresis. He has a 30–pack-year tobacco history and no known TB exposure. Past medical history otherwise notable only for the recent pneumonia. He is concerned about unresolved infection versus malignancy or chronic obstructive lung disease and seeks further evaluation.

A 61-year-old male presents with ten days of progressive exertional dyspnea and increased cough on a background of known COPD, initially following a bronchitic upper respiratory illness. Over the past 48 hours he developed acute, sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain and two small episodes of hemoptysis after climbing a single flight of stairs. He reports a 40–pack-year tobacco history and a recent prolonged car trip four days ago. He also notes new right calf swelling and intermittent palpitations. Baseline exercise tolerance was mildly limited by COPD, but current symptoms are markedly worse, raising concern for pulmonary embolism complicating his chronic lung disease; he denies fever or sputum purulence.

A 38-year-old female presents with three months of progressive epigastric pain and new postprandial vomiting. She describes an earlier history of intermittent heartburn and dyspepsia that responded to antacids, but over the last eight weeks she notes early satiety and bothersome bloating after small meals and has lost approximately 8 kg unintentionally. Vomitus is nonbloody; she reports intermittent dark, tarry stools and increasing fatigue consistent with iron-deficiency anemia. She recalls a remote H. pylori infection treated years ago. Pain is worse with meals and partially relieved by sitting upright. No fevers or overt jaundice. Given the constellation of dyspepsia, weight loss, and intermittent melena, outpatient endoscopic evaluation is arranged to assess for peptic ulcer or obstructing gastric lesion.

A 47-year-old woman presents with three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and intermittent pleuritic right-sided chest pain that acutely worsened over the past 72 hours after a transcontinental flight. She describes a new, small-volume hemoptysis and persistent dry cough; symptoms are worse with exertion and improve slightly at rest. Over the past week she noted unilateral right calf swelling and aching. She reports mild low-grade fevers and palpitations; at home she noted faster heartbeats with minimal activity. Past medical history includes well-controlled hypertension and recent use of combined hormonal contraception. The constellation of pleuritic pain, dyspnea, calf swelling, hemoptysis, tachycardia, and recent immobilization is concerning for venous thromboembolism, prompting urgent evaluation.

A 55-year-old woman reports 10 days of progressive exertional dyspnea and a new pleuritic right-sided chest pain that acutely worsened two days ago. She developed a persistent dry cough after a viral upper respiratory infection three weeks ago and notes scant streaks of blood with expectoration this week. She also describes new right calf aching and swelling after a weekend of prolonged travel last month. She feels intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness on exertion. She has a 30-pack-year smoking history and a remote diagnosis of mild COPD. No fever or purulent sputum. Symptoms are concerning for pulmonary embolism with possible pulmonary infarction on a background of chronic airway disease.

A 61-year-old female reports five days of progressive dyspnea and a productive cough that began after a mild upper respiratory illness. Sputum has turned purulent and she endorses intermittent pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort with low-grade fevers and chills. She has known COPD related to prior tobacco exposure (former 25-pack-year smoker) and baseline limited exercise tolerance. Over the last 48 hours she notes resting shortness of breath and subjective hypoxia with increased work of breathing and audible wheeze; she denies hemoptysis. Symptoms have worsened despite home bronchodilator use and now interfere with routine activities, prompting evaluation for possible infectious pneumonia versus COPD exacerbation.

A 50-year-old woman presents with three weeks of progressive swelling and foamy urine. Symptoms began with mild periorbital puffiness and ankle edema following a brief viral upper respiratory illness and have progressed to 8 pounds of weight gain and exertional dyspnea. She also notes intermittent lightheadedness on standing. Primary care dipstick reportedly showed heavy proteinuria; recent clinic labs demonstrated low serum albumin and elevated cholesterol. She has a remote history of well-controlled hypertension. No hematuria, fever, or rash is reported. The constellation—new nephrotic-range proteinuria with hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and volume overload—raises concern for an underlying glomerular process such as membranous nephropathy versus focal segmental disease, and she seeks nephrology evaluation.

A 59-year-old female presents with a 10-day history of intermittent blurring in the right eye that progressed to a persistent central scotoma and near-complete visual impairment over the past 48 hours. She also reports a new, throbbing temporal headache, scalp tenderness when brushing her hair, and jaw fatigue with chewing. Low-grade fevers and increasing fatigue have accompanied the visual change, and she notes two months of morning shoulder stiffness consistent with polymyalgia-type symptoms. She denies eye trauma, discharge, or photophobia. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Urgent ophthalmoscopy documented a right afferent pupillary defect with optic disc pallor/edema. The constellation raises concern for giant cell arteritis with ischemic optic neuropathy.

A 30-year-old woman reports a two-week history of progressive shortness of breath with marked worsening over the past four days and new left-sided pleuritic chest pain. Dyspnea began as exertional breathlessness shortly after an eight-hour flight and has progressed to intermittent breathlessness at rest; the chest pain is sharp and worse with deep inspiration. She noted a single episode of scant hemoptysis last night and has intermittent palpitations with subjective tachycardia. For three days she has had new swelling and tenderness of the left calf. She takes combined oral contraceptives, has low-grade fever and a mild nonproductive cough, and a past history of seasonal allergic rhinitis. No prior thrombotic events, denies illicit drug use; symptoms prompted urgent evaluation.
