A 59-year-old female reports six weeks of progressive, fluctuating ocular and bulbar weakness with intermittent right greater-than-left ptosis and binocular diplopia that worsen toward evening. She now notes nasal regurgitation, effortful chewing, and slurred speech with several coughing/choking episodes during meals. She describes proximal neck and shoulder weakness causing difficulty lifting arms overhead and shortness of breath with minimal exertion; symptoms are notably fatigable and improve with brief rest. The patient recalls a mild upper respiratory illness two weeks before onset. Past medical history includes hypertension and hypothyroidism. Primary care ordered a chest CT demonstrating an anterior mediastinal mass suspicious for thymoma; neuromuscular junction disorder is suspected and outpatient neurophysiology referral was arranged.

A 39-year-old female presents with a three-week history of progressive productive cough and new exertional dyspnea that began after a presumed viral upper respiratory infection. Cough is daily, occasionally blood-tinged, and accompanied by pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort when breathing deeply. She reports intermittent low-grade fevers, night sweats, and an unexplained six-pound weight loss over one month. She has intermittent wheeze and decreased exercise tolerance compared with baseline; childhood asthma noted but no recent inhaler use. Over the past four days she developed mild swelling and tenderness of the right calf. She uses combined hormonal contraception and denies recent travel. Concern is for thromboembolic disease versus postinfectious complication such as bronchiectasis or atypical infection.

An 18-year-old male presents with sudden left-sided pleuritic chest pain and acute shortness of breath that began after a bout of forceful coughing late last night. Pain is sharp, worse with inspiration, and associated with shallow rapid breaths and a persistent dry cough; he denies fever or sputum production. He notes daily e-cigarette use for about a year and a childhood history of intermittent wheeze. Onset progressed over several hours and he felt neck crepitus this morning. He is tall and thin by report. He denies recent trauma or leg swelling. Concern is for a primary spontaneous pneumothorax with possible subcutaneous emphysema; he seeks evaluation for worsening dyspnea and persistent pleuritic pain.

An 83-year-old woman presents with a two-month history of progressive unsteadiness and recurrent low-impact falls, accompanied by new urinary urgency and intermittent incontinence. Family reports gradual cognitive slowing with reduced initiation and short-term memory lapses; gait is described as short-stepped and “magnetic,” with hesitation on turning. She has had several brief episodes of right-hand clumsiness and transient confusion but no persistent aphasia or severe focal deficit. Symptoms worsened after a treated urinary tract infection three weeks ago. Past medical history includes hypertension and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. She notes occasional orthostatic lightheadedness on standing. No recent head trauma, fever, or visual loss. Concern is raised for a neurodegenerative or hydrocephalic process versus transient ischemic events contributing to falls.

A 31-year-old man presents with sudden-onset dyspnea and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began 36 hours ago and has progressively worsened. He reports scant hemoptysis and lightheadedness on exertion. Symptoms began a week after a prolonged transcontinental flight; he also notes new right calf swelling and tenderness. At home he measured a rapid pulse and felt mildly short of breath at rest. He has a remote history of mild intermittent asthma and no known cardiac disease. There was a brief febrile prodrome two weeks ago treated conservatively. He denies recent trauma or illicit drug use. The temporal cluster of dyspnea, unilateral leg swelling, pleuritic pain, tachycardia, and hemoptysis raises concern for pulmonary embolism.

A 62-year-old man presents with three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and new lower extremity swelling, worse over the past five days after a brief upper respiratory illness. He describes increasing shortness of breath with minimal exertion, two-pillow orthopnea and nightly paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea that awoke him once last night. He notes nonproductive cough, 5-lb weight gain, and intermittent palpitations described as irregular and rapid, with mild lightheadedness but no syncope. He also reports a vague substernal pressure with exertion that resolves with rest. Past medical history includes long-standing hypertension and a 30-pack-year remote smoking history. Exam findings now suggest congestive heart failure exacerbation, and he is concerned about new-onset atrial fibrillation contributing to his symptoms.

A 39-year-old woman presents with a two-week history of episodic vertigo and progressive gait instability, which has intensified over the past 48 hours. Vertigo is described as spinning spells lasting several minutes to an hour, often provoked by head turning and accompanied by nausea and imbalance. Over the last week she developed intermittent diplopia and blurred vision, and she reports two short episodes of right-sided numbness and tingling lasting about 10–20 minutes. She also notes new urinary urgency and generalized fatigue. Symptoms began after a recent mild upper respiratory infection. Past history is notable for episodic migraine without aura. She denies head trauma, fever, or ear pain. The clustered visual, sensory, and vestibular features raise concern for a central process (postinfectious vestibulopathy, demyelinating lesion, or posterior circulation ischemia).

An 83-year-old woman reports six weeks of progressive gait instability with three falls, worsening short-term memory, and new urinary urgency progressing to occasional incontinence. Family notes slowed speech and apathy; she has difficulty initiating steps and appears to shuffle with a broad, magnetic gait. Symptoms acutely worsened after a treated urinary tract infection two weeks ago. She describes intermittent orthostatic lightheadedness on standing but denies focal limb numbness or new focal weakness. Past medical history includes well-controlled hypertension and longstanding osteoarthritis limiting endurance. No recent syncope or chest pain. The temporal clustering of gait disturbance, cognitive decline, and urinary symptoms raises concern for a frontal-subcortical process such as normal-pressure hydrocephalus versus worsening small-vessel ischemic change contributing to falls.

A 20-year-old female college student presents with acute onset right-sided pleuritic chest pain and progressive shortness of breath that began 48 hours ago, shortly after a 10-hour international flight. Pain is sharp, worse with inspiration, and associated with a dry cough that produced a streak of blood once. She reports palpitations, lightheadedness, and low-grade fevers; she also noticed new swelling and tenderness in her right calf. She takes combined oral contraceptives and has no prior thrombotic history. She denies smoking or recent immobilizing illness beyond the flight. On arrival she is tachycardic and mildly hypoxemic on room air. The timeline and focal calf findings raise concern for deep venous thrombosis with pulmonary embolism.

A 14-year-old male presents with six days of progressive blurring and dimming in the right eye, associated with aching pain on eye movement and sensitivity to light. He notes colors look "washed out" on the affected side and has seen occasional floaters; vision decline began after a week of nasal congestion and low-grade fevers. He also reports intermittent occipital headache and a brief episode of numbness in the left hand two days before the visual symptoms worsened. No trauma, vomiting, or seizure activity. Past history is notable only for childhood eczema; immunizations up to date. He denies recent travel, illicit drug use, or contact lens wear. Symptoms are concerning for an inflammatory optic neuropathy versus postinfectious process.

A 70-year-old male presents with a three-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea and productive cough. He reports increased yellow-green sputum and low-grade fevers after a presumed bronchitic illness; baseline COPD had been reasonably controlled. Ten days ago he developed sudden pleuritic right-sided chest pain and an acute increase in breathlessness following a prolonged car trip, and since then notes intermittent hemoptysis and persistent fatigue. Over the past week he has also developed new orthopnea and bilateral ankle swelling. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and a 40-pack-year smoking history. He denies chest pressure at rest but is concerned about pulmonary embolism versus COPD exacerbation or evolving heart failure given the edema and exertional decline.

A 7-year-old female presents with a three-week history of progressive morning headache accompanied by intermittent nonbilious vomiting and increased sleepiness. Parents report two brief spells of right-hand clonic jerking with transient confusion and post-event lethargy, and since last week she has developed intermittent blurred vision and a subtle head tilt. They also note an unsteady, wide-based gait and occasional slurred speech at school. Symptoms began shortly after a self-limited upper respiratory infection; there is no history of head trauma or fever now. Past history is notable only for mild language delay. Between episodes caregivers have observed decreased use of the right hand. Concern is for a focal intracranial process—posterior fossa or cortical lesion—with associated focal seizures and raised intracranial pressure.

A 21-year-old woman presents with five days of progressive blurred vision in her left eye accompanied by aching pain with eye movement and sensitivity to bright light. Vision was normal until she noticed central dimming and difficulty distinguishing reds while reading; the blurring has worsened intermittently, now limiting near tasks. She endorses brief flashes of light and reports a left relative afferent pupillary defect on self-testing at home. Two weeks prior she had a mild upper respiratory illness that resolved; she denies trauma, discharge, or fever. Over the past 48 hours she has had transient numbness and tingling in the right hand and occasional neck stiffness. No prior eye disease or systemic autoimmune diagnosis is known.

A 71-year-old male reports three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent nonproductive cough that began after a flu-like illness. He describes intermittent low-grade fevers, increasing fatigue, and an unintentional six-pound weight loss. A former 40 pack-year smoker with well-controlled hypertension, he notes occasional pleuritic chest discomfort and reduced exercise tolerance now limiting walking across the house. On self-observation he has resting shortness of breath; clinic pulse oximetry has shown mild hypoxemia. Examiners auscultate fine bilateral inspiratory crackles at the lung bases. The temporal pattern after viral illness with subacute cough, weight loss, crackles, and hypoxemia raises concern for organizing pneumonia or an exacerbation of underlying interstitial lung disease rather than simple bronchitis.

A 95-year-old female presents with acute, painless central vision loss in the right eye that progressed over 48 hours. She reports two weeks of new-onset, persistent right-sided temporal headache and focal scalp tenderness, with intermittent jaw claudication when eating and low-grade fevers. Over the past month she has noted decreased appetite, fatigue and modest weight loss, and several weeks of morning shoulder and hip stiffness limiting dressing. She denies eye pain, diplopia, trauma, or discharge. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. Recent outpatient testing demonstrated elevated inflammatory markers. The constellation of sudden monocular visual loss with cranial symptoms and proximal stiffness is concerning for ischemic optic involvement from suspected giant cell arteritis.

A 31-year-old female presents with progressive dyspnea and pleuritic right-sided chest pain for five days after a transcontinental flight ten days ago. She reports sudden onset shortness of breath with exertion that has progressed to resting dyspnea, associated with pleuritic pain worse with deep inspiration, intermittent hemoptysis and a dry cough. She notes new right calf swelling and cramping for three days and palpitations with lightheadedness. She takes combined oral contraceptives and has no smoking history. She endorses low-grade fever and decreased exercise tolerance. No prior thrombotic events. Symptoms began after recent prolonged travel and are concerning for deep vein thrombosis with pulmonary embolism; she denies recent surgery or pregnancy.

A 20-year-old female college student reports four weeks of progressive lightheadedness, palpitations, and near-syncope triggered by standing. Symptoms began about one week after a self-limited viral gastroenteritis and are provoked by prolonged upright posture and after meals. She describes persistent fatigue, cognitive "brain fog," intermittent tremulousness, and markedly reduced exercise tolerance. She also endorses nausea and early satiety with abdominal bloating, and has missed classes because of postural dizziness. On standing the heart races but she denies chest pain, focal weakness, or shortness of breath. No new medications or illicit drug use; past medical history notable only for seasonal allergic rhinitis. She reports prior brief orthostatic lightheadedness but this episode is more sustained and limiting.

A 36-year-old man presents with six months of progressively worsening axial low back pain and stiffness. Pain is worst at night and on waking, improves with routine activity and stretching, and is minimally relieved by OTC NSAIDs. He reports morning stiffness lasting 45 minutes and intermittent right hip ache radiating to the groin. Over the past two months he has noticed decreased forward flexion and a sense of chest tightness with deep inspiration, limiting exercise tolerance. He has focal heel pain at the Achilles insertion consistent with enthesitis and intermittent fatigue. Last month he had an episode of unilateral eye pain, redness, and photophobia diagnosed as anterior uveitis. There is a family history of psoriasis. No fevers, urinary symptoms, or recent infections.

A 44-year-old woman presents with two weeks of intermittent left-sided weakness and tingling, episodic diplopia, and unsteady gait. Symptoms began gradually after a session of vigorous neck stretching and were initially brief but have increased in frequency and duration, now lasting up to 20 minutes with residual fatigue. She also reports new occipital headache and posterior neck pain, worse with Valsalva and head rotation. There is subjective slurred speech during some episodes but no loss of consciousness. Past medical history includes well-controlled hypertension and occasional migraine without recent aura. She denies fever, chest pain, or recent infection. Given the posterior circulation symptoms—vertigo, ataxia, visual disturbance—and neck trauma history, she is concerned about vertebral artery dissection or recurrent transient ischemic attacks.

A 68-year-old woman reports three months of progressive gait instability and slurred speech. She initially noted trouble with tandem walking and unsteady turns, now using a cane after two recent falls. Family describes worsening dysarthria and a coarse intention tremor of the right hand, with intermittent horizontal diplopia. She also endorses new urinary urgency and an unintentional eight-pound weight loss over eight weeks. Symptoms began subacutely after a brief respiratory illness. Past history notable for remote stage I breast carcinoma treated many years ago and osteopenia. She denies new medications. On review she notes increasing difficulty swallowing thin liquids and trouble with fine finger coordination, prompting concern for a central cerebellar process.

A 24-year-old male presents with severe right lower leg pain and progressive swelling that began about 36 hours after sustaining a closed tibial shaft fracture while playing soccer. Pain is constant, out of proportion to injury, and markedly worse with passive plantarflexion of the toes. On exam he has a tense anterior compartment with visible fullness, paresthesia over the dorsum of the foot, and weakness of ankle dorsiflexion producing an unsteady gait. Pedal pulses are palpable but reduced compared with the contralateral side; capillary refill is delayed. He reports inability to bear weight and increasing analgesic-resistant discomfort overnight. He denies fever, shortness of breath, or chest pain. No prior bleeding disorders or anticoagulant use.

A 50-year-old man presents with five days of progressive exertional dyspnea and new sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain, accompanied by a dry cough and a single episode of scant hemoptysis. He recalls a prolonged car trip three weeks ago after which he noted aching and swelling of the right calf that has persisted. He also reports intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness when climbing stairs. His past medical history includes treated hypertension and a remote 20–pack-year smoking history. He denies fever or productive sputum but mentions mild night sweats and an unintentional six-pound weight loss over two months. He is concerned about a possible pulmonary embolus versus an atypical infection, and has had no prior thrombotic events.

A 4-year-old female presents with a five-day history of persistent cough and intermittent noisy breathing after an episode of choking on a small food particle six days ago. Initially she had forceful coughing and transient gagging, then developed a harsher, worse cough that is nocturnal and associated with audible wheeze and occasional inspiratory stridor. Caregiver reports low-grade fever the first two days, decreased oral intake and activity, and one brief spell of pallor and cyanosis that resolved. On outpatient exam there was focal diminished breath sounds over the right mid-lung and a localized wheeze; pulse oximetry once read 93% on room air. No prior history of asthma or recurrent pneumonia; vaccinations up to date. Parents are concerned about possible retained aspiration.

A 34-year-old man presents with four days of progressive blurred vision in the left eye, associated with aching pain that worsens on eye movement and intermittent flashes of light. He describes colors as “washed out” on the left and notes difficulty reading fine print; symptoms began a week after a self-limited upper respiratory illness. He also reports two brief episodes of numbness and tingling in the right hand over the past month and a recent sense of mild imbalance when turning quickly. On review he denies discharge, fever, or trauma. Prior ocular history is unremarkable. Exam in clinic revealed a relative afferent pupillary defect on the left and subtle optic disc edema. He is concerned about sudden visual loss and intermittent neurologic symptoms.

A 60-year-old male reports a three-month history of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that began after a presumed viral bronchitis and has gradually limited his walking tolerance. He notes a 6-kg unintentional weight loss, intermittent low-grade fevers, and increasing fatigue; he denies hemoptysis but now experiences exertional desaturation and occasional night sweats. He is a former 20 pack-year smoker and spent decades in construction with possible asbestos exposure. Office exam revealed fine inspiratory "velcro" crackles at the bases and new digital clubbing. Past medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension. He is worried symptoms represent an interstitial lung process such as pulmonary fibrosis and requests further evaluation.

A 38-year-old woman presents with six weeks of progressive, daily holocephalic pressure and throbbing headaches, accompanied by transient visual obscurations and intermittent blurred vision. Headaches are worse on awakening and with Valsalva, and she reports new pulsatile tinnitus and photophobia but no fevers or focal weakness. She notes 20-pound weight gain over four months and irregular menses. Ophthalmologic exam by her primary provider reportedly showed optic disc swelling. She has nausea and occasional vomiting with severe flares. Past history significant only for childhood migraine; no recent infections or head trauma. She is a nonsmoker and denies alcohol use. Concern is for raised intracranial pressure—idiopathic intracranial hypertension versus secondary intracranial process—requiring neuroimaging and ophthalmology evaluation.

A 28-year-old man presents with sudden-onset right-sided pleuritic chest pain and progressive dyspnea that began about 12 hours ago after heavy lifting at the gym. The sharp pain worsens with deep inspiration and is accompanied by a dry cough and intermittent lightheadedness; he reports palpitations and mild resting shortness of breath. He is a current cigarette and occasional cannabis smoker and describes a tall, thin body habitus. He denies fever, hemoptysis, leg swelling, or recent long travel. At home he noticed decreased air entry on the right and subtle neck crepitus. He has no chronic lung disease and seeks evaluation for suspected spontaneous pneumothorax given acute unilateral findings, tachycardia, and concern for mild hypoxemia.

A 30-year-old woman presents with three weeks of progressive postprandial fullness, early satiety, and intermittent non‑bilious vomiting. The symptoms began about two weeks after a self‑limited viral gastroenteritis and are now accompanied by dull epigastric pain, upper abdominal bloating, and frequent heartburn. She reports persistent nausea with most meals and an unintentional 6‑kg weight loss from reduced intake. Bowel movements remain regular without melena or hematochezia, and she denies fevers or night sweats. She notes episodic lightheadedness when meals are delayed and increased fatigue. No history of peptic ulcer disease or diabetes. She has tried over‑the‑counter antacids with minimal relief and is concerned about possible delayed gastric emptying versus peptic pathology.

A 16-year-old female presents with recurrent, severe left-sided throbbing headaches for one week, associated with transient visual scotomas and intermittent right arm weakness. Each episode begins with scintillating visual aura lasting 10–20 minutes followed by numbness and mild dysarthria, then a pounding headache with photophobia and nausea; one episode included vomiting. Symptoms often start after exertion during soccer practice and began two weeks after a self-limited upper respiratory illness. Episodes last several hours and her school performance has declined. She denies loss of consciousness, fever, neck stiffness, or recent head trauma. Family history is notable for maternal migraine with aura. No prior neurologic disorders; immunizations up to date. She is otherwise healthy and not taking regular medications.

A 95-year-old man presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a dry cough, with a three-day acute worsening after a mild upper respiratory illness. He now notes resting breathlessness and intermittent low-grade fevers, and his family reports an 8-pound unintentional weight loss over two months. On exertion he becomes markedly short of breath and coughs without hemoptysis; he also reports new orthopnea and mild lower extremity swelling. He has a remote 30-pack-year smoking history. Exam at home showed increased work of breathing and bibasilar fine inspiratory crackles; oxygen saturation falls with minimal ambulation. He denies chest pain or syncope. The constellation is most consistent with progressive interstitial lung disease with acute decompensation versus superimposed infection or heart failure.

A 95-year-old female presents with sudden-onset left hemiparesis and expressive aphasia noted by family 36 hours ago. Symptoms began abruptly while she was sitting and progressed over minutes; family also observed a new right facial droop and intermittent choking with thin liquids consistent with oropharyngeal dysphagia. She had two days of malaise and low-grade fever before the event and is now intermittently confused and unable to complete basic self-care. Past medical history includes chronic atrial fibrillation and hypertension; she is not anticoagulated because of recurrent falls. No known recent head trauma or seizure activity. Examination at home suggested decreased left-sided strength and diminished verbal output compared with baseline.

A 99-year-old female with longstanding hypertension, known COPD, and chronic diastolic heart failure presents with five days of progressive dyspnea and a productive cough. Symptoms began after a brief upper respiratory illness and have worsened with minimal exertion; she reports yellow-green sputum and low-grade fevers. Family notes increasing orthopnea and two nights of poor sleep from breathlessness, now accompanied by mild confusion and reduced oral intake. On exam at home she was noted to have new bilateral lower extremity swelling and audible rattles when lying flat. The clinical picture is most consistent with a congestive exacerbation complicated by superimposed lower respiratory infection, with hypoxemic symptoms out of proportion to her baseline COPD.

An 82-year-old male reports three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent nonproductive cough that began after a brief upper respiratory illness. He describes marked decline in exercise tolerance — now breathless after walking half a block — and a 10-pound unintentional weight loss over the same interval. He denies hemoptysis but notes intermittent low-grade chills. Past history includes well-controlled hypertension and a prior diagnosis of COPD; he is a former smoker. At baseline he used to be independent but has needed more frequent rest breaks. On self-exam he has noticed widening of his fingertips and bedside exam revealed bibasilar inspiratory crackles. He is concerned about worsening interstitial lung disease versus superimposed infection or malignancy.

A 22-year-old female presents with progressive right leg weakness and numbness for ten days, worsened over the past 72 hours. Symptoms began after a self-limited upper respiratory illness three weeks ago and initially involved distal paresthesia in the foot, now extending to the thigh with new gait instability and difficulty climbing stairs. She describes intermittent electric shock–like sensations down the spine with neck flexion and a two-day episode of blurred vision in the right eye that has partially resolved. She also reports new urinary urgency and hesitancy without dysuria, increased fatigue, and episodic headaches consistent with her history of migraine. She denies recent trauma, high fevers, or illicit drug use. No prior neurologic deficits; baseline anxiety managed nonpharmacologically.

A previously healthy 4-year-old girl presents with a four-day history of progressive noisy breathing and a barky cough that began after two days of clear rhinorrhea. Parents report nocturnal worsening with intermittent inspiratory stridor and audible wheeze, particularly at night and with crying, accompanied by low-grade fever and reduced oral intake. Today she has increased work of breathing with mild intercostal retractions and hoarseness but no vomiting or cyanosis. Family notes prior episodes of viral-induced wheeze at age two and a history of atopic dermatitis. Exam at home suggested persistent stridor at rest. Parents are concerned about respiratory distress overnight; symptoms feel distinct from prior reactive episodes and are most consistent with a croup-like illness possibly triggering bronchospasm.

A 5-year-old female presents with four days of progressive cough and noisy breathing. Symptoms began as clear rhinorrhea and a low-grade fever after daycare exposure and have evolved into a persistent, harsh cough with frequent nocturnal paroxysms and audible expiratory wheeze. Parents note increased work of breathing with activity, occasional subcostal retractions, decreased oral intake, and mild lethargy. She has intermittent posttussive vomiting but no choking episode. Past history is notable for viral-associated wheeze and atopic dermatitis; no prior hospitalizations. There is concurrent nasal congestion and mild ear tugging. Parents report minimal improvement with humidified air at home and are concerned about worsening shortness of breath, raising concern for a viral-triggered asthma/reactive airways exacerbation.

A 51-year-old woman reports sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye over the past 48 hours, preceded for two weeks by intermittent transient blackouts described as brief grayouts and one-minute episodes of blurred vision (amaurosis fugax). She now has persistent severe blur with new floaters and occasional flashes of light but denies ocular pain or trauma. She also notes a mild right temporal headache and recent episodes of palpitations and lightheadedness. Past history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She denies fever, jaw claudication, or recent infection. Given the acute monocular ischemic picture, she is worried about an arterial occlusion and reports urgent evaluation in clinic where decreased vision was confirmed, prompting planned vascular and cardiac workup.

An 18-year-old female reports five days of progressive bilateral leg weakness and numbness, now causing tripping and difficulty climbing stairs. Symptoms began as intermittent paresthesias in the feet and evolved to constant sensory loss with gait instability and a bandlike mid-thoracic back pain. She notes urinary hesitancy with one episode of retention and new difficulty sensing vibration in the toes. Flexing the neck provokes electric shock–like sensations. Symptoms began roughly two weeks after a self-limited upper respiratory illness. On review she endorses no visual loss or fever. She is concerned for an inflammatory myelopathy (e.g., transverse myelitis or early demyelinating disease) given the subacute progression, sensory level, hyperreflexia, and autonomic bladder symptoms.

A 41-year-old man presents with five days of progressive shortness of breath and a new sharp, pleuritic right-sided chest pain that began acutely two days ago. Pain is worse with inspiration and with deep cough; he reports scant hemoptysis once yesterday. He notes palpitations and intermittent lightheadedness when climbing stairs. Symptoms started after a prolonged cross-country flight last week; he also developed right calf swelling and tenderness over the past 48 hours. He is a current cigarette smoker (about one pack per day) and recalls a mild upper respiratory illness two weeks ago. He denies fever at home but feels warm with exertion. No prior clotting disorder. He is anxious about possible pulmonary embolism given the timeline and leg findings.

A 14-year-old female presents with a six-week history of progressive palpitations, tremulousness, and heat intolerance. She reports a two-month pattern of increased sweating, more frequent loose bowel movements, and an unintentional weight loss despite unchanged appetite. Parents note worsening irritability and insomnia interfering with school. Menstrual cycles, previously regular, have become irregular over the past two months. On exam at the clinic she felt her heart racing with minimal exertion and mentioned a new fullness at the base of her neck; she also describes intermittent sensation of eye grittiness and lid retraction. There is no history of recent infection or medication changes. Symptoms began gradually and have intensified over the last several weeks, prompting evaluation for a possible hyperthyroid process.

An 85-year-old female reports three months of progressive exertional dyspnea that began after a self-limited bronchitic illness. Initially she had a dry cough that never fully resolved and now experiences breathlessness with minimal exertion, notably when climbing a single flight of stairs. Her primary care clinician documented bibasilar inspiratory crackles and new digital clubbing. She notes reduced walking tolerance and intermittent lightheadedness on exertion; home pulse oximetry has fallen into the high 80s while ambulating. No fever or hemoptysis. On review, she has mild unintentional weight loss and daytime fatigue. The clinical picture is most consistent with an interstitial process, with concern for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis complicated by secondary pulmonary hypertension and exertional hypoxemia.

A 69-year-old woman reports three months of progressive exertional dyspnea with a persistent dry cough that has acutely worsened over the past two weeks. She endorses intermittent pleuritic chest discomfort, low-grade fevers, and an unintentional 10-pound weight loss with decreased appetite. She denies hemoptysis or new cardiac symptoms but notes marked decline in exercise tolerance; oxygen saturation falls into the mid-80s with moderate exertion. Exam reveals bibasilar fine inspiratory crackles and early digital clubbing. Past medical history is notable only for well-controlled hypertension; she is a former 30 pack-year smoker. No recent infectious exposures. The clinical picture is concerning for a chronic interstitial lung process with superimposed acute worsening.

A 16-year-old female reports three weeks of progressively worsening daily holocephalic headache, described as dull and pressure-like, with associated photophobia and nausea. Over the past ten days she has developed intermittent binocular horizontal diplopia and transient visual obscurations triggered by standing, and she hears a unilateral pulsatile tinnitus. Her primary care clinician noted bilateral optic disc swelling on fundoscopic exam and referred her urgently. She endorses a 25-pound weight gain over six months and irregular menses. She denies fever, focal numbness, limb weakness, or head trauma. Sleep and school attendance are increasingly affected. No tobacco or illicit drug use. Current concern is raised intracranial pressure, and she seeks evaluation for possible idiopathic intracranial hypertension.

A 42-year-old woman presents with sudden onset of new floaters and intermittent photopsias in her right eye beginning two days ago. The flashes were initially sporadic but progressed to a subjective "curtain" over the superior peripheral field with mild central blurring and reduced visual acuity compared with baseline. She describes no eye pain, no recent head trauma, and no discharge. Ocular history notable for high axial myopia and prior amblyopia in childhood. She has a longstanding history of migraine with visual aura but reports this event feels different. Symptoms began after an episode of prolonged coughing last week. Exam elsewhere has been unremarkable; she is concerned about possible posterior vitreous detachment versus retinal detachment and seeks urgent ophthalmic evaluation.

A 65-year-old woman reports recurrent transient episodes of slurred speech and left arm weakness over the past two weeks. Each spell lasts 10–20 minutes, is sometimes preceded by lightheadedness after exertion, and is accompanied by brief episodes of blurred vision described as transient monocular vision loss. She also notes intermittent confusion and new gait instability between events. She has known hypertension and chronic atrial fibrillation and is maintained on anticoagulation; she denies fever or headache. On recent primary care exam a right-sided carotid bruit was documented. She is concerned these represent transient ischemic attacks rather than peripheral vertigo, given the focal motor and speech features, and seeks urgent evaluation for cerebrovascular imaging and possible carotid stenosis.

A 0-year-old female brought by caregiver for 48 hours of progressive respiratory distress following two days of rhinorrhea and low‑grade fever. Caregiver notes persistent cough, audible labored breathing and markedly reduced oral intake to less than half usual volumes with fewer wet diapers. At home there were frequent rapid breaths with nasal flaring and visible intercostal retractions, and brief self‑resolving color change episodes with stimulation. Clinic pulse oximetry showed intermittent desaturations into the low 90s. Lung auscultation was notable for diffuse expiratory wheeze without focal crackles. No significant vomiting. Birth history uncomplicated and no prior admissions. Working impression is viral bronchiolitis with hypoxemia, feeding intolerance and early dehydration, raising concern for observation for apnea‑like events and supportive care.

A 60-year-old woman with hypertension and a remote history of provoked left-leg DVT presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a chronic productive cough that acutely worsened over the past three days. She now reports new right-sided pleuritic chest pain and two small episodes of hemoptysis after a long car trip two weeks ago. She endorses low-grade fevers, decreased exercise tolerance, and an unintended 8-pound weight loss over two months. On ambulation she becomes notably short of breath and lightheaded; she denies orthopnea or leg swelling at present. She is worried about recurrent thromboembolism versus worsening COPD and seeks evaluation for possible hypoxia and persistent chest pain.

A 95-year-old female presents with three days of progressive dyspnea and a productive cough that began after a choking episode while eating. Family notes new noisy swallowing and intermittent regurgitation over the last week, followed by low-grade fever and increased work of breathing. She now desaturates with minimal exertion and requires low-flow supplemental oxygen at rest. Past medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension and mild cognitive impairment with recent decline in attention. On exam she has bibasilar crackles greater on the right and decreased breath sounds at the right base. Clinical concern is aspiration-related pneumonia with hypoxemia in the setting of dysphagia and frailty.

A 22-year-old female reports an eight-day history of progressive visual disturbance in her right eye that began after a mild upper respiratory infection. She describes central blurring and a new central scotoma with intermittent photopsias and floaters; color perception is muted compared with the left eye. Eye movement provokes a sharp retro-orbital ache but she denies trauma or discharge. Symptoms have worsened over several days, now limiting reading and driving; intermittent frontal headache accompanies episodes of decreased acuity. She has no prior ocular disease, wears no contact lenses, and has a history of seasonal eczema. No fever, limb weakness, or sensory change. She is anxious about possible optic neuritis given the pain with eye movement and progressive dyschromatopsia.

A 19-year-old male presents with a five-day history of progressive blurring and central darkening of vision in the right eye, beginning shortly after a week of nasal congestion and sore throat. He describes pain exacerbated by eye movement, decreased color saturation, and intermittent photophobia; he denies trauma. Over the past two days he has noticed brief flashes of light and a small central scotoma that make reading difficult. He also reports transient numbness and tingling in the left hand and a sense of imbalance on stairs that began after the visual symptoms. No prior ophthalmologic issues or systemic illness noted. The constellation—unilateral painful vision loss with color desaturation following a viral prodrome—raises concern for optic neuritis and possible early demyelinating disease.

A 29-year-old female reports three days of progressive shortness of breath and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began two days after a long international flight. Dyspnea is present at rest and with minimal exertion and is accompanied by intermittent small-volume hemoptysis and a dry cough. She also notes palpitations, lightheadedness, and subjective low-grade fevers. For four days she has had increasing tenderness and swelling of the right calf. She takes combined oral contraceptives and has no prior thrombotic or cardiopulmonary disease. She denies smoking or illicit drug use. Symptoms have worsened despite acetaminophen, prompting evaluation for suspected pulmonary embolism secondary to deep venous thrombosis.

An 82-year-old man reports two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and reduced walking tolerance, with three days of pleuritic right-sided chest pain and scant hemoptysis. He describes a productive cough and low-grade fevers after a brief upper respiratory prodrome. Past history notable for hypertension and a provoked deep venous thrombosis five years ago; remote cigarette exposure. Over the past 48 hours he developed new palpitations and lightheadedness. At home he observed mild right calf swelling and increasing ankle edema. On exam he has an irregularly irregular tachycardia, decreased breath sounds at the right base, and bibasilar crackles. Differential includes pulmonary embolism versus infectious consolidation with small reactive pleural effusion, complicated by new atrial fibrillation.

A 16-year-old male reports sudden onset of sharp, right-sided pleuritic chest pain and progressive shortness of breath beginning two hours after a late basketball game. Pain is localized, worsens with inspiration, and is accompanied by a dry cough and mild lightheadedness; he denies fever or syncope. He notes a week-long upper respiratory illness two weeks ago and admits to occasional vaping of nicotine and marijuana. He is otherwise active, tall and thin, with a history of childhood wheeze but no chronic lung disease. Paramedics observed tachypnea and palpable subcutaneous crepitus in the neck; he reports hearing decreased breath sounds on the right. He is concerned about a pneumothorax given sudden onset and exertional trigger.

A 32-year-old man presents with five days of progressive pleuritic right-sided chest pain and exertional dyspnea that began after a ten-hour bus ride. He describes intermittent blood-tinged sputum since day three and a new persistent dry cough. He noticed swelling and aching in his right calf two days ago and has felt palpitations and mild tachycardia at rest. He reports low-grade fever and diaphoresis overnight but no known sick contacts. Past history is notable only for childhood exercise-induced asthma; he smokes intermittently and works a sedentary job. He denies prior thrombotic events. Symptoms have worsened with minimal activity and he feels mildly short of breath at rest, prompting today’s presentation.

A 55-year-old male presents with 10 days of progressive exertional dyspnea and intermittent left-sided pleuritic chest pain. Symptoms began after a long transcontinental flight and have worsened over a week; he notes transient lightheadedness on climbing stairs and two episodes of blood-tinged sputum. He also reports a nonproductive cough, low-grade fevers, and reduced exercise tolerance. Over the past five days he developed left calf swelling and tenderness. Past medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension and a 30-pack-year former smoker. He denies recent illness otherwise. The temporal sequence—posttravel calf symptoms followed by pleuritic pain and hemoptysis—raises concern for pulmonary embolism with concomitant pulmonary infarction.

A 40-year-old female reports a six-week history of progressive palpitations and fatigue accompanied by an unintentional 10-pound weight loss despite normal appetite. She notes marked heat intolerance, a fine resting hand tremor, and difficulty sleeping. Over the past two weeks she has developed exertional dyspnea with decreased exercise tolerance and an intermittent rapid, irregular pulse; she was evaluated in an emergency setting and told she had atrial fibrillation. She also describes new gritty eye irritation with mild prominence of the eyes and a diffuse fullness in the lower anterior neck. Menstrual cycles have become irregular over the same interval. No chest pain, fevers, or focal neurologic deficits are reported. She denies recent travel or steroid use.

A 56-year-old man reports progressive exertional dyspnea for ten days with new right-sided pleuritic chest pain that worsened over the past 48 hours. Pain is sharp with deep breaths; he noted a small amount of blood‑streaked sputum this morning. He has felt palpitations and intermittent lightheadedness with minimal exertion, and his oxygen saturation drops with walking. He also reports new swelling and tenderness in the right calf after a prolonged car trip three weeks ago. Past history includes chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and a 30 pack‑year smoking history with baseline exertional limitation that is now markedly worse. He denies fever or orthopnea. Overall the presentation is concerning for pulmonary embolism on a background of COPD.

A 63-year-old woman reports six weeks of progressive palpitations accompanied by unintended weight loss, heat intolerance, and a fine resting tremor. She describes intermittent watery diarrhea and a new anterior neck fullness that she first noticed a month ago; symptoms have intensified over the past two weeks. She now tires easily and develops exertional dyspnea and lightheadedness during episodes of rapid, irregular heartbeat. She has noted an irregularly irregular pulse at home. Past medical history is notable only for well-controlled hypertension. She denies fever, recent infection, or changes in her medications. Given the cluster of adrenergic symptoms, neck mass, and arrhythmia, she is concerned about hyperthyroidism from a toxic multinodular goiter complicated by possible atrial fibrillation.

A 37-year-old man presents with five days of progressive exertional dyspnea that began shortly after a long-haul flight. He describes new sharp, right-sided pleuritic chest pain that started 36 hours ago and a single small episode of blood-tinged sputum. He notes lightheadedness with minimal exertion and palpitations; on self-check his heart rate felt noticeably fast. Two days after the flight he developed swelling and aching of the right calf. He has low-grade subjective fevers and denies recent illness, chest trauma, or prolonged immobility aside from the flight. Past history significant only for intermittent childhood asthma without daily inhaler use. He is anxious about a blood clot given the temporal link between travel, calf swelling, chest pain, and worsening dyspnea.

A 37-year-old woman presents with three days of progressive shortness of breath and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began abruptly after she noticed swelling in her right calf. Dyspnea is worse with exertion and accompanied by a dry cough and a single episode of scant hemoptysis yesterday. She reports palpitations and intermittent lightheadedness but denies fever or productive sputum. She recently completed a long cross-country driving trip and takes combined oral contraception. Past history is notable only for seasonal allergic rhinitis; she has no known chronic lung disease or prior thromboembolism. Symptoms started after several days of prolonged sitting, and she has curtailed activity because of exertional intolerance.

A 42-year-old man presents with six weeks of progressive epigastric pain and early satiety, describing a gnawing, postprandial discomfort that intensifies after solid meals and is occasionally followed by nonbloody vomiting. He reports a 10-pound unintended weight loss and new fatigue over the same interval. Over the past two weeks he has noticed intermittent dark, tarry stools and lightheadedness on standing. He has a remote history of peptic ulcer disease and acknowledges frequent ibuprofen use for back pain. He has well-controlled type 2 diabetes and notes prior episodes of prolonged fullness after meals, raising concern for gastroparesis versus recurrent ulcer-related gastric outlet obstruction. No fevers, jaundice, or alcohol bingeing are reported. He seeks evaluation for endoscopic assessment and anemia workup.

A 6-year-old female is brought for three months of progressively muffled hearing and new difficulty following classroom instructions. Symptoms began after a prolonged upper respiratory infection and have been accompanied by intermittent ear fullness and two brief episodes of ear pain with low-grade fever over the past year. Parents report chronic nasal obstruction, persistent mouth-breathing, and loud snoring at night for six months. Her teacher notes unclear speech and inattentiveness. Prior care included two courses of antibiotics for acute otitis media. On home otoscopy parents described dullness and occasional fluid behind both ears. Overall picture suggests adenoid hypertrophy with eustachian tube dysfunction leading to serous otitis media, conductive hearing loss, recurrent URI symptoms, and concern for speech delay.

A 54-year-old man reports three days of progressive shortness of breath with sudden-onset, pleuritic right-sided chest pain 36 hours ago. He describes scant hemoptysis and marked exercise intolerance, worsened after a 10-hour car trip last week. He has a 30–pack-year smoking history and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with known hypertension. Over the past two days he developed aching and swelling of the right calf and intermittent palpitations; he denies fever or purulent sputum. At home he noted lightheadedness with one near-syncope. The combination of unilateral leg swelling, pleuritic chest pain, tachycardia and hypoxemic symptoms on a background of COPD raises concern for acute pulmonary embolism complicating chronic airway disease; he reports no prior DVT or anticoagulation.

A 30-year-old man reports a 36-hour history of progressive shortness of breath and sharp, pleuritic right-sided chest pain that increases with inspiration. He has intermittently coughed up small amounts of blood and notes new palpitations and lightheadedness when standing. Two days before symptom onset he completed a prolonged 12-hour bus trip and since then has had right calf aching with visible swelling. He is a current smoker with a history of mild intermittent asthma but no prior thrombotic events. At home he felt his heart racing and noticed low oxygen saturation on a pulse oximeter, prompting evaluation for possible pulmonary embolism related to right lower-extremity deep vein thrombosis. He denies recent trauma or anticoagulant use.

A 58-year-old female presents with two months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that began after an episode of atypical pneumonia. Symptoms have gradually worsened; she now notes activity-related oxygen desaturation and significantly reduced exercise tolerance but denies fever or hemoptysis. Primary care exam documented fine basilar inspiratory "velcro" crackles and subtle digital clubbing. She reports mild fatigue but no night sweats. Past medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension and a remote 20 pack-year smoking history. A recent chest CT demonstrated basilar-predominant reticular changes concerning for early fibrotic process, and she seeks pulmonary evaluation for diagnostic clarification and management.

A 10-year-old girl presents with ten days of progressive headaches and new balance problems. Headaches began after a two-week upper respiratory illness and started as intermittent frontal pressure evolving into daily throbbing pain with photophobia and phonophobia; she describes occasional scintillating visual auras and transient blurred vision. Over the past 48 hours she developed nausea with two episodes of non-bloody emesis and increasing unsteadiness, veering to the right when walking and needing to hold on to furniture. There has been low-grade fever at home but no seizure, loss of consciousness, or focal weakness. Sleep is disturbed by pain. Birth and development history are unremarkable and there is no recent head trauma.
