A 41-year-old woman reports two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and activity limitation, with acute pleuritic left-sided chest pain that began three days ago. She describes a dry cough with one episode of scant hemoptysis and intermittent palpitations; symptoms worsen with climbing stairs and improve when sitting upright. She notes new right calf swelling and tenderness for the past week after a long-haul flight three weeks earlier. She has lifelong mild asthma usually well controlled and no recent febrile illness. There is concern for an evolving pulmonary embolism secondary to deep venous thrombosis given the temporal pattern, pleuritic pain, hemoptysis, tachycardia, and decreased exertional tolerance; she denies syncope or known coagulopathy.

An 89-year-old man presents with a two-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea and a new productive cough that began after a presumed upper respiratory infection. Sputum has become yellow-tinged and he endorses intermittent low-grade fevers and a 4-pound unintentional weight loss over one month. He now reports pleuritic right-sided chest discomfort with deep breaths. Known COPD and hypertension in his past medical history. In clinic he was noted to be mildly hypoxemic with oxygen saturation around 90% on room air and exam revealed bibasilar crackles with scattered wheeze. Primary concern is COPD exacerbation versus community-acquired or post-obstructive pneumonia, with additional consideration of underlying bronchogenic carcinoma given the weight loss and subacute course.

A 28-year-old male reports four days of progressive blurred vision in his right eye with aching retro-orbital pain that worsens on eye movement and intermittent photopsias; he also notes marked desaturation of colors and a gray patch centrally. Symptoms began after a mild upper respiratory illness two weeks earlier. He describes new paresthesias in both feet and a brief electric shock sensation down his spine with neck flexion, plus occasional urinary urgency over the past week. On exam at urgent care he was noted to have a relative afferent pupillary defect on the right and reduced visual acuity from baseline. He denies head trauma, fevers, or recent travel. Family history is notable for autoimmune thyroid disease. He is otherwise active and uses no medications.

A 46-year-old male reports two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a productive cough that began after a viral upper respiratory infection. Sputum is mucoid turning greenish with intermittent blood streaks over the past three days. He also describes pleuritic right-sided chest pain that worsens with deep breaths and low-grade fevers with night sweats. Baseline exercise tolerance has declined from walking two miles to three blocks. Past pulmonary history includes bronchiectasis diagnosed by prior CT and remote, treated pulmonary sarcoidosis. He is a 20–pack-year smoker and works in metal fabrication with intermittent dust exposure. No known cardiac history or recent travel. He is concerned about worsening hemoptysis and would like evaluation for possible infectious exacerbation or progression of underlying lung disease.

A 65-year-old female complains of three months of progressive gait instability and cognitive slowing. Family reports increasing short-term memory lapses and apathy with a broad‑based, shuffling/magnetic gait that has produced two recent near‑falls. She also notes new urinary urgency with occasional leakage over the past month, worse after a treated urinary tract infection two weeks ago. On review she describes distal numbness and burning in her feet consistent with chronic sensory peripheral neuropathy. Past medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes, both reportedly stable. She denies headache, fever, or overt weakness but has slowed speech and poor balance when turning. There is concern for possible normal‑pressure hydrocephalus versus progression of small‑vessel cognitive impairment, prompting neuroimaging and gait assessment.

A 98-year-old man presents with two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and new orthopnea. He has a chronic dry cough attributed to long-standing idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, but reports a three-day stepwise decline after a recent upper respiratory infection with low-grade fever. Family notes increased night-time breathlessness and a need for supplemental oxygen at rest. He denies chest pain but endorses fatigue and occasional lightheadedness on minimal exertion. On exam he reports worsening cough productive only of scant sputum; prior baseline mobility has declined. He notes mild lower-extremity swelling. Previously stable pulmonary function was followed conservatively; current course is felt to reflect an acute exacerbation with new resting hypoxemia and increased bilateral basal inspiratory crackles.

A 33-year-old female reports ten days of progressive vision loss in the right eye, describing a central gray spot and difficulty reading, with color desaturation noted for reds. Vision decline began after a brief viral upper respiratory illness and is accompanied by dull retro-orbital pain that worsens with eye movement. She also endorses intermittent paresthesias of the right forearm and two episodes of transient imbalance while climbing stairs. On exam she noticed a relative afferent pupillary defect when covering the right eye. She has a remote history of episodic migraine without aura but says current symptoms are qualitatively different. No fever, rash, or recent trauma; she is otherwise healthy and not taking chronic medications.

A 29-year-old female presents with two weeks of progressive neurologic symptoms, primarily left-sided numbness and intermittent right-hand clumsiness that began as tingling in the fingertips and now interferes with typing. She describes two brief episodes of blurred vision in the left eye with pain on eye movement and transient binocular diplopia. Over the past week she developed gait instability with a sensation of disequilibrium and an electric shock–like sensation down her spine when she bends her neck. She also notes urinary urgency and increased fatigue limiting her exercise tolerance. Symptoms started several weeks after a self-limited viral upper respiratory illness. No recent trauma, illicit drug use, or new medications. Family history is noncontributory. She is concerned about a central nervous system process.

An 88-year-old woman reports three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent nonproductive cough that began after a self-limited upper respiratory illness. She now notes oxygen desaturation with minimal ambulation and intermittent lightheadedness; orthopnea and two-pillow dyspnea developed over the past five days. She has bibasilar crackles and new bilateral lower extremity edema by history, without chest pain. Past medical history is notable for long-standing hypertension and chronic atrial fibrillation. Family members describe decreased exercise tolerance and one episode of mild hemoptysis last week. She denies fever or overt infectious symptoms currently. Concern is for decompensated cardiopulmonary disease—possible evolving pulmonary hypertension or heart failure exacerbation with superimposed bronchitic change—requiring further evaluation.

An 82-year-old man presents with eight weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and three pillow orthopnea, now sleeping upright most nights because of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He notes a seven-pound weight gain and new bilateral pitting lower‑extremity edema over the past fortnight. Intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness accompany exertion; he has a remote diagnosis of atrial fibrillation and long-standing hypertension. On review he reports longstanding numbness in both wrists from prior carpal tunnel release. Exam at home showed bibasilar crackles and prominent neck veins. Chronic kidney disease limits prior diuretic adjustments. Given his age, slowly progressive heart failure with preserved ejection fraction from possible transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis versus rate‑related decompensation from atrial fibrillation is suspected. Further cardiology evaluation is planned.

A 39-year-old man reports five days of progressive shortness of breath and pleuritic right-sided chest pain that began after a prolonged cough following a recent upper respiratory infection. He initially had congestion and low-grade fever; cough became productive on day three with a small amount of blood-tinged sputum. He now notes exertional dyspnea and persistent tachypnea at rest, limiting his usual jogging routine. Yesterday he developed mild right calf aching and visible swelling. Past history is notable only for intermittent exercise-induced asthma in adolescence; he denies trauma, recent travel, or known clotting disorders. He is anxious about worsening symptoms and requests evaluation for possible pulmonary embolism versus postinfectious pneumonia.

A 0-year-old male infant presents with three days of progressive increased work of breathing after a household contact developed rhinorrhea. Parents report persistent tachypnea with nasal flaring and intercostal retractions, audible wheeze on exhalation, and intermittent oxygen desaturations to the high 80s when unsettled. He has had poor oral intake with only two small feeds per day and visibly decreased urine output over 24 hours. No significant vomiting or fever. In the emergency setting he required gentle nasal suctioning and supplemental oxygen for brief improvement. A point-of-care nasal swab returned positive for RSV. No prior hospitalizations or chronic conditions; mother reports uncomplicated pregnancy and term delivery. Parents are concerned about worsening work of breathing and dehydration.

A 38-year-old male presents with sudden onset shortness of breath and sharp, right-sided pleuritic chest pain that started two days ago and worsens with deep inspiration. He notes one episode of scant hemoptysis and increasing exertional dyspnea; symptoms began after a prolonged 10-hour flight three weeks ago. Over the past week he developed progressive right calf swelling and tenderness. He describes intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness but denies fever or productive cough. Past history notable only for a 10-pack-year remote smoking history and family history of clotting disorder. He works a sedentary job and is overweight. He reports mild resting tachycardia and subjective low oxygen levels. Concern centers on pulmonary embolism secondary to deep venous thrombosis.

A 56-year-old man presents with five days of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and sharp, right-sided pleuritic chest pain. Symptoms began after a long car trip two weeks ago and he reports new right calf swelling and tenderness since that trip. He also describes a three-day productive cough with scant blood-tinged sputum and intermittent palpitations when walking. He notes orthopnea at night but denies fevers or syncope. Past medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension and a 30-pack-year former smoking history. Onset was subacute, with tachycardia at rest and shortness of breath limiting his usual walk; he denies prior lung disease. He is concerned about possible pulmonary embolism given the calf swelling and recent travel.

A 57-year-old male reports two months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough. Symptoms started insidiously and have worsened from walking one block to becoming short of breath with routine chores; he now notes exertional oxygen desaturation and increased breathlessness climbing stairs. He has lost about 10 pounds unintentionally and has intermittent low-grade fevers without sweats or night chills. He is a former 30–pack-year smoker and worked for decades in stone masonry with known silica exposure. He denies hemoptysis or chest pain. At home he notices increased work of breathing and auscultates persistent fine inspiratory basal crackles. Past medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension. Concern is for progressive interstitial lung disease with possible superimposed infection or early pulmonary hypertension.

A 50-year-old man reports a two-day history of abrupt, painless loss of vision in the right eye after a week of progressive blurring and difficulty reading. He describes a dense central scotoma with inferior visual field loss and complains of a new constant right temporal headache and jaw claudication when chewing, accompanied by localized scalp tenderness. He also endorses two months of morning shoulder and hip stiffness limiting dressing, consistent with polymyalgia rheumatica. Past history is notable for hypertension. He denies trauma, ocular redness, or photophobia. The constellation of acute monocular visual loss with temporal symptoms raises concern for anterior ischemic optic neuropathy due to giant cell arteritis and warrants urgent evaluation to preserve vision.

A 56-year-old female reports progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough for four months. She initially became short of breath with brisk walks but now tires with minimal household activity; symptoms reliably worsen after cleaning her apartment aviary. She also describes intermittent low-grade fevers, unintentional 6-lb weight loss, and new fatigue, and denies chest pain or orthopnea. Prior exam noted inspiratory bibasilar crackles and early digital clubbing. Home pulse oximetry shows desaturation into the mid-80s with ambulation. Pulmonary function testing revealed a restrictive pattern with reduced DLCO, and CT chest reportedly demonstrates basilar reticulation with patchy ground-glass opacities. The presentation is most consistent with chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis or another interstitial lung disease related to avian exposure.

A 48-year-old man reports six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a productive cough that began after a community-acquired pneumonia. Sputum has become more purulent and is occasionally blood-tinged. He describes new exertional wheeze and reduced exercise tolerance, and has noticed a three-kg unintentional weight loss over the same interval. He endorses intermittent low-grade fevers but denies chest pain. Past history notable for a 30–pack-year smoking history; he also reports nightly heartburn and regurgitation suggestive of reflux. He has no prior diagnosis of chronic lung disease. Symptoms are worst in the mornings and with activity, and he is concerned about persistent infection versus a postinfectious or smoking-related process.

A 15-year-old male reports six weeks of crampy periumbilical abdominal pain and intermittent loose stools that have become more frequent and nocturnal over the past ten days. He describes intermittent frank hematochezia for three days, a 4–5 kg weight loss, reduced appetite, and increasing fatigue with pallor noted by his mother. Pain is worse after meals and sometimes awakens him; he has low-grade fevers and night sweats. He also complains of perianal discomfort with a small fissure and occasional serous drainage. Growth velocity feels slower over the past year. No recent travel or antibiotic use. Family history is notable for inflammatory bowel disease in a first-degree relative. He denies vomiting, respiratory symptoms, or urinary complaints.

A 25-year-old woman presents with eight weeks of progressive solid‑food dysphagia and persistent burning epigastric pain. Pain is predominantly postprandial, associated with early satiety and intermittent regurgitation; she describes one recent partial food impaction that resolved at home. She reports unintentional 7‑kg weight loss and worsening fatigue; prior labs showed microcytic iron‑deficiency anemia. Symptoms began after a short course of antibiotics for sinusitis and occur against a background of long‑standing seasonal allergic rhinitis and eczema. She also has intermittent heartburn relieved by antacids and denies hematemesis or overt melena. Clinical concern centers on eosinophilic esophagitis versus peptic stricture or a motility disorder; she requests evaluation for endoscopy with biopsies and nutritional counseling.

A 16-year-old male presents with a five-day history of progressive vision loss in his left eye, described as central blurring and a gray spot that worsens when reading. He endorses sharp, retro-orbital pain with eye movement and new photophobia. He notes colors seem "washed out" on the affected side and intermittent diplopia when tired. Symptoms began about one week after a self-limited viral upper respiratory illness. At home he detected a relative afferent pupillary defect and reduced acuity in the left eye. Associated complaints include a persistent periorbital headache and one episode of transient paresthesia in the right forearm. He denies trauma, fever, or recent travel. Findings are most concerning for an inflammatory optic neuropathy such as optic neuritis.

A 92-year-old female reports acute, progressive loss of vision in the right eye over four days after several brief, transient episodes of complete blackout in that eye over the preceding two weeks. She describes a central dark spot and difficulty reading and recognizing faces; the episodes were painless but now the deficit persists. Over the same interval she has developed new temporal scalp tenderness and intermittent jaw claudication when chewing. She notes increasing malaise but denies headache or focal weakness. Past history is notable for hypertension and long-standing bilateral cataracts with reduced baseline acuity. She is worried the brief losses represented embolic “shadows”; she understands the change is different and more severe than her chronic cataract-related blurring.

A 75-year-old man presents with three months of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and decreased exercise tolerance, now limiting him to short walks. He reports a persistent, nonproductive cough and new bilateral ankle swelling; he notes intermittent palpitations and fatigue with minimal exertion. He says he had a provoked deep venous thrombosis with presumed pulmonary embolism about 18 months ago that was treated. He has chronic hypertension and a remote smoking history. On exertion he becomes breathless and has documented oxygen desaturation at home. He denies chest pain, fevers, or hemoptysis. The constellation of progressive dyspnea, prior thromboembolism, peripheral edema, and exertional hypoxemia raises concern for chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension complicating underlying cardiopulmonary disease.

A 53-year-old woman reports two weeks of progressive central blurring in the right eye with intermittent metamorphopsia and new floaters; she describes brief flashes of light in that eye several times per day. Symptoms began after a mild upper respiratory illness. Over the past five days she developed a unilateral temporal headache with scalp tenderness and jaw claudication when chewing. She also notes morning stiffness across the shoulders and persistent fatigue. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. There is no ocular discharge or trauma, and she denies diplopia but is concerned about worsening vision and difficulty reading. Symptoms are disrupting sleep and daily activities, prompting evaluation for possible ischemic optic process.

A 13-year-old female reports two weeks of progressive shortness of breath and noisy breathing, most pronounced during soccer practice. Symptoms began after a self-limited upper respiratory infection and started as an intermittent nonproductive cough but evolved into exertional dyspnea with throat tightness and audible inspiratory stridor. She also notes intermittent expiratory wheeze and sudden breathless episodes that improve within minutes with rest. Exercise tolerance has fallen from a full game to being able to sprint only briefly. No fever, syncope, or cyanosis. She has a history of seasonal allergic rhinitis and occasional nighttime cough. Parents tried steam and extra fluids with minimal benefit. No prior hospitalization; symptoms worry her because they limit activity and cause anxiety at school.

A 73-year-old female reports four months of progressive gait instability and cognitive slowing. She notes gait has become shuffling and broad-based, requiring a cane and resulting in two recent falls without head trauma. Family describes new short-term memory loss, apathy, and difficulty with executive tasks; she also reports new urinary urgency with occasional daytime leakage. A noncontrast head CT previously showed ventriculomegaly, and she experienced transient improvement in gait after a therapeutic lumbar puncture. Past medical history notable for hypertension and knee osteoarthritis limiting mobility. No fevers, focal sensory loss, or chest pain. Symptoms have worsened over the past two weeks, prompting concern for possible normal-pressure hydrocephalus versus neurodegenerative disease.

A 69-year-old man presents with two months of progressive exertional dyspnea and three weeks of pleuritic right-sided chest pain. He reports a chronic morning cough that has recently become blood‑streaked on several occasions and an unintentional eight‑pound weight loss over six weeks. Symptoms began after a provoked left lower‑extremity DVT three months ago and he notes decreased exercise tolerance compared with baseline. His spouse has observed mild digital clubbing. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and remote COPD; he is a former 40‑pack‑year smoker. He denies fever but endorses intermittent lightheadedness on exertion. He is concerned about recurrent pulmonary embolism versus an underlying lung process such as malignancy or chronic thromboembolic disease.

An 8-year-old male presents with three days of progressive vertigo, persistent nonbloody emesis, and difficulty walking. Symptoms began two days after a self-limited upper respiratory illness with low‑grade fevers and nasal congestion. Parents describe acute onset of unsteady, wide‑based gait and frequent falls, intermittent horizontal eye movements consistent with nystagmus, and slurred speech; he also has a daily occipital headache and decreased appetite. Episodes of worsening dizziness are triggered by head turning and are accompanied by mild photophobia. There is no history of head trauma, seizures, or prior neurologic problems. He has tolerated small sips of clear fluids but has had minimal urine output. Family notes increased irritability and difficulty coordinating hand movements over the last 48 hours.

A 24-year-old man presents with a three-week history of progressive neurologic symptoms beginning after a brief febrile upper respiratory illness. He first noticed blurred vision and aching behind the right eye with transient color desaturation, followed days later by tingling and numbness in the left foot that ascended to the calf. Over the last week he reports intermittent diplopia, unsteady gait with frequent near-falls, and a reproducible electric shock sensation down the spine with neck flexion. He also endorses new urinary urgency and marked fatigue limiting work. Symptoms have waxed and waned but overall worsened, prompting evaluation for inflammatory demyelination versus postinfectious transverse myelitis; neuroimaging and neurologic referral are planned. No prior neurologic history or recent travel.

A 52-year-old man presents with sudden severe occipital headache and persistent vertigo that began two days ago while turning his neck during yard work. The headache was immediate and sharp, followed within hours by progressive gait instability and nausea; over the last 24 hours he has noted new left arm weakness and intermittent left facial numbness with mild difficulty swallowing. He denies loss of consciousness but reports a brief episode of neck pain at onset. Past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Exam today is notable for ataxic gait and decreased strength in the left upper extremity. The timeline and focal brainstem-cerebellar symptoms raise concern for a vertebral artery dissection with evolving cerebellar infarct.

A 17-year-old male presents with acute central chest pain and shortness of breath that began three hours after basketball practice. He describes the pain as sharp and pleuritic, worse with deep inspiration and radiating toward his neck; he also notes a new sensation of neck fullness and crepitus. The patient had a week of mild nonproductive cough but no fever. He has a history of intermittent asthma treated with occasional inhaler use and reports daily e-cigarette vaping. Onset followed a bout of forceful coughing and Valsalva-like strain. He denies syncope or leg swelling. Concern is for spontaneous pneumomediastinum or small pneumothorax related to recent coughing and vaping, prompting urgent imaging and observation.

An 86-year-old female reports six months of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry, nonproductive cough with gradual decline in walking distance. She notes a three-week acute worsening after a presumed upper respiratory illness with new low-grade fevers and a 5-pound unintentional weight loss. Family observed increased breathlessness on minimal exertion and intermittent lightheadedness. Exam previously documented bibasilar fine inspiratory crackles and new digital clubbing; she now reports resting breathlessness and desaturation with stair climbing. She has a remote history of rheumatoid arthritis and chronic hypertension. She denies chest pain or frank sputum production but is more fatigued and has mild dependent ankle swelling. She is worried symptoms represent progressive lung disease rather than simple bronchitis.

An 87-year-old female reports sudden onset of right arm and leg weakness with slurred speech 36 hours ago, initially mild but progressively worse over the first day. She describes right facial droop and difficulty finding words; family witnessed a fall at home without loss of consciousness. There has been intermittent confusion and difficulty ambulating since the event. Past vascular history notable for long-standing hypertension and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and prior carotid duplex showing moderate left carotid stenosis with an audible carotid bruit. No preceding chest pain or shortness of breath. She remains alert but functionally limited, unable to dress the right arm. Symptoms are most consistent with an acute left hemispheric ischemic stroke, and family brought her for urgent evaluation.

A 29-year-old male reports two weeks of progressive neurologic symptoms beginning as intermittent numbness and tingling in the right fingertips that extended into the forearm and, more recently, the right leg. Episodes last several hours and are now accompanied by transient right-sided weakness and clumsiness with fine motor tasks. He describes a sharp occipital headache worsened by neck flexion with brief electric sensations down the spine (Lhermitte phenomenon). He also had one self-limited episode of blurred vision in the left eye with color desaturation and photophobia over 48 hours. Gait has been unsteady at times, and he notes new urinary urgency without dysuria. Symptoms began after a mild upper respiratory illness; he denies trauma, fever, or prior similar attacks.

A 97-year-old man presents with three months of progressive gait instability and two recent falls. Family describes a shuffling, difficulty-initiating or "magnetic" gait with frequent steps that are narrow and slow, accompanied by increasing urinary urgency and intermittent urge incontinence. There is noticeable cognitive slowing and diminished initiation compared with baseline, and both mobility and mentation seemed to worsen after a recently treated urinary tract infection. He also reports episodic lightheadedness on standing with near-syncope suggestive of orthostatic dizziness. A prior non-contrast head CT reportedly showed ventriculomegaly greater than expected for atrophy, raising concern for normal-pressure hydrocephalus. No new focal weakness or sensory loss is appreciated, though lower-extremity stiffness and deconditioning markedly limit function. Caregiver seeks evaluation for possible CSF diversion versus addressing reversible contributors.

A 35-year-old woman presents with four days of progressive bilateral lower extremity weakness, numbness, and difficulty walking. Symptoms began as mid-thoracic back pain two days after a febrile upper respiratory illness approximately two weeks ago, then evolved to paresthesias ascending to the umbilicus with a clear sensory level at T6. She now reports gait instability, frequent stumbling, and decreased ankle reflexes with reduced vibration and proprioception in the feet. On day three she developed urinary retention necessitating intermittent catheterization at home. Additionally she describes intermittent blurred vision and brief flashes of light in the right eye over the past week. She denies trauma, prior neurologic disease, or systemic rash.

A 66-year-old man presents with three days of progressive word‑finding difficulty and slurred speech; family notes he now struggles to name common objects and has trouble following complex instructions. Symptoms began after intermittent two‑week spells of transient visual blurring and brief dizziness; over the last 48 hours he developed mild right hand clumsiness with frequent dropping of utensils and a subtle right facial droop. He reports a dull, nonpositional headache but no fever or neck stiffness. Past medical history notable for hypertension and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Exam reveals expressive aphasia and decreased fine motor control of the right hand. Recent MRI brain demonstrates restricted diffusion in the left MCA distribution consistent with an acute ischemic infarct; he remains hemodynamically stable.

A 76-year-old man reports a six-month history of progressive gait difficulty and cognitive slowing. He describes a broad-based, "magnetic" shuffling gait with step hesitation and two falls in the past month; family members note short-term memory impairment and reduced problem-solving. He has developed new urinary urgency during the same interval. He has long-standing hypertension under outpatient management. He also endorses intermittent bilateral leg numbness and cramping that worsen with walking, raising concern for lumbar spinal stenosis as a competing contributor. A recent noncontrast head CT reportedly showed ventriculomegaly. He denies fever, headache, or focal head trauma and has no prior formal diagnosis of dementia.

A 40-year-old male presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough, now limiting his ability to climb stairs. Symptoms began after he began caring for several indoor racing pigeons and were preceded by a brief upper respiratory illness. He reports intermittent low-grade fevers, 6 lb unintentional weight loss, and pleuritic left-sided chest discomfort with deep inspiration. On exertion he notes increased wheeze and marked fatigue. He denies hemoptysis but describes persistent inspiratory crackles at the bases and occasional night sweats. No known asthma history or recent travel. He had tried over-the-counter cough suppressants without benefit. He is most concerned the exposure has triggered a chronic lung process.

A 26-year-old female reports a four-day history of progressive blurring of vision in her right eye accompanied by a deep, retro-orbital ache that worsens with eye movement. She describes colors appearing washed-out and a central dark spot that makes reading difficult; she denies floaters or flashes. One week before symptoms she had a mild viral upper respiratory illness. She also describes two brief episodes of left-arm numbness and tingling in the past month that resolved spontaneously. An urgent assessment documented a right afferent pupillary defect and subtle optic disc edema. She denies trauma, contact lens use, fever, or prior autoimmune diagnosis. Family history is notable for autoimmune thyroid disease.

A 91-year-old male presents with five days of progressive dyspnea and a productive, yellow-green cough. Symptoms began after a brief choking episode on solids one week ago; he has known oropharyngeal dysphagia since a prior left hemispheric stroke. He also notes low-grade fevers, decreased appetite, and increased fatigue. Baseline mobility is limited by chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which he reports has been stable until this episode. On arrival he is tachypneic with resting hypoxemia and exam reveals coarse crackles and diminished breath sounds at the right base. Portable chest radiograph performed in the ED demonstrates a right lower lobe consolidation. Impression is likely aspiration pneumonia on a background of COPD contributing to acute respiratory compromise.

A 49-year-old female reports four months of progressively worse epigastric pain radiating to the back, classically worse after meals, accompanied by oily, foul-smelling stools and early satiety. She notes an unintentional 15-pound weight loss and intermittent yellowing of the eyes with pale stools over the past six weeks. Symptoms began after a hospitalization for presumed biliary colic and suspected gallstone pancreatitis six months ago. She was recently found to have elevated fasting glucose and new-onset diabetes. She denies heavy alcohol use currently but describes episodic nausea without frank vomiting. No fevers or melena. She is most concerned about continued weight loss and worsening malabsorption and requests evaluation for possible chronic pancreatitis versus an obstructing pancreatic head process.

An 86-year-old woman presents with a three-week history of progressive central visual blurring and distortion in the right eye. She describes straight lines becoming wavy (metamorphopsia), a persistent central scotoma that interferes with reading and face recognition, and intermittent micropsia; she has noticed new floaters but denies flashes, ocular pain, or headache. Symptoms began with subtle difficulty reading small print and have steadily worsened, now requiring a handheld magnifier. Past ocular history includes cataract extraction in both eyes. Medical history notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. No recent trauma, systemic constitutional symptoms, or prior intravitreal injections. Concern is raised for new neovascular age-related macular degeneration with possible choroidal neovascularization prompting urgent ophthalmology evaluation.

A 15-year-old female presents with three days of progressive shortness of breath and a sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began abruptly after a severe coughing spell. Symptoms followed a five-day viral upper respiratory infection with nasal congestion and sore throat; she now has intermittent dry cough and mild subjective fever. Parents note increased breathing effort with exertion and occasional palpitations at rest. She started combined oral contraceptives six weeks ago and has no recent travel or immobilization. On exam she appears tachypneic with focal reduction in right-sided breath sounds. Differential includes pulmonary embolism versus secondary spontaneous pneumothorax; an asthma exacerbation triggered by the preceding infection is also considered. She denies leg swelling or prior thrombotic history.

A 49-year-old man reports two weeks of intermittent focal neurologic symptoms characterized by brief episodes of right arm numbness and weakness accompanied by word‑finding difficulty and slurred speech. The spells began as fleeting paresthesias after exertion and have progressed to several daily episodes lasting five to twenty minutes; he had one episode this week of transient darkening in the left eye. Symptoms resolve completely between events. Past history is notable for untreated hypertension and hyperlipidemia; he currently smokes and his partner recently noticed a new left‑sided neck bruit. He denies headache, fever, chest pain, or syncope. The temporal pattern and mixed cortical and ocular findings are most concerning for left‑hemispheric transient ischemic attacks, raising concern for ipsilateral carotid stenosis or an embolic source.

A 74-year-old woman presents with six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea that began after a self-limited bronchitic illness. She now tires after walking a single block and has a persistent dry cough with occasional scant sputum and mild night sweats. Family notes 4 kg of unintentional weight loss and increased breathlessness over two weeks. On exam she has bibasilar inspiratory crackles and mild finger clubbing by report; oxygen saturation falls with minimal exertion. She has a remote 20-pack-year smoking history and longstanding hypertension. She denies chest pain, orthopnea, or leg swelling. Concern is for a subacute interstitial lung process—possible pulmonary fibrosis or post-infectious exacerbation—rather than simple reactive airways disease.

A 13-year-old female reports six weeks of progressive palpitations and a persistent resting fast pulse, noted by family at home. She has lost about 3 kg despite an increased appetite, and describes new heat intolerance with frequent sweating and a fine tremor of her hands. Mother noticed a fullness at the front of the neck over the last month. She also reports irregular periods and reduced exercise tolerance, stopping soccer practices because she tires more quickly. Symptoms began gradually after a brief viral upper respiratory illness and have steadily worsened; she denies fever, rash, or illicit drug use. There is no prior endocrine disease in the patient, and home pulse checks are consistently in the 100s.

A 53-year-old man reports three weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and increased cough following a viral upper respiratory illness. He describes a daily productive cough with green sputum, nocturnal cough waking him twice weekly, and new orthopnea requiring two pillows. He notes wheeze with minimal exertion and developing bilateral ankle swelling over the past week. He has a 35–pack-year smoking history and a prior diagnosis of chronic bronchitic COPD; he also has known hypertension. He denies fever but had a single episode of scant blood-tinged sputum. Symptoms began after the URI and have steadily worsened, prompting concern for COPD exacerbation with possible congestive decompensation and secondary pulmonary hypertension.

A 32-year-old male aviary hobbyist reports six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent nonproductive cough that began after deep-cleaning his pigeon loft. He describes intermittent pleuritic chest discomfort and low-grade fevers with an unintended five-kilogram weight loss. Symptoms partially abated after a brief outpatient prednisone course but recurred on return to the birds. Exam notable for fine inspiratory crackles at the bases and early digital clubbing. He is a former 5–pack-year smoker and otherwise healthy. Chest CT performed by his primary clinician showed patchy bilateral ground-glass opacities. The clinical picture is concerning for hypersensitivity pneumonitis from avian antigen exposure versus another subacute interstitial lung process.

A 45-year-old woman reports a four-day history of progressively worsening bifrontal headache accompanied by new right-sided weakness and intermittent visual blurring. The headache is constant, worse with Valsalva, and has been associated with nausea and two brief witnessed generalized shaking episodes. Family notes increasing confusion and slowed speech over 24 hours. She has a long-standing history of episodic migraine but describes this pain as different and more severe; exam earlier noted mild papilledema. She completed treatment for acute sinusitis three weeks ago and has been using combined oral contraceptives for several months for menorrhagia. The constellation of severe headache, focal neurologic deficit, seizures, and papilledema is concerning for a cerebral venous thrombosis versus other intracranial process.

A 48-year-old man reports two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and intermittent substernal tightness that began after a self-limited febrile upper respiratory illness three weeks ago. He now has orthopnea and awakens once nightly with shortness of breath consistent with paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, new bilateral ankle swelling, and a marked decline in exercise tolerance — formerly could bicycle 30 minutes, now breathless after minimal exertion. He describes intermittent palpitations and occasional lightheadedness without syncope, along with persistent fatigue and poor appetite. He denies productive cough or hemoptysis. No prior cardiac hospitalization, though he notes a remote history of hypercholesterolemia. Symptoms raise concern for new cardiac dysfunction, possibly post-viral cardiomyopathy or an arrhythmic process, prompting urgent evaluation.

A 4-year-old boy presents with a three-day runny nose that progressed to 48 hours of a progressively barky cough and noisy breathing. Parents describe pronounced nocturnal worsening with intermittent inspiratory stridor and hoarseness, episodes of audible expiratory wheeze, and a low-grade fever to about 38°C. He now has mild tachypnea with suprasternal retractions and decreased oral intake because coughing provokes gagging. Symptoms improve modestly with cool-mist humidification and a single dose of acetaminophen, but several cough spells are prolonged and tiring. There is no drooling, vomiting, or witnessed foreign-body event. Past history notable for RSV bronchiolitis as an infant and atopic dermatitis, with no prior chronic lung disease.

A 31-year-old woman presents with two weeks of progressive neurologic symptoms beginning as intermittent right-sided paresthesias and evolving to persistent numbness of the right forearm and foot, with new mild right leg weakness causing tripping. She also reports intermittent horizontal diplopia and days of blurred vision in the left eye, and a transient Lhermitte-like electric sensation with neck flexion. Symptoms began about ten days after a self-limited upper respiratory illness and have been associated with profound fatigue and recent urinary urgency. She denies fever, headache, or recent trauma. Past history notable for episodic migraines in adolescence and baseline anxiety. Symptoms are interfering with work and ambulation, prompting urgent evaluation for a possible demyelinating or inflammatory process.

A 65-year-old woman presents with two weeks of progressive central blurring and distortion in the left eye, now evolving over 48 hours into marked central vision loss with difficulty reading and loss of contrast. She describes intermittent metamorphopsia and new floaters that preceded the decline. Over the same interval she developed a dull left temporal headache with scalp tenderness and jaw claudication when chewing, without fever or trauma. She recalls brief transient monocular visual obscurations several months ago. Past medical history includes longstanding hypertension and hyperlipidemia and prior uncomplicated cataract extraction in both eyes. She denies diplopia, systemic rash, or recent infections. Symptoms suggest an ischemic optic process and prompt urgent ophthalmology and vascular assessment.

A 24-year-old man presents with a six-day history of worsening bifrontal throbbing headache, worse in the mornings and with Valsalva, accompanied by marked photophobia and persistent nausea. Two days into the headache he noted transient right-sided hand and forearm numbness lasting about 15 minutes, and since day three he reports mild neck stiffness and a low-grade fever. He had a viral upper respiratory illness about two weeks ago with lingering nasal congestion and pressure, but denies recent travel or illicit drug use. Over the past 48 hours he developed intermittent blurred vision; on self-check his vision seems slightly worse and light sensitivity has increased. He has not had similar episodes previously and seeks evaluation for an evolving neurological process.

A 55-year-old woman reports three weeks of intermittent palpitations and new lightheadedness, worse with minimal exertion and occurring several times daily. She notes an unintentional 8-lb weight loss, increased sweating and heat intolerance, a fine hand tremor, and looser stools without blood. Symptoms have progressed from brief episodes to prolonged spells with a sensation of an irregular heartbeat; she measured a rapid, irregular pulse at home. She denies chest pain or syncope. On self-exam she recently noticed fullness at the front of her neck; on exam there is a diffusely enlarged, non-tender thyroid and an irregularly irregular tachycardia consistent with atrial fibrillation. Past history notable only for well-controlled hypertension. No recent travel or medication changes.

A 68-year-old female reports progressive exertional dyspnea over the past six months, with marked decline in walking tolerance and increasing shortness of breath when climbing stairs. She also has a persistent dry cough and generalized fatigue; she notes unintentional weight loss of several pounds and no fevers or hemoptysis. Over the last four weeks she has noticed lightheadedness and episodic oxygen desaturation with exertion. Exam shows bibasilar "Velcro" inspiratory crackles, mild digital clubbing, and trace pitting edema of the ankles. She is a former smoker and has a history of well-controlled hypertension. Symptoms acutely worsened after a respiratory infection two months ago. The presentation is most concerning for chronic interstitial lung disease with possible secondary pulmonary hypertension/right-heart strain.

A 35-year-old woman three weeks postpartum reports five days of sharp, pleuritic right-sided chest pain and progressive exertional dyspnea. The pain is worse with deep inspiration and coughing; she also notes intermittent palpitations and mild lightheadedness when climbing stairs. Two weeks ago she had a brief febrile upper respiratory illness, and she had a prolonged car ride home shortly thereafter. Over the past 48 hours she developed new right calf aching with visible swelling and one scant episode of blood-tinged sputum. She has no personal history of coagulopathy. Given her postpartum status, recent immobilization, unilateral calf swelling, and acute pleuritic symptoms, she is highly suspicious for deep venous thrombosis with possible pulmonary embolism.

A 47-year-old male presents with a three-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea and intermittent right-sided pleuritic chest pain. He describes a dry cough that has recently produced small amounts of blood on two occasions and associated low-grade fevers with night sweats. Symptoms began after a ten-hour bus trip; he also developed new left calf swelling and aching. He has a 12–pack-year smoking history and works in construction with intermittent silica dust exposure. He denies known asthma or prior pneumonia but notes occasional exertional wheeze and easy fatigability. He reports brief presyncope with exertion. Concern is for pulmonary embolism with possible pulmonary infarction on a background of smoking-related airway disease; concurrent leg DVT and occupational lung exposure are relevant.

A 54-year-old man with type 2 diabetes reports a ten-day history of progressive right periorbital pain and swelling that began after a presumed sinus infection. He notes increasing blurred vision in the right eye and new horizontal diplopia when looking laterally. Over the past 48 hours he developed mild proptosis and worsening eyelid erythema; pain is constant and exacerbated by eye movement. He also endorses low-grade fever and malaise. On exam in clinic he has limited extraocular movements on the right and subjective color desaturation. Given the temporal sequence from ethmoid sinusitis to orbital inflammation with ophthalmoplegia and acute visual decline, he is most concerning for orbital cellulitis with possible cavernous sinus thrombosis requiring urgent imaging and specialist evaluation.

A 53-year-old woman presents with ten days of progressive right-eye blurring and a new inferior visual field defect, initially intermittent haze that now limits reading. The visual decline followed onset of a persistent, gnawing right temporal headache and localized scalp tenderness over the temple. She reports jaw claudication when chewing and proximal morning stiffness of shoulders and hips for several weeks consistent with polymyalgia rheumatica. Mild low-grade fevers accompany the systemic symptoms. Past medical history includes well-controlled hypertension. She denies ocular discharge or trauma. The temporal pain and jaw claudication preceded the acuity loss, raising concern for a vasculitic process such as giant cell arteritis with ischemic optic involvement; she is seeking urgent ophthalmology and rheumatology assessment.

A 73-year-old female presents with two weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and reduced tolerance for her usual household activities. She describes new orthopnea, requiring two pillows for the past five nights, and one episode of abrupt nighttime breathlessness suggestive of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Family reports a 3–4 kg weight gain and new bilateral pitting ankle edema over ten days. She denies chest pain but notes intermittent palpitations. Symptoms began after a self-limited upper respiratory illness three weeks ago and have steadily worsened. Past history is notable for long-standing hypertension and osteoarthritis without prior heart-failure diagnosis. Home exam reportedly showed mild bibasilar crackles. Concern is for decompensated heart failure, likely HFpEF related to hypertension, with possible new atrial fibrillation.

A 19-year-old male college student reports six weeks of progressive polyuria and polydipsia with an unintended 11-pound weight loss, now presenting with 48 hours of worsening nausea, recurrent vomiting, and diffuse, crampy abdominal pain. Over the past day he developed increasing fatigue, lightheadedness and rapid, deep breathing; family members noted intermittent confusion and reduced urine output. He is insulin-dependent and missed his evening dose two nights ago after a brief gastroenteritis with poor oral intake. On review he describes dry mouth and a pounding heartbeat but denies fever or focal neurologic deficits. The timeline and constellation of polyuria, weight loss, vomiting, tachypnea, tachycardia and mental status change suggest severe hyperglycemia with possible diabetic ketoacidosis.

An 18-year-old male reports sudden onset of right-sided pleuritic chest pain and progressive shortness of breath over the past 36 hours. Pain began during an intense basketball practice, is sharp, worse with deep inspiration and coughing, and is associated with a dry cough and mild lightheadedness. He had a brief upper respiratory sniffle three days earlier that seemed to improve. He notes intermittent palpitations and rapid breathing but denies fever, hemoptysis, calf pain, or recent trauma. He describes a tall, thin body habitus and occasional marijuana vaping. On self-exam he felt mild crepitus over the right chest and reports decreased air movement on that side. Presentation is most consistent with a primary spontaneous pneumothorax requiring prompt evaluation.

A 56-year-old man reports six weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough that began after a brief upper respiratory illness. He now becomes short of breath walking a flight of stairs and notes intermittent pleuritic left-sided chest discomfort with deep inspiration. Over the same interval he has experienced low-grade fevers and an unintentional 10-pound weight loss. He is a 30-pack-year former smoker and has a history of well-controlled hypertension. At home he has noticed oxygen saturation falls with exertion and occasional wheeze when active. He denies hemoptysis or chest pressure at rest. Symptoms have slowly worsened, raising concern for an evolving interstitial or postinfectious pulmonary process versus atypical infection.

A 69-year-old man reports ten days of progressive blurring and distortion of the left central visual field, now described as a dense central scotoma with intermittent metamorphopsia. He experienced a brief episode of transient monocular vision loss two weeks ago. Over the past week he developed throbbing left temporal headache, scalp tenderness, and jaw claudication when chewing, accompanied by low-grade fevers and malaise. He denies trauma, eye discharge, or significant photophobia but notes mild diplopia on extreme gaze. Past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Ophthalmology documented decreased visual acuity and a pale, swollen left optic disc, raising concern for arteritic ischemic optic neuropathy from suspected giant cell arteritis; urgent rheumatology/vascular evaluation was requested.

A 68-year-old female presents with sudden, painless loss of vision in the right eye over 48 hours, preceded by a three-week history of new persistent temporal headache and scalp tenderness when brushing her hair. She describes intermittent jaw claudication with chewing and prominent morning stiffness in the shoulders and hips consistent with polymyalgia rheumatica. She has experienced low-grade fevers and a three-pound unintentional weight loss in the past month. Past medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension. She denies prior ocular disease, recent trauma, or neurologic deficits. The temporal pattern and associated systemic symptoms raise concern for giant cell (temporal) arteritis with ischemic optic neuropathy as the likely cause of acute monocular vision loss.

A 37-year-old man presents with two weeks of progressively worse exertional dyspnea and sharp right-sided pleuritic chest pain. Symptoms began several days after a prolonged flight and were accompanied by new intermittent palpitations and a single episode of small-volume hemoptysis. He also reports recent right calf swelling and aching; he is an active smoker with a 10-pack-year history and uses a rescue inhaler infrequently for childhood asthma. At home he noticed episodes of rapid pulse and mild lightheadedness with exertion; no fever, cough, or weight loss. He describes his exercise tolerance as decreased from running three miles to struggling with one flight of stairs. No prior thromboembolic events, but his father had a "blood clot" in his 50s.

A 28-year-old woman presents with five days of progressively blurred vision in her left eye, described as a gray wash centrally with difficulty reading and color desaturation. She reports dull retro-orbital pain that worsens with eye movement and associated photophobia; she also notes new floaters intermittently. Symptoms began after a short viral upper respiratory illness. On self-exam she noticed the pupil in the affected eye seemed slower to constrict. She has had increasing fatigue and two brief episodes of numbness and tingling in her right hand over the past week. Past history is notable only for childhood eczema. She denies trauma, contact-lens overwear, or recent travel. She is concerned about optic neuritis and requests ophthalmology and neurology evaluation.

A 5-year-old female presents with three weeks of persistent right-sided ear drainage and progressive hearing difficulty. Parents report recurrent upper respiratory infections over the past three months with ongoing nasal congestion and snoring, followed by ear fullness and intermittent otalgia. The drainage is foul-smelling and seropurulent; she has reduced responsiveness to conversational speech at daycare and occasional imbalance when running. Prior brief courses for acute otitis media were helpful initially, but the ear never fully cleared. Current constellation—eustachian tube dysfunction with presumed otitis media with effusion progressing to chronic suppurative otitis media—is suspected, and a cholesteatoma is a concern given the persistent malodorous otorrhea. No high fevers or toxic appearance; development otherwise age-appropriate.

A 14-year-old female presents with three days of progressive blurring of the right central vision and aching retro-orbital pain that worsens with eye movement. She describes a gray central scotoma and marked difficulty distinguishing red from green; nearby objects appear faded in the affected eye. Symptoms began two weeks after a febrile upper respiratory illness and were preceded last winter by a brief episode of right hand numbness that resolved in 48 hours. She also has a right-sided frontal headache but denies trauma, photophobia, fever now, or constitutional weight loss. On exam at an urgent care she was noted to have reduced visual acuity in the right eye and a suspected relative afferent pupillary defect; no skin rash or joint swelling. Parents are concerned about persistent vision loss.

A 59-year-old man reports three months of gradually progressive exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough, with more rapid decline over the past two weeks limiting his usual walks. He denies fevers or purulent sputum but describes occasional pleuritic chest tightness on deep inspiration. On prior exam he was noted to have fine inspiratory crackles at the bases and new digital clubbing. He is a former smoker with long-standing hypertension. He now becomes lightheaded with exertion and notes intermittent breathlessness that is associated with exertional oxygen desaturation and mild ankle swelling. Clinical concern is for interstitial lung disease with developing pulmonary hypertension and early right-sided congestion; further pulmonary evaluation is planned.
